yoruba: Ìpàdánù oyè yìí ni ó fa ìbínú ní ìta-gbangba, George fi orin fẹ̀sùn kan “jàndùkú soca” – ìyẹn àkójọpọ̀ òṣìṣẹ́ ilé iṣẹ́ agbóhùnsáfẹ́fẹ́ àti olùdaríI wọn – fún ìpàdíàpòpọ̀ tí ó mú wọn kọ orin “Soca Kingdom” ní àsìkò ìdájọ́ láti yan ẹni tí ó jáwé olúborí.

english: He sings:
yoruba: Ó kọrin:

english: On the stage was a next set of drama, the DJs and them playing "Savannah"
yoruba: Lórí ìtàgé ni eré tí ó kàn-án wà, àwọn DJ àti wọn ń kọ "Savannah"

english: But when the mafia come, they switching from "Savannah" to ‘Kingdom’
yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n nígbà tí àwọn jàndùkú dé, wọ́n sún láti "Savannah" sí ‘Kingdom’

english: They join forces to win the big fight... this year you have to team up with Jesus Christ
yoruba: Wọ́n pawọ́pọ̀ láti borí ìjà ńlá náà... lọ́dún yìí ẹ ní láti pawọ́pọ̀ pẹ̀lú Jésù Kristì ọmọ Màríà

english: In another version of the song, George accuses Montano of "bad talking" him, and belittles the honorary doctorate Montano recently received from the University of Trinidad and Tobago for his contribution to soca music.
yoruba: Nínú ẹ̀dà orin náà mìíràn , George fi ẹ̀sùn kan Montana pé ó ń "sọ ọ̀rọ̀ àlùfànṣá" sí òun, ó sì fi ẹnu tẹ́ oyè ọ̀mọ̀wé tí Montano ṣẹ̀ṣẹ̀ gbà ní Ifásitì Trinidad àti Tobago látàrí ipa tí ó kó ní ti ìgbélárugẹ orin soca.

english: Soon after George’s song was released, Montano responded with "Dr. Mashup", in which he directly addressed allegations of rigging the Road March contest:
yoruba: Kò pẹ́ tí a gbé orin George jáde, Montano fèsì pẹ̀lú orin tí a pe àkọlée rẹ̀ ní "Dr. Mashup", nínúu rẹ̀ ni ó ti sọ màdàrú tí wọ́n ṣe níbi ìdíje Ìwọ́de Ojúná:

english: That was not the end of it: at a new Carnival party, "Hydrate", on January 13, both artists performed. George included his new verse and Montano supposedly had the last word:
yoruba: Kò tán síbẹ̀: níbi ayẹyẹ Ijó ìta-gbangba tuntun, "Hydrate", ní ọjọ́ 13 oṣù Ṣẹrẹ, àwọn akọrin méjèèjì ṣeré. George lé orin rẹ̀ tuntun Montano náà sọ ọ̀rọ̀ ìkẹyìn:

english: After their performances, Montano’s manager, Anthony Chow Lin On, posted a photo to Instagram in which he comically holds the two apart:
yoruba: Lẹ́yìn eré, alábòójútó Montano, Anthony Chow Lin On, tari àwòrán kan sí orí Instagram tí ó fi ara jọ ẹ̀fẹ̀ ìtúká ẹni méjì tí ó ń jà:

english: The post left fans to wonder if the feud was real or simply a publicity stunt:
yoruba: Àtẹ̀jáde náà mú ìfura dání bóyá ìjà tòótọ́ ni tàbí ète lásán-làsàn:

english: Stunt or not, many social media users following the feud have pointed out that this type of lyrical sparring (known as a "sound clash") is not new; in fact, it is intricately woven into the origins of calypso music, and its modern-day hybrid, soca.
yoruba: Ète tàbí bẹ́ẹ̀ kọ́, ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ òǹlo ẹ̀rọ-alátagbà tó ń tẹ̀lé awuyewuye náà ti tọ́ka sí irúfẹ́ àríyànjiyàn orin báyìí (tí a mọ̀ sí "orin ìjà") kò jẹ́ tuntun; àti pé, ó bá orísun orin calypso mu, ó sì jẹ́ àmúlùmálà, soca.

english: In a recent interview, George himself addressed the fact that he was just "documenting the history" as he "always does", following the path of legendary calypsonians who did the same.
yoruba: Nínú ìfọ̀rọ̀wánilẹ́nuwò kan, George fúnra rẹ̀ sọ òtítọ́ ibẹ̀ wípé òun kàn ń "ṣe àkópamọ́ ìṣẹ̀lẹ̀ àtijọ́ " gẹ́gẹ́ "bí ó ṣe máa ń ṣe", títọpa àwọn ènìyàn jàǹkàn-jàǹkàn tí ó ti kọ orin calypso sẹ́yìn.

english: While calypso music is well known for its social and political commentary, an early form of the music involved verbal dueling similar to the war of words taking place between George and Montano.
yoruba: Orin calypso jẹ́ ìlúmọ̀nánká tí ó máa ń sọ nípa àwùjọ àti ìṣèlú, ní ìbẹ̀rẹ̀ pẹ̀pẹ̀ orin náà ni ìsọ̀rọ̀ síra ẹni méjì tí ó fi ara pẹ́ ogun ọ̀rọ̀ tí ó ń lọ ní àárín-in George àti Montano.

english: Calypso tents, where calypsonians perform during the Carnival season, were hugely popular for their "extempo wars", live contests in which singers would improvise lyrics on the spot mocking each other, or on a specific theme.
yoruba: Abẹ́ àtíbàbà orin Calypso, níbi tí àwọn eléré calipso ti máa ń ṣeré ní àsìkò Ijó ìta-gbangba, gbajúmọ̀ fún "ogun àìròtẹ́lẹ̀ ", ìdíje tí àwọn akọrin yóò kọrin èébú sí ara wọn láì rò tẹ́lẹ̀ lójú ẹsẹ̀, tàbí lórí àkọ́lé kan.

english: The banter between the performers is locally referred to as "picong".
yoruba: Ìfigagbága àwọn akọrin wọ̀nyí ni a mọ̀ sí "picong".

english: Such performances are typically interactive, with audiences echoing one of several refrains, the most common of which is "Santimanitay!", a derivative of the French phrase “sans humanité”, or “without pity”.
yoruba: Irúfẹ́ eré wọ̀nyí máa ń fi àyè gba ìdásí, tí àwọn olùwòràn yóò máa gbe orin, ọ̀kan tí ó wọ́pọ̀ jù lọ ni "Santimanitay!", tí ó jẹ́ ẹ̀dà àbọ̀-ọ̀rọ̀ Faransé “sans humanité”, tàbí “àìláàánú”.

english: But audiences have rarely witnessed a back-and-forth like this in recorded soca music.
yoruba: Àmọ́ àwọn òǹwòrán kò ì tíì rí irú èyí rí nínú orin soca tí a ti ká sílẹ̀.

english: And real or not, the George/Montano feud has listeners as engaged as any extempo wars audience, both at Carnival events and online.
yoruba: Ó jẹ́ òtítọ́ tàbí kò jẹ́ òtítọ́, àwọn olólùfẹ́ẹ George/Montano dá sí ogun àìròtẹ́lẹ̀ wọn gẹ́gẹ́ bí olùwòràn, ní Ijó ìta-gbangba àti lórí ayélujára.

english: George and Montano will, very likely, both in the running for the 2019 Road March title and at the very least, the added drama makes for good entertainment and more music.
yoruba: George àti Montano yô, láì sí àní-àní, nínú ìdíje Ìwọ́de Ojúná ọdún 2019 àti èyí tí ó kéré jù lọ, awuyewuye ìjà gẹ́gẹ́ bí ìdárayá gidi àti orin.

english: Soca lovers could ask for nothing more.
yoruba: Àwọn olólùfẹ́ẹ Soca kò le è béèrè ju bẹ́hẹ̀ lọ.

english: The Spiny Babbler, Nepal's only endemic bird, fascinates ornithologists and bird lovers alike
yoruba: Spiny Babbler, ẹyẹ orílẹ̀-èdè Nepal, fa àwọn onímọ̀-nípa-ẹyẹ àti olólùfẹ́ ẹyẹ mọ́ra

english: Spiny Babbler
yoruba: Spiny Babbler

english: Spiny Babbler, the bird found only in Nepal. Photo by Sagar Giri. Used with permission.
yoruba: Spiny Babbler, ẹyẹ tí a kò le è rí níbòmìrán àyàfi ní Nepal. Àwòrán láti ọwọ́ọ Sagar Giri. A lò ó pẹ̀lú àṣẹ.

english: Although more than 800 bird species are found in Nepal, the Spiny Babbler (Turdoides nipalensis) is the only bird that is endemic to the country.
yoruba: Bí-ó-ti-lẹ-jẹ́-pé ẹ̀yà ẹyẹ orílẹ̀ èdè Nepal ju 800 lọ, ẹyẹ Spiny Babbler (Turdoides nipalensis) jẹ́ ẹ̀dá tí kò sí ní ibòmíràn àyàfi orílẹ̀ èdè náà.

english: The greyish-brown bird, called Kaande Bhyakur in Nepali, lives in dense scrub and can be spotted more easily at elevations ranging from 500 meters to 2135 meters.
yoruba: Ẹyẹ aláwọ̀ eérú-àti-pupa-rẹ́súrẹ́sú náà, tí à ń pè ní Kaande Bhyakur ní èdè ìbílẹ̀ Nepali, ń fi igbó ṣe ìtẹ́ a sì lè fi ojú bà á bí ó bá ń fò lókè lálá láti ìwọ̀n mítà 500 sí mítà 2135.

english: Although the Spiny Babbler has been fascinating ornithologists the world around for years, environmental degradation is threatening this unique, much-loved bird.
yoruba: Bí ó ti lẹ̀ jẹ́ pé Spiny Babbler náà ti fa àwọn onímọ̀-nípa-ẹyẹ àgbáyé mọ́ra fún ọdún pípẹ́, ìbàjẹ́ àyíká ti ń ṣe ìdẹ́rùbà àkàndá, ẹyẹ tí àwọn ènìyàn fẹ́ràn yìí.

english: The book The Status of Nepal’s Birds: The National Red List Series states:
yoruba: Ìwée nì The Status of Nepal’s Birds: The National Red List Series sọ wípé:

english: It seeks insects almost entirely on the ground among low bushes, appearing only occasionally.
yoruba: Ó máa ń wá kòkòrò nínú koríko ilẹ̀, ẹ̀kànànkan ni a sì máa ń rí i.

english: Spiny Babbler mounts branches of bushes or small trees to sing, bill pointed upward and tail down. It is a good mimic, with squeaks, chuckles and chirps.
yoruba: Spiny Babbler máa ń bà lé ẹ̀ka koríko àti igi kéékèèké láti kọrin, àgógó ẹnu ẹyẹ yóò wà ní òkè irú ní ìsàlẹ̀.

english: It is most easily located by its song and occasionally sings as late as September and October. The species is subject to seasonal altitudinal movements.
yoruba: Ó dára ní wíwò, iké oríṣiríṣi. Orin rẹ̀ ni a fi ń mọ ibi tí ó wà, àárín oṣù Ọ̀wẹwẹ̀ àti Ọ̀wàrà. Ẹ̀dá ẹyẹ yìí máa ń fò sókè lálá nínú àwọn àkókò kan nínú ọdún.

english: The Spiny Babbler, found only in Nepal, has fascinated ornithologists and bird lovers from around the world. Don Messerschmidt writes about ornithologist S. Dillon Ripley’s account of the bird in his book Search for the Spiny Babbler:
yoruba: Ẹyẹ Spiny Babbler, tí a lè rí ní Nepal nìkan, ti fa àwọn onímọ̀-nípa-ẹyẹ àti olólùfẹ́ ẹyẹ káríayé mọ́ra. Don Messerschmidt kọ nípa àkọsílẹ̀ tí onímọ̀-nípa-ẹyẹ S. Dillon Ripley ṣe nípa ẹyẹ náà nínú ìwée rẹ̀ Ìṣàwárí ẹyẹ Spiny Babbler:

english: It was a species that had defied scientists for years, since 1843 or 1844.
yoruba: Ó jẹ́ ọ̀wọ̀ ẹyẹ tí kò ka àwọn onímọ̀ ìjìnlẹ̀ sáyẹ́ǹsì sí fún ọdún gbọgbọrọ, láti ọdún 1843 tàbí 1844.

english: At that time Brian Hodgson’s Nepali collectors working for him in the unknown vastnesses of Nepal had secured several specimens, he writes.
yoruba: Ní ìgbà yẹn àwọn aṣiṣẹ́ fún Brian Hodgson tí ó jẹ́ aṣèwádìí Nepali tí ṣe àkójọ onírúurú àpẹẹrẹ, ó kọ.

english: The Spiny Babbler had remained a mystery ever since, one of the five species of Indian birds, which, along with the Mountain Quail, had apparently vanished from the face of the earth.
yoruba: Ẹyẹ Spiny Babbler ti jẹ́ ẹranko tí ó ju ìmọ̀ ènìyàn lọ ní ọjọ́ tí ó ti pẹ́, ọ̀kan nínú ọ̀wọ̀ ẹyẹ márùn-ún ní India, pẹ̀lú Àparò Òkè gíga, kò sí lórílẹ̀ ayé mọ́n.

english: But not quite, for if my guess was right, here it was hopping about large as life on the wooded slopes above Rekcha.
yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n bí èrò mi bá jẹ́ òtítọ́, ó ń fò kiri níbi ní gẹ̀rẹ́gẹ̀rẹ́ òkè Rekcha.

english: Likewise, former-American ambassador to Nepal Scott DeLisi spent years trying to spot and photograph this bird.
yoruba: Bẹ́ẹ̀ gẹ́gẹ́, ikọ̀-ọba orílẹ̀-èdè America tẹ́lẹ̀ sí ìlú Nepal Scott DeLisi fi ọ̀pọ̀ ọdún wá ẹyẹ yìí àti láti ya àwòrán-an rẹ̀.

english: The bird is threatened by the clearance of scrub for agriculture and expansion of urban areas.
yoruba: Ẹyẹ náà ti ń dínkù látàrí ìgbẹ́ pípa fún iṣẹ́ ọ̀gbìn àti ìtẹ́lọ ìgbèríko di ìgboro.

english: Outside protected areas, it is sometimes threatened by hunting, and the hills surrounding the Kathmandu Valley have seen a decline in Spiny Babbler numbers.
yoruba: Bí a bá yọ ti agbègbè ààbò kúrò, nígbà mìíràn pípa ẹyẹ yìí fún oúnjẹ, ní òkè kékeré tí ó yí àfonífojì Kathmandu ká ti mú kí ẹyẹ Spiny Babbler dínkù ni iye.

english: However, the same habitat loss that is destroying the Spiny Babbler's habitat in some areas might actually be creating more in others.
yoruba: Síbẹ̀, ohun tí ó ń fa àdánù ní agbègbè kan náà lè mú wọn pọ̀ ní agbègbè mìíràn.

english: As the forest continues to thin due to deforestation throughout the country, the scrub-dominated habitat that they call home is being created in its wake.
yoruba: Bí igbó ṣe ń dínkù látàrí ìgbẹ́ pípa àti igi gẹdú gígé jákèjádò orílẹ̀ èdè náà, igbó tí wọ́n fi ṣe ilé ti di ti nǹkan mìíràn.

english: But only time will tell what is in store for the population of Nepal's only endemic bird.
yoruba: Àmọ́ ṣá ìgbà àti àkókò ni yóò sọ ohun tí yóò ṣẹlẹ̀ sí àwọn ẹyẹ ìlú Nepal tí kò sí ní ibòmíràn.

english: Nigeria's retired military generals battle for influence in 2019 presidential elections
yoruba: Àwọn ọ̀gágun ajagun fẹ̀yìntì orílẹ̀-èdè Nàìjíríà wọ̀yáàjà láti nípa lórí ètò ìdìbò ọdún-un 2019

english: Olusegun Obasanjo, former President of Nigeria.
yoruba: Olúṣẹ́gun Ọbásanjọ́, Ààrẹ àná orílẹ̀-èdè Nàìjíríà.

english: As Nigeria prepares for another presidential election in February, retired military generals turned politicians are key to understanding Nigeria's political space.
yoruba: Bí orílẹ̀-èdè Nàìjíríà ṣe ń múra fún ètò ìdìbò sí ipò Ààrẹ nínú Oṣù Èrèlé, àwọn ọ̀gágun tí ó ti jagun fẹ̀yìntì tí wọn di olóṣèlú, jẹ́ igi gbòógì fún òye ètò òṣèlú orílẹ̀-èdè Nàìjíríà.

english: Nigeria has been ruled by either former generals or those who have their support since 1999 when democratic governance returned.
yoruba: Àwọn ọ̀gágun tí ó ti fẹ̀yìntì tàbí àwọn tí wọn ṣe àtìlẹ́yìn fún láti dé orí ipò ni ó ti ń tukọ̀ orílẹ̀-èdè Nàìjíríà láti ọdún 1999 tí ìjọba tiwantiwa ti padà.

english: The recent public feud between former President Olusegun Obasanjo and the incumbent President Muhammadu Buhari — both retired military dictators — has a great impact on next month's elections.
yoruba: Asọ̀ tí ó wáyé láìpẹ́ yìí láàárín Ààrẹ àná, Olúsẹ́gun Ọbásanjọ́ àti Ààrẹ tí ó wà lórí àlééfà, Ààrẹ Muhammadu Buhari – tí àwọn méjèèjì jẹ́ ajagun fẹ̀yìntì afipásèjọba ológun –ní ipa tí ó pọ̀ lórí ètò ìdìbò oṣù tí ó ń bọ̀.

english: In a rare open letter to Buhari, Obasanjo has accused him of plans to rig the 2019 elections. He wrote:
yoruba: Nínú ìwé àpilẹ̀kọ kan tí a kò rí irúu rẹ̀ rí tí ó kọ ránṣẹ́ sí Buhari, Ọbásanjọ́ fi ẹ̀sùn kàn-án wípé ó ní ètè láti ṣe èrú ìbò. Ó kọ ọ́ sínú ìwé náà wípé:

english: Democracy becomes a sham if elections are carried out by people who should be impartial and neutral umpires, but who show no integrity, acting with blatant partiality, duplicity and imbecility.
yoruba: Ìtìjú ńlá gbáà ló jẹ́ fún ìjọba tiwantiwa, bí ètò ìbò tí o yẹ kí ó lọ ní ìrọwọ́-ìrọsẹ̀ láì fi ti apá kan ṣe, ṣùgbọ́n tí ìṣesíi wọn kò fi ìṣedéédé hàn, àìmúdọ́gba tí ó hàn kedere, ẹ̀tàn àti ìjòye àwòdì máà le è gbẹ́dìẹ.

english: Obasanjo insisted that Buhari would not deliver "free, fair, credible and peaceful elections" and warned that what "is happening under Buhari’s watch can be likened to what we witnessed under Gen. Sani Abacha.
yoruba: Ọbásanjọ́ tẹnu mọ́ ọn wípé Buhari kò leè "ṣe ètò ìbò tí ó kẹ́sẹjárí", àti wípé ìsèjọba tiwantiwa ní abẹ́ ìṣàkóso Buhari ni a lè fi wé tí ìjọba ológun fàmílétè-kí-n-tutọ́ọ ti Gen. Sani Abacha.

english: In 1998, Sani Abacha, a military dictator, had called for general elections but it became obvious that Abacha had no intention of handing power over to civilians.
yoruba: Ní ọdún 1998, Sani Abacha, tí ó jẹ́ ológun apàṣẹwàá ní ìgbà náà, pè fún ìbò gbogboògbò ṣùgbọ́n tí ó hàn ketekete pé Abacha kò ṣetán láti gbé ìjọba sílẹ̀ fún alágbádá.

english: The five political parties at the time endorsed Abacha as their sole presidential candidate.
yoruba: Ní àsìkò tí à ń sọ̀rọ̀ọ rẹ̀ yìí, àwọn ẹgbẹ́ òṣèlú márùn-ún ọ̀tọ̀ọ̀tọ̀ ni ó fọwọ́ síi wípé kí Abacha ó jẹ́ olùdíje fún ipò Ààrẹ nínú ẹgbẹ́ òṣèlúu wọn.

english: Now deceased, Abacha became infamous for his repression of human rights and corruption.
yoruba: Ní báyìí ó ti ṣípò-padà, òkìkí Abacha tàn káàkiri ó sì di ìlú-mọ̀-ọ́-ká nípa ìtẹrí ẹ̀tọ́ ọmọ-ènìyàn mọ́lẹ̀ àti ìjẹgùdùjẹrà.

english: Obasanjo alleged that Buhari was towing the "same path" as Abacha "in mad desperation".
yoruba: Ọbásanjọ́ tẹnumọ́ọ wípé "ipasẹ̀ " Abacha ní ọjọ́ kínní àná náà ni Buhari ń tọ́ báyìí "láì wo ẹ̀yìn wò."

english: Shehu Garba, the media assistant to President Buhari, dismissed Obasanjo's letter:
yoruba: Shehu Garba, tí ó jẹ́ olùrànlọ́wọ́ pàtàkì fún Ààrẹ Buhari lórí gbígbé ìròyìn jáde, bu ẹnu àtẹ́ lu ìwé àpilẹ̀kọ Ọbásanjọ́:

english: The elections starting in February will be free and fair as promised the nation and the international community by President Buhari.
yoruba: Ètò ìdìbò tí yóò wáyé nínú osù tí ó ń bọ̀ yìí yóò lọ ní pẹ̀lẹ́-kùtù, gẹ́gẹ́ bí Ààrẹ Buhari ti ṣe ìlérí fún ọmọ orílẹ̀-èdè yìí àti àgbáyé.

english: Obasanjo, the letter writer?
yoruba: Ọbásanjọ́, òǹkọ̀wé àpilẹ̀kọ?

english: Olusegun Obasanjo, former military head of state (1976-1979) and later Nigeria’s democratically elected president (1999-2007), has consistently criticized successive governments in Nigeria.
yoruba: Olúṣẹ́gun Ọbásanjọ́, tí ó jẹ́ Ààrẹ ìjọba ológun àná (láti ọdún 1976 sí 1979), tí ó sì tún ṣe Ààrẹ ìjọba alágbádá tí ìbò gbé wọlé (ní ọdún 1999 sí 2007), kúndùn láti máa bu ẹnu àtẹ́ lu àwọn ètò ìjọba Ààrẹ orílẹ̀-èdè Nàìjíríà tí ó jẹ tẹ̀lé e.

english: Last year, Obasanjo had advised Buhari not to seek re-election as president but to "consider a deserved rest at this point in time and at this age".
yoruba: Ní èṣí, Ọbásanjọ́ gba Buhari ni ìmọ̀ràn láti má díje fún ipò Ààrẹ fún ìgbà kejì, ṣùgbọ́n kí ó "da ìfẹ̀yìntì rò nítorí ọjọ́ oríi rẹ̀ ".

english: This advice caused ripples in Nigeria because Obasanjo was a strong supporter of the Buhari’s candidacy during the 2015 presidential elections.
yoruba: Àmọ̀ràn yìí dá yánpọnyánrin sílẹ̀ ní orílẹ̀-èdè Nàìjíríà nítorí wípé Ọbásanjọ́ jẹ́ alátìlẹ́yìn àgbà fún Buhari gẹ́gẹ́ bí òǹdíje nínú ìbò ipò Ààrẹ ni sáà àkọ́kọ́ ní ọdún 2015.

english: Prior, Obasanjo had scolded Goodluck Jonathan in a public letter written in 2013, Obasanjo accused Jonathan of driving the country to the precipice and allowing deceit, corruption and mutual distrust to tear at the fabric of the nation.
yoruba: Ṣáájú àsìkò yìí, Ọbásanjọ́ ti bá ìjọba Goodluck Jónátánì wí nínú ìwé àpilẹ̀kọ tí ó kọ ránṣẹ́ sí i ní ọdún 2013, Ọbásanjọ́ fi ẹ̀sùn kan Jónátánì wípé ó ń darí orílẹ̀-èdè Nàìjíríà lọ sí oko ìparun pẹ̀lú bí ó ṣe fi àyè gba ẹ̀tàn, ìjẹ́gùdùjẹrà, ìbápín àìgbẹ́kẹ̀lé láti fa aṣọ iyì àti ìtẹ̀síwájú orílè-èdè náà ya pẹ́rẹpẹ̀rẹ.

english: Ironically, Obasanjo had also supported Jonathan's election in 2011. And in 2007, he promoted the election of Jonathan Goodluck's predecessor, Umaru Musa Yar’Adua.
yoruba: Ní àpárá, Ọbásanjọ́ ti Goodluck Jónátánì lẹ́yìn nínú ètò ìdìbò tí ó wáyé ní ọdún 2011. Àti wípé ni ọdún 2007, òun yìí kan náà ni ó ti Umaru Musa Yar'Adua tí ó jẹ kí Jónátánì ó tó jẹ lẹ́yìn digbídigbí.

english: However, Obasanjo went against Yar’Adua when the latter became sick and did not hand properly hand over power to Jonathan, his then deputy.
yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n tí ó pa ìdí ọ̀rẹ́ dá sí Yar'Adua lẹ́yìn ìgbátí ó bẹ̀rẹ̀ àìsàn tí kò sì gbé ètò ìṣe ìjọba fún igbákèjì rẹ̀ tii ṣe Goodluck Jónátánì.

english: Former Nigerian President Goodluck Jonathan with newly sworn-in President Muhammadu Buhari during his inauguration ceremony on May 29, 2015.
yoruba: Ààrẹ orílẹ̀-èdè Nàìjíríà àná Goodluck Jonathan with pẹ̀lú Ààrẹ tí ó ṣẹ̀ṣẹ̀ gorí àlééfà Muhammadu Buhari níbi ayẹyẹ ìfilọ́lẹ̀ ìjọba tuntun ní ọjọ́ 29, oṣù Èbìbì, ọdún 2015.

english: Public Domain photo from the US State Department.
yoruba: Àworan Ìkápá Gbogboògbò láti ẹ̀ka ìjọba US.

english: Retired generals never rest in Nigeria
yoruba: Ọ̀gágun tí ó ti jagun fẹ̀yìntì kì í sinmi ní orílẹ̀-èdè Nàìjíríà

english: Nigeria’s political landscape is held by retired generals or their cronies. Obasanjo, for instance, has been instrumental in the emergence of Nigerian presidents from 2007 to 2015.
yoruba: Abẹ ìgbèkùn àwọn ọ̀gágun tí ó ti jagun fẹ̀yìntì àti àwọn asọ́mogbée wọn ni orílẹ̀-èdè Nàìjíríà wà. Bí àpẹẹrẹ, Ọbásanjọ́ jẹ́ alẹ́nulọ́rọ̀ tí ó mọ àludé tòun àpadé bí àwọn Ààrẹ ṣe ń gba ipò láti ọdún 2007 sí 2015.

english: However, unlike civilians – Yar’Adua and Jonathan – who he promoted and also criticized, Buhari is somewhat different.
yoruba: Bíótiwùkíórí, láì jọ ti àwọn alágbádá – Yar'Adua àti Jónátánì – tí ó gbé ní arugẹ, tí ó sì tún yẹpẹrẹ wọn, ti Buhari dá yàtọ̀ gedegbe.

english: Although Obasanjo supported Buhari’s election in 2015, he cannot fully take the praise alone.
yoruba: Bí ó ti lẹ̀ jé pé Ọbásanjọ́ ti Buhari lẹ́yìn láti leè yege ní ọdún 2015, a kò leè sọ pé àtìlẹyìn rẹ̀ nìkan ni ó gbé e dé ipò Ààrẹ.

english: This is because Buhari’s ascendance to power was made possible by his allegiance with Bola Tinubu’s defunct Action Congress of Nigeria (ACN).
yoruba: Nítorí ohun tí ó jẹ́ kí ó ṣeé ṣe ò ju bí Buhari ṣe fi ọwọ́ wẹ ọwọ́ pẹ̀lú ẹgbẹ́ òṣèlú ìgbàanì Action Congress of Nigeria (ACN) ti Bọ́lá Tinubu.

english: Buhari’s Congress for Progressive Change (CPC) later merged with ACN, in February 2013, to form the All Progressive Congress (APC) .
yoruba: Ẹgbẹ́ òṣèlú Congress for Progressive Change (CPC) ti Buhari jẹ ọmọ ẹgbẹ́ ní ìgbẹ̀yìngbẹ́yín parapọ̀ mọ́ ACN, wọ́n sì di ọkàn nínú oṣù Kejì ọdún 2013, èyí tí ó ṣe okùnfà ìdásílẹ̀ ẹgbẹ́ òṣèlú tuntun tí orúkọ rẹ̀ ń jẹ́ Àjọ Ìtẹ̀síwájú Gbogboògbò (APC).

english: In addition, Buhari a former military head of state (1983-1985) is a member of the ‘club’ of retired generals who have dominated Nigeria’s political space.
yoruba: Ní àfikún, Buhari tí ó ṣe olórí ìjọba ológun ní ọdún (1983 sí 1985) jẹ́ ọ̀kan lára àwọn ọmọ ‘ẹgbẹ́’ ọ̀gágun tí ó ti fẹ̀yìntì tí ó ti takú ti ètò òṣèlú orílẹ̀-èdè Nàìjíríà.

english: Therefore, as harsh as Obasanjo’s reprimand might sound, a lot depends on the dynamics of the power block to which they both belong.
yoruba: Fún ìdí èyí, bí Ọbásanjọ́ ṣe tàbùkù Buhari ní gbangba tó, ó níí ṣe pẹ̀lú agbára àti ipò ẹgbẹ́ tí àwọn méjèèjì wà gẹ́gẹ́ bí ọ̀gágun tí ó ti jagun fẹ̀yìntì.

english: Obasanjo is not alone, however, in his criticism of Buhari.
yoruba: Ọbásanjọ́ nìkan sì kọ́ ni ọ̀gágun tí ó ti jagun fẹ̀yìntì tí ó ń tàbùkù Buhari.

english: Theophilus Danjuma, a retired general, had in March last year accused "the Nigerian armed forces of aiding the ongoing killings in Nigeria".
yoruba: Theophilus Danjuma, tí òun náà jẹ́ ọ̀gágun tí ó ti jagun fẹ̀yìntì ní oṣù kẹ́ta ọdún tí ó kọjá fi ẹ̀sùn kan "ẹgbẹ́ ológun orílẹ̀-èdè Nàìjíríà wípé ó ń gbárùkù ti ìpànìyàn nípakúpa tí ó ń lọ ní orílẹ̀-èdè Nàìjíríà".

english: Danjuma, a former chief of army staff and later minister of defense, chastised the military for taking sides in the pastoral/farmer crisis in the country, but especially in his home state of Taraba.
yoruba: Danjuma, tí ó jẹ olórí àwọn ológun, tí o si tún jẹ́ mínísítà fún ètò abo ní ìgbà kan rí, bu ẹnu àtẹ́ lu ẹgbẹ́ ológun bí wọ́n ṣe ń gbé lẹ́yìn apá kan dá apá kan sí nínú aáwọ̀ tí ó wáyé láàárín àwọn darandaran àti àgbẹ̀, pàápàá jù lọ èyí tí ó wáyé ní ilée rẹ̀ tí í ṣe ìpínlẹ̀ Taraba.

english: Similarly, Danjuma recently raised an alarm about plans to use “the police and soldiers” to manipulate the 2019 elections.
yoruba: Ìrí-bá-kan-náà, Danjuma fi ariwo ta nípa ète bí àwọn “ọlọ́pàá àti ológun” ṣe ń gbìmọ̀pọ̀ láti ṣe ẹ̀rú nínú ìbò ọdún 2019.

english: Similarly, in February last year, former military head of state Ibrahim Babangida publicly advised President Buhari not to stand for re-election, arguing that 21st century Nigeria needs to tap younger generations.
yoruba: Bákan náà ẹ̀wẹ̀wẹ̀, nínú Oṣù Kejì ọdún tí ó kọjá, ajagun fẹ̀yìntì tí ó tún jẹ́ olórí orílẹ̀-èdè Nàìjíríà láyé ológun, Ibrahim Babangida gba Ààrẹ Buhari ní ìyànjú láti máà du ìje fún ipò Ààrẹ fún ìgbà kejì, nítorí wípé ọgọ́rùn-ún ọdún 21 tí Nàìjíríà wà yìí jẹ́ àsìkò àwọn ọ̀dọ́ tí ó ní ìrírí ìgbàlódé.

english: He believes that there "comes a time in the life of a nation when personal ambition should not override national interest".
yoruba: Ó gbàgbọ́ wípé ìgbàkanìgbàkàn “ohun tí yóò jẹ́ àǹfààní gbogbo ará ìlú gbọdọ̀ bo orí àǹfààní ti ara ẹni.”

english: But it may be a while before Nigeria gets a civilian president who has no links or backing from the retired generals "club".
yoruba: Pẹ̀lú bí gbogbo nǹkan ṣe ń lọ, yóò fẹ́rẹ̀ẹ́ pẹ́ díẹ̀ kí orílẹ̀-èdè Nàìjíríà ó tó le è ní Ààrẹ tí kò ní nǹkan ṣe pẹ̀lú, tàbí tí kò ní àtìlẹ́yìn "ẹgbẹ́ " àwọn ọ̀gágun ajagun fẹ̀yìntì.

english: An owl refuses to leave Tanzanian parliament. What does it all mean?
yoruba: Òwìwí kan kọ̀ kò kúrò nínú ilé ìgbìmọ̀ ìjọba Tanzania. Àmìi kí ni èyí?

english: Nyerere Square in Dodoma, the capital of Tanzania, and home of the parliament, "Bunge".
yoruba: Gbàgede Nyerere Square ní Dodoma, olú-ìlú orílẹ̀-èdè Tanzania, àti ilé ìgbìmọ̀ aṣòfin, "Bunge".

english: Photo by Pernille Bærendtsen, used with permission.
yoruba: Àwòrán láti ọwọ́ọ Pernille Bærendtsen, a lò ó pẹ̀lú àṣẹ.

english: On January 29, when the Tanzanian parliament (Bunge) assembled in Dodoma for its first session of 2019, an owl flew into the building, perched on the ceiling and observed the assembly from above.
yoruba: Ní ọjọ́ 29 oṣù Ṣẹrẹ, nígbà tí àwọn àjọ ìjọba Tanzania (Bunge) péjọ ní Dodoma fún ìjókòó ìpàdé tí ó ṣáájú nínú ọdún-un 2019, ẹyẹ òwìwí kan fò wọ inú ilé ìpàdé, ó sì bà sí orí ajá, níbi tí ó ti ń wo ìpéjọ láti òkè téńté.

english: The incident drew national attention and provoked questions from social media users and newspapers.
yoruba: Ìṣẹ̀lẹ̀ náà di ìròyìn tí ó sì tàn kálékáko, tí ó sì ń mú àwọn ènìyàn ṣe onírúurú ìbéèrè láti orí ẹ̀rọ-alátagbà àti ìwé ìròyìn.

english: What could the presence of an owl in parliament mean?
yoruba: Àpẹẹrẹ wo ni ti òwìwí nínú ilé ìgbìmọ̀ ?

english: The owl has been spotted twice inside the halls of parliament in the city of Dodoma. What does it seem to signal?
yoruba: Ẹyẹ òwìwí náà ti jẹ́ rírí nínúu gbọ̀ngan ilé ìgbìmọ̀ ìlú Dodoma ní ẹ̀rìnmejì. Àpẹẹrẹ wo ni èyí túmọ̀ sí?

english: "Bad omen?" the regional weekly, The East African, proposed.
yoruba: "Àmì burúkú?" ìwé ìròyìn ẹkùn-ìlú ọlọ́sẹ̀ọ̀sẹ̀, Ìlà-oòrùn Afrika, dá ìmọ̀ràn.

english: The British blogger and media analyst, Ben Taylor, went further:
yoruba: Akọbúlọ́ọ̀gù ọmọ Gẹ̀ẹ́sì àti onímọ̀ kíkún nípa iṣẹ́ ìròyìn, Ben Taylor, sọ síwájú sí i:

english: Cartoon by Samuel Mwamkinga (Joune), used with permission.
yoruba: Àwòrán-ẹ̀fẹ̀ láti ọwọ́ọ Samuel Mwamkinga (Joune), a lòó pẹ̀lú àṣẹ.

english: Tanzanian cartoonist, Samuel Mwamkinga (Joune), later illustrated the incident with a reference to the British term "a group of owls" based on the Greek perception that owls are wise (illustration used with permission).
yoruba: Ayàwòrán-ẹ̀fẹ̀ ọmọ bíbíi Tanzania, Samuel Mwamkinga (Joune), lẹ́yìn wá, ya àpẹẹrẹ àwòrán ìṣẹ̀lẹ̀ náà pẹ̀lú ìtọ́ka sí ìsọlọ́rúkọ ní èdè Gẹ̀ẹ́sì "àkójọpọ̀ àwọn òwìwí" látàrí ìmọ̀ àwọn Gíríìkì tí ó ní wípé ọlọ́gbọ́n ni ẹyẹ òwìwí (pẹ̀lú àṣẹ ni a fi lo àwòrán àpẹẹrẹ).

english: The owl is, however, seen as an omen of death and misfortune in Tanzania.
yoruba: Síbẹ̀, ojú nǹkan búburú, àmì ikú àti òfo ní Tanzania ni àwọn ènìyàn fi wò ó.

english: And — the owl was determined to stay in Bunge, according to The Citizen:
yoruba: Àti pé — òwìwí náà ti pinnu láti dúró sí Bunge, gẹ́gẹ́ bí Ọmọọ̀lú Náà ti wí:

english: The owl, a nocturnal bird, could not leave... despite several attempts by parliament officials to evict it.
yoruba: Òwìwí, ẹyẹ òru, kò le è kúrò... pẹ̀lú gbogbo ọ̀nà tí àwọn àjọ ọba gbà láti lé e jáde.

english: Owls are not unusual in Tanzania, and neither is Tanzanians’ inclination toward superstition. A 2010 survey found that 93 percent of Tanzanians believe in witchcraft.
yoruba: Ẹyẹ òwìwí kì í ṣe ẹyẹ rere ní Tanzania, àti pé, bẹ́ẹ̀ ni Tanzania kì í ní ìgbàgbọ́-asán. Ìwò káàkiri ọdún-un 2010 kan fi hàn wípé ìdá 94 ọmọ bíbí Tanzania ní ìgbàgbọ́ nínú agbára Àjẹ́.

english: No ordinary parliament session
yoruba: Ìpàdé ìgbìmọ̀ lásán kọ́

english: For this particular session, the presence of the owl offered a symbolism, even for the nonsuperstitious, which was too stark to be ignored.
yoruba: Fún ti ìpàdé yìí, ẹyẹ òwìwí nínúu ìpàdé ní ìtúmọ̀ tí ó ní àpẹẹrẹ, pàápàá fún àwọn tí kò ní ìgbàgbọ́-asán, tí ó le pátápátá láti mú ojú kúrò.

english: On the agenda for Tanzania’s first parliamentary session of 2019 were the proposed amendments of the Political Parties Act, which has followed a months-long, intense debate in an increasingly unstable political climate.
yoruba: Ní orí ìlànà ètò ìpàdé àkọ́kọ́ ìgbìmọ̀ọ Tanzania ọdún-un 2019 ni ìdámọ̀ràn àtúnṣe sí Òfin Ẹgbẹ́ Òṣèlú, tí ó ti ní àríyànjiyàn lemọ́lemọ́ nínúu ìṣèlú tí nǹkan kò ṣe ẹnu re.

english: Tanzania made history in 1992 as one of the first countries in Africa to establish a multiparty system, which allowed opposition parties.
yoruba: Tanzania wọ ìwé ìtàn ní ọdún-un 1992 gẹ́gẹ́ bíi orílẹ̀-èdè àkọ́kọ́ ní Ilẹ̀-adúláwò tí yóò dá ètò ẹgbẹ́ òṣèlú púpọ̀ sílẹ̀, èyí tí ó fi àyè gba ẹgbẹ́ ìkọjúsí.

english: The Political Parties Act (here with proposed amendments) was also introduced in 1992 and has been amended over time with the latest amendment in 2009.
yoruba: Òfin Ẹgbẹ́ Òṣèlú náà (rè é níbi pẹ̀lú àtúnṣe tí a gbà ní ìmọ̀ràn) bákan náà di lílò ní ọdún-un 1992, ó sì ti rí àtúnṣe ní ọ̀pọ̀ ìgbà bíi àtúnṣe ti ọdún-un 2009.

english: With the owl perching above the assembly, Tanzanian parliamentarians agreed to amend the act — a step that critics regard as a serious weakening of the multiparty system in Tanzania, and thus also democracy.
yoruba: Pẹ̀lú wípé òwìwí wọ̀ sí òkè téńté nínúu ìpàdé, kò dí ìpinnu àwọn ìgbìmọ̀ lọ́wọ́ láti ṣe àtúnṣe sí òfin — ìgbésẹ̀ tí àwọn atàbùkù ní wípé ó sọ ètò ẹgbẹ́ òṣèlú púpọ̀ Tanzania, àti ìjọba tiwantiwa bákan náà di yẹpẹrẹa

english: In short, the renewal of the act provides more authority to the government-appointed registrar to not only deregister political parties but also to issue punishments in the form of imprisonment if a political party.
yoruba: Gẹ́gẹ́ bí Reuters ti ṣe wí, ìsọdituntun òfin náà ti fi agbára tí ó pọ̀ sí ọwọ́ àwọn akọ̀wé ìrántí tí ìjọba-yàn láti da ìwé àṣẹ ẹgbẹ́ òṣèlú nù àti láti fi ìyà ìfisẹ́wọ̀n jẹ ẹgbẹ́ olóṣèlú tí ó bá ṣẹ̀ sí òfin.

english: For instance, carries out civic education related to voter registration and other politically-motivated activities, according to Reuters.
yoruba: Ní àpẹẹrẹ, bí ó bá ṣe ìdánilẹ́kọ̀ọ́ ìlú tí ó ní í ṣe pẹ̀lú ìforúkọsílẹ̀ òǹdìbò àti àgbékalẹ̀ ètò mìíràn tí ó ní í ṣe pẹ̀lú ìṣèlú.

english: Several media quoted Zitto Kabwe, leader of the opposition party ACT-Wazalendo, who already back in August 2017 criticized the proposed amendment of the act, predicting it may undermine political rights.
yoruba: Ọ̀pọ̀ ilé-ìròyìn ni ó ṣe àtúnwí ọ̀rọ̀ Zitto Kabwe, olórí ẹgbẹ́ òṣèlú alátakò ACT-Wazalendo, ẹni tí ó jẹ́ wípé nínú oṣù Ògún ọdún-un 2017 bu ẹnu àtẹ́ lu ìdámọ̀ràn àtúnṣe òfin náà, wípé ó ṣe é ṣe kí ó rọ́ ẹ̀tọ́ òṣèlú sẹ́yìn.

english: Kabwe then compared it to the Media Services Bill 2016, which set the free and independent media back. Now, Kabwe calls attention to the inherent contradiction caused by the amendment of the Political Parties Act:
yoruba: Kabwe wá fi wé Àbádòfin Iṣẹ́ Ìròyìn ọdún-un 2016, èyí tí ó fi òmìnira fún ilé iṣẹ́ ìròyìn tí ó sì dá ilé ìròyìn aládàánialáìgbáralé-ìjọba padà. Wàyí, Kabwe pe àkíyèsí sí ìjì lẹ́sẹ̀ tí àtúnṣe Òfin Ẹgbẹ́ Òṣèlú dá sílẹ̀:

english: You can’t have a constitution that allows freedom of association then give someone powers to revoke that freedom of association.
yoruba: A kò le è ní ìwé-òfin tí ó fi ẹ̀tọ́ fún òmíràn ìkẹ́gbẹ́ kí ó tún wá fún ẹnìkan ní agbára láti mú ẹ̀tọ́ òmìnira ìkẹ́gbẹ́ kúrò.

english: In recent years, Tanzania has turned increasingly authoritarian in its legislation, resulting in less space for critical political opponents and independent media.
yoruba: Ní ẹnu ọdún mélòó kan sẹ́yìn, òfin orílẹ̀-èdè Tanzania ti ń yí padà di aláfagbára ṣe, arapa rẹ̀ sì ń fa àìrí àyè fún ẹgbẹ́ òṣèlú mìíràn àti ilé iṣẹ́ ìròyìn aláìgbáralé-ìjọba láti ṣe bí ó ṣe ní abẹ́ òfin.

english: Now, critics say the amended Political Parties Act will make it more difficult to practice politics that are critical of the president and Chama Cha Mapinduzi (The Party of the Revolution), in power since independence in 1961.
yoruba: Ní báyìí, àwọn aṣàyẹ̀wò fínnífínní ti sọ wípé àtúnṣe Òfin Ẹgbẹ́ Òṣèlú kò ní mú un rọrùn fún ètò ìṣèlú tí ó jẹ́ pàtàkì fún Ààrẹ àti Chama Cha Mapinduzi (Ẹgbẹ́ Àyípadà Náà), tí ó ti wà ní orí àlééfà láti ìgbà tí òmìnira dé ní ọdún-un 1961.

english: Opposition is essential for a vibrant democracy. A strong opposition will check up on government and challenge it.
yoruba: Ìtakò jẹ́ dandanàndan nínú ìjọba tiwantiwa tí ó yé kooro. Alátakò gidi yóò ṣe àyẹ̀wò fínnífínní sí ètò ìjọba, yóò sì pè é ní ìjà.

english: If there is no opposition, diversity of citizen needs are unlikely to be represented well.
yoruba: Bí kò bá sí alátakò, ó ṣe é ṣe kí ojú àwọn onírúurú ìyàtọ̀ ohun tí ọmọ-ìlú nílò ó máa jẹ́ ṣíṣe bí ó ti ṣe tọ́.

english: In 15 tweets, doctoral student Rachel McLellan walked readers through possible consequences of the new act, and characterizes a situation where a critical opposition will find itself cornered:
yoruba: Nínú túwíìtì 15, akẹ́kọ̀ọ́ ìmọ̀ ìṣègùn Rachel McLellan la àwọn ènìyàn ní òye nípa èrèdíi òfin tuntun náà, àti irú ibi tí ìtako tí ó mú ọpọlọ dání yóò ti wúlò :walked readers through possible consequences of the new act, and characterizes a situation where a critical opposition will find itself cornered:

english: Superstitious or not — those critical of Tanzania's authoritarian turn found some wicked relief in the presence of the owl and the unsuccessful attempts to chase it away.
yoruba: Ìgbàgbọ́-asán ni tàbí bẹ́ẹ̀ kọ́ – àwọn tí ó ń ṣe àgbéyẹ̀wò ìṣèjọba àfagbáraṣe orílẹ̀-èdè Tanzania rí ìdánilójú awuyewuye wọn pẹ̀lú ti ẹyẹ òwìwí tí ó wọ inú ilé ìgbìmọ̀ àti ìgbésẹ̀ gbogbo láti lé e dánú àmọ́ tí kò bọ́ sí i.

english: The owl remained. Speaker of the Parliament, Job Ndugai, tried to tweak traditional belief with a pragmatic explanation:
yoruba: Òwìwí náà ta kété. Agbẹnusọ Ìgbìmọ̀, Job Ndugai, gbìyànjú láti yí ìgbàgbọ́ ìbílẹ̀ padà pẹ̀lú àlàyé tí ó ní iyè nínú:

english: Honourable Members of Parliament, we have been seeing an owl in this House since morning but in the tradition of people of Dodoma, an owl that is seen during daytime cannot have any effect on anyone.
yoruba: Ẹ̀yin Ọmọ Ìgbìmọ̀ Ọlọ́lá, a ti ń rí ẹyẹ òwìwí kan nínú Ilé yìí láti òwúrọ̀ àmọ́ nínú ìgbàgbọ́ ìbílẹ̀ Dodoma, òwìwí tí a bá rí ní ojú-ọjọ́ kò ní ohunkóhun ń ṣe fún ẹnikẹ́ni.

english: This means that we have nothing to worry about its presence.
yoruba: Èyí jásí wípé kò sí ìbẹ̀rù.

english: For the critical, however, there is nothing pragmatic about the new act.
yoruba: Fún àwọn tí ó ń wá àṣìṣe, síbẹ̀, kò sí ohun tí ó ní iyè nínú nípa òfin tuntun náà.

english: With tensions rising ahead of 2019 presidential elections, Nigerians fear internet shutdown
yoruba: Pẹ̀lú àìbalẹ̀-ọkàn tí ó ń pọ̀ sí i ní ìmúra ìbò ààrẹ ọdún-un 2019, Ọmọ orílẹ̀-èdè Nàìjíríà ń bẹ̀rùu pípa ẹ̀rọ-ayélujára

english: Fears of an internet shutdown in Nigeria looms as tensions continue to rise ahead of 2019 presidential elections.
yoruba: Ìbẹ̀rùbojo gba orílẹ̀-èdè Nàìjíríà kan látàrí awuyewuye pé ó ṣe é ṣe kí ẹ̀rọ ayélukára-bí-ajere ó di pípa ní àsìkò ìbò ààrẹ ọdún-un 2019.

english: Fear has spread across Nigeria that the government may switch off the internet during the presidential elections in February 2019.
yoruba: Ẹ̀rù ti ń tàn ká orílẹ̀-èdè Nàìjíríà wípé ó ṣe é ṣe kí ìjọba ó pa ẹ̀rọ-ayélujára ní àsìkò ìbò ààrẹ nínú oṣù Èrèlé ọdún-un 2019.

english: What started as mere speculation has morphed into intense worry as election day approaches. Yomi Kamez of Quartz Africa explains:
yoruba: Ohun tí ó bẹ̀rẹ̀ bí àhesọ lásán ti ń di ohun tí ó ń gbé àwọn ènìyàn ní ọkàn bí ìbò ṣe ń sún mọ́lé. Yomi Kamez ti Quartz Africa ṣàlàyé :

english: You can tell fears of an internet shutdown are running high in a country when citizens are looking into methods of staying online in case of a blockage.
yoruba: A lè sọ wípé ìbẹ̀rùbojo nípa pípa ẹ̀rọ-ayélujára ń gbilẹ̀ sí i ní orílẹ̀-èdè tí àwọn ọmọ-ìlú ń wá ìlànà tí yóò mú wọn wà ní orí ayélukára-bí-ajere bí ìdígàgá bá wáyé.

english: This past weekend, Quartz Africa’s guide to staying online during internet or social media blockages was our most read story, driven entirely by traffic from Nigeria.
yoruba: Ní ìsinmi tí ó kọjá lọ, ìtọ́sọ́nà bí a ṣe lè wà ní orí ayélukára-bí-ajere ti Quartz Africa kó jọ bí ìdígàgá ẹ̀rọ-ayélujára tàbí ẹ̀rọ-alátagbà bá wáyé ni ìròyìn-in wá tí àwọn òǹkàròyìn kà jù lọ, tí ọ̀pọ̀ sì jẹ́ ọmọ orílẹ̀-èdè Nàìjíríà.

english: Scores of people shared concerns on social media at the possibility Nigeria might follow other African countries [like Sudan, Zimbabwe] that have taken to blocking social media or shut down the internet altogether under the guise of security concerns.
yoruba: Ọ̀gọ̀rọ̀ ènìyàn ni ó sọ ní orí ẹ̀rọ-alátagbà wípé a kì í ṣe é mọ̀, Nàìjíríà lè tọ ipa ẹsẹ̀ àwọn orílẹ̀-èdè Adúláwọ̀ [bíi Sudan, Zimbabwe] tí ìjọba ti dígàgá ẹ̀rọ-alátagbà tàbí pa ẹ̀rọ-ayélujára ní àpapọ̀ ní ìrí ọ̀ràn ààbò.

english: Recent events related to social media, hate speech, an unjust judiciary firing and replacement, and the breaking down of trust in the media have all contributed to the growing collective concern.
yoruba: Àwọn ìṣẹ̀lẹ̀ tí ó jẹ́ mọ́n ẹ̀rọ-alátagbà, ọ̀rọ̀ ìkórìíra, ìdádúró lẹ́nu iṣẹ́ àti ìrọ́pò adájọ́, àti àìgbàgbọ́ nínú ilé iṣẹ́ ìròyìn ni ó parapọ̀.

english: De-fanging the judiciary and rule of law
yoruba: Yíyọ-eyín onídàájọ́ àti ìdọ́gba lábẹ́ òfin

english: On January 25, 2019, Nigerians were shocked by President Muhammadu Buhari’s unilateral suspension of the Chief Justice of Nigeria Justice Walter Onnoghen, and the immediate appointment and swearing in of Justice Ibrahim Tanko Muhammad, as the acting Chief Justice of Nigeria (CJN).
yoruba: Ní ọjọ́ 25, oṣù Ṣẹrẹ ọdún-un 2019, ìyàlẹ́nu ni ó jẹ́ fún ọmọ orílẹ̀-èdè Nàìjíríà nígbà tí Ààrẹ Muhammad Buhari ní òun nìkan dá Adájọ́ Àgbà Orílẹ̀-èdè Nàìjíríà, Onídàájọ́ Walter Onnoghen dúró ní ẹnu iṣẹ́, tí ó sì yan ẹlòmíràn ní kíákíá, ìyẹn Ibrahim Tanko Muhammad ẹni tí a búra fún gẹ́gẹ́ bíi aṣiṣẹ́ bíi Adájọ́ Àgbà Orílẹ̀-èdè Nàìjíríà (CJN).

english: Onnoghen had been charged with financial negligence and fraud.
yoruba: Ẹ̀sùn àìbìkítà àti ìṣowó-ìlú-mọ́kumọ̀ku ni a fi kan Onnoghen.

english: However, many critics say these charges were a ploy to gag the judiciary ahead of the elections and intimidate other arms of government.
yoruba: Síbẹ̀, àwọn alátakò sọ wípé ẹ̀sùn wọ̀nyí jẹ́ ìgbésẹ̀ láti di àjọ onídàájọ́ ní ẹnu ní ìpalẹ̀mọ́ ìbò, àti dáyàfo ẹ̀ka ìjọba tí ó kù.

english: The suspension of Onnoghen contradicts the provisions of the 1999 Constitution of the Federal Republic of Nigeria for the removal of judicial officers.
yoruba: Ìdádúróo Onnoghen ta ìpá sí òfin Orílẹ̀-èdè Nàìjíríà ọdún-un 1999 fún ìyọkúrò àwọn adájọ́ .

english: The Third Schedule, Part 1 of the 1999 Constitution states that only the National Judicial Council (NJC) has the power to recommend removals from office. Part IV of the Constitution further reiterates this law.
yoruba: Àlàálẹ̀ Ìkẹta, Apá 1, ti ìwé òfin ọdún-un 1999 sọ wípé Àjọ Onídàájọ́ (NJC) nìkan ni ó ní àṣẹ láti lè rọ adájọ́ ní oyè. Apá IV ìwé òfin náà túbọ̀ sọ síwájú nípa òfin yìí.

english: Nigerian President Muhammadu Buhari did not apply these principles.
yoruba: Ààrẹ orílẹ̀-èdè Nàìjíríà Muhammadu Buhari kò tẹ̀lé àwọn àlàálẹ̀ wọ̀nyí.

english: He usurped the powers of the NJC which is constitutionally mandated to recommend such removals from the judiciary or Senate (upper house of parliament) which must then ratify such decisions.
yoruba: Ó fi ipá gba agbára lọ́wọ́ NJC tí ó ní àṣẹ ní abẹ́ òfin láti sọ bóyá kí a rọ adájọ́ tàbí aṣojú-ṣòfin (ilé ìgbìmọ̀ àgbà) ní oyè, tí yóò sì fi ohùn sí irúfẹ́ ìgbésẹ̀ náà.

english: The president's action was both tyrannical and lawless.
yoruba: Ìwà ìfagbáraṣèjọba ni ààrẹ hù, bẹ́ẹ̀ ni kò sì bá òfin mú.

english: An editorial in Punch newspaper described Buhari's action as dictatorial and capable of precipitating a constitutional crisis:
yoruba: Ìrò olóòtú ìwé ìròyìn Punch pe ìhùwàsíi Buhari gẹ́gẹ́ bíi ti apàṣẹ-wàá àti pé ìwà náà lè fa rògbòdìyàn-an ti òfin:

english: Buhari’s action is vile, perfidious and indefensible.
yoruba: Ìhùwàsíi Buhari burú jáyì, ó ní ẹ̀tàn nínú, kò sì ní orí kò sì ní ìdí.

english: It is an action only fit for jackboot regimes, where the constitution could easily be suspended...
yoruba: Ìwà àkóso ìjọba fàmílétèntutọ́, tí ìwé òfin lè di ìfọwọ́rọ́tìsẹ́gbẹ̀ẹ́...

english: Needless to say, the president’s singular and misguided action has the tendency to plunge the country into an unnecessary constitutional crisis and, perhaps, derail 20 unbroken years of democratic governance.
yoruba: Ní ti òtítọ́, ìwà àdánìkanṣe ààrẹ lè da ìwé òfin orílẹ̀-èdè Nàìjíríà rú yányán, bóyá, ó lè da ìrìnàjò ogún ọdún ìjọba tiwantiwa rú.

english: This is not unlike other despotic and undemocratic acts that the government has been associated with  in the past, even if it might be considered more audacious, far-reaching and probably unexpected.
yoruba: Èyí kò yàtọ̀ sí àwọn ìwà ìfagbáraṣèjọba àti ìtàpá sí ìjọba àwa-arawa tí a ti mọ ìṣàkóso ìjọba náà mọ́n, kódà bí a bá kà á sí ìwàa kò kàn mí, tí ó nípa tí ó pọ̀ àti tí a kò lérò.

english: The governments of the United States and the United Kingdom also condemned the attack on the judiciary.
yoruba: Ìjọba orílẹ̀-èdè Amẹ́ríkà àti United Kingdom náà sọ̀rọ̀ òdì sí ìdìgbòlùu àjọ onídàájọ́.

english: On Twitter, netizens echoed the message.
yoruba: Ní oríi gbàgede ẹ̀rọ-alátagbà Twitter, àwọn ènìyàn ń sọ.

english: Tackling hate speech is the new ‘national security’ mantra
yoruba: Ìgbógunti ọ̀rọ̀ ìkórìíra ni gbólóhùn tuntun ‘ààbò orílẹ̀-èdè’

english: Another sign of a possible internet shut down is the government’s tendency to control free speech online on the basis of concerns for national security.
yoruba: Àmì mìíràn tí ó ń tọ́ka sí wípé ó lè bọ́ sí kí wọn ó ti ayélujára pa ni èròńgbà ìjọba láti pa òmìnira ọ̀rọ̀ sísọ orí ayélujára mọ́n ní ìbámu pẹ̀lú dídáàbobo orílẹ̀-èdè.

english: Recently, the government directed security agencies to "tackle the propagation of hate speech, especially through social media".
yoruba: Ní kò pẹ́ kò pẹ́, ìjọba pa àṣẹ fún àwọn agbófinró láti "wá wọ̀rọ̀kọ̀ fi ṣ'àdá lórí ọ̀rọ̀ ìkórìíra, pàápàá ní orí ẹ̀rọ-alátagbà".

english: This, according to reports by the Cable, will be achieved by monitoring social media accounts of "prominent Nigerians".
yoruba: Èyí, gẹ́gẹ́ bí ìròyìn láti ọwọ́ọ Cable ti ṣe sọ, yóò jẹ́ mímú ṣẹ nípasẹ̀ ṣíṣe alamí aṣàmúlò ẹ̀rọ-alátagbà "ọmọ orílẹ̀-èdè Nàìjíríà tí ó lókìkí".

english: In July last year, Nigerian Minister of Information Lai Mohammed described the growing level of fake news and hate speech in the country as a threat to national security.
yoruba: Nínúu oṣù Agẹmọ ọdún-un tí ó kọ́ja, Olórí Ẹ̀ka tí ó ń rí sí Ètò Gbígbé Ọ̀rọ̀ Síta fún Orílẹ̀-èdè Nàìjíríà Láí Mohammed ní wípé ewu ńlá ni ìbísí àhesọ ìròyìn àti ọ̀rọ̀ ìkórìíra tí ó ń gbilẹ̀ yóò mú bá ààbò orílẹ̀-èdè.

english: A year earlier, Nasir El-Rufai, governor of Kaduna State, described fake news and hate speech as the "biggest threat" to national security.
yoruba: Ní ọdún méjì sẹ́yìn, Nasir El-Rufai, gómìnà ìpínlẹ̀ Kaduna, sọ wípé àhesọ àti ọ̀rọ̀ ìkórìíra jẹ́ “ìṣòro ńlá” tí ó lè fa ìfọ̀kànbalẹ̀, ààbò ẹ̀mí àti dúkìá orílẹ̀-èdè yà.

english: However, it is ironic that both Lai and El-Rufai are now concerned about fake news and hate speech as a national security threat.
yoruba: Bí ó ti wù kí ó rí, pẹ̀lú ẹ̀gàn ni ó jẹ́ pé ọ̀ràn-an àhesọ àti ọ̀rọ̀ ìkórìíra kan Lai àti El-Rufai gẹ́gẹ́ bíi ìṣòro ààbò orílẹ̀-èdè Nàìjíríà.

english: As opposition politicians, they both made unsubstantiated accusations to the former government.
yoruba: Bí olóṣèlú ẹgbẹ́ alátakò, àwọn méjèèjì kò ní ẹ̀rí tí ó dájú tí yóò fi ìdí ẹ̀sùn tí ó fi kan ìjọba àná múlẹ̀.

english: For instance, Nassir El-Rufai, current governor of Kaduna State alleged in 2014 — without evidence — that he was “number 7 on [President Jonathan Goodluck’s] sniper’s list”.
yoruba: Fún àpẹẹrẹ, Nassir El-Rufai, gómìnà ìpínlẹ̀ẹ Kaduna lọ́wọ́lọ́wọ́ tẹnu mọ́ ọn ní ọdún-un 2014 — láìsí ẹ̀rí — wípé “ẹni kéje ni òun jẹ́ nínú àwọn tí [Ààrẹ Jónátàànì Goodluck] fẹ́ ṣe ikú pa ”.

english: El-Rufai also claimed that Goodluck, then president, was a sponsor of the Boko Haram militant group. Similar claims were made by Lai Mohammed, who was then the National Publicity Secretary of APC.
yoruba: El-Rufai tún sọ wípé nígbà tí Goodluck ń tu ọkọ̀ gẹ́gẹ́ bí ààrẹ, jẹ́ agbátẹrù ẹgbẹ́ apani-ní- ìfọnná-finṣu Boko Haram. Bẹ́ẹ̀ náà ni Láí Mohammed tí ó ti ṣe Akọ̀wé Alukoro Orílẹ̀-èdè rí fún ẹgbẹ́ òṣèlú APC ti ṣe sọ.

english: As opposition politicians, these officials have in fact been proven to be purveyors of fake news and hate speech, using social media to devastating effects.
yoruba: Gẹ́gẹ́ bíi olóṣèlú alátakò, àwọn òṣìṣẹ́ ọba ti fi hàn wípé àwọn gan-an ni adárúgúdù tí ó ń dá àhesọ àti ọ̀rọ̀ ìkórìíra sílẹ̀, tí ó ń lo ẹ̀rọ-alátagbà fi dá rúgúdù sílẹ̀.

english: But their actions were never considered a threat to national security; they were neither arrested nor was the internet shut down for this reason.
yoruba: Àmọ́ wọn kò rí ìwàa wọn gẹ́gẹ́ bíi ewu fún ààbò àti àlàáfíà orílẹ̀-èdè; wọn kò di ẹni à ń fi ọwọ́ọ ṣìgún òfin mú tàbí mú kí a pa ayélujára nítorí ìwàa wọn.

english: Social media and elections in Nigeria
yoruba: Ẹ̀rọ-alátagbà àti ìbò orílẹ̀-èdè Nàìjíríà

english: Movements like the 2012 #OccupyNigeria and the 2014 #BringBackOurGirls gained global acclaim due to social media usage in Nigeria.
yoruba: Ìjà fún ìyàtọ̀ ìgbé-ayé ní orílẹ̀-èdè Nàìjíríà ọdún-un 2012 #OccupyNigeria àti ìpolongo ọdún-un 2014 #BringBackOurGirls mi gbogbo àgbáyé tìtì nítorí wípé àwọn ènìyàn ṣe àmúlò ẹ̀rọ-alátagbà fún ìpolongo ẹ̀dùn ọkàn-an wọn.

english: In 2015, social media played an important role in Nigeria's elections when Twitter became a bitter and divisive battleground during campaign season and was used to propagate hate speech and disinformation.
yoruba: Ní ọdún-un 2015, ẹ̀rọ-alátagbà kó ipa ribiribi nínú ìbò orílẹ̀-èdè Nàìjíríà nígbà tí Twitter di ibi ìkorò àti gbàgede ìjà ìpínyà ní àsìkò ìpolongo, a sì mú u lò fún ìtànká ọ̀rọ̀ ìkórìíra àti ìròyìn tí kò ní òtítọ́ kan nínú.

english: This year, it has already played a major role as the medium of choice for political participation by Nigeria’s energetic youth population.
yoruba: Ní ọdún tí a wà yìí, ó ti ṣe ojúṣe gẹ́gẹ́ bíi ọ̀nà kan tí àwọn ọ̀dọ́ọ Nàìjíríà yàn láti ní ẹnu nínú ọ̀rọ̀ ìṣèlú.

english: Netizens have used social media to call attention to despotic government actions like the sacking of the CJN, that otherwise would have gone unnoticed by the general public.
yoruba: Àwọn tí ó ń lo ẹ̀rọ-ayárabíaṣá ti ṣe àmúlò ẹ̀rọ-alátagbà láti fi pe ìjọba sí àkíyèsí, bíi ti ìdádúró-lẹ́nu-iṣẹ́ ti CJN, bí bẹ́ẹ̀ kọ́, kò bá ti máà jẹ́ mímọ̀ fún ọmọ ìlú.

english: Nigerians took to social media to note their displeasure, mount pressure on the government to rescind its action and mobilize protests:
yoruba: Àwọn ọmọ bíbí orílẹ̀-èdè Nàìjíríà fi orí ẹ̀rọ-alátagbà sọ ohun tí ó ń gbé wọn ní ọkàn, bẹ́ẹ̀ náà ni wọ́n lò ó fi yọ ìjọba lẹ́nu láti pa èròńgbàa rẹ̀ tì àti fún ìfẹ̀hónúhàn:

english: Whether or not the internet holds steady during elections, there is strong reason to believe that political speech online and on the street will be a target of government scrutiny.
yoruba: Bó yá ayélujára wà ní àsìkò ìbò tàbí kò ní í wà, ìdí tí ó dájú ń bẹ láti ní ìgbàgbọ́ wípé ọ̀rọ̀ òṣèlú ní orí ayélukára-bí-ajere àti ní ojú òpópónà yóò jẹ́ ohun tí ìjọba yóò fi ojú sí.

english: Who will win Trinidad & Tobago Carnival's 2019 Road March?
yoruba: ‪Ta ni yóò jáwé olúborí nínú Ayẹyẹ ijó ìta-gbangba orílẹ̀-èdè Trinidad àti Tobago ọdún-un 2019?‬

english: A carnival masquerader “jumps up” to soca music on stage at the Queen's Park Savannah, on Carnival Tuesday, 2009.
yoruba: Aparadà ijó ìta-gbangba kan fò sókè sí orin soca ní orí ìtàgé ní Queen's Park Savannah, ní Ijó ìta-gbangba ọjọ́ Ìṣẹ́gun, ọdún-un 2009.

english: Photo by Georgia Popplewell, used with permission.
yoruba: Àwòrán láti ọwọ́ọ Georgia Popplewell, a lò ó pẹ̀lú àṣẹ.

english: When revelers take to the streets each year for Trinidad and Tobago Carnival, they do so with a soundtrack.
yoruba: Àwọn alárìíyá máa ń gba títì kan ní ọdọọdún fún Ijó ìta-gbangba Ijó ìta-gbangba Trinidad àti Tobago, tí wọn ń ṣe pẹ̀lú orin.

english: Their playlist is always an energetic mix of that year's hottest soca music hits, but the Road March — the song that is played the most at specified judging points along the parade route — is a title that comes with both a valuable prize package and the prestige of being part of a proud history.
yoruba: Àwọn àṣàyàn orin tí wọ́n máa ń jó sí máa ń jẹ́ àkójọpọ̀ orin soca tí ó mi ìgboro títì nínú ọdún yẹn, àmọ́ Ìwọ́de Ojúnà — orin náà tí máa ń jẹ́ jíjó jù lọ ní àwọn ibi kọ̀ọ̀kan ní ojú ọ̀nà ìyíde — jẹ́ oyè tí ó mú ẹ̀bùn àti iyì ìgbélárugẹ àjogúnbá ohun àtijọ́.

english: For most soca performers, the appeal of winning the Road March is, quite literally, street cred.
yoruba: Fún àwọn òṣèré soca, kí ni kan ní í máa mú ni jáwé olúborí nínú Ìwọ́de Ojúnà, kò ju, dídáńgájíá ní oríi òpópónà.

english: Claims in the last decade or so of the competition being rigged — ostensibly by a group of powerful radio station owners, DJs and music industry executives known as the "soca mafia" — have not eroded the belief that the Road March represents the voice of the people.
yoruba: Ní ọdún mẹ́wàá sẹ́yìn tàbí nnkan bẹ́ẹ̀ ni wọ́n sọ pé ìdíje náà ní màgòmágó nínú — pẹ̀lu ìlọ́wọ́sí àwọn alẹ́nulọ́rọ̀ tí ó ni ilé iṣẹ́ ìgbóhùnsáfẹ́fẹ́, afiorin-tí-a-ti-ká-sílẹ̀ dá àwọn ènìyàn lára dá àti àwọn aláṣẹ ilé iṣẹ́ orin kíkọ tí a mọ̀ sí “jàndùkú soca” — kò ì yọ́ ìgbàgbọ́ wípé Ìwọ́de Ojúnà jẹ́ ohun àwọn ènìyàn.

english: Soca star Machel Montano, who has won the coveted Road March title a whopping nine times thus far, describes it as "the song that make[s] the people feel the most vibes and come out of themselves" — and which artist wouldn't want to lay claim to that?
yoruba: Ìràwọ̀ òṣèrée soca Machel Montano, ẹni tí ó ṣe ojúkòkòrò jáwé olúborí nínú Ìwọ́de Ojúnà ní ẹ̀rìnmẹ́sàn-án, ṣe àpèjúwe rẹ̀ gẹ́gẹ́ bí "orin tí ó máa ń mú àwọn ènìyàn ní ìdùnnú àti tí máa ń mú àwọn ènìyàn jáde nínú ara wọn" — akọrin wo ni kò ní fẹ́ gba irú oyè bẹ́ẹ̀?

english: But don't be fooled into thinking that the road to the Road March is solely based on creative merit.
yoruba: Àmọ́ kí ẹnikẹ́ni máà rò wípé iṣẹ́ ọpọlọ nìkan ni ìrìnàjò sí Ìwọ́de Ojúnà.

english: A Road March song must have certain key ingredients to even be in the running:
yoruba: Orin Ìwọ́de Ojúnà gbọdọ̀ ní àwọn èròjà tí ó ṣe kókó nínú kí ó tó lè kópa:

english: 1. A danceable, yet powerful melody that makes people want to “break away” on stage, with lyrics that capture the feelings of joyful release and abandon that Carnival represents.
yoruba: 1. Ó gbọdọ̀ ṣe é jó sí, síbẹ̀ ó ní láti dùn ún ní etí àwọn ènìyàn tí yóò “mú wọn gbàgbé ara” ní orí ìtàgé, pẹ̀lú ọ̀rọ̀ orin tí yóò mú ayọ̀ jáde, èyí tí a mọ Ijó ìta-gbangba mọ́.

english: 2. A refrain that the audience can echo, in the call and response tradition of the calinda, from which calypso — and its modern-day hybrid, soca — originated.
yoruba: 2. Ègbè tí àwọn òǹwòran lè kọ tẹ̀lé orin, ní ìdásí àti ìdáhùn tí í ṣe àṣà calinda, tí calypso — àti àdàlù ìgbàlódé, soca — ti wáyé.

english: 3. A well-timed release.
yoruba: 3. Orin tí a gbé jáde ní ìgbà tí ó yẹ.

english: If a song peaks too early in the season and doesn't have staying power, competing tunes can usurp its position.
yoruba: Bí orín bá tètè jáde, tí kò sí dúró pẹ́ títí ní ìgboro, orin mìíràn tí ó ń bá a figagbága lè rọ́ ọ sí ẹ̀gbẹ́.

english: Conversely, if a great tune is released too late, masqueraders may not have enough time to get familiar with it during pre-Carnival events.
yoruba: Ní ọ̀nà mìíràn, bí orin tí ó dára gan-an bá pẹ́ jù kí ó tó jáde, àwọn ayírapadà lè máà ní àyè tí ó tó fún wọn láti mọ ọ̀rọ̀ orin náà ní ìgbáradì kí ọjọ́ Ijó ìta-gbangba ó tó dé.

english: Sometimes, the Road March contest has a clear favourite that never gets challenged; at others, the competition is so stiff that it's simply too close to call.
yoruba: Ní ìgbà mìíràn ẹ̀wẹ̀wẹ̀, ìdíje Ìwọ́de Ojúnà máa ń ní orin àyànfẹ́ tí kò ní afigagbága rárá; kò sí rí bẹ́ẹ̀ nígbà mìíràn, ìfigagbága náà máa ń le dé ibi wípé ó máa ń ṣòro láti yan olúborí.

english: In no particular order, here are some the songs that we think are the biggest contenders for Trinidad and Tobago Carnival's 2019 Road March...
yoruba: Láì wípé ọ̀kan ju ọ̀kan lọ, àwọn wọ̀nyí ni orin tí a rò wípé yóò figagbága nínú Ijó ìta-gbangba Ìwọ́de Ojúnà Trinidad àti Tobago ọdún-un 2019...

english: 1. "Savannah Grass" by Kes
yoruba: 1. "Savannah Grass" láti ọwọ́ọ Kes

english: The Queen's Park Savannah, an oasis of green space in the middle of Trinidad's capital, is the hub of the country's Carnival celebrations and home to the festival's main stage.
yoruba: Pápáa Queen's Park Savannah, ibi tí ó ní ewéko bíi kàá-sí-nǹkan ní àárín gbùngbùn olú ìlú Trinidad, ni ibi tí ayẹyẹ Ijó ìta-gbangba àti ilé ìtàgé àjọ̀dún náà.

english: This song perfectly captures the significance of the space, and the memories it has helped create for masqueraders through the years.
yoruba: Orin yìí dá lóríi agbègbè ayẹyẹ náà, àti ìrántí tí ó ti mú bá àwọn ayírapadà tí ó ti ń kópa láti ọdúnmọ́dún.

english: There is a reverence about the tune: as if the Savannah is the sun at the centre of the Carnival universe and everything else just has the privilege of revolving around it.
yoruba: Orin náà ń fi ọ̀wọ̀ wọ agbègbè náà: bí ẹni wípé Agbègbè Papa náà ni oòrùn ní àárín àgbá-ńlá Ijó ìta-gbangba àti ohun tí ó kù ń yí i ká.

english: "Savannah Grass" is an invitation to experience this magical world.
yoruba: "Savannah Grass" jẹ́ ìpè sí ìrírí idán ayée àjọ̀dún yìí.

english: Oxymoronically, the loose steadiness of the percussion is a nod to both the regimented dedication of Carnival lovers and their easygoing way of enjoying themselves.
yoruba: Bẹ́ẹ̀ kọ́, àmọ́ bẹ́ẹ̀ náà ni, ìlù orin náà ba orin náà mú gẹ́gẹ́ bí àwọn olólùfẹ́ẹ Ijó ìta-gbangba tí ó máa ń gbádùn un Ijó ìta-gbangba ṣe máa ń fẹ́ ẹ.

english: The tune is both melodious and energetic, with a pace that makes it a good song for "chipping" (the light shuffle step with which masqueraders walk/dance down the road).
yoruba: Orin náà dún dáadáa ní etí àti pé ó mú èèyàn gbàgbé ara rẹ̀, ní ọ̀nà tí ó ń mú kí àwọn ayírapadà ó máa gbé ẹsẹ̀ ní ọ̀kọ̀ọ̀kan bí wọ́n ṣe ń rìn/jó ní ojú ọ̀nà.

english: By its clever incorporation of archival Carnival footage, the official video further elevates the genius of the song by showing how it seamlessly spans generations and builds on the foundation blocks of calypso to produce a fresh soca offering.
yoruba: Orin náà ṣe àmúlò àti àfikún àwòrán ìlànà Ijó ìta-gbangba bí a ti ṣe mọ̀ ọ́ ni ìgbà-dé-ìgbà, fídíò orin náà túbọ̀ ṣe àfihàn ìdàgbàsókè orin soca láti ìpilẹ̀ṣẹ̀ tí í ṣe orin calypso.

english: Even if it does not win Road March (though it has a very good chance!), "Savannah Grass" will go down in the annals of soca music as one of the timeless tunes that stir the emotions of Carnival lovers everywhere.
yoruba: Bí kò bá ti ẹ̀ jáwé olúborí nínú ìdíje Ìwọ́de Ojúnà (bí ó ti lẹ̀ jé pé ó ní àyè tí ó pọ̀!), "Savannah Grass" yóò wà nínú àkópamọ́ orin soca gẹ́gẹ́ bí orin ìgbà-dé-ìgbà tí ó mú inú àwọn olólùfẹ́ẹ Ijó ìta-gbangba ní ibi gbogbo dùn.

english: 2. "Rag Storm" by Super Blue, featuring 3 Canal
yoruba: 2. "Rag Storm" láti ọwọ́ọ Super Blue, pẹ̀lú àjọṣepọ̀ 3 Canal

english: An interesting idiosyncrasy of "playing mas'" and dancing to soca music is that somehow, people's hands go up in the air, usually with whatever they are holding at the moment, from drinks to facecloths.
yoruba: Ìwà tí ó dùn mọ́ni ti "playing mas'" àti jíjó sí orin ni wípé ní bákan, àwọn èèyàn máa ń ju ọwọ́ sí òkè, pẹ̀lú ohunkóhun tí wọ́n bá mú ní ọwọ́, títì kan ohun-mímu àti aṣọ inujú.

english: Colloquially called "rags", these come in handy for soaking up the sweat while "jumping up". The practice was not lost on Super Blue, who wrote a song called "Get Something and Wave", that won the 1991 Road March.
yoruba: Aṣọ inujú yìí ni wọ́n máa ń pè ní "àkísà", èyí tí wọn máa fi ń nu àágùn bí wọ́n bá ń "fò sókè". Ìlànà Ijó ìta-gbangba náà kò sọnù ní ara Super Blue, ẹni tí ó kọ "Get Something and Wave", orin tí ó jáwé olúborí nínú Ìwọ́de Ojúnà ọdún-un 1991.

english: He echoed the concept a few years later with "Bacchanal Time", in which he commanded masqueraders to "start to wave" as the brass section played the familiar "F-jam" or "tantana" melody in the background.
yoruba: Ó fọnrere àtinúdá náà ní ọdún tí ó tẹ̀lé oyè tí ó gbà pẹ̀lú "Bacchanal Time", tí ó pa àṣẹ fún àwọn ayírapadà láti máa "fi ọwọ́ " bí àwọn afọnfèrè brass ṣe ń kọrin "F-jam" tí gbogbo ènìyàn mọ̀ tàbí "tantana" tí ó ń dún ní abẹ́lẹ̀.

english: Super Blue had come up with a formula for the type of song that worked on the road: he won again in 1995 with his ode to cricketer Brian Lara, in which he directed his audience to "raise yuh bat and party".
yoruba: Super Blue tí ṣe àgbékalẹ̀ ìlànà fún irúfẹ́ orin kan tí ó dára fún ojú ọ̀nà: ó tún jáwé olúborí ní èèkàn sí i ní ọdún-un 1995 pẹ̀lú orin-in rẹ̀ ewì sí agbábọ́ọ̀lù kríkẹ́ẹ̀tì Brian Lara, tí ó pa á ní àṣẹ fún àwọn olùwòran láti "na pátákóo wọn sí òkè kí wọn ó ṣe àríyá".

english: "Rag Storm" has many of those same elements — the lavway-type call-and-response, with a wild aerobic pace that encourages frenzied rag-waving.
yoruba: "Ìjì Àkísà" ní àwọn ohun tí ó mú soca yàtọ̀ — bíi irúfẹ́ lavway ìpè-àti-ìfèsì, pẹ̀lú àyè tí ó fẹ́ fún àwọn ènìyàn láti fi àkísà.

english: It's a great song for the stage as masqueraders break loose and “play themselves”, and may very well prove to be one to beat in this year's Road March race.
yoruba: Orin tí ó dára lórí ìtàgé fún àwọn ayírapadà láti tú ara sílẹ̀ àti “ṣeré tìkára wọn”, lè fi hàn kedere wípé kò kì í ń ṣe wàsá láti fi ọwọ́ rọ́ sí ẹ̀gbẹ́ nínú ìdíje Ìwọ́de Ojúnà ti ọdún nìí.

english: 3. "Famalay" by Machel Montano, Bunji Garlin and Skinny Fabulous
yoruba: 3. "Famalay" lọ́wọ́ọ Machel Montano, Bunji Garlin àti Skinny Fabulous

english: If there's one song that's aggressively going after the Road March title this year, it's this big tune that has several winning ingredients:
yoruba: Bí ó bá ní orin kan tí ń fi gbogbo ọ̀nà wá oyè Ìwọ́de Ojúnà ti ọdún yìí, ni orin yìí tí ó ní àyè láti jáwé olúborí:

english: a driving "power soca" beat, strong lyrics that capture the essence of the unity of the festival, and a clever hook that appeals to the tribal facet of Carnival — going everywhere with your crew, or as Trinbagonians say, your "famalay" (not to be confused with "family"):
yoruba: ìlù "soca tí ó tani jí", ọ̀rọ̀ orin tí ó sọ nípa ìṣọ̀kan tí àjọ̀dún náà máa ń mú wá, àti ègbé ọlọ́pọlọ tí ó kó gbogbo ẹ̀yà tí ó ń kópa nínú Ijó ìta-gbangba náà pọ̀ — tí ó ń bá òṣìṣẹ́ akọrin kiri, tàbí bí àwọn ọmọ ìbílẹ̀ Trinbago ṣe máa ń sọ, “famalay” rẹ (kí a máà ṣèṣì fi wé “ẹbí”) :

english: Well, let me tell you one time, famalay is famalay and that different from bloodline
yoruba: Ṣé ẹ rí i , ẹ jẹ́ kí n sọ fún un yín ní ẹ̀rìnkan sí i, famalay ni famalay ń jẹ́ àti pé ó yàtọ̀ sí ẹbí tí ènìyàn ti wá

english: Some say them is blood but them don't want to see the sunshine
yoruba: Àwọn kan ní ẹ̀jẹ̀ ni àmọ́ wọn kò fẹ́ rí oòrùn

english: Famalay doh ever ‘fraid to have your back at all time...
yoruba: Famalay kì í bẹ̀rù láyé láti tì ọ́ lẹ́yìn ní ìgbà gbogbo...

english: Without giving instructions (with the exception of one verse in which Skinny sings "show me yuh hand" and "come follow me"), the song achieves an almost militaristic sense of purpose.
yoruba: Láì pa àṣẹ (yàtọ̀ sí abala kan tí Skinny kọ "fi ọwọ́ọ̀ rẹ hàn mí" àti "wá tẹ̀lé mi", orin náà dàbí orin ológun.

english: Its sweet soca hook, peppered with the occasional dancehall-inspired lyrical improvisation, has been driving crowds wild at Carnival fetes.
yoruba: Ègbé soca tí ó dùn ní etí, pẹ̀lú ọ̀rọ̀ orin dancehall díẹ̀díẹ̀, ti ń da orí àwọn ènìyàn rú ní ìtaja Ijó ìta-gbangba.

english: Though there was some discussion as to whether or not "Famalay" would even qualify for the Road March contest because Skinny hails from St. Vincent and the Grenadines, the rules say that once "the majority of the lead vocal performance" is "undertaken and carried out by nationals of Trinidad and Tobago", the song can be a contender — and this one definitely is.
yoruba: Bí ó ti lẹ̀ jé pé ó ní àríyànjiyàn bóyá "Famalay" yóò kópa nínú Ìwọ́de Ojúnà tàbí kò ní í kópa, nítorí Skinny wá láti St. Vincent àti Grenadines, òfin sọ wípé bí “ọ̀pọ̀ àwọn akọrin tí ó ń lé orin” yẹ kí "ó jẹ́ ṣíṣe láti ọwọ́ọ ọmọ bíbíi Trinidad àti Tobago", orin náà lè jẹ́ afigagbága – eléyìí sì jẹ́ ọ̀kan.

english: This is not to say that it's a three-song race. With just about three weeks to go before Carnival, there other tunes — including two wicked ones by female artists Destra Garcia and Patrice Roberts — that may just give our picks a run for their money, and with soca performers still dropping new tracks, the battle for Road March 2019 is still being fought.
yoruba: Èyí kì í ṣe wípé orin mẹ́ta péré ni ó ń du oyè. Ó ku bí ọ̀sẹ̀ mẹ́ta kí Ijó ìta-gbangba ó wáyé, àwọn orin wọn mìíràn — tí ó ní akọrin obìrin Destra Garcia àti Patrice Roberts —tí yóò mú ìdíje le fún àwọn ọkùnrin, àti bí àwọn akọrin soca ṣì ń gbé àwo orin tuntun jáde, ìfigagbága Ìwọ́de Ojúnà ọdún-un 2019 ṣì ń lọ lọ́wọ́.

english: Let the dead tell their stories about Hong Kong
yoruba: Jẹ́ kí àwọn òkú ó sọ ìtàn nípa Hong Kong

english: Temple Street, Yau Ma Tei, Hong Kong. PHOTO: David Yan (CC BY 2.0)
yoruba: Òpópónà Ilé-ìsìn òrìṣà, Yau Ma Tei, Hong Kong. ÀWÒRÁN: David Yan (CC BY 2.0)

english: Warning: this story includes graphic descriptions of death and violence. A version of this story was previously published on Medium.
yoruba: Ìkìlọ̀: ìròyìn yìí ní àwọn àwòrán tí ó ń ṣe àfihàn ikú àti ipá. Medium ti ṣe àtẹ̀jáde ẹ̀dàa ìròyìn yìí ṣáájú èyí.

english: If you have traveled to Hong Kong, you have probably visited Yau Ma Tei, a popular night market district where people go to enjoy shopping and street food.
yoruba: Bí o bá ti rìnrìn àjò lọ sí Hong Kong, o ṣe é ṣe kí o dé Yau Ma Tei, agbègbè ọjà alẹ́ tí ó jẹ́ ìlúmọ̀nánká níbi tí àwọn ènìyàn ti máa ń lọ ra ọjà àti oúnjẹ ẹ̀gbẹ́ẹ títì.

english: Yau Ma Tei is one of the most densely populated areas in Hong Kong.
yoruba: Yau Ma Tei jẹ́ ọ̀kan lára àwọn agbègbè tí èró pọ̀ sí jù lọ ní Hong Kong.

english: Since 2016, the district has been the site of "20,000 ways to die in Yau Ma Tei", a guided "homicide tour" founded by Melody Chan and myself, who have lived in the area for many years.
yoruba: Láti ọdún-un 2016, ẹ̀ka- ìlú náà ti di ibùdó fún "20,000 ọ̀nà láti gbà kú ní Yau Ma Tei", ìtọ́nà "ìrìnàjò afẹ́ ìpànìyàn" tí Melody Chan àti èmitìkarami ṣe olùdásílẹ̀, tí ó ti ń gbé àdúgbò náà fún ọdún púpọ̀.

english: Through the tour, we seek to address the meaning of life and living conditions in Hong Kong.
yoruba: Nípasẹ̀ ìrìnàjò afẹ́ náà, a fẹ́ mọ bí ayé àti ìgbé ayé ṣe rí ní Hong Kong.

english: The 1.5-kilometer tour route runs north and south of Yau Ma Tei and visits 12 murder scenes over two hours.
yoruba: Ìrìnàjò afẹ́ ojúnà oní kìlómítà 1.5 náà lọ láti arẹwà àti gúúsù Yau Ma Tei, àti ìrìnàjò dé ibi tí a ti pa ènìyàn 12 ní àárín-in wákàtí méjì.

english: We started it  originally as a Halloween activity to raise funds for a local organization.
yoruba: A bẹ̀rẹ̀ ẹ rẹ̀ gẹ́gẹ́ bíi ètò Halowíìnì láti kó owó jọ fún ilé-iṣẹ́ ìbílẹ̀ kan.

english: As the feedback was excellent, we continued organizing tours at night during the winter months when the weather is cooler.
yoruba: Èsì tí a gbà dára tó bẹ́ẹ̀ ni ó mú wa tẹ̀síwájú nínú ìrìnàjò alẹ́ nínú oṣù tí yìnyín bá ń bọ́ tí ojú ọjọ́ bá tútù.

english: The tour guides are social workers, teachers, medical doctors and other professionals.
yoruba: Oníṣẹ́ ìlú ni àwọn amọ̀nà, olùkọ́, oníṣègùn àti àwọn onímọ̀ mìíràn.

english: Thus far, about 500 people have taken the tour.
yoruba: Bí a bá kà á ní ẹníméjì, ó ti tó ènìyàn 500 tí ó ti ṣe ìrìnàjò náà.

english: The homicide cases we selected date mostly from 2012 to 2016. Details of the cases were compiled from newspaper reports and records from the Coroner's Court.
yoruba: Àwọn ọ̀ràn ìpànìyàn tí a yàn wáyé ní àárín-in ọdún-un 2012 to 2016. Nínú ìwé ìròyìn ni a ti ṣa àwọn ìròyìn àti àkọsílẹ̀ láti ọwọ́ọ ilé ẹjọ́ Oníwàádìí-ẹni-tí-ó-kú.

english: Below is a trailer of the tour's 2017 edition on YouTube:
yoruba: Ní ìsàlẹ̀ ni àwòrán-eré ránpẹ́ ìrìnàjò afẹ́ ọdún-un 2017 ní oríi YouTube:

english: So close, yet so isolated
yoruba: Ó súnmọ́, síbẹ̀ ó jìnà

english: The population density in downtown Kowloon peninsula is about 44,000 people per square kilometer, and about 20,000 people live in Yau Ma Tei.
yoruba: Iye ènìyàn tí ó ń gbé ní ilẹ̀-tí-omí-fẹ́rẹ̀ẹ́-yíká Kowloon tó bíi èèyàn 40,000 ní orí ìwọ̀n kìlómítà kọ̀ọ̀kan, àti bí i ènìyàn 20,000 ni ó ń gbé Yau Ma Tei.

english: Many apartments are sub-divided into smaller units. People live so closely together, but at the same time, they are quite isolated.
yoruba: Ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ ńláǹlà ni a pín sí kéékèèké. Àwọn ènìyàn ń gbé súnmọ́ ara wọn, àmọ́ síbẹ̀, wọ́n jìnà sí ara wọn.

english: Quite a number of the cases featured on the tour involve elderly people.
yoruba: Àìmọye àwọn ènìyàn tí ó wà nínú ìrìnàjò afẹ́ náà jẹ́ àgbàlagbà.

english: In one case, an old man committed suicide by jumping out of the fourth-floor window of a building with a rope tied around his neck.
yoruba: Bàbá arúgbó kan pa ara rẹ̀ nígbà tí ó bẹ́ láti ojúu fèrèsé ilé alájà-mẹ́rin pẹ̀lú okùn tí ó so mọ́ ọrùn.

english: The body dangled on the outer wall of the building above the street all night, but no one noticed it until the next morning when the residents of a building across the street opened their window.
yoruba: Òkúu rẹ̀ ń fì ní ìta ògiri ilé náà ní títì ní àárín alẹ́, àmọ́ kò sí ẹni tí ó se àkíyèsí àfi ní ìgbà tí ó di fẹ̀ẹ̀rẹ̀ nígbà tí àwọn alùgbé ilé òdì kejì ṣí fèrèsée wọn.

english: Another case involves two elderly people who were found dead at home, one starved to death.
yoruba: Òmíràn ní í ṣe pẹ̀lú àwọn àgbàlagbà méjì tí a bá òkúu wọn nínú ilé, ọ̀kan kú ikú ebi.

english: It was later revealed that the husband was the caretaker of the wife, who was suffering from dementia.
yoruba: Àsẹ̀yìnwá ni ó tó yé wípé ọkọ náà ni ó ṣe olùtọ́jú aya, ẹni tí ó arán ń ṣe.

english: The husband had a fall in the living room and died, and the wife slowly starved to death in bed.
yoruba: Ọkọ náà kọsẹ̀ nínú yàrá ìgbàlejò, ó sì kú, ebí sì ṣe wẹ́rẹ́ pa ìyàwó sí orí ibùsùn.

english: It is difficult to imagine that no one had taken notice of the somewhat desperate living conditions of two elderly people.
yoruba: Ó jẹ́ ohun ìbànújẹ́ wípé kò sí ẹni tí ó fura sí irú ìgbé ayé ìjìyà àwọn àgbàlagbà méjì.

english: According to the 2016 population census, there were about 1.16 million people aged 65 and over in Hong Kong—about 15.9 per cent of the total population.
yoruba: Gẹ́gẹ́ bí ètò ìkànìyàn ọdún-un 2016, mílíọ̀nù èèyàn 1.16 million ni ọmọ ọdún 65 àti jù bẹ́ẹ̀ lọ ní Hong Kong— ìyẹn 15.9 ìdá gbogbo ènìyàn.

english: About 150 thousand of those people lived alone.
yoruba: Ẹgbẹ̀rún 150 àwọn ènìyàn wọ̀nyí ni ó ń dá gbé.

english: The average monthly income of retired elderly people in 2016—including pension and family and government support—was HK$5,780 (US$720).
yoruba: HK$5,780 (US$720) ni owó oṣù àwọn àgbàlagbà tí í ṣe òṣìṣẹ́-fẹ̀yìntì ní ọdún-un 2016 — àti owó ìrànwọ́ ìjọba lápapọ̀.

english: The current individual median income is about HK$16,800 (US$2,200) dollars.
yoruba: Lọ́wọ́lọ́wọ́ báyìí, owó oṣù tí ó kéré jù lọ nínú tó HK$16,800 (US$2,200) dollars.

english: But living with family or others does not guarantee support. There are many family tragedies in the city, among the working classes, in particular.
yoruba: Àmọ́ gbígbé pẹ̀lú ẹbí tàbí ọ̀rẹ́ kò kan ti ìtìlẹyìn. Ìjàmbá oríṣi ni ó máa ń ṣẹlẹ̀ nínú ẹbí ní ìlú, pàápàá jù lọ ní àárín àwọn tí ó ń ṣiṣẹ́.

english: In one case, the deceased was a 15-year-old girl who was into cosplay. She performed well in her studies but quarrelled with her family because of her hobby.
yoruba: Ìṣẹ̀lẹ̀ kan wáyé, ọmọdébìnrin ọmọ ọdún 15 ni olóògbé tí ó máa ń múra bí ẹ̀dá-inú ìtàn tí a mọ̀ sí cosplay.

english: Eventually, she dropped out of school and became a photo model to earn a living.
yoruba: Ó f'akọyọ nínú ẹ̀kọ́ọ rẹ̀ àmọ́ ó bá ẹbíi rẹ̀ ní gbólóhùn asọ̀ nítorí olólùfẹ́ẹ rẹ̀.

english: She was murdered by a client who had paid her HK$500 dollars (US$65) to take pictures of her.
yoruba: Àbálọ àbábọ̀, ó kúrò ní ilé-ìwé, ó sì di ẹni-àpẹẹrẹ àwòrán láti so ẹ̀mí àti ara ró. Ẹni tí ó ṣiṣẹ́ fún tí ó san owó ọ̀yà HK$500 dollars (US$65) fún un ni ó pa a.

english: In another case, a dead baby with its umbilical cord intact was found in a bag in Yau Ma Tei subway station by a cleaning lady.
yoruba: Òmíràn jẹ́ òkú ọmọ-ọwọ́ kan tí ìwọ́ọ rẹ̀ ṣì wà ní a ara rẹ̀, tí obìrin kan tí ó ń ṣe ìmọ́tótó ìbùdókọ̀ abẹ́-ilẹ̀ ní Yau Ma Tei bá nínú àpò kan.

english: Upon investigation, the police found out that the mother was a foreign domestic helper who became pregnant and was afraid that her employers would dismiss her. The woman was arrested and jailed.
yoruba: Lẹ́yìn ìwádìí, àwọn ọlọ́pàá ṣe àrídájú wípé ọmọ-ọ̀dọ̀ kan láti ilẹ̀ òkèèrè tí ó ń bẹ̀rù wípé ọ̀gá òun yóò lé òun ni ẹnu iṣẹ́ bí ó bá mọ̀ wípé òun ní oyún ni ìyáa rẹ̀. Obìrin náà jẹ èrè iṣẹ́ ọwọ́ọ rẹ̀ ní ẹ̀wọ̀n.

english: During this segment of the tour, the guide raises the question: aren't the woman's employers also guilty?
yoruba: Ní abala ìrìnàjò afẹ́ yìí, amọ̀nà ṣe ìbéèrè: ṣé àwọn ọ̀gá obìnrin náà kò jẹ̀bi bí?

english: It is difficult to imagine not noticing that the person who served you daily is pregnant.
yoruba: Kò sí bí ó ṣe lè ṣẹlẹ̀ kí wọn ó máà mọ̀ wípé ẹni tí ó ń ṣiṣẹ́ fún wọn ní ojúmọ́ ní oyún ní inú.

english: There are more than 370,000 helpers in Hong Kong and the law requires them to live in their employers’ homes.
yoruba: Ọmọ-ọ̀dọ̀ tí ó wà ní Hong Kong ju 370,000 lọ, òfin ṣì fi àyè gbà wọ́n kí ó máa gbé nínú ilé ọ̀gáa wọn.

english: This arrangement makes them vulnerable to abuse in the form of long working hours, poor diet, etc.
yoruba: Èyí ni àyè fi sílẹ̀ láti lè rí wọn bá sùn bí wọn bá ń ṣiṣẹ́ fún wákàtí púpọ̀, láì jẹun tí ó ṣe ara ní oore, àti bẹ́ẹ̀ bẹ́ẹ̀ lọ.

english: About a year after that case, another foreign domestic helper was fired for getting pregnant.
yoruba: Lẹ́yìn ọdún kan tí ìṣẹ̀lẹ̀ yẹn wáyé, ọmọ-ọ̀dọ̀ ilẹ̀-òkèèrè mìíràn gba ìdádúró ní ẹnu iṣẹ́ fún oyún tí ó ní.

english: It took two years for the woman to successfully appeal the illegal termination of the contract in court.
yoruba: Ó gba obìnrin náà ní ọdún méjì gbáko nílé ẹjọ́ láti jà fún ìdádúró láì bá òfin mu ní ẹnu iṣẹ́.

english: Grassroots murderers
yoruba: Ìpànìyàn ní àárín àwọn ènìyàn

english: Many of the murders in Yau Ma Tei are crimes of passion committed by ordinary people, and as is typical when the crime is not premeditated, the perpetrators make many mistakes.
yoruba: Ọ̀gọ̀rọ̀ ìpànìyàn ní Yau Ma Tei jẹ́ ẹsẹ̀ tí ó ti ọwọ́ àwọn ènìyàn fún ra wọn wá, tí ó jẹ́ ẹsẹ̀ tí wọn kò gbèrò tàbí pa ète rẹ̀ tẹ́lẹ̀, tí àwọn tí ó dá ẹ̀ṣẹ̀ sì ṣe àṣìṣe.

english: There is the case in which a man killed his older brother in an open street with a nine-inch fish knife that penetrated the brother's lungs.
yoruba: Ó ní ìṣẹ̀lẹ̀ tí ọkùnrin kan pa ẹ̀gbọ́n-ọn rẹ̀ ọkùnrin ní ìta gbangba ní ojúu títì pẹ̀lú ọbẹ̀ ìwọ̀n ínṣì mẹ́sàn-án tí ó wọ inú ẹ̀dọ̀ fóró ẹ̀gbọ́n-ọn rẹ̀ lọ.

english: The knife was supposed to be a gift for the brother.
yoruba: Ẹ̀bùn ni ó yẹ kí ọbẹ̀ náà jẹ́ fún ẹ̀gbọ́n náà.

english: One killer stayed at the crime scene after the murder; another used his ID card to book a hotel room to hide the body.
yoruba: Apànìyàn kan takú sí ibi ìpànìyàn lẹ́yìn tí ó pa ènìyàn tán; òmíràn fi ìwé pẹlẹbẹ ìdánimọ̀ọ rẹ̀ gba iyàrá tí ó tọ́jú òkú ẹni tí ó pa sí.

english: Another murder took place in a convenience store.
yoruba: Ìpànìyàn mìíràn wáyé ní ilé ìtaja-ohun-èlò-inú-ilé.

english: The incident was recorded by closed-circuit TV.
yoruba: Ẹ̀rọ-ayàwòrán amóhùnmáwòrán ká ìṣẹ̀lẹ̀ náà sílẹ̀.

english: The murderer was a tourist holding a Canadian passport, who stabbed the storekeeper after the latter questioned him for taking items from the shop without paying.
yoruba: Onírìn àjò ìgbafẹ́ tí ó ń lo ìwé-ìrìnnà Orílẹ̀-èdè Canada ni apànìyàn náà, ẹni tí ó gún òǹtajà ìsọ̀ náà nígbà tí òǹtajà bíi léèrè ìdí tí ó fi kó ọjà láì san owó.

english: An encounter with souls and their shadows
yoruba: Àlábàápàdé àwọn ẹ̀mí àti òjìjíi wọn

english: The majority of tour patrons are college students.
yoruba: Ọ̀pọ̀ àwọn arìnrìn-àjò afẹ́ jẹ́ akẹ́kọ̀ọ́ ilé-ẹ̀kọ́ gíga.

english: Some join out of curiosity; others consider it a way to educate themselves.
yoruba: Àwọn kan kópa nítorí wọ́n fẹ́ rí àrídájú; àwọn mìíràn rí i bí ọ̀nà láti fi ìmọ̀ kún ìmọ̀.

english: A doctor who was part of a team of medical workers who took the tour said this of one case:
yoruba: Oníṣègùn kan tí í ṣe ikọ̀ òṣìṣẹ́ ìlera tí ó ṣe ìrìnàjò náà sọ wípé:

english: The protagonist of the case is very similar to the patients we often encounter in the accident and emergency wards – drug addicts, street sleepers, refugees.
yoruba: Ẹni ọ̀ràn yìí dà bíi àwọn aláàárẹ̀ tí a máa ń bá pàdé nínú ìyára ìtọ́jú àwọn tí ó ní ìjàmbá àti ìtọ́júu pàjàwìrì – àwọn tí egbògi olóró tí sọ di ìdàkudà, àwọn tí ó ń sun títì, àwọn ogún-lé-mi-dé.

english: We all have to rescue them in the emergency room.
yoruba: Iṣẹ́ẹ gbogbo wa ni láti dóòlà ẹ̀míi wọn ní yàráa pàjàwìrì.

english: But usually they are quite hostile in their attitudes.
yoruba: Àmọ́ wọ́n máa ń kanra nígbà mìíràn.

english: It’s very difficult to deal with them and we tend to lose patience over time.
yoruba: Kì í rọrùn bí a bá ń ṣe ìtọ́júu wọn, nítorí náà a máa sọ sùúrù nù.

english: This guided tours remind us that we must be patient and should not become indifferent.
yoruba: Ìrìnàjò afẹ́ yìí rán wa létí wípé a nílòo sùúrù bí a bá ń dá àwọn aláàárẹ̀ lóhùn.

english: And their lives are very miserable and they struggle hard to survive.
yoruba: Àti pé ayé ìrora ni wọ́n ń gbé, wọ́n sì ń tiraka láti gbé.

english: Yau Ma Tei's 20,000 residents will all eventually die in different ways.
yoruba: Onírúurú ikú ni yóò pa gbogbo àwọn olùgbée 20,000 Yau Ma Tei.

english: We believe that upon their death, their souls will become part of the fabric of the city and continue to linger in the alleys and streets, reminding people of the meaning of existence.
yoruba: Ìgbàgbọ́ọ wa ni wípé bí ikú bá kanlẹ̀kùn, ẹ̀míi wọn yóò máa ráre kiri ní àárín-in àdúgbò àti ní òpópónà, láti máa rán àwọn ènìyàn létí nípa ìtúmọ̀ ìwà láyé.

english: The tour aims to create a space for these shadows to reveal their stories.
yoruba: Ìrìnàjò yìí ń lépa láti pèsè àyè fún àwọn òjìjí láti sọ ìtàn ara wọn.

english: The number one cause of suicide is untreated depression.
yoruba: Ohun tí ó ń fa ikú ni ìbàjẹ́ ọkàn tí a ò wò sàn.

english: Depression is treatable and suicide is preventable.
yoruba: Ìbàjẹ́ ọkàn ní ìwòsàn, a sì lè dènà ìpànìyàn.

english: You can get help from confidential support lines for the suicidal and those in emotional crisis.
yoruba: Ó lè rí ìrànwọ́ fún àwọn tí ó ń bá ìparaẹni fà á àti àwọn tí ó wà nínú ìbàjẹ́ ọkàn.

english: Visit Befrienders.org to find a suicide prevention helpline in your country.
yoruba: Lọ sí Befrienders.org fún ojú òpó ìbánisọ̀rọ̀ ìdènà ìparaẹni ní orílẹ̀-èdèe rẹ.

english: Azerbaijan leader gives first TV interview after 15 years in office. He could use more practice.
yoruba: Olórí orílẹ̀-èdè Azerbaijan tàkùrọ̀sọ àkọ́kọ́ ní orí amóhùnmáwòrán lẹ́yìn ọdún 15 ní orí àlééfà. Ó lè lo ọ̀nà mìíràn.

english: President Ilham Aliyev's interview with REAL TV on February 12.
yoruba: Ìfọ̀rọ̀wọ́rọ̀ Ààrẹ Ilham Aliyev àti amóhùnmáwòran REAL TV ní Oṣù Èrèlé 12.

english: Screenshot from REAL TV's YouTube channel.
yoruba: Àpá àwòrán wá láti REAL TV ẹ̀rọ-alátagbà YouTube channel.

english: How often should a country's leader give interviews to the local media of that country?
yoruba: Ẹ̀rìn mélòó ló yẹ kí ààrẹ orílẹ̀ èdè ní ìtakùrọ̀sọ pẹ̀lú ilé ìgbéròyìn jáde tí ìlúu rẹ̀?

english: Once a week?
yoruba: Ẹẹ̀kan l'ọ́sẹ̀?

english: Once a month?
yoruba: Ẹẹ̀kan l'óṣù?

english: Rulers of authoritarian countries might sometimes settle on a very controlled interview with state media once a year or less.
yoruba: Àwọn olórí orílẹ̀ èdè afipá ṣe ìjọba máa ń ṣe ìtakùrọ̀sọ pẹ̀lú àwọn ilé ìgbéròyìn jáde ní èèkàn l'ọ́dún tàbí kí ó kéré jù bẹ́ẹ̀ lọ.

english: The answer to this question in Azerbaijan is quite extraordinary.
yoruba: Ìdáhùn sí ìbéèrè yìí kọyọyọ ní Azerbaijan.

english: Earlier this month, President Ilham Aliyev, who became Azerbaijan's leader in October 2003, gave his first-ever interview to local television.
yoruba: Ní ìbẹ̀rẹ̀ oṣù yìí, Ààrẹ Ilham Aliyev, tí ó di olórí ilẹ̀ Azerbaijan ní Oṣù Ọ̀wàrà ọdún 2003, ṣe ìtakùrọ̀sọ alákọ̀ọ́kọ́ọ rẹ̀ pẹ̀lú ilé ìṣẹ́ amóhùn-máwòrán ti ìlúu rẹ̀.

english: The hour-long February 12 interview with pro-government journalist Mirshahin Aghayev — once known for having a more independent stance — was broadcast on the privately owned pro-government broadcaster REAL TV.
yoruba: Ìfọ̀rọ̀-wáni-lẹ́nuwò oníwákàtí kan ọ̀hún tí ó wáyé lọ́jọ́ 12 oṣù yìí, pẹ̀lú oníròyìn ìjọba Mirshahin Aghayev — tí a ti mọ̀ tẹ́lẹ̀ rí fún ìdúróṣinṣin aìfi òlò p'ohùn — di gbígbésáfẹ́fẹ́ ní ilé ìṣẹ́ amóhùn-máwòrán aládàáni agbè fún ìjọba REAL TV.

english: It aroused significant interest in Azerbaijan, where citizens are used to listening to Aliyev make speeches but unaccustomed to seeing him discuss ideas with an interlocutor.
yoruba: Ó gbọn òǹgbẹ ni Azerbaijan, ilẹ̀ tí àwọn ará ìlú ti máa ń gbọ́ kí Aliyev sọ̀rọ̀ lórí afẹ́fẹ́, àmọ́ tí wọn kò sì rí i rí kó tàkùrọ̀sọ pẹ̀lú oníbèèrè.

english: Even Aliyev's Twitter account comes across as a bizarre monologue rather than an attempt at public outreach.
yoruba: Kódà ìṣàmúlò Twitter Aliyev dà gẹ́gẹ́ bí wèrè aládàásọ̀rọ̀ ju ìgbìyànjú ìbá ará ìlú sọ̀rọ̀ lọ.

english: In the end, however, the interview proved an underwhelming debut.
yoruba: Ní ìgbẹ̀yìn-gbẹ́yín, ìfọ̀rọ̀-wáni-lẹ́nuwò ọ̀hún jẹ́ àkọ́ṣe tí ó kọyọyọ.

english: Many on social media commented on the president's understated body language, somewhat dazed appearance and a reliance on state media talking points.
yoruba: Púpọ̀ àwọn tí ó wà lórí ẹ̀rọ ayélujára gbogbo sọ̀rọ̀ lórí aìkọbì-ara sí bí ààrẹ ṣe gbé ara rẹ̀, bí ó ṣe múra àti àwọn kókó tí ilé ìṣe ìgbóhùn sáfẹ́fẹ́ ìjọba sọ̀rọ̀ lé lórí.

english: Given that Aliyev does not have to impress anyone — Azerbaijan has never had a free and fair election in its 27-year independence — why did he bother to do this?
yoruba: Gẹ́gẹ́ bí a ti mọ̀ pé kò pọn dandan kí Aliyev ṣàfihàn ara rẹ̀ bí ó ṣe tó — Azerbaijan kòì tí ì dìbò tí kò sí kọ́mí-n-kọ́họ lẹ́yìn ọdún 37 tí ó ti gba òmìnira — kíni ó mú u ṣe èyí?

english: President Ilham Aliyev's interview with REAL TV on February 12.
yoruba: Ìfọ̀rọ̀wánilẹ́nuwo Ààrẹ Ilham Aliyev's pẹ̀lú REAL TV ní ọjọ́ 12, oṣù Èrèlé.

english: Screenshot from REAL TV's YouTube channel.
yoruba: Àwòrán láti orí ẹ̀rọ-alátagbà YouTube ti REAL TV.

english: The topics of the interview broadly mirrored those highlighted in state media — the long-standing conflict with Armenia over Nagorno-Karabakh, public services, economic reforms and Azerbaijan's relations with the Eurasian Union and European Union trade blocs.
yoruba: Àwọn kókó ìtakùrọsọ ọ̀hún dá lórí — ìjàkú akátá pẹ̀lú Armenia lóríi Nargono- Karabakh, iṣẹ́ ìlú, àtúnṣe sí ètò ọrọ̀ Ajé, àti ìbáṣepọ̀ pẹ̀lú Ẹgbẹ́ Aláṣẹpọ̀ Eurasian àti Ẹgbẹ́ Aláṣẹpọ̀ Europe.

english: No new insights were provided.
yoruba: A kò rí ohun tuntun kan gbámu.

english: After the video received a host of negative comments like "Resignation" and "No more tales are needed" in addition to dislikes during its first day online, REAL TV's YouTube channel closed comments.
yoruba: Lẹ́yìn ìgbà tí fídíò ọ̀hún gba kòbákùngbé ìjábọ̀ bíi “Kọ̀wé fipò sílẹ̀” àti “A kò fẹ́ àlọ́ atanijẹ mọ́” pẹ̀lú ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ àìní ìfẹ́ràn ní ọjọ́ àkọ́kọ́ tí a gbé e sórí ayélujára, ìkànnì REAL TV ní oríi YouTube ti ìsọsí pa.

english: Opposition politician Azer Gasimli said the interview showed the government was "very worried" amid stewing public dissatisfaction and a sluggish economy.
yoruba: Olóṣèlú alátakò Azer Gasimli sọ pé ìfọ̀rọ̀-wáni-lẹ́nuwò ọ̀hún fi hàn pé "ìfoyà ti dé bá" ìjọba láàárín bí àwọn ará ìlú ò ṣe gba ti wọn àti ọ̀rọ̀ ajé ìlú tí ó ń ṣ'òjòjò.

english: I watched Ilham Aliyev's first interview with a local journalist.
yoruba: Mo wo ìtàkùrọsọ àkọ́kọ́ tí Ilham Aliyev ṣe pẹ̀lú oníròyìn ilẹ̀ yìí kan.

english: I think it is meaningless to say or write something in response to what the President said.
yoruba: Mo rò pé kò mọ́gbọ́n dání láti sọ tàbí kọ nǹkan kan l’ ésì si ohun tí Ààrẹ sọ.

english: Because we have responded to him for many years.
yoruba: Nítorí pé a ti ń fún un l'ésì fún ọdún pípẹ́.

english: The interview was not sincere.
yoruba: Kò sí hóró òótọ́ kán nínú ìtàkùrọsọ ọ̀hún.

english: Both the President and the journalist remind me of "ships floating on a lie".
yoruba: Ààrẹ àti oníròyìn ọ̀hún rán mi l'étí nípa “ọkọ̀ tó léfòó lórí irọ́ ”.

english: My conclusion: the government is very worried!
yoruba: Ní àkótán: ara ò rọ ìjọba!
