yoruba: Akọrin, ọmọ ilé ìwé àti àwọn aládùúgbò péjọ ní — Kingston, Lionel Town, Ridge Red Bank àti White River — fún ìdánilẹ́kọ̀ọ́ ọlọ́jọ́ mẹ́rin nínúu oṣù Ẹrẹ́nà àti Igbe.

english: There, they honed their communication skills and learned about the impact of climate change.
yoruba: Níbẹ̀, wọ́n fi ẹ̀kọ́ kún ẹ̀kọ́ ìmọ̀ ìtàkùrọ̀sọ àti kọ́ nípa ipa àyípadà ojú-ọjọ́.

english: Powerful lyrics emerged, ideas flowed and eye-opening field trips provided on-the-ground perspectives:
yoruba: Ọ̀rọ̀ orin tí ó lágbára gbérí, ọgbọ́n ń tayọ àti ìrìnàjò ìṣíjú ojú ẹsẹ̀:

english: Translation Original Quote
yoruba: Ìtúmọ̀ Ìtúnwí-ọ̀rọ̀ Ọlọ́rọ̀ gan-an

english: Mother Earth she bawls
yoruba: Ìyá Ilẹ̀-ayé ń ké tantan

english: Deep in the forest where the trees fall
yoruba: Nínú igbó kìjikìji níbi tí àwọn igi ń wó sí

english: Look upon the reef, see the fish how small
yoruba: Wo òkúta ìsàlẹ̀ òkun, wo ẹja bí ó ṣe kéré

english: Give them a little time, make them grow big and tall
yoruba: Fún wọn ní àsìkò, jẹ́ kí wọ́n dàgbà àti ga

english: Artists from Kingston, Clarendon and Spanish Town working together on lyrics at the Climate Change Messaging workshop.
yoruba: Àwọn akọrin láti Kingston, Clarendon àti Spanish Town ń ṣiṣẹ́ pọ̀ lóríi ọ̀rọ̀ orin níbi ìdánilẹ́kọ̀ọ́ Ìfiṣẹ́ránṣẹ́ Àyípadà Ojú-ọjọ́.

english: Photo by Emma Lewis, used with permission.
yoruba: Àwòrán-an Emma Lewis, a lò ó pẹ̀lú àṣẹ.

english: With Panos’ launch of a new Caribbean theme song for Earth Day, the Jamaican group is booked solid for school and community concerts, as well as the Read Across Jamaica initiative and tree-planting sessions.
yoruba: Pẹ̀lú ìfilọ́lẹ̀ẹ Panos fún àkòrí orin tuntun fún Caribbean fún Àyájọ́ Ilẹ̀-ayé, ẹgbẹ́ẹ Jamaica náà ti ṣe tán láti ṣe eré ní iléèwé àti ní àdúgbò, láì yọ Kàwé Jákèjádò Jamaica sílẹ̀ àti iṣẹ́ igi gbíngbìn.

english: Lyrics like these, delivered to a roots reggae rhythm and infused with dancehall vibes, somehow manage to hit home:
yoruba: Àwọn orin báwọ̀nyí, tí a kọ sí orí ìlú reggae àtijọ́ tí a fi àlùjó kún, ṣe kẹ̀rẹ̀kẹ̀rẹ̀ mi ìgboro:

english: Mother Nature yearns for life
yoruba: Ìyá Ìṣẹ̀dá ń kérora fún ìwàláàyè

english: The more the factories burn, she cries.
yoruba: Bí àwọn iléeṣẹ́ ṣe ń ṣiṣẹ́, ìyá ń ké.

english: When will we learn, and be wise?
yoruba: Ìgbà wo ni a óò kọ́ ẹ̀kọ́, tí a ó fi gbọ́n?

english: The more the ice caps melt, the sea rise.
yoruba: Bí omi-dídì ilé ayé ṣe ń yọ́, òkun ń kún.

english: Despite the release of detained Reuters reporters, free speech remains under threat in Myanmar
yoruba: Pẹ̀lú ìdásílẹ̀ àwọn akọ̀ròyìn-in Reuters, ẹ̀ṣẹ̀ ní òmìnira ọ̀rọ̀ sísọ ṣì jẹ́ ní Myanmar

english: Two Reuters journalists Wa Lone and Kyaw Soe Oo walked free from Insein prison in Yangon.
yoruba: Akọ̀ròyìn Reuters méjì Wa Lone àti Kyaw Soe Oo rìnrìn òmìnira lẹ́yìn tí a dá wọn sílẹ̀ ní ẹ̀wọ̀n Insein ní Yangon.

english: Photo and caption by Myo Min Soe / The Irrawaddy is a content partner of Global Voices.
yoruba: Àwòrán àti ọ̀rọ̀ abẹ́-àwòrán láti ọwọ́ọ Myo Min Soe / Irrawaddy náà ń bá Ohùn Àgbáyé ṣiṣẹ́ ìròyìn.

english: Media groups and human rights advocates are celebrating the release of Reuters journalists Wa Lone and Kyaw Soe Oo who spent more than 500 days in detention for their role in investigating the massacre of some Rohingya residents in northern Myanmar.
yoruba: Àwọn ẹgbẹ́ iléeṣẹ́ oníròyìn àti ajà-fún-ẹ̀tọ́ ọmọnìyàn ń ṣe àjọyọ̀ọ ti ìdásílẹ̀ lẹ́wọ̀n-ọn akọ̀ròyìn Reuters Wa Lone àti Kyaw Soe Oo tí ó lò ju ọjọ́ 500 ní àtìmọ́lé fún ipa tí wọ́n kó nínú ìwádìí òfíntótó ìṣẹ̀lẹ̀ ìpanípakúpa àwọn olùgbée Rohingya kan ní gúúsù Myanmar.

english: But despite their release, the state of free speech in the country is still undermined by the continued detention and persecution of some artists, journalists, and activists.
yoruba: Àmọ́ pẹ̀lú ìdásílẹ̀ tí wọ́n dá wọn sílẹ̀, ipò yẹpẹrẹ ni òmìnira ọ̀rọ̀ sísọ ní ìlú náà nítorí wípé ìtìmọ́lé àti ìfìyàjẹ àwọn akọrin, akọ̀ròyìn, àti ajìjàǹgbara ṣì wà síbẹ̀ sẹpẹ́.

english: Consider the following cases:
yoruba: Ka àwọn ọ̀ràn ìsàlẹ̀ yìí síwájú:

english: Defamation case against The Irrawaddy
yoruba: Ìfẹ̀sùn Ìbanilórúkọjẹ́ kan Irrawaddy Náà

english: A defamation complaint was filed by the military's Yangon Region Command against The Irrawaddy's Burmese-language editor U Ye Ni over the news website's alleged unfair coverage of the armed clashes between government forces and the insurgent Arakan Army in Rakhine State.
yoruba: Ẹ̀ka ológun Agbègbè Yangon kọ ìwé ẹ̀sùn-un ìbanilórúkọjẹ́ sí olóòtú èdèe-Burmese U Ye Ni wípé ibùdó-ìtakùn-àgbáyé akọ̀ròyìn náà gbè lẹ́yìn ẹnìkan nínú ìròyìn ìkọlù láàárín-in ọmọ-ogun ìjọba àti àwọn adárúgúdù sílẹ̀ Ọmọ ogun Arakan ní Ìpínlẹ̀ Rakhine tí ó tẹ̀ jáde.

english: The Irrawaddy said it did nothing but report the escalating armed clashes in the region since the start of 2019.
yoruba: Irrawaddy Náà sọ wípé òun kò ṣe àṣemáṣe ju jíjábọ̀ọ ìwọ̀yáàjà tí ó bẹ́ sílẹ̀ ní sàkání náà láti ìbẹ̀rẹ̀ ọdún-un 2019.

english: Here is U Ye Ni’s response to the case filed by the military:
yoruba: Èsì tí U Ye Ni fún àwọn ọmọ ajagun rè é :

english: I feel sorry about the military’s misunderstanding of us.
yoruba: Ó ká mi lára nípé iṣẹ́ẹ wa kò yé ikọ̀ ajagun yékéyéké.

english: Journalism dictates that we reveal the suffering of people in a conflict area.
yoruba: Nínú ìmọ̀ ìjìnlẹ̀ iṣẹ́ ìkọ̀ròyìn ni ó ti fi lélẹ̀ wípé a gbọdọ̀ tànmọ́lẹ̀ sí ìjìyà àwọn ènìyàn ní ibi tí rògbòdìyàn bá wà.

english: Our intention behind the coverage is to push those concerned to solve the problems by understanding the sufferings of the people.
yoruba: Èròńgbà wa tí a fi tẹ̀lé ìròyìn náà ó ju láti fa àkíyèsí àwọn tí yóò tán ìṣòro sí ìjìyà àwọn ènìyàn.

english: The Irrawaddy is a content partner of Global Voices.
yoruba: Àjọṣepọ̀ tí ó dán mọ́nrán ń bẹ ní àárín-in Ohùn Àgbáyé àti Irrawaddy.

english: Jailed for satire
yoruba: Àjùsẹ́wọ̀n fún yẹ̀yẹ́

english: Meanwhile, five members of the Peacock Generation Thangyat troupe were sent to Insein prison to await trial for their satirical performance mocking the army. Thangyat is performance art similar to slam poetry featuring folk verses with traditional musical notes and is combined with song, dance, and chants.
yoruba: Ìyẹn bẹ́ẹ̀, àwọn ọmọ ẹgbẹ́ẹ ajótà Ìran Ọ̀kín Thangya márùn-ún di èrò ẹ̀wọ̀n tí ó wà ní Insein títí di ìgbà tí wọn yóò lọ sí ilé ẹjọ́ fún ẹ̀fẹ̀ tí wọ́n fi ológun ṣe. Eré ìtàgé tí ó ní àkójọpọ̀ orin abínibí, ijó àti ewì ni a mọ Thangyat mọ́.

english: The group was charged with violating article 505(a) of the penal code which criminalizes the circulation of statements, rumors, or reports with the intent to cause any military officer to disregard or fail in his duties.
yoruba: Ẹ̀gbẹ́ alájòótà yìí ti tasẹ̀ àgẹ̀rẹ̀ sí òfin abala 505(a) tí ó ní wípé ọ̀daràn ni ẹni tí ó bá polongo ọ̀rọ̀, àyesọ, tàbí jábọ̀ irúu rẹ̀ pẹ̀lú èrò láti mú kí ikọ̀ ajagun ó máà ka ojúṣe rẹ̀ kún tàbí kùnà láti ṣe ojúṣee rẹ̀.

english: Zeyar Lwin, one of the accused, said:
yoruba: Ọ̀kan lára ẹni tí a fi ẹ̀sùn kàn, Zeyar Lwin, sọ pé:

english: All of our cases are political issues so that they need to resolve them as political issues.
yoruba: Gbogbo ẹ̀sùn tí wọ́n fi kàn wá jẹ́ ti òṣèlú torí ìdí èyí ó yẹ kí wọ́n ṣe àtúnṣe gẹ́gẹ́ bíi ọ̀rọ̀ òṣèlú.

english: And also, I’d like to say all of us need to join the work for amending the 2008 constitution being done in parliament.
yoruba: Bákan náà, mo máa sọ wípé gbogbo wa ní láti darapọ̀ mọ́ iṣẹ́ àtúnṣe sí ìwé òfin ọdún-un 2008 tí ó ń lọ lọ́wọ́ nínú ìgbìmọ̀ ìjọba.

english: In my opinion all of these issues can be resolved if we can do the primary work of amending the constitution.
yoruba: Ní tèmi, gbogbo ọ̀ràn yìí pátá yóò jẹ́ yíyẹ̀ lulẹ̀ bí a bá le è ṣe iṣẹ́ àkọ́bẹ̀rẹ̀ ti àtúnṣe sí ìwé òfin.

english: Zeyar Lwin is referring to the 2008 constitution which many analysts believe was designed to reinforce military rule even after the restoration of civilian leadership.
yoruba: Zeyar Lwin ń tọ́ka sí ìwé òfin ọdún-un 2008 tí ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ àwọn atúnǹkanká gbàgbọ́ wípé a ṣe é to láti fi agbára fún ìṣèjọba ikọ̀ ajagun pàápàá lẹ́yìn tí alágbáda gba ìjọba.

english: Sickly filmmaker in detention
yoruba: Aya-eré-ìtàgé aláàárẹ̀ nínú àtìmọ́lé

english: The case of filmmaker Min Htin Ko Ko Gyi also reflects the restrictions imposed on critical artists.
yoruba: Ọ̀ràn aya-eré-ìtàgé Min Htin Ko Ko Gyi tún fi ìrísí ìhámọ́ tí a há àwọn akọrin pàtàkì mọ́.

english: A complaint filed by a military officer against the filmmaker's ‘defamatory’ Facebook posts led to his arrest.
yoruba: Ìwé ẹ̀sùn tí ọ̀físà jagunjagun kọ nípa àwọn àtẹ̀jáde ‘ìbanilórúkọjẹ́’ tí aya-eré-ìtàgé gbé sí orí Facebook tí ó fà á tí a fi fi òfin mú un.

english: Min Htin Ko Ko Gyi is the founder of the Myanmar Human Rights Human Dignity Film Festival and a known critic of the military's involvement in politics.
yoruba: Min Htin Ko Ko Gyi ni olùdásílẹ̀ iléeṣẹ́ Àjọ̀dún Eré Ajàfẹ́tọ̀ọ́ Iyì Ọmọnìyàn àti ìlúmọ̀nánká alátakò ìlọ́wọ́sí ikọ̀ ajagun nínú òṣèlú.

english: His supporters are calling for his release on humanitarian grounds, since he has had half of his liver removed due to cancer and suffers from heart and kidney problems.
yoruba: Àwọn alátìlẹ́yìn-in rẹ̀ ń pè fún ìtúsílẹ̀ẹ rẹ̀ lóríi ẹ̀tọ́ ọmọnìyàn, látàrí wípé a ti yọ àbọ̀ ẹ̀dọ rẹ̀ nítorí àrùn jẹjẹrẹ àti àrùn ọkàn àti ìṣòro kíndìnrín.

english: The Human Rights Film Network, a partnership of 40 human rights film festivals around the world, sent this letter to the government:
yoruba: Àjọṣe Eré Ẹ̀tọ́ Ọmọnìyàn, tí ó jẹ́ àjọṣepọ̀ àjọ̀dún eré ajàfẹ́tọ̀ọ́ ọmọnìyàn 40 kárí ayé, fi lẹ́tà ṣọwọ́ sí ìjọba:

english: As a concerned international human rights community, we seek reassurance from the Myanmar government to ensure that Section66(d), which was meant to enhance progress of telecommunications, will not be used to silence the voice of Myanmarese civilians seeking to voice their opinions and take part in the democratic process in Myanmar.
yoruba: Gẹ́gẹ́ bí ẹgbẹ́ ajìjàǹgbara àgbáyé tí ọ̀rán kàn, a tọrọ ìdánilójú ìjọba Myanmar láti ríi dájú wípé Abala 66 (d), tí ó yẹ kí ó sún ìtẹ̀síwájú ẹ̀rọ ayárabíàṣá síwájú, tí kò ní jẹ́ lílò fún ìpalẹ̀mọ́ ọmọ ìlúu Myanmar tí ó fẹ́ sọ èròo ọkàn-an wọn àti lọ́wọ́ sí ètò ìṣèlú ìjọba àwa-arawa ní Myanmar.

english: The letter refers to the controversial Section 66(d) defamation law which has been used by authorities to charge critics, activists, and journalists.
yoruba: Lẹ́tà náà tọ́ka sí ti àríyànjiyàn Abala 66(d) tí ó sọ nípa òfin ìbánilórúkọjẹ́ tí àwọn aláṣẹ ń lò láti to fi ẹ̀sùn ìtakò, ìjìjàgbara, àti akọ̀ròyìn.

english: Min Htin Ko Ko Gyi's petition for bail was rejected by a local court. His next hearing is scheduled for May 9, 2019.
yoruba: Ilé ẹjọ́ ìbílẹ̀ kọ ìwé ẹ̀dùn tí Min Htin Ko Ko Gyi kọ fún béèlì. Ìgbẹ́jọ́ọ rẹ̀ tún di ọjọ́ 9, oṣù Èbìbì ọdún-un 2019.

english: “They should never have been jailed in the first place.”
yoruba: “Kò yẹ kí wọ́n di èrò ẹ̀wọ̀n ní ìbẹ̀rẹ̀.”

english: Wa Lone and Kyaw Soe Oo were sentenced to seven years in prison for violating the colonial-era Official Secrets Act.
yoruba: A rán Wa Lone àti Kyaw Soe Oo sí ẹ̀wọ̀n ọdún méje fún rírú òfin Ìkọ̀kọ̀ sáà-akónilẹ́rú.

english: The Supreme Court upheld their conviction last April with finality but they were released from prison after they were granted a presidential pardon during the country’s traditional New Year.
yoruba: Ilé Ẹjọ́ Àgbà di ìdálẹ́jọ́ tí wọ́n ṣe ní oṣù Igbe tí ó kọjá àmọ́ a dá wọn sílẹ̀ lẹ́yìn ìdáríjì ààrẹ ní àsìkò Ọdún Tuntun ìbílẹ̀ orílẹ̀ èdè náà.

english: Groups like the Southeast Asian Press Alliance welcomed the release of Wa Lone and Kyaw Soe Oo but they also highlighted the injustice suffered by the two reporters:
yoruba: Àwọn ẹgbẹ́ bíi Southeast Asian Press Alliance kí Wa Lone àti Kyaw Soe Oo káàbọ̀ lẹ́yìn-in tí a dá wọn sílẹ̀ àmọ́ wọ́n sọ ìyànjẹ tí ó kojú àwọn akọ̀ròyìn méjèèjì:

english: They should never have been jailed in the first place, because they committed no crime.
yoruba: Kò yẹ kí wọ́n di èrò ẹ̀wọ̀n ní ìbẹ̀rẹ̀, nítorí wọn kò jẹ̀bi ẹ̀sùn tí wọ́n fi kàn wọ́n.

english: While we welcome this positive development, the case of Wa Lone and Kyaw Soe Oo is proof that journalists are in constant risk of political reprisal for keeping power in check.
yoruba: Nígbàtí a gba ìdàgbàsókè yìí wọlé, ẹjọ́ọ Wa Lone àti Kyaw Soe Oo jẹ́ ẹ̀rí wípé ẹ̀mí àwọn akọ̀ròyìn tí ó ń ṣe àyẹ̀wò sí ìṣèlú wà nínú ewu ìgbẹ̀san òṣèlú.

english: Brazilian indigenous people buy shares in railway company to denounce its failed environmental obligations
yoruba: Àwọn ọmọ ìbílẹ̀ Brazili ra ìpín ìdókòòwò ní iléeṣẹ́ reluwé láti bá a wí fún ìkùnà ojúṣe àyíkáa rẹ̀

english: Indigenous peoples say the newly expanded railway impacted the area's wildlife and threatens their safety.
yoruba: Àwọn ọmọ ìbílẹ̀ sọ wípé iṣẹ́ tuntun fífẹ reluwé ń kóbá àwọn ẹranko agbègbè náà àti ààbòo wọn.

english: Image: Pedro Biava, used with permission.
yoruba: Àwòrán: Pedro Biava, tí a fi àṣẹ lò.

english: On April 24, the shareholders’ meeting of Rumo Logística, a Brazilian railway consortium, had a few new, unexpected faces: a group of five indigenous people of Guarani and Tupi ethnicities who had recently bought six shares of the company.
yoruba: Ní ọjọ́ 24 oṣù Igbe, ìpàdé akópìnín Rumo Logística, ìgbìmọ̀ reluwé orílẹ̀ èdèe Brazili, gba àwọn àlejò àìròtẹ́lẹ̀ tuntun: ẹgbẹ́ ẹlẹ́ni márùn-ún ìbílẹ̀ kan tí ó wá láti ẹ̀yà Guarani àti Tupi tí ó ṣẹ̀ṣẹ̀ ra ìpín ìdókòwò mẹ́fà iléeṣẹ́ náà.

english: They each represent one of the five officially designated Indigenous Lands in the southeastern state of São Paulo that was affected by a 90-year-old cargo railway which Rumo operates and, in 2014, began to expand.
yoruba: Ọ̀kọ̀ọ̀kan wọ́n jẹ́ aṣojú Ilẹ̀ Ìbílẹ̀ tí ìjọba fọwọ́ sí ní gúúsù ìlà oòrùn ìpínlẹ̀ São Paulo tí reluwé akẹ́rù aláàdọ́run ọdún iléeṣẹ́ Rumo ń kó bá, ní ọdún-un 2014, bẹ̀rẹ̀ sí í fẹ̀ sí i.

english: In order to compensate for the impact caused by the railway expansion, the state contractually obligates the company to "build new houses, prayer sites, a bridge, community gardens and acquire micro-tractors" for the communities.
yoruba: Láti san owóo gbà máà bínú fún ìbàjẹ́ tí ìmúgbòòrò sí i ilé iṣẹ́ náà kó bá agbègbèe náà, ìpínlẹ̀ ti fi ẹ̀tọ́ fún iiléeṣẹ́ reluwé náà láti "kọ́ ilé tuntun, ibùdó ìwúre, afárá, ọgbà àti ra ẹ̀rọ ìṣánko kékeré" fún àwọn agbègbè náà.

english: Around 5,000 people live across the five Indigenous Lands impacted by the railway's expansion.
yoruba: Ó tó bíi ẹgbẹ̀rún márùn-ún ènìyàn tí ó ń gbé jákèjádò Ilẹ̀ Ìbílẹ̀ tí fífẹ̀ reluwé kó bá.

english: But indigenous representatives say the company has failed to fulfill such duties, according to a story by Folha de São Paulo.
yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n àwọn aṣojú ìbílẹ̀ sọ wípé iléeṣẹ́ náà ti kùnà láti ṣe irú ẹ̀tọ́ náà, gẹ́gẹ́ bíi ìròyìn láti ọwọ́ Folha de São Paulo.

english: The Federal Prosecutor's Office confirms this: 63 out of the 97 renovation works provided for in the concession contract are frozen.
yoruba: Ọ̀fíìsì Abánirojọ̀ Ìjọba Àpapọ̀ jẹ́rìí sí i èyí: 63 nínúu iṣẹ́ àtúnṣe 97 ìwé àdéhùn ìfìmọ̀ṣọ̀kan ti di àpatì.

english: On April 19, prosecutors recommended Ibama, Brazil's national environmental agency, to immediately suspend the new railway's construction as well as Rumo's operation license.
yoruba: Ní ọjọ́ 19 oṣù Igbe, àwọn afẹ̀sùnkanni pa á láṣẹ fún Ibama, àjọ ètò àyíká orílẹ̀ èdè Brazili, láti ṣíra dá iṣẹ́ reluwé tuntun náà dúró, wọ́n sì gba ìwé àṣẹ Rumo.

english: They also recommended the agency to fine Rumo in 10 million reais (2,5 million US dollars).
yoruba: Bákan náà ni wọ́n tún gba àjọ náà níyànjú láti mú kí Rumo ó san owó ìtanràn mílíọ̀nù 10 owóo reais (ìyẹn mílíọ̀nù 2,5 owóo dọ́là orílẹ̀ èdèe US).

english: In a letter read at the April 24 assembly, the five indigenous shareholders detailed their plight.
yoruba: Nínúu lẹ́tà tí a kà níbi àpèjọ ọjọ́ 24 oṣù Igbe, àwọn aràpín-ìdókòòwò ìbílẹ̀ náà ṣàlàyé ẹ̀dùn-un ọkàn-an wọn.

english: They've described how the trains have affected wildlife in the area, as well as limited people's circulation.
yoruba: Wọ́n ti ṣe àlàyé ìjàmbá tí àwọn ọkọ̀ ojú irin náà ti fà fún ẹranko inú ìgbẹ́ tí ó wà ní agbègbè náà, àti dín àwọn ọmọ ènìyàn lọ́wọ́ láti fọ́n ká sí agbègbè.

english: In addition, they've reported their struggle in dialoguing with the Rumo, and also discredited the corporation's latest Annual Sustainability Report, which states Rumo it is "perfectly fulfilling their obligations, in a participatory and inclusive way, with the affected indigenous communities".
yoruba: Ní àfikún, wọ́n ti jábọ̀ akitiyan ìtàkùrọ̀sọ wọn pẹ̀lú Rumo, tí wọ́n sì bu ẹnu àtẹ́ lu Àtẹ̀jáde Ìgbéró Ọlọ́dọọdún-un iléeṣẹ́ náà, tí ó sọ pé Rumo "ń ṣe ojúṣe rẹ̀ bí ó ti tọ́ àti bí ó ti ṣe yẹ, ní ọ̀nà tí ó fa àwọn ọmọ ìbílẹ̀ wọ inú iṣẹ́ ".

english: Speaking with reporter Pedro Biava of newspaper Brasil de Fato, Adriano Karai, of Guarani ethnicity, said the indigenous shareholders’ goal was simply to have their voices heard by the company's investors rather than profiting from the shares (which they bought for 17 reais each, around 4,30 US dollars).
yoruba: Nígbà tí ó ń bá Pedro Biava ajábọ̀-ìròyìn ìwé ìròyìn Brasil de Fato fọ̀rọ̀jomitoro, Adriano Karai, tí ó wà láti agbègbè Guarani, sọ wípé ìlépa àwọn alájọpín ìdókòòwò ìbílẹ̀ náà ni láti mú kí ohùn-un wọn ó dé etí ìgbọ́ àwọn olùdókòòwò iléeṣẹ́ náà dípòo kí wọn ó jèrè láti ara ìdókòòwò náà (èyí tí wọ́n ra ọ̀kọ̀ọ̀kan-an ní 17 owó reais, tí ó tó bíi 4,30 owóo dọ́là US).

english: Karai also described how the newly expanded railway has affected his community of Tenondé, located in the city of Paralheiros:
yoruba: Karai tún ṣe àpèjúwe bí iṣẹ́ẹ fífẹ reluwé tuntun náà ti ṣe kóbá agbègbèe rẹ̀ Tenondé, tí ó wà ní ìlúu Paralheiros:

english: Translation Original Quote
yoruba: Ìtúmọ̀ Ìtúnwí-ọ̀rọ̀ Ọlọ́rọ̀ gan-an

english: There is the noise of the train, which runs all night.
yoruba: Ariwo ọkọ̀ ojú irin náà, tí ó máa ń gbalẹ̀ kan títí lálẹ́.

english: The animals don't show up at hunting places anymore.
yoruba: Àwọn ọmọ ẹranko kì í jẹ́ sí ibi ìdẹ mọ́ bíi tẹ́lẹ̀ .

english: We don’t have any quiet nights.
yoruba: A kò ní alẹ́ àìláriwo.

english: They also transport a lot of grains that end up spilling on the land, and we know that that food isn't of good quality, it is transgenic.
yoruba: Bákan náà ni wọ́n máa ń gbé ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ ọkàn tí ó máa ń dànù káàkiri ilẹ̀, a sì mọ́ wípé oúnjẹ yẹn kì í ṣe ojúlówó, tí àtọwọ́dá ni.

english: Our lives are also in danger: the train passes through our territories, where walk visiting communities through trails.
yoruba: Ẹ̀mí àwa gan-an alára ń bẹ nínú ewu: ọkọ̀ ojú irin náà ń gba ilẹ̀ àjogúnbáa wa kọjá, níbi tí àwọn àpá ẹsẹ̀ àwọn àlejò afẹsẹ̀ rìn tọ́.

english: We are in constant danger of being hit by a train, because now there is one every ten minutes.”
yoruba: A wà nínú ewu ńlá ìjàmbá ikú ọkọ̀ ojú irin, nítorí ọkọ̀ ojú-irin ń pa ènìyàn nínúu ìṣẹ́jú mẹ́wàá mẹ́wàá báyìí.”

english: According to the Folha story, the indigenous communities initially proposed to Rumo that it outsourced the renovation works to a local committee run by the communities themselves.
yoruba: Gẹ́gẹ́ bíi ìròyìn Folha, ní àkọ́kọ́, àwọn agbègbè ìbílẹ̀ ti gbèrò pẹ̀lú Rumo wípé kí ó gbé iṣẹ́ àtúnṣe náà fún ìgbìmọ̀ tí ó jẹ́ ọmọ ìbílẹ̀.

english: According to the Prosecutor's Office, the company had initially agreed, but shortly after the October 2018 election of President Jair Bolsonaro, who ran on an explicitly anti-indigenous platform, it shifted its approach.
yoruba: Ní ti Ọ́fíìsì Abánirojọ̀, iléeṣẹ́ náà ti kọ́kọ́ gba àbá náà wọlé, ṣùgbọ́n ní kété tí ó di ẹ̀yìn-in ìbò oṣù Ọ̀wẹwẹ̀ ọdún-un 2018 tí ó gbé Ààrẹ Jair Bolsonaro tí kò fi bò wípé òun kórìíra ti ìbílẹ̀ sí orí àlèèfà, àyípadà dé bá ìpinnu ìgbésè ti ó wà nílẹ̀ tẹ́lẹ̀tẹ́lẹ́rí.

english: On November 20, Rumo suddenly canceled its participation at a meeting with the communities, and since then hasn't shown up at any other meetings.
yoruba: Ní ọjọ́ 20 oṣù Belu, Rumo ṣàì dédé fagi lé ìkópa pẹ̀lú àwọn agbègbè ìbílẹ̀, tí kò ì tíì tún yọjú níbi ìpàdé láti ìgbà náà.

english: Speaking with Folha, the company said it never signed any agreement with the indigenous communities of outsourcing the renovation works to their committee.
yoruba: Nínú ìtàkùrọ̀sọ pẹ̀lú Folha, iléeṣẹ́ náà sọ wípé òun kò fi ìgbà kan t'ọwọ́ bọ ìwé àdéhùn pẹ̀lú àwọn agbègbè ìbílẹ̀ náà láti gbé iṣẹ́ àtúnṣe náà fún wọn ṣe.

english: The shareholders’ assembly on April 24 ended without any formal agreements, but Rumo's representatives said that the indigenous claims will be discussed at an internal meeting in May.
yoruba: Àpéjọ àwọn alájọpín ìdókòòwò tí ó wáyé lọ́jọ́ 24 oṣù Igbe wá sí òpin láì sí ìpinnu tí ó lórí, àmọ́ àwọn aṣojú Rumo sọ wípé ọ̀rọ̀ ti ìbílẹ̀ náà yóò jẹ́ sísọ nínú ìpàdé ti abẹ́nú tí yóò wáyé nínú oṣù Èbìbì.

english: Expansion works began in 2014. Around 5,000 indigenous peoples live in the area.
yoruba: Iṣẹ́ àtúnṣe bẹ̀rẹ̀ ní 2014. Àwọn ọmọ ìbílẹ̀ tí ó ń gbé ní agbègbè náà tó bíi 5,000.

english: Image: Pedro Biava, used with permission.
yoruba: Àwòrán: Pedro Biava, pẹ̀lú àṣẹ ni a fi lò ó.

english: Shareholder activism
yoruba: Ìjàgbara Alájọpín-ìdókòòwò

english: The Guarani and Tupi aren't the only ones engaging with so-called "shareholder activism", a practice that isn't very common in Brazil.
yoruba: Àwọn ọmọ ìbílẹ̀ Guarani àti Tupi nìkan kọ́ ni ó ṣe ohun tí a pè ní "ìjàgbara alájọpín- ìdókòòwò", tí ó jẹ́ ohun tuntun ní Brazil.

english: In 2010, the group Articulation of those Affected by Vale (Articulação dos Atingidos e Atingidas pela Vale) purchased the company's shares in order to sit at their assemblies.
yoruba: Ní ọdún-un 2010, ẹgbẹ́ Ìmọ́rọ̀-yéni-yékéyéké àwọn tí ọ̀ràn-an Vale náà kàn (Articulação dos Atingidos e Atingidas pela Vale) ra ìpín ìdókòòwò iléeṣẹ́ náà láti lè bá wọn jókòó ní àjọ wọn.

english: Vale one of the largest mining corporations in the world, and the operator of the dam that ruptured in the city of Brumadinho in January 2019, killing 236 people (34 are still missing).
yoruba: Vale ni ọkàn lára iléeṣẹ́ awakùsà ní àgbáyé, òun sì ni ó ṣe àkóso ìdídò tí ó ba ìlúu Brumadinho jẹ́ nínú oṣùu Ṣẹẹrẹ ọdún-un 2019, tí ó mú ẹ̀mí èèyàn-an 236 lọ (tí 34 ṣì ti di ẹni àwátì).

english: On April 30, the day of a shareholders’ meeting, Articulation members pinned posters with the deceased people's names on the walls of Vale's headquarters, as reported by newspaper O Globo.
yoruba: Ní ọjọ́ 30 oṣù Igbe, ọjọ́ ìpàdé alájọpín ìdókòòwò, àwọn ọmọ ẹgbẹ́ Ìmọ́rọ̀-yéni-yékéyéké lẹ ìwé-àlẹ̀mógiri tí a tẹ orúkọ àwọn tí ó ti re ọ̀run àrìnmabọ̀ mọ́ ara ògiri olú-ilé-iṣẹ́ẹ Vale, gẹ́gẹ́ bí ìwé ìròyìn O Globo ti rò ó.

english: By voicing their concerns at those meetings, the companies are forced to register the activists’ demands in their minutes.
yoruba: Nítorí àìdéènà-pa-ẹnu ọ̀ràn tí ó kàn wọ́n gbọ̀ngbọ̀n nínú àwọn ìpàdé wọ̀nyẹn, ó di dandan kí àwọn iléeṣẹ́ náà ó kọ ohun tí àwọn ajìjàgbara náà ń fẹ́ sílẹ̀ nínú ìpàdée wọn.

english: One of the Articulation members, Carolina de Moura, herself a Vale shareholder, told O Globo:
yoruba: Obìnrin kan lára àwọn ọmọ ẹgbẹ́ Ìmọ́rọ̀-yéni-yékéyéké, Carolina de Moura, tí òun náà ní ìpín nínú ìdókòòwò Vale, sọ fún O Globo:

english: Translation Original Quote
yoruba: Ìtúmọ̀ Ìtúnwí-ọ̀rọ̀ Ọlọ́rọ̀ gan-an

english: We will keep speaking up.
yoruba: A kò ní dẹ́kun láti máa sọ ohun tí ó ń gbé wa lọ́kàn síta fún aráyé gbọ́.

english: The company must invest everything they make in improving our rivers and caring about human lives.
yoruba: Iléeṣẹ́ náà gbọdọ̀ lo èrè tí wọ́n bá rí fi tún àwọn odòo wa ṣe àti ṣíṣe àbójútó ẹ̀mí ọmọ ènìyàn.

english: Tanzanian authorities detain and deport Ugandan human rights leader
yoruba: Ìjọba Tanzania fi Ajìjàgbara Ọmọ Orílẹ̀-èdèe Uganda sí àtìmọ́lé, wọ́n sì lé e kúrò nílùú

english: Dr. Wairagala Wakabi [Image by CIPESA and used with permission]
yoruba: Dókítà Wairagala Wakabi [Àwòrán láti CIPESA tí a fi àṣẹ lò]

english: Wairagala Wakabi, a leading digital rights advocate from Uganda, was detained at Julius Nyerere International Airport in Dar es Salaam, Tanzania on April 25.
yoruba: Wairagala Wakabi, àgbà ọ̀jẹ̀ ajàfẹ́tọ̀ọ́ ẹ̀rọ ayárabíàṣá tí ó wá láti Uganda, di ẹni àtìmọ́lé ní Pápákọ̀ òfuurufú Julius Nyerere International Airport ní Dar es Salaam, Tanzania lọ́jọ́ 25 oṣù Igbe.

english: Wakabi was invited to speak at the annual Tanzania Human Rights Defenders’ Day hosted by the Tanzania Human Rights Defenders Coalition (THRDC).
yoruba: A fi ìwé pe Wakabi kí ó wá á sọ̀rọ̀ níbi ètò Àyájọ́ Àwọn Olùgbèjà Ẹ̀tọ́ Ọmọnìyàn ní Tanzania ọlọ́dọọdún tí Àgbáríjọ Olùgbèjà Ẹ̀tọ́ Ọmọnìyàn ti Tanzania (THRDC) jẹ́ olùgbàlejò.

english: Wakabi is the Executive Director of the Collaboration on International ICT Policy for East and Southern Africa (CIPESA), one of the foremost organizations working on internet policy and online free speech in Africa.
yoruba: Wakabi ni Olùdarí Àgbà Ìfọwọ́sowọ́pọ̀ Ètò-ìmúlò Ìmọ̀-ẹ̀rọ Gbogboògbò fún Ìlà-Oòrùn àti Gúúsù Ilẹ̀ Adúláwò (CIPESA), ọ̀kan gbòógì nínú ilé-iṣẹ́ tí ó ń ṣe ètò tí ó dá lórí ètò-ìmúlò ẹ̀rọ ayélujára àti òmìnira ọ̀rọ̀ sísọ ní orí ayélujára ní ilẹ̀ Adúláwò.

english: Wakabi was deported back to Uganda after several hours of interrogation, during which he was denied access to a lawyer.
yoruba: Lẹ́yìn ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ wákàtí tí a fi ọ̀rọ̀ wá Wakabi lẹ́nu wò, tí wọn kò sì jẹ́ kí ó rí agbẹjọ́rò, a dá a padà sí Uganda.

english: Attorneys from the Tanzania Human Rights Defenders Coalition attempted to advocate on his behalf, but were told only that Wakabi was being deported on grounds of "national interest":
yoruba: Àwọn aṣojú láti Àgbáríjọ Olùgbèjà Ẹ̀tọ́ Ọmọnìyàn gbìyànjú láti jà fún un, àmọ́ a sọ fún wọn wípé fún "àǹfààní ìlú" ni a fi dá Wakabi padà sí ìlúu rẹ̀:

english: Though the ordeal lasted only a few hours, it brought great consternation among rights advocates in the region, who have grown wary of Tanzania's treatment of activists and journalists.
yoruba: Bí ó ti lẹ̀ jẹ́ pé ìṣẹ̀lẹ̀ náà kò ju wákàtí díẹ̀ lọ, ó mú ìjáyà ńlá bá àwọn ajàfẹ́tọ̀ọ́ ní agbègbè náà, tí ọ̀ràn ìwà àìtọ́ tí orílẹ̀-èdèe Tanzania ń wù sí àwọn ajìjàgbara àti oníṣẹ́-ìròyìn ń peléke sí i.

english: In November last year, Angela Quintal and Muthoki Mumo both staff of Committee to Protect Journalists, were detained for several hours in Dar es Salaam, Tanzania, and had their passports temporarily seized.
yoruba: Nínú oṣù Belu ọdún tí ó ré kọjá, àwọn òṣìṣẹ́ Ìgbìmọ̀ tí ó ń Dáàbò bo Oníṣẹ́-ìròyìn, Angela Quintal àti Muthoki Mumo di ẹni àtìmọ́lé fún ọ̀pọ̀ wákàtí ní Dar es Salaam, Tanzania, tí ìwé ẹ̀rí ọmọ-ìlú-fún-ìrìnnàa wọ́n di gbígbà lọ́wọ́ọ wọn.

english: Human Rights Watch asserted that Tanzania under the leadership President John Magufuli has witnessed "a marked decline in respect for free expression, association and assembly".
yoruba: Human Rights Watch sọ wípé lábẹ́ ìṣàkóso ìjọba Ààrẹ John Magufuli Tanzania ti rí "ìrésílẹ̀ ìbọ̀wọ̀ fún òmìnira ọ̀rọ̀ sísọ, ìkẹ́gbẹ́ àti àpéjọ dé ojú àmì".

english: In 2015, the United Republic of Tanzania promulgated the Cybercrimes Act.
yoruba: Ní ọdún-un 2015, Orílẹ̀èdè Olómìnira Ìṣọ̀kan Tanzania kéde Ìgbésẹ̀ Ìrúfin Orí Ẹ̀rọ Ayélujára.

english: Within a year of the passing of that law, at least 14 Tanzanians were arrested and prosecuted under the law for insulting the president on social media.
yoruba: Ní àárín ọdún kan tí a kéde òfin yẹn, ó ti tó bí ọmọ orílẹ̀ èdèe Tanzania 14 tí òfín ti mú tí a sì ti dálẹ́jọ́ lábẹ́ òfin fún pé wọ́n sọ̀rọ̀ mọ́ṣààsí sí ààrẹ lórí ẹ̀rọ alátagbà.

english: March 2018 saw the passing of the Electronic and Postal Communications (Online Content) Regulations, making it mandatory for bloggers to register and pay roughly US $900 per year to publish online.
yoruba: Pẹ́pẹ́yẹ gbé ọmọ pọ̀n nínú oṣù Ẹrẹ́nà ọdún-un 2018 nígbàtí a gba Ìlànà Ẹ̀rọ Ayárabíàṣá (Ohun orí ayélujára) àti Ìtàkùrọ̀sọ Ìfìwéránṣẹ́ wọlé tí ó mú un ní túláàsì fún àwọn akọbúlọ́ọ̀gù láti fi orúkọ sílẹ̀ tí wọ́n á sì san owó orí tí ó tó bíi US $900 lọ́dún kí wọn ó tó lè gbé àtẹ̀jáde sí orí ayélujára.

english: This caused many independent blogs to go dark.
yoruba: Èyí mú kí ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ búlọ́ọ̀gù aládàádúró ó wọ òkùnkùn.

english: The stifling of independent media through a mixture of sanctions against media outlets and legal threats against journalists has created an atmosphere of intimidation, self-censorship and fear of expressing alternative views about the country’s leaders.
yoruba: Ìpalẹ́numọ́ iléeṣẹ́ akọ̀ròyìn aládàádúró nípasẹ̀ àwọn àdàlù ìṣíwèé fún ilé iṣẹ́ akọ̀ròyìn àti ìrókẹ́kẹ́ mọ́ oníṣẹ́-ìròyìn ti di ìdẹ́rùbà, ìkóra-ẹni-ní-ìjánu àti ìbẹ̀rù láti sọ èrò ọkàn ẹni nípa àwọn olórí orílẹ̀ èdè náà.

english: The detention and subsequent deportation of Wakabi back to Uganda appears to be a continuation of the Tanzania's government assault on free speech and dissent.
yoruba: Àtìmọ́lé àti ìdápadà Wakabi sí Uganda jẹ́ ìtẹ̀síwájú ìdojú-ìjà-kọ òmìnira ọ̀rọ̀ tòun èrò ọkàn ẹni ní Tanzania.

english: Digital journalist Luis Carlos Diaz is missing in Venezuela
yoruba: Oníròyìn Orí ẹ̀rọ-alátagbà Luis Carlos Diaz di àwátì ní Venezuela

english: "Where is Luis Carlos?"
yoruba: "Níbo ni Luis Carlos wà?"

english: Image of the public online campaign shared by Provea.
yoruba: Àwòrán ìpolongo orí ayélujára tí Provea taari síta.

english: In the image they indicate the last time he had been contacted and the last time he tweeted.
yoruba: Wọ́n sọ ìgbà tí a pè é kẹ́yìn àti túwíìtì tí ó tẹ̀ kẹ́yìn nínú àwòrán náà.

english: On the evening of March 11, political commentator Naky Soto and wife of Venezuelan journalist and media activist Luis Carlos Diaz tweeted that he had been missing for five hours.
yoruba: Ní ìrọ̀lẹ́ ọjọ́ 11, oṣù Ẹrẹ́nà olùfèsì sí ọ̀rọ̀ ìṣèlú Naky Soto tí ó tún jẹ́ aya akọ̀ròyìn àti ajììjàǹgbara iṣẹ́ ìròyìn tí ó jẹ́ ọmọ orílẹ̀ Venezuela, Luis Carlos Díaz túwíìtì pé òun ti ń wá ọkọ òun fún wákàtí márùn-ún.

english: [Update] The Union of Press Workers (in Spanish, the SNTP) reported that Luis Carlos had been detained by the Bolivarian Intelligence Forces (SEBIN):
yoruba: [Ìròyìn tí ó tẹ̀ wá lọ́wọ́] Àjọ àwọn Òṣìṣẹ́ Ìròyìn (SNTP lédè Spanish) jábọ̀ pé àwọn Agbófinró Ọ̀tẹlẹ̀múyẹ́ Bolivaria (SEBIN) ti fi Luis Carlos sí àtìmọ́lé.

english: URGENT A Sebin commission confirms that journalist Luis Carlos Díaz has been detained by that police organism.
yoruba: PÀJÁWÌRÌ Àjọ Sebin kan fìdíi rẹ̀ múlẹ̀ pé akọ̀ròyìn Luis Carlos Diaz ti wà ní àhámọ́ àwọn ọlọ́pàá yẹn.

english: They pointed their weapons at journalist [and members of the Press Union] Marco Ruiz, Luz Mely Reyes and Federico Black.
yoruba: Wọ́n yọ àwọn ohun ìjà ti akọ̀ròyìn Marco Ruiz, Luz Mely Rehes àti Federico Black [pẹ̀lú àwọn ọmọ ẹgbẹ́ òṣìṣẹ́ ìròyìn.

english: Hours before, Soto had tweeted that Luis Carlos Díaz had been missing for five hours:
yoruba: Wákàtí díẹ̀ sẹ́yìn, Soto túwíìtì pé àwọn ti ń wá Luis Carlos Díaz fún wákàtí márùn-ún:

english: @LuisCarlos is on his bike, but since 5:30 I've heard nothing from him and:
yoruba: @LuisCarlos wà ní orí kẹ̀kẹ́ẹ rẹ̀, ṣùgbọ́n láti aago 5:30 ni mi kò ti gbúròó rẹ̀ mọ́, bẹ́ẹ̀:

english: – he's not at the radio station
yoruba: – Kò sí ní ilé iṣẹ́ ìgbóhùnsáfẹ́fẹ́ náà

english: – he's not at home
yoruba: – Kò sí nílé

english: – he hasn't tweeted
yoruba: – Kò tíì túwíìtì

english: – he isn't answering calls
yoruba: – Kò gbé ìpèe rẹ̀

english: – he isn't answering SMS or WhatsApp messages
yoruba: – Kò fèsì sí àtẹ̀jíṣẹ́ tàbí iṣẹ́-ìjẹ́ oríi WhatsApp

english: [Update] As members of SEBIN searched Diaz's and Soto's home, Luz Mely Reyes reported live from the scene.
yoruba: [Ìròyìn tó tẹ̀wá lọ́wọ́] Luz Mely Reyes tí ìṣẹ̀lẹ̀ náà ṣe ojúu rẹ̀, fi tó wa létí nípa bí àwọn Agbófinró SEBIN ṣe yẹ ilée Díaz pẹ̀lú ilée Soto náà wò.

english: The SNTP also reported the incident:
yoruba: Ìsọ̀kan àwọn Oníròyìn náà fẹ ọ̀rọ̀ náà lójú:

english: URGENT At this time, 3:30 am, a commission from the Intelligence Forces arrives to journalist and human rights activist Luis Carlos Díaz's home, missing since 5:30 pm #WhereIsLuisCarlos
yoruba: NÍ KÍÁKÍÁ Ní dédé àsìkò yìí, ní dédé agogo 3:00 òwúrọ̀ kùtùkùtù, ìgbìmọ̀ láti àjọ Amúninípá dé ilé oníròyìn àti ajà-fún- ẹ̀tọ́ọ ọmọ ènìyàn Luis Carlos Díaz, tí ó ti di ẹni àwátì láti agogo 5:30 ìrọ̀lẹ́ #NiboNiLuisCarlosWa.

english: Other human rights and freedom of speech organizations joined the campaign through #DondeEstaLuisCarlos (Where is Luis Carlos?) which is, at the moment, a trending topic in Venezuela's twittosphere.
yoruba: Àwọn ajàfúnẹ̀tọ́ ọmọnìyàn àti àjọ òmìnira ọ̀rọ̀ sísọ náà darapọ̀ mọ ìpolongo yìí pẹ̀lú #DondeEstaLuisCarlos (Níbo ni Luis Carlos wà?), tí ó jẹ́ pé, ní báyìí, ni àkọlé tí ó gbajúmọ̀ ní orí ìkànnì ayélujára Twitter ti Orílẹ̀ Èdè Venezuela.

english: Díaz is a journalist and a human rights and freedom of speech advocate who is well known and highly appreciated in Venezuela and abroad for his commentary and criticism of the government of Nicolas Maduro.
yoruba: Díaz jẹ́ ajábọ̀ ìròyìn àti a-jà-fún-ẹ̀tọ́-ọmọ ènìyàn tí ó jẹ́ ògbólógbòó ajàfúnẹ̀tọ́ òmìnira ọ̀rọ̀ sísọ tí wọ́n sì mọ ìṣe rẹ̀ fún un l'órílẹ̀ èdè Venezuela àti òkè òkun fún ìdásọ́rọ̀ àti ìtakò ìjọba Nicholas Maduro.

english: He has long worked with Soto producing web-based video and radio programs focused on politics and human rights in Venezuela.
yoruba: Ó ti tó ìgbà díẹ̀ kan tí ó ti ń ṣiṣẹ́ pẹ̀lú ìyàwó rẹ̀ àti olùdásọ́rọ̀ òṣèlú tí ó gbajúmọ̀ n nì, Naky Soto, tí wọn sì ń ṣe ìgbéjáde àwọn fídíò àti ètò Ìgbóhùnsáfẹ́fẹ́ lórí ayélujára èyí tí ó dá lórí ìṣèlú àti ẹ̀tọ́ ọmọ ènìyàn ní Venezuela.

english: He has also worked as an educator and promoter of the creation of citizen media spaces and independent media projects.
yoruba: Ó ti ṣiṣẹ́ gẹ́gẹ́ bí akọ́ni àti olùgbé-lárúgẹ ìdásílẹ̀ àyè ọ̀tọ̀ fún àwọn ará ìlú àti àwọn àkànṣe eto ìgbóhùn sáfẹ́fẹ́ tí kò lọ́wọ́ ìjọ̀ba nínú.

english: Díaz has also been part of the Global Voices community for more than a decade.
yoruba: Díaz tún jẹ́ olùkópa nínú ẹgbẹ́ Ohùn Àgbáyé fún ọdún mẹ́wàá.

english: To me, Luis Carlos is a brilliant person, well versed in information and networks in this chaotic Venezuela of ours.
yoruba: Lọ́dọ̀ tèmi, Luis Carlos jẹ́ onílàákàyè ẹ̀dá kan, ó gbọ́njú nínú ìròyìn gbígbà àti ìkànsì-ara-ẹni nínú Venezuela ti wa yìí tí kò fara rọ.

english: He has been able to make links with society (from criticism to cultural spaces) #WhereIsLuisCarlos.
yoruba: Ó ti ṣe àwárí ìjápọ̀ nínú ìlú (láti ìtakò sí ibi ìṣẹ̀ṣe) #NiboniLuisCarlosWa.

english: Just a few days prior to his disappearance, the state-affiliated media program Con el Mazo Dando showed a video clip of a recent broadcast of Diaz.
yoruba: Láàrin ọjọ́ péréte tó ṣíwájú ìpòóráa rẹ̀, ètò ìkàn-sára- ẹni ti ìjọba Con el Mazo Dando ṣàfihàn fídíò tí Díaz sọ̀rọ̀ nínúu rẹ̀.

english: The program's host, politician Diosdado Cabello, insinuated that Diaz had helped to orchestrate the nationwide power outage that had Venezuelans living in the dark for more than 24 hours on March 7 and 8.
yoruba: Atọ́kùn ètò ọ̀hún, olóṣèlú Diosdado Cabello, rò kàn pé Díaz lọ́wọ́ sí ìfẹ̀hónú hàn àìsí ináa mọ̀nàmọ̀nà tí ò lọ jákèjádò orílẹ̀ èdè èyí tí ó mú kí àwọn ọmọ Venezuela máa gbé nínú òkùnkùn fún ó lé ní wákàtí mẹ́rin lé lógún lọ́jọ́ 7 àti 8 Oṣù Ẹrẹ́nà

english: There is no evidence to support this.
yoruba: Kò sí ẹ̀rí tí ó fi ẹsẹ̀ rinlẹ̀.

english: It's been been seven hours since Luis Carlos Díaz has gone missing.
yoruba: Wákàtí méje ti ré kọjá lọ tí Luis Carlos Díaz ti di àwátì.

english: [Díaz] is a journalist for Unión Radio Noticias and he's a human rights activist.
yoruba: [Díaz] jẹ́ oníròyìn fún ilé iṣẹ́ ìgbóhùnsáfẹ́fẹ́ Unión Radio Noticias , ó sì tún jẹ́ ajàfúnẹ̀tọ́ ọmọnìyàn.

english: We're at the SEBIN headquarters and they deny having him [in custody there] #WhereIsLuisCarlos
yoruba: Àwa ní olú ilé iṣẹ́ẹ SEBIN headquarters àti pé wọ́n ní àwọn kò ní í [ní àhámọ́ àwọn] #NiboNiLuisCarlosWa.

english: [Update: they later confirmed Diaz was in custody]
yoruba: [Ìròyìn tí ó tẹ̀ wá lọ́wọ́: they wọ́n pàpà jẹ́wọ́ wípé [Diaz wà ní akolóo wọn]

english: Journalist Vladimir Villegas denounced that he had been detained by government forces:
yoruba: Akọ̀ròyìn Vladimir Villegas sọ wípé kò rí bẹ́ẹ̀ mọ́ wípé ìjọba ni ó fi ọwọ́ agbára mú u:

english: We've been informed that @Unionradionet journalist Luis Carlos Díaz, has been detained by State's security forces.
yoruba: radionet Luis Carlos Díaz, ti wà nínú àtìmọ́lé agbófinró Ìlú.

english: We express our concern for his physical integrity.
yoruba: A bá a kẹ́dùn ipò tí ó wà.

english: We demand any information of his whereabouts and respect for his human rights.
yoruba: A béèrè fún ìtọ́sọ́nà nípa mímọ ibi tí ó wà, àti ìbọ̀wọ̀ fún ẹ̀tọ́ ọmọnìyàn-an rẹ̀.

english: The Global Voices community stands in solidarity with Luis Carlos, his family, and all other independent journalists working to hold power to account in Venezuela.
yoruba: Ẹgbẹ́ Ohùn Àgbáyé dúró ṣinṣin pẹ̀lú Luis Carlos, ẹbíi rẹ̀, àti oníròyìn aládàáṣiṣẹ́ gbogbo àwọn tí ó ń mú ìjọba ṣe bí ó ti yẹ ní Venezuela.

english: We wish for his safe and speedy return, and will continue to update this story as it develops.
yoruba: À ń retíi rẹ̀ kí ó dé kíákíá ní àlàáfíà ara àti ẹ̀mí, a ó máa gbé àwọn ìròyìn síta nípa ìròyìn yìí bí ó ba ṣe ń tẹ̀ wá lọ́wọ́.

english: Nigeria's social media bill will obliterate online freedom of expression
yoruba: Ìwé àbádòfin ìlò ẹ̀rọ alátagbà yóò pa òmìnira ọ̀rọ̀ sísọ lórí ayélujára ní Nàìjíríà

english: The draconian bill will legalize internet shutdowns in Nigeria
yoruba: Ìwé àbádòfin náà yóò fi àṣẹ fún ìṣánpa ẹ̀rọ ayélujára ní Nàìjíríàj

english: Senator Mohammed Sani Musa is the sponsor of the social media bill. Screenshot from Channel Television You Tube video.
yoruba: Aṣojú Mohammed Sani Musa ni agbátẹrùu ìwé àbádòfin ìlò ẹ̀rọ alátagbà. Àwòrán àgékù láti ibùdó Channel Television You Tube .

english: On November 20, the Protection from Internet Falsehoods and Manipulation of other Related Matters Bill 2019, known as the "social media bill", sponsored by Senator Mohammed Sani Musa, sailed through a second reading.
yoruba: Lọ́jọ́ 20 oṣù Belu, Ìwé Àbádòfin tí ó fi Ààbò fún Irọ́ àti Màkàrúrù tí ó rọ̀ mọ́ ọn ti ọdún-un 2019, tí a mọ̀ sí "ìwé àbádòfin ìlò ẹ̀rọ alátagbà", tí Aṣojú kan tí orúkọ rẹ̀ ń jẹ́ Mohammed Sani Musa ṣe agbátẹrùu rẹ̀, ti di kíkà nínú ìgbìmọ̀ fún ìgbà kejì.

english: The social media bill aims to curb online falsehoods and mis- and disinformation.
yoruba: Èròńgbà ìwé àbádòfin ìlò ẹ̀rọ alátagbà náà ni láti dẹ́kun àwọn àhesọ àti gbólóhùn tí kì í ṣe òtítọ́ lórí ẹ̀rọ ayélukára bí ajere.

english: However, the real intent is not regulation, but rather, the annihilation of online freedom of expression, criminalization of government criticism and legalization of internet shutdowns in Nigeria.
yoruba: Bí-ó-ti-lẹ̀-jẹ́-wípé, kì í ṣe láti fi òfin de ìlò ẹ̀rọ alátagbà ni ìwé àbádòfin náà dá lé lórí, àmọ́ ṣá, ó máa pa òmìnira ọ̀rọ̀ sísọ lórí ayélujára, ìsọ alátakò ìjọba di ọ̀daràn àti fífi àtìpà ẹ̀rọ ayélujára fúngbà díẹ̀ sínú ìwé òfin.

english: A similar bill was beaten dead in its track in 2016.
yoruba: Àtẹ̀pa bí erín bá tẹ koríko ni àwọn ọmọ Nàìjíríà tẹ irú ìwé àbádòfin báyìí pa ní ọdún-un 2016.

english: Any form of government criticism is a crime
yoruba: Ẹ̀ṣẹ̀ ni bí o bá gbó ìjọba lẹ́nu (tako ìjọba)

english: This bill aims to "[prevent] the transmission of false statements or declaration of facts in Nigeria", according to Section 1a.
yoruba: Gẹ́gẹ́ bí Abala 1A ti ṣe ṣàlàyé, èròńgbà ìwé àbádòfin yìí ni láti "[máà jẹ́] kí ìgbéjáde ọ̀rọ̀ tí kò ní òtítọ́ kan nínú tàbí èyí tí ẹ̀ríi rẹ̀ kò f'ẹsẹ̀ rinlẹ̀ tó ó jáde ní Nàìjíríà".

english: It will ban the dissemination statements likely to be "prejudicial" to Nigeria, including subjects like public health, public safety, "public tranquility or public finances" and Nigeria's "friendly relations with other countries".
yoruba: Yóò yọ ọwọ́ kílàńkó àwọn àtẹ̀jáde irọ́ tí ó lè kó orílẹ̀ èdèe Nàìjíríà sí "ìyọnu", láwo láì gbàgbée àwọn ọ̀ràn bíi ètò ìlera gbogboògbò, ààbòo gbogboògbò, "ìbalẹ̀-ọkàn-an gbogboògbò tàbí ìṣúná owóo gbogboògbò" àti "àwọn ìbáṣepọ̀ orílẹ̀-èdèe Nàìjíríà pẹ̀lú àwọn orílẹ̀ èdè mìíràn".

english: The bill will also "detect, control and safeguard against coordinated misuse of online accounts and bots", according to Section 1c.
yoruba: Abala 1c sọ bí ìwé àbádòfin náà yóò ṣe "mú, ṣàkóso àti fi ààbò bo ìlònílòkulò àwọn ìṣàmúlò àti ẹ̀rọ adánìkanṣiṣẹ́ orí ẹ̀rọ ayélujára".

english: In other words, everything is permissible to monitor and control in the proposed law — under the guise of fighting false information.
yoruba: Ní àlàyé síwájú sí i, kò sí ohun tí ojú òfin tuntun náà kò leè tó bí ó bá ti jẹ́ lórí ayélujára — lábẹ́ àbùradà à ń gbógun ti àhesọ àti irọ́ pọ́nbẹ́lẹ́.

english: The social media bill is omniscient since it will be binding for every Nigerian citizen, regardless of residence or geographic location, as long as the ambiguous "false statement of fact" is transmitted within the country.
yoruba: Ọ̀run ń ya bọ̀ ni ìwé àbádòfin ìlò ẹ̀rọ alátagbà náà, kò yọ ẹnìkan sílẹ̀, gbogbo ọmọ orílẹ̀ èdèe Nàìjíríà ni yóò bá, kò kan agbègbè tàbí ibi tí ènìyàn fi ṣe ibùgbé, máà ṣe é l'oògùn máà mọ́, ọwọ́ àwọn ológìnní ojú tólé ojú tóko ni "gbólóhùn irọ́ tí kò ní ẹ̀rí" tí ó bá gba òpópónà ẹ̀rọ ayélukára bí ajere Nàìjíríà yóò bọ́ sí.

english: Section 3a to b(i) of the social media bill states that:
yoruba: Abala 3a sí b(i) ti ìwé àbádòfin ìlò ẹ̀rọ alátagbà sọ wípé:

english: A person must not do any act in or outside Nigeria in order to transmit in Nigeria a statement knowing or having reasons to believe that it is a false statements of fact; and the transmission of the statement in Nigeria is likely to be, prejudicial to the security of Nigeria or any part of Nigeria.
yoruba: Ẹnikẹ́ni kò gbọdọ̀ wu ìwà kíwà kan nínú tàbí lẹ́yìn odi Nàìjíríà láti tari gbólóhùn tí kò ní òtítọ́ kan tí a kò leè fi ẹ̀ríi rẹ̀ múlẹ̀ síta; àti àgbésórí afẹ́fẹ́ ayélujára gbólóhùn t'ó lè kó orílẹ̀ èdèe Nàìjíríà síta bí ọmọ ọjọ́ mẹ́jọ nípa ti ààbò ìlú.

english: The nebulous "national security" excuse is used to justify the trumping of free expression.
yoruba: Ọ̀ràn-an ti "ààbò orílẹ̀-èdè" ni orí Èṣù tí òfin náà dúró lé láti pa ẹ̀tọ́ sí òmìnira ọ̀rọ̀ sísọ mọ́.

english: But it does not stop there, the Nigerian government is always right and cannot be criticized.
yoruba: Àmọ́ kò tán síbẹ̀, kò sí ẹní tó lè tako ìjọba Nàìjíríà tàbí gbó o lẹ́nu nítorí kì í ṣ'àṣìṣe.

english: According to Section 3b(vi), any statement that diminishes “public confidence in the performance of any duty or function of, in the exercise of any power of the government” is prohibited.
yoruba: Ní Abala 3b(vi), gbólóhùn tí ó bá yẹpẹrẹ “ojúṣe tàbí ìṣe, tí ó jẹ́ ti ìjọba lójú ará ìlú” kò leè la orí ayélujára kọjá.

english: According to Section 3b(v), this applies to any statement that: "incites feelings of enmity, hatred, directed at persons or ill-will between different groups of persons".
yoruba: Gẹ́gẹ́ bí Abala 3b(v) ti ṣe fi hàn, èyí ní í ṣe pẹ̀lú gbólóhùn tí ó: "fa ìmúnilọ́tàá, tí a sọ sí ẹnìkan tàbí ìtara láàárín àwọn ènìyàn".

english: This is dangerous because it leaves regulators open to contradictory interpretations that could be abused by political actors.
yoruba: Èyí léwu nítorí ó fi àyè gba àwọn onípò àṣẹ láti lo agbára nílòkulò.

english: Who defines and approves what incites feelings of hatred?
yoruba: Ta ní í sọ bóyá gbólóhùn kan lè fa rògbòdìyàn?

english: It means that seeking transparency or even daring to hold a politician accountable could be declared hateful.
yoruba: Ìyẹn túmọ̀ sí wípé lílo inú kan tàbí mímú àwọn olóṣèlúu mú ìléríi wọn ṣe lè já sí ìkórìíra lójúu wọn.

english: The punishment upon conviction for any provisions of the bill is a fine that ranges between 200,000 and 10 million naira [about $556 to $28,000 United States dollars], imprisonment for a term not exceeding three years or both.
yoruba: Owó ìtanràn fún ẹni tí ilé ẹjọ́ bá dá lẹ́bi tó láàárín ẹgbẹ̀rún 200 àti ẹgbẹẹgbẹ̀rún 10 owó naira [tí ó tó $556 sí $28,000 owó orílẹ̀ èdèe United States], ìtìmọ́lé fún ọdún mẹ́ta tàbí méjèèjì.

english: Police licensed to shut down the internet
yoruba: Àṣẹ fún Àjọ Agbófinró láti ṣán ẹ̀rọ ayélujára pa fúngbà díẹ̀

english: The social media bill also grants the government unlimited power to switch off the internet, through the "Access Blocking Order" as contained in Section 12, number 3:
yoruba: Ìwé àbádòfin ìlò ẹ̀rọ alátagbà náà fún ìjọba lágbára bí ó ṣe hù wọ́n láti ṣán ẹ̀rọ ayélukára bí ajere pa nígbàkúùgbà tí ó bá lérò wípé ó tọ́, nípasẹ̀ "Àṣẹ Ìdígàgá Ìráyè" láti lo ayélujára bí ó ti ṣe wà ní Abala 12, òǹkaye 3:

english: The Law Enforcement Department may direct the NCC [Nigerian Communications Commission – the regulatory agency for the telecommunication industry] to order the internet access service provider to take reasonable steps to disable access by end-users in Nigeria.
yoruba: Ẹ̀ka Agbófinró leè fi àṣẹ fún Àjọ Ìgbóhùnsáfẹ́fẹ́ Nàìjíríà NCC [Nigerian Communications Commission – tí ó ń ṣe bòńkárí ìtàkùrọ̀sọ orí ẹ̀rọ ayárabíàṣá] láti pa á láṣẹ fún apèsè àyè sí ìlò ẹ̀rọ ayélujára kí ó gbé ìgbésẹ̀ lójú ẹsẹ̀ tí ò ní mú àwọn òǹlò rí àyè lo ayélujára ní Nàìjíríà.

english: Internet service providers must comply with this blocking order or risk upon conviction a fine within the range of 5 to 10 million naira [$14,000-28,000 USD].
yoruba: Àwọn apèsè ayélujára gbọdọ̀ tẹ̀lé òfin ìdígàgá yìí tàbí kí wọ́n ó sanwó ìtanràn tí ó tó ẹgbẹẹgbẹ̀rún 5 sí 10 owó naira [$14,000-28,000 USD].

english: In addition, the bill under consideration indemnifies the internet service providers from any "civil or criminal liability" incurred from a lawsuit brought against them for "complying to any access blocking order", according to section 12, number 5.
yoruba: Ní àfikún, ìwé àbádòfin náà fi àrídájú ààbò bo àwọn apèsè iṣẹ́ ẹ̀rọ ayélujára tí kò ní mú wàhálà "ará ìlú tàbí bẹ́ẹ̀ " tí kò bá à lè jáde láti ìdájọ́ kan tí ẹnikẹ́ni kò bá pè wọ́n fúnopé "wọ́n tẹ̀lé òfin ìdígàgá ìráyé" sí ayélujára, ìyẹn bí abala 12, òǹkaye 5 ṣe fi lélẹ̀.

english: The human rights violations get murkier because the law grants the police a legal license to command an access-blocking order at whim.
yoruba: Ìtẹ́rí ẹ̀tọ́ ọmọnìyàn náà ṣ'ókùnkùn sí i nítorí wípé òfin náà gba àwọn ọlọ́pàá láyè lábẹ́ òfin láti pa àṣẹ ìdígàgá-àyè bí ó ti ṣe hù wọ́n.

english: Section 15a states that only the "initiative" of the police in face of "overwhelming sufficing evidence" is needed to cancel an internet shutdown in the country.
yoruba: Abala 15a sọ wípé “iṣẹ́ ọpọlọ” ọlọ́pàá ní àsìkò "ìṣèwádìí ẹ̀rí tó dájú" jẹ́ kókó láti fagilé ìṣánpá ẹ̀rọ ayélujára ní orílẹ̀ èdè náà.

english: Consequently, "no appeal may be made to the High Court" [Section 13(2)] by any party to revoke such a ban without first applying to the police to revoke an existing blocking order.
yoruba: Ní ìparí, “kò sí àyè fún ẹjọ́ọ kò tèmi lọ́rùn ní Ilé-ẹjọ́ Gíga” [Abala 13(2)] tí eẹnikẹ́ni lè fi yẹ ìdígàgá sílẹ̀ láì máà kọ́kọ́ tọ ọlọ́pàá lọ láti fagilé òfin ìdígàgá náà.

english: The implications of this are obvious — no one can resort to the courts for redress in the face of this violation while the blocking order persists.
yoruba: Ipa èyí hàn gbàgàdà — ẹnikẹ́ni kò ní leè gba ilé ẹjọ́ lọ fún ìgbèjà ìfẹ̀tọ́ ẹni dunni yìí tí ìdígàgá náà ṣì wà.

english: The lawmakers behind the social media bill
yoruba: Àwọn aṣojú-ṣòfin tí ó wà lẹ́yìn ìwé àbádòfin ẹ̀rọ alátagbà náà

english: Three lawmakers seem to be the arrowhead of the bill in the Senate, the upper house of Nigeria’s parliament: Mohammed Sani Musa (the sponsor of the bill), Abba Moro and Elisha Abbo.
yoruba: Àwọn aṣojú-ṣòfin mẹ́ta kan ni ó gbé ìwé àbádòfin náà sórí nínú ìgbìmọ̀, ilé ìgbìmọ̀ àgbà: Mohammed Sani Musa (agbátẹrùu ìwé àbádòfin), Abba Moro àti Elisha Abbo.

english: Mohammed Sani Musa’s company, Activate Technologies Limited, supplied the Permanent Voter Cards (PVCs) machine used for the 2019 general elections, while he was the candidate of the ruling All Progressives Congress (APC) for Niger East Senatorial district, according to the investigate outlet, Premium Times.
yoruba: Ilé-iṣẹ́ẹ Mohammed Sani Musa, Activate Technologies Limited, ni ó kó ẹ̀rọ Ìwé-pélébé Ìdìbò Alálòpẹ́ (PVCs) tí a lò fún ìbò ọdún-un 2019, nígbà tí ó jẹ́ òǹdíjedupò lábẹ́ ẹgbẹ́ olóṣèlúu tí ó ń tukọ̀ ètò ìṣèlú lọ́wọ́ All Progressives Congress (APC) fún Aṣojú Ìlà-Oòrùn Niger, ìyẹn gẹ́gẹ́ bí ilé iṣẹ́ aṣèwádìí, Premium Times ṣe tẹ̀ ẹ́ jáde.

english: This is an allegation that the Independent National Electoral Commission (INEC) admitted.
yoruba: Àjọ Elétò (INEC) gba ẹ̀sùn náà mọ́ra.

english: Musa’s conflict of interest raised some doubts about the true independence of Nigeria’s election umpire in the last election.
yoruba: Ọ̀ràn yìí fi hàn pé àwọn alákòóso ìbò tí ó kọjá kò ṣiṣẹ́ láì lọ́wọ́ àwọn alágbára ń'nú.

english: Ishaku Elisha Abbo of the opposition People’s Democratic Party (PDP) is a senator representing the Adamawa North Senatorial District in Adamawa State, in northeast Nigerian.
yoruba: Ishaku Elisha Abbo ti ẹgbẹ́ alátakò People’s Democratic Party (PDP) jẹ́ aṣojú tí ó ń ṣojú Ẹkùn-un Àríwá Adamawa ní Ìpínlẹ̀ Adamawa, ní ìlà-oòrùn àríwá orílẹ̀ èdèe Nàìjíríà.

english: In July 2019, in the presence of a police officer, Abbo assaulted a female staff member in an adult sex toy store in Abuja.
yoruba: Nínú oṣù Agẹmọ 2019, ní ìṣojú ọlọ́pàá, Abbo ṣe àṣemáṣe pẹ̀lú òṣìṣẹ́bìnrin kan nínú ìsọ̀ ohun ìbálòpọ̀ ní olú-ìlú Nàìjíríà ní Abuja.

english: After a video of the assault went viral on social media, Abbo offered a public apology.
yoruba: Lẹ́yìn tí àwòrán càṣemáṣe náà fọ́n ká sórí ẹ̀rọ alátagbà, Abbo offered mọ ìwàa rẹ̀ lẹ́bí, ó sì bẹ̀bẹ̀.

english: Abba Moro, also with the PDP, is the senator representing Benue South district, northcentral Nigeria.
yoruba: Abba Moro, tí í ṣe ọmọ ẹgbẹ́ẹ PDP, ni aṣojú fún ẹ̀ka Gúúsù Benue, àárín gbùngbùn àríwá Nàìjíríà.

english: On March 15, 2014, Moro, as minister of interior, was responsible for the Nigerian Immigration Recruitment tragedy in which about 6 million Nigerian youths who applied for 4,000 vacant positions in Nigerian Immigration Service were forced to assemble in various recruitment locations in the country.
yoruba: Ní ọjọ́ 15, oṣù Ẹrẹ́nà, ọdún-un 2014, Moro, tí í ṣe ọ̀gá pátápátá ètò abélé, ló wà nídìí ìṣẹ̀lẹ̀ abanilọ́kànjẹ́ Ìgbanisíṣẹ́ Ẹ̀ṣọ̀ aṣọ́bodè Nàìjíríà tí àwọn ọ̀dọ́langba tí ó tó bíi ẹgbẹẹgbẹ̀rún 6 tó fẹ́ àyè iṣẹ́ ẹgbẹ̀rún 4 tí ó ṣí sílẹ̀ nínú iléeṣẹ́ Ẹ̀ṣọ̀ Aṣọ́bodè Nàìjíríà tí wọ́n kóra jọ níbi orísìírísìí jákèjádò orílẹ̀ èdè náà.

english: The resulting stampede due to overcrowding led to about 20 deaths and multiple injuries.
yoruba: Ìṣẹ̀lẹ̀ tí ó burúkú jáì náà tí ó ṣekú pa ogún ènìyàn àti ìpalára fún ọ̀pọ̀ èèyàn.

english: Moro was a recipient of part of the application fees paid by the job-seekers amounting to 675 million naira [about $1.8 million USD].
yoruba: Moro gbà nínú of owó ìwáṣẹ̀ tí àwọn awáṣẹ́ san tí ó ń lọ bíi ẹgbẹẹgbẹ̀rún 675 owóo naira [ $1.8 USD].

english: Moro not only enriched himself but also bypassed the extant procurement laws for the Immigration Service.
yoruba: Moro kó owó sápòo rẹ̀ bẹ́ẹ̀ náà ó fo òfin ìgbanǹkan Aṣọ́bodè dá.

english: "No need for silence, fear or self-pity" – #SayNoToSocialMediaBill!
yoruba: "Kò nílò ìdákẹ́ jẹ́jẹ́, ìbẹ̀rù bojo tàbí ìkáàánú-araẹni" – #SayNoToSocialMediaBill!

english: Using the hashtag #SayNoToSocialMediaBill, Nigerian netizens took to Twitter to express their collective indignation:
yoruba: Nípa lílo àmì #SayNoToSocialMediaBill, àwọn ọmọ orí ayélujára orílẹ̀ èdèe Nàìjíríà bọ́ sóríi Twitter láti sọ èrò ọkàn-an wọn:

english: In a statement, Amnesty International condemned the use of "laws to justify human rights violations" because it will not only stop Nigerians "from speaking their minds" but will also "send them to jail for doing so".
yoruba: Nínú gbólóhùn kan, Amnesty International fajúro sí lílo "àwọn òfin tí ó ń fìdìí ìfojú ẹ̀tọ́ ọmọnìyàn gbolẹ̀ múlẹ̀ " nítorí pé kò ní pa àwọn ọmọ Nàìjíríà lẹ́nu mọ́ "láti máà sọ èrò ọkàn-an wọn" tí yóò sì tún "rán wọn lọ s'ẹ́wọ̀n fún wípé wọ́n ṣe bẹ́ẹ̀ ".

english: The parliament, under the pretext of curbing mis- and disinformation, is considering the enactment of a draconian law.
yoruba: Lábẹ́ àbùradà à ń dẹ́kun gbólóhùn irọ́ àti ọ̀rọ̀ àhesọ, ń gbèrò ìṣòfin tí kò ní ìfẹ́ ará ìlú lọ́kàn.

english: Ironically, the greatest propagators of false information online are political actors.
yoruba: Ó jẹ́ ohun ìyàlẹ́nu, àwọn olóṣèlúu ló léwájú níbi ká gbé gbólóhùn irọ́ sórí ayélujára.

english: Both Nigeria's ruling and main opposition parties turned Twitter into a minefield of ethnic hate speech, disinformation and propaganda during the 2019 presidential elections.
yoruba: Ẹgbẹ́ olóṣèlúu tí ó ń jẹ lọ́wọ́ àti ẹgbẹ́ alátakò gbòógì sọ Twitter di pápá ogun fa ọ̀rọ̀ ìkórìíra ẹlẹ́yàmẹ́lẹ́yá, ìròyìn tí kò pójú òṣùwọ̀n àti ọ̀rọ̀ ẹ̀tàn lásìkò ìdìbò ààrẹ ọdún-un 2019.

english: Read more:
yoruba: Kà síwájú sí i:

english: Social media propelled ethnocentric disinformation and propaganda during the Nigerian elections
yoruba: Ẹ̀rọ alátagbà fa ọ̀rọ̀ ìkórìíra ẹlẹ́yàmẹ́lẹ́yá, ìròyìn tí kò pójú òṣùwọ̀n àti ọ̀rọ̀ ẹ̀tàn lásìkò ìdìbò ààrẹ ọdún-un 2019

english: Twitter was a minefield of false information during the 2019 Nigerian elections
yoruba: Twitter di pápá ogun fún gbólóhùn irọ́ lásìkò ìdìbò orílẹ̀-èdèe Nàìjíríà ọdún-un 2019

english: In these troubling times of freedom of expression in Nigeria, the wise charge from American writer Toni Morrison evokes hope:
yoruba: Ní àkókò bíi ti òmìnira ọ̀rọ̀ sísọ ní Nàìjíríà tí a wà yìí, ọ̀rọ̀ ọlọ́pọlọ láti ẹnu òǹkọ̀wé orílẹ̀-èdèe Amẹ́ríkà Toni Morrison tí ó mú ìrétí dání:

english: This is precisely the time when artists go to work. There is no time for despair, no place for self-pity, no need for silence, no room for fear.
yoruba: ‎Èyí ni ìgbà tí àwọn ayàwòrán ń ṣiṣẹ́. Kò sáyé fún ìsọ̀rètínù, kò sáyé fún ìkáàánú-ara, kò nílò ìdákẹ́ jẹ́jẹ́, kò sí àyè fún ìbẹ̀rù bojo.

english: We speak, we write, we do language.
yoruba: A sọ, a kọ, a p'èdè.

english: The bill is currently at its second reading in the Senate. To become law, it will need to move to committee stage where legislators will review it.
yoruba: Ìwé àbádòfin ìlò ẹ̀rọ alátagbà náà ti jẹ́ kíkà ní ìgbà kejì nínú ìgbìmọ̀ Aṣojú-ṣòfin.

english: The committee presents its report to Parliament, the bill is debated, a clean copy is re-presented to the Senate for a final vote and then, there's the presidential assent.
yoruba: Kí ó tó di òfin, ó gbọdọ̀ gba ìgbìmọ̀ kan tí àwọn aṣojú-ṣòfin yóò yẹ̀ ẹ́ wò. Ìgbìmọ̀ọtẹ̀ẹ́kótó náà yóò sì jábọ̀ àbájáde àyẹ̀wòo rẹ̀ fún Ìgbìmọ̀ àgbà, láti gbé e yẹ̀ wò, tí wọn yóò tẹ òmíràn jáde fún àyẹ̀wò tí ó kẹ́yìn, kí ààrẹ ó tó bu ọwọ́ lù ú.

english: The Parliament must be hard-pressed to throw out the social media bill in its entirety.
yoruba: A gbọdọ̀ fajú ro sí ìgbésẹ̀ Ìgbìmọ̀ kí wọ́n ba ju ìwé àbádòfin ìlò ẹ̀rọ alátagbà náà dànù sígbó.

english: This is because Africa’s most populous country will slide smoothly into full dictatorship once freedom of expression has been extinguished.
yoruba: Nítorí orílẹ̀ èdèe tí ó gbajúmọ̀ jù lọ nílẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀ yóò yẹ̀ gẹ̀rẹ̀ sí ìjọba ìfipámúnisìn ní kété tí òmìnira ọ̀rọ̀ sísọ bá di títẹ̀ bọlẹ̀.

english: Tanzania high court upholds ruling to end child marriage despite attempts to repeal it
yoruba: Ilé ẹjọ́ gíga Tanzania pa á láṣẹ fún ìfòpinsí ìsoyìgì láàárín àgbàlagbà àti ọmọdé láì wo ti ìgbésẹ̀ ìmúpadàa rẹ̀

english: "This is the best decision the court has ever made"
yoruba: "Èyí ni ìpinnu tí ó dára jù lọ tí ilé-ẹjọ́ yóò ṣe"

english: Schoolgirls in Tanzania pose for a photo on July 10, 2007. Photo by Fanny Schertzer, used with permission via Wikimedia Commons, CC BY 2.0.
yoruba: Àwọn Ọmọiléèwé ọmọdébìnrin ní Tanzania dúró fún àwòrán lọ́jọ́ 10 oṣù Agẹmọ ọdún-un, 2007. Fanny Schertzer ni ó ya àwòrán, a lò ó pẹ̀lú àṣẹ láti Wikimedia Commons, CC BY 2.0.

english: In October 2019, Tanzania's high court upheld the landmark 2016 ruling that increased the minimum age of marriage for girls and boys to 18.
yoruba: Nínú oṣù Ọ̀wàrà 2019, ilé ẹjọ́ gíga Tanzania ṣe ìdímú ṣinṣin ìdájọ́ ọdún-un 2016 tí ó pàṣẹ ó kéré jù, ọmọbìnrin àti ọmọkùnrin gbọdọ̀ pé ọmọ ọdún méjìdínlógún kí ó tó ṣe ìgbéyàwó.

english: The Tanzanian government attempted to repeal this decision, claiming that girls mature earlier and marriage is a form of protection for pregnant young women, and should, therefore, be allowed to marry earlier than 18.
yoruba: Àjọ ọba orílẹ̀ èdèe Tanzania gbéègbésẹ̀ láti ṣe ìmúpadà ìpinnu yìí, nítorí wípé àwọn ọmọdébìnrin ń yára bàlágà àti wípé ààbò ni ìgbéyàwó jẹ́ fún ọ̀dọ́bìnrin aláboyún.

english: But on October 23, 2019, the Tanzanian government lost its appeal and the high court ruling remains: The marriage age for both males and females is 18, reinforcing the ban on child marriage in Tanzania.
yoruba: Àmọ́ ní ọjọ́ 23 oṣù Ọ̀wàrà ọdún-un 2019, ìjọba orílẹ̀ èdèe Tanzania pàdánù ẹjọ́ọ kòtẹ́milọ́rùnun rẹ̀ tí àṣẹ ilé ẹjọ́ gíga ṣì dúró: akọ àtabo gbọdọ̀ pé ọjọ́ orí méjìdínlógún kí wọn ó tó ṣe ìgbéyàwó, tí èyí sì ń fi agbára kún ìgbẹ́sẹ̀ ìsoyìgì ọmọdé ní Tanzania.

english: According to the United Nations Population Fund (UNFPA), Tanzania has one of the highest prevalence rates of child marriage in the world.
yoruba: Gẹ́gẹ́ bí United Nations Population Fund (UNFPA) ti ṣe wí, Tanzania ni ìsoyìgì ọmọdé pọ̀ sí jù lọ lágbàáyé.

english: Netizens were quick to express their delight over the ruling.
yoruba: Àwọn ọmọ orí ayélujára ṣíra láti fi ìdùnnúu wọn hàn lóríi ìdájọ́ náà.

english: Some congratulated Rebeca Z. Gyumi, the petitioner and respondent behind this case.
yoruba: Àwọn kan kí Rebeca Z. Gyumi, aláfisùn àti ẹni tí ó lé wájú nínú ọ̀ràn ìsoyìgì àwọn ọmọdé náà.

english: Gyumi is the founder and executive director of Msichana Initiative (Young Woman Initiative), a Tanzanian nongovernmental organization that empowers girls through education.
yoruba: Gyumi ni olùdásílẹ̀ àti alákòóso àgbà Msichana Initiative (Ètò fún àwọn Ọ̀dọ́mọbìnrin), iléeṣẹ́ tí kì í ṣe tìjọba tí ó ń ró àwọn ọmọdébìnrin lágbára nípasẹ̀ ti ẹ̀kọ́ ìwé.

english: The fight to end child marriage in Tanzania
yoruba: Ìgbésẹ̀ láti fòpin sí ìsoyìgì ọmọdé ní Tanzania

english: In 2016, Gyumi challenged the constitutionality of the Law of Marriage Act, 2002 (LMA) that allowed females under the age of 18 to get married.
yoruba: Lọ́dún-un 2016, Gyumi na ọwọ́ ìka àbùkù sí agbára Òfin Ìgbéyàwó; Law of Marriage Act, 2002 (LMA) tí ó gba obìnrin tí kò tó ọmọ ọdún méjìdínlógún láyè láti ṣe ìgbéyàwó.

english: According to Tanzania Demographic and Health Survey (TDHS),  36 percent of women aged 25-49 get married before their 18th birthday compared to only 5 percent for men the same age.
yoruba: Gẹ́gẹ́ bí ìwádìí nípa ìlera Tanzania Demographic and Health Survey (TDHS) ṣe ti ṣàlàyé, ìdá 36 obìnrin tí ọjọ́ oríi wọ́n wà ní 25-49 ní í ṣe ìgbéyàwó kí wọn ó tó pé ọmọ ọdún méjìdínlógún, tí àwọn akẹgbẹ́ẹ wọn lọ́kùnrin sí jẹ́ ìdá 5.

english: The LMA allowed girls as young as 14 to get married with consent from a court and age 15 with the consent of the parents whereas 18 years was the minimum age for a male.
yoruba: Òfin LMA fi àyè gba ọmọdébìnrin tí ọjọ́ oríi wọn kò ju ọdún mẹ́rìnlá lọ láti ṣe ìgbéyàwó pẹ̀lú ìlọ́wọ́sí ilé-ẹjọ́, ìlọ́wọ́sí òbí fún ọmọ ọdún márùn-ún-dínlógún, nígbà tí ọdún méjìdínlógún jẹ́ ọjọ́ orí tí ó kéré jù lọ fún ọmọkùnrin.

english: Through her attorneys, Gyumi argued that the LMA provisions were discriminatory for giving preferential treatment to males in the matter of eligible marriage age.
yoruba: Nípasẹ̀ àwọn aṣojú rẹ̀, Gyumi ṣàlàyé wípé àlàálẹ̀ LMA kọ iyán obìnrin kéré nítorí pé ó fún àwọn ọkùnrin ní àǹfààní ju àwọn obìnrin lọ.

english: They further argued that the provisions infringed the right to equality and they were too vague and too susceptible to arbitrary interpretation to deny female children their right to education.
yoruba: Nítẹ̀síwájú, wọ́n sọ wípé àlàálẹ̀ náà fi ẹ̀tọ́ dídọ́gba ọmọ ènìyàn yí ẹrẹ̀fọ̀ àti pé wọn fi ẹ̀tọ́ àǹfààní sí ẹ̀kọ́ ìwé dun àwọn ọmọdébìnrin.

english: Gyumi petitioned the High Court to find the provisions of LMA null and void.
yoruba: Gyumi rọ Ilé-ẹjọ́ Gíga láti gbé àlàálẹ̀ LMA tì sẹ́gbẹ̀ẹ́.

english: The High Court never declared the provisions in the LMA null and void.
yoruba: Ilé-ẹjọ́ Gíga kò ṣe bẹ́ẹ̀.

english: But they found the provisions unconstitutional and gave the government one year to correct the anomalies in the LMA provisions.
yoruba: Àmọ́ wọ́n rí i lóòótọ́ wípé kò bá òfin mu wọ́n sì fún ìjọba lọ́dún kan láti ṣe àtúnṣe sí ohun tí kò tọ̀nà nínú àlàálẹ̀ LMA.

english: Through the attorney general, the government was directed to put 18 years as the eligible age of marriage for both females and males.
yoruba: Nípasẹ̀ aṣojú àgbà àwọn adájọ́, a pa ìjọba láṣẹ láti gbé ọjọ́ orí ìgbéyàwó sí ọdún méjìdínlógún fún obìnrin àti ọkùnrin.

english: However, then-Attorney General George Masaju was aggrieved by the ruling and immediately served a notice of appeal to the High Court:
yoruba: Síbẹ̀, aṣojú àgbà àná banújẹ́ sí ìdájọ́ náà ó sì kọ ìwé àtúnpè-ẹjọ́ sí Ilé-ẹjọ́ Gíga náà:

english: Official: I've been served government documents of appeal in the case of #childmarriage. Case number 204 of September 2017.
yoruba: Pẹ̀lú ìfọwọ́sí àṣẹ ìjọba: mo ti gba ìwé àtúnpè-ẹjọ́ lóríi ẹjọ́ #childmarriage. Ẹjọ́ òǹkaye 204 ti oṣù Ọ̀wẹwẹ̀ ọdún-un 2017.

english: Read more: Mozambique criminalizes child marriage
yoruba: Kà síwájú sí i: Mozambique sọ ìsoyìgì ọmọdé di ìwà ọ̀daràn

english: Grounds for appeal
yoruba: Àyè fún àtúnpè-ẹjọ́

english: In four months of court proceedings, the government sought to appeal the 2016 ruling that required the revision of the provisions LMA that allowed girls to be married at the age of 15.
yoruba: Láàárín oṣù mẹ́rin ìgbẹ́jọ́, ìjọba gbèrò láti ṣe àtúnpè-ẹjọ́ ọdún-un 2016 tí yó ṣe àtúnṣe sí àlàálẹ̀ LMA èyí tí ó fi àyè gba ọmọdébìnrin ọlọ́jọ́-orí márùn-úndínlógún gẹ́gẹ́ bí ẹni tí ó ti bàlágà fún ìgbéyàwó.

english: The appellant, represented by principal state attorneys, Mark Mulwambo and Alesia Mbuya, provided biological differences and customary and Islamic laws as grounds for the appeal.
yoruba: Atẹ́jọ́pè, tí ó jẹ́ aṣojú àwọn adájọ́ ìpínlẹ̀, Mark Mulwambo àti Alesia Mbuya, ṣe àgbékalẹ̀ ìyàtọ̀ ìwà ẹ̀dá obìnrin àti ọkùnrin tí wọ́n sì fi àṣà ìbílẹ̀ àti òfin ẹ̀sìn Ìmàle gbá àtúnpè-ẹjọ́ náà nídìí.

english: Ms. Mbuya argued that biological differences put boys and girls in "different categories" and that therefore, the law treats them differently.
yoruba: Ms. Mbuya sọ wípé ìyàtọ̀ ìwà ẹ̀dá fi ọmọdékùnrin àti ọmọdébìnrin sí "ìsọ̀rí ọ̀tọ̀ọ̀tọ̀ " àti pé, òfin fi ojú ọ̀tọ̀ọ̀tọ̀ wò wọ́n.

english: She argued that because girls matured earlier, the law took that into consideration. She argued that marriage could protect unmarried girls who get pregnant at an early age.
yoruba: Ó sọ síwájú sí i wípé nítorí àwọn ọmọdébìnrin máa ń tètè bàlágà ju ọmọdékùnrin lọ ni òfin fi la àlàálẹ̀ bẹ́ẹ̀. Ó sọ wípé ìgbéyàwó lè fi ààbò bo ọmọdébìnrin tí kò sí nílé ọkọ tí ó ti di abaraméjì láì tó ọjọ́ orí tí ó tọ́.

english: Further, she argued the court erred by “equating the age of the child and the age of marriage,” meaning that the court should consider male and female children differently when it comes to marriageable age.
yoruba: Ó sọ síwájú sí i wípé ilé ẹjọ́ kùnà bí ó ṣe “ṣe ìmúdọ́gbandọ́gba ọjọ́ orí ọmọ àti ọjọ́ orí tí ó yẹ fún ìgbéyàwó”, èyí tí ó túmọ̀ sí wípé ọ̀tọ̀ ni ti tọ́lú ọ̀tọ̀ ni ti tọ́lùú wò, ọ̀tọ̀ ni ó yẹ kí ilé ẹjọ́ ó là kalẹ̀ fún ọjọ́ orí ìgbéyàwó ọkùnrin àti obìnrin.

english: Netizens were quick to criticize the grounds the appellant provided in court.
yoruba: Àwọn ọmọ orí ayélujára ti yára bu ẹnu àtẹ́ lu ìdí tí àtẹ́jọ́pè fi sílẹ̀ nínú ìgbẹ́jọ́.

english: Read more: Mozambique, Cote d'Ivoire make legal strides for women and children’s rights
yoruba: Kà síwájú sí i: Mozambique, Cote d'Ivoire gbé ìgbésẹ̀ akọni fún ẹ̀tọ́ àwọn obìnrin àti ọmọdé

english: Gender equality
yoruba: Dídọ̀gba abo atakọ

english: The court’s ruling is a step toward eliminating harmful practices and ending all forms of discrimination against girls in Tanzania.
yoruba: Ìdájọ́ ilé ẹjọ́ náà jẹ́ atọ́ka sí ìfòpinsí àwọn àṣà tí ó ń mú ìpalára bá àwọn ọmọdébìnrin àti onírúurú ẹlẹ́yàmẹyà tòun ìfọwọ́rọ́sẹ́yìn àwọn ọmọdébìnrin ní Tanzania.

english: According to the United Nations, in order to achieve gender equality by 2030, governments need to change discriminatory laws and adopt legislation that proactively advances equality.
yoruba: Ní ti àjọ United Nations, kí a tó lè yege níbi ti dídọ́gba abo atakọ ní ọdún-un 2030, ìjọba ní láti ṣe àyípadà òfin ìyàsọ́tọ̀ọtọ̀ àti ṣíṣe àmúlò ìṣòfin tí yóò mú ìmúdọ́gba tí à ń sọ wáyé.

english: Data shows that the age of marriage is directly related to levels of education and wealth (TDHS 201).
yoruba: Àbájáde ìwádìí ṣe àfihàn-an rẹ̀ wípé ọjọ́ orí tí ó tọ́ láti ṣe ìgbéyàwó bá ìpele ìwé tí ènìyàn kà àti ọrọ̀ tí ènìyán ti kó jọ (TDHS 201) tan.

english: In Tanzania, there is a 6-year difference between the age of marriage between girls with no education and girls with secondary or higher education.
yoruba: Ní Tanzania, ó ní ìyàtọ̀ ọdún mẹ́fà tí ó wà láàárín ọmọdébìnrin tí kò lọ sí ilé ìwé àti àwọn tí ó ka ìwé gíga tàbí ìwé gíga jù lọ.

english: In Tanzania, it is illegal to impregnate or marry schoolgirls with 30-year imprisonment as punishment.
yoruba: Ní Tanzania, ohun tí kò bá òfin mu ni kí a fẹ́ tàbí fún akẹ́kọ̀ọ́bìnrin lóyún, ẹ̀wọ̀n ọgbọ̀n ọdún ni ẹní bá tasẹ̀ àgẹ̀rẹ̀ sófin yóò fi gbára.

english: Pregnant schoolgirls are not allowed to return to school even after they have given birth.
yoruba: Akẹ́kọ̀ọ́bìnrin tí ó bá lóyún kì í padà sí ilé ìwé pàápàá tí ó bá bímọ tán.

english: The ban on child marriage will protect all girls, regardless of their school enrollment status.
yoruba: Ìfòfinde ìsoyìgì pẹ̀lú ọmọdé máa ń fi ààbò fún àwọn ọmọdébìnrin, láì ro bí wọ́n ṣe wọ ilé ìwé.

english: In Tanzania, child marriage bars girls from education and leads to school dropout, according to data from the Tanzania National Survey, 2017).
yoruba: Ní Tanzania, ìgbéyàwó ọmọdébìnrin kì í jẹ kí ọmọdébìnrin ó kàwé tí wọn kò sì ní àǹfààní láti parí ẹ̀kọ́ọ wọn, gẹ́gẹ́ bí èsì ìwádìí láti Tanzania National Survey, 2017 ṣe ní i lákọsílẹ̀.

english: This ban creates better conditions for schoolgirls to finish school without barriers.
yoruba: Ìfòfinde ìsoyìgì yìí ṣe àgbékalẹ̀ ìgbé ayé tó dára fún akẹ́kọ̀ọ́bìnrin láti parí ẹ̀kọ́ọ wọn láì sí ìdádúró.

english: Even so, impregnated schoolgirls are still faced with an unconstitutional ruling that prohibits them from returning to school.
yoruba: Pẹ̀lú bẹ́ẹ̀, akẹ́kọ̀ọ́bìnrin tí ó bá fẹ́rakù ṣì ń kojú òfin tí ó ní wọn kò gbọdọ̀ padà wá sílé ìwé.

english: Kanye West's use of Jamaican symbols sparks national dialogue on ‘branding’
yoruba: Ààmì ìdánimọ̀ orílẹ̀ èdèe Jamaica tí Kanye West lò di awuyewuye tí ó dá fìrìgbagbòó lórí ‘ìsààmì’

english: Jamaica-themed merchandise appeared in the online store
yoruba: Ẹrù ọjà pẹ̀lú àkórí nípa Jamaica di títà lórí ayélujára

english: Kanye West performs at The Museum of Modern Art's annual Party in the Garden benefit, New York City, May 10, 2011. Photo by Jason Persse, CC BY-SA 2.0.
yoruba: Kanye West ń kọrin níbi ayẹyẹ ọlọ́dọọdún Ilé-ọnà ti Ọnà Ìgbàlódé ní Garden benefit, New York City, ọjọ́ 10, oṣù karùn-ún, 2011. Àwòrán láti ọwọ́ọ Jason Persse, CC BY-SA 2.0.

english: American rapper Kanye West brought his "Sunday Service" pop-up concert to Kingston, Jamaica, at the start of its National Heroes Day holiday weekend (October 19-21, 2019).
yoruba: Ọ̀kọrin tàkasúfèé tí ó jẹ́ ọmọ orílẹ̀ èdèe Amẹ́ríkà Kanye West gbé àríyá "Ìsìn Ọjọ́ Ọ̀sẹ̀ " pop-up concert wá sí Kingston, Jamaica, ní kété tí ìsinmi ọjọ́ ọ̀sẹ̀ fún Àyájọ́ Ọjọ́ Àwọn Málegbàgbé Ọmọ Orílẹ̀-èdè náà (19-21, oṣù Ọ̀wàrà ọdún-un 2019) yóò bẹ̀rẹ̀.

english: This was the first time the rapper had taken his huge gospel choir outside the United States, reportedly at the request of a Jamaican member of his staff.
yoruba: Èyí ni ìgbà àkọ́kọ́ tí ọ̀kọrin náà yóò kó ẹgbẹ́ akọrin ìyìnrere rẹ̀ kúrò ní Amẹ́ríkà, ní ìjẹ́pèe ti agbè fún ìjọba orílẹ̀ èdèe kan tí ó Ja kí ó gbé ètò náà wá sílùú òun.

english: However, the event was besieged with criticism from the outset, culminating with West's unapproved use of Jamaican emblems on merchandise being sold on his website.
yoruba: Síbẹ̀, àríyá náà tí rí ìtakò láti ìbẹ̀rẹ̀ pẹ̀pẹ̀, tí ó Ho forí sọlẹ̀ pẹ̀lú àmì ìdánimọ̀ọ orílè-èdèe Jamaica tí West we lórí ọjà tí ó ń tà lóríi ibùdó ìtakùn àgbáyée rẹ̀ láì gba àṣẹ láti lò ó.

english: With just two days’ notice, the free concert took place at Emancipation Park in Kingston, the capital city — a location that jarred some commentators because of controversial comments West had made about slavery during a media interview in May 2018.
yoruba: Láàárín ọjọ́ méjì ni ìkéde fi lọ síta, inúu gbàgede Emancipation Park tó wà ní Kingston, olú ìlú orílẹ̀ èdè náà ni bẹbẹ́ ti wáyé — ojú ibi tí ó mú àwọn sọ̀rọ̀sọ̀rọ̀ kan wí tẹnu wọn látàrí àwọn ọ̀rọ̀ tó mú àríyànjiyàn dání tí West sọ nípa òwò ẹrú nínú ìfọ̀rọ̀wánilẹ́nuwò kan báyìí lóṣù karùn-ún ọdún-un 2018.

english: The park was opened in 2002 in honour of the "full freedom" of 300,000 slaves in Jamaica on August 1, 1838.
yoruba: Ọdún-un 2002 ni gbàgede náà di lílò ní ìbọ̀wọ̀ fún "òmìnira dójú àmì" fún àwọn ẹrú 300,000 ní Jamaica lọ́jọ́ 1, oṣù kẹjọ ọdún-un 1838.

english: That may have been the first bone of contention around the concert, but it was not the last.
yoruba: Ó lè jẹ́ èyí gan-an ni oun àkọ́kọ́ nípa àríyá orin náà, ṣùgbọ́n òun kọ́ ni ó gbẹ̀yìn.

english: Even as Culture Minister Olivia "Babsy" Grange responded to early criticism by saying the country was benefitting from the concert, one music promoter felt the show, which was livestreamed on the Sunday Service website, "upstaged" other cultural activities over Heroes Day weekend.
yoruba: Pàápàá jù lọ bí Olóòtú Ètò Àṣà Olivia "Babsy" Grange ṣe bẹnu-àtẹ́ lu àwọn alátakò nígbà tí ó sọ wípé orílẹ̀ èdè náà ṣe àbápín nínú èrè àríyá náà, ní èyí tí aṣagbátẹrù orin kan lérò wípé àríyá náà tí ó ṣe é wò lójú ẹsẹ̀ bí ó ṣe ń lọ lóríi ìtakùn àgbáyée Ìsìn Ọjọ́ Ọ̀sẹ̀, "gba" àwọn ètò tí ó rọ̀ mọ́ àṣà ìbílẹ̀ tí ó jẹ́ ti Ìsinmi àwọn Málegbàgbé Ọmọ orílẹ̀ èdè sẹ́gbẹ̀ẹ́.

english: In addition, Kingston residents, who suffered unusually heavy traffic flows throughout the week, predicted chaos and confusion during the evening rush hour.
yoruba: Láfikún, àwọn olùgbée Kingston, tí ó bá súnkẹrẹ fàkẹrẹ kòdìmú lọ́sẹ̀ yẹn, fọ àfọ̀tẹ́lẹ̀ làásìgbò àti rọ̀tìrọti bí àwọn tó ṣíwọ́ iṣẹ́ bá ń darí lọ sílé nírọ̀lẹ́.

english: Nevertheless, the concert went smoothly, several thousand Jamaicans  enjoyed the show and Jamaican media companies earned online kudos for their flawless production:
yoruba: Láì sí àní-àní, àríyá náà lọ ní ìrọwọ́-ìrọsẹ̀, ẹgbẹẹgbẹ̀rún lọ́nà ẹgbẹ̀rún àwọn Nev orílẹ̀-èdèe Jamaica gbádùn-un àríyá náà tí àwọn iléeṣẹ́ agbóhùnsáfẹ́fẹ́ orílẹ̀ èdèe Jamaica náà gba ìgbóríyìn fún iṣẹ́ takuntakun tí wọ́n ṣe:

english: Word on the street is that there may be a move by [Sunday Service] to seek patent/ownership rights on the Kingston, Jamaica logos as well as the fabled streamer-tailed humming bird.
yoruba: Ìròyìn etíìgbọ́ ìgboro ni wípé ó ṣeé ṣe kí ìgbésẹ̀ wà láti (Ìsìn Ọjọ́-àìkú) láti gba àsẹ èmi-ni-monií/ẹ̀tọ́ oníhun ààmì ìdánimọ̀ọ Kingston, orílẹ̀ èdè Jamaica àti ti ẹyẹ olùlànà onírù gígùn.

english: I have done a fair amount of online searches for information to corroborate the claim without luck but have come across their online release of merchandise bearing these landmark symbols, which coincided with the concert...
yoruba: Mo ti ṣe àwọn ìwádìí kan lórí ayélujára tí mo sì ṣe àwárí láti fi ti ẹ̀rí lẹ́yìn àmọ́ kádàrá kò ṣe mí lóore, mo ṣalábàápàdé ọjàa wọn tí wọ́n ń tà lórí ayélujára tó ní àwọn ààmi ìdánimọ̀ wọ̀nyí, tí ó sì ṣe dọ́gba-n-dọ́gba pẹ̀lú àríyá náà...

english: Jamaica’s reality is that successive political administrations have never fully appreciated the economic value of the brand "Jamaica" nor the symbols that [represent] that brand including its flag and its coat of arms.
yoruba: Òtítọ́ orílẹ̀ èdèe Jamaica ni wípé àwọn ìjọba àná kò fi ìgbàkan kọbiara sí ìgbéró èto ọrọ̀ Ajée ‘Jamaica’ tàbí àwọn ààmi ìdánimọ̀ tó jẹ́ ti wọn bíi àsíá àti àsíá apata.

english: The same is true for our music and its associated brand marks, Ska, Mento, Rock Steady, Reggae among others.
yoruba: Bákannáà ni ó rí fún orin wa àti ohun tí ó rọ̀ mọ́, Ska, Mento, Rock Steady, Reggae àti bẹ́ẹ̀ bẹ́ẹ̀ lọ.

english: That Jamaica was blindsided by the release of clothing bearing the island’s important symbols is a classic case of guerilla marketing.
yoruba: Ilẹ̀ Jamaica kò tètè lajú sí òwò aṣọ ṣíṣe tí ó ní ààmì pàtàkì erékùṣù tí yóò mú àwọn ènìyàn rà á wìtìwìtì.

english: Having a concert to promote the line at the historic Emancipation Park provides tacit assent of not only the line of garments by the government and people of Jamaica, but also of the use of the country’s national symbols in their creation.
yoruba: Bí a bá fi ètò àríyá ṣe ìgbélárugẹ àwọn ọjà wọ̀nyí nínúu gbàgede Emancipation Park tí ó mú ìlọsíwájú bá ohun tí ó ju aṣọ lọ láti ọ̀dọ̀ ìjọba àti àwọn ọmọ orílẹ̀ èdèe Jamaica náà, pẹ̀lú lílo àwọn ààmìi orílẹ̀ èdè náà ní ọ̀nà àrà.

english: I have noticed that there is now hurried pushback by the Ministry of Culture as well as from the Mayor of Kingston. Both should realize that this isn’t a bottle that will be easy to re-cork.
yoruba: Mo ti ṣe àkíyèsí wípé Iléeṣẹ́ Ètò Àṣà àti Olùdarí ìlúu Kingston ti ń gbé ìgbésẹ̀ẹ pàjáwìrì láti ra nǹkan padà. Kí àwọn méjèèjì mọ̀ pé àtúnṣe kì í ṣe nǹkan tó ma yá kíákíá.

english: I hope that the government has good lawyers.
yoruba: Mo lérò wípé ìjọba ní àwọn agbẹjọ́rò tó ká ojú òṣùwọ̀n.

english: Indeed, lawyers may still have quite a bit of work to do to untangle the confusion surrounding the use of Jamaica's national symbols.
yoruba: Lóòótọ́, àwọn agbẹjọ́rò ṣì níṣẹ́ láti ṣe láti tú kókó awuyewuye etí aṣọ ti lílo àsíá orílẹ̀ èdèe Jamaica.

english: Deadly police raids in Guinea as President Alpha Condé clings to power
yoruba: Ìrọ́lù ọlọ́pàá tí í mú ikú bá ‘ni ní Guinea bí Ààrẹ Alpha Condé ṣe kọ̀ láì gbé’ jọba sílẹ̀

english: "Cities have been paralyzed"
yoruba: "Ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ ìlú ti kọ̀yìn síjọba lórí ìgbésẹ̀ yìí"

english: Screenshot from a France 24 news flash about the situation in Guinea.
yoruba: Àgékù ohun tí ó ń ṣẹlẹ̀ ní Guinea láti ìròyìn ránpẹ́ France 24 kan.

english: Police violence erupted in Guinea on October 14, resulting in the death of several people and massive arrests, following demonstrations protesting against current president Alpha Condé's plans to modify the constitution to run for a third term.
yoruba: Ìwà ipá bẹ́ sílẹ̀ ní Guinea lọ́jọ́ 14 oṣù Ọ̀wàrà, tí ó ti fa ikú ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ ènìyàn tí wọ́n sì ń kó àwọn ènìyàn kiri lẹ́yìn ìyíde ìféhónúhàn tí ó tako ìjọba ààrẹ tí ó wà lórí oyè ìyẹn Alpha Condé, ẹni tí ó ń gbèrò láti yí ìwé-òfin padà kí ó bá fi ààyè gba òun láti lọ fún ìgbà kẹta.

english: The streets of the capital, Conakry, and other cities have turned into battlefields between law enforcement forces and demonstrators.
yoruba: Ojúu pópó olú ìlú náà, Conakry, àti àwọn ìlú tó kù ti di ojú ogun láàárín àjọ agbófinró àti àwọn ọmọ ìlú tó ń fi èhónú hàn.

english: Police forces have the advantage of new legal privileges that allow them to use deadly force if they deem it necessary for security reasons.
yoruba: Iléeṣẹ́ ọlọ́pàá ti lo àǹfààní tuntun tí ó fún wọn láṣẹ láti lo ohun ìjà aṣekúpani bí ó bá dé ojú ẹ̀.

english: The demonstrations have already killed six people, including one police officer, and wounded many.
yoruba: Àwọn afẹ̀hónúhàn ti rán ẹni mẹ́fà sí ọ̀run àjànto, ní èyí tí ó jẹ́ pé ọlọ́pàá kan wà nínúu àwọn tí ó jẹ́ Ògún nípè, ọ̀pọ̀ èèyàn ló sì fi ara pa.

english: Read more: Security forces in Guinea now have the right to use deadly force
yoruba: Kà síwájú sí i: Àwọn ẹ̀ṣọ́ aláàbò ní Guinea ti ní àṣẹ láti lo ohun ìjà aṣekúpani

english: Demonstrators oppose any change to the constitution seen as an attempt by the president to run legally for a third mandate.
yoruba: Àwọn afẹ̀hónúhàn kò lọ́wọ́ sí kílàńkó àyípadà sí ìwé-òfin tí wọ́n rí gẹ́gẹ́ bí ìgbésẹ̀ ààrẹ láti wà lórí ipò fún ẹlẹ́ẹ̀kẹ́ta.

english: Indeed, the constitution limits the total number of presidential mandates to two in a row. Condé, now 81, should end his mandate in October 2020.
yoruba: Ní tòótọ́, ìwé-òfin náà fi ààyè ọdún méjì gba ẹni tí ó bá wà ní ipò ààrẹ láti ṣèjọba. Condé, ẹni ọdún 81, yẹ kí sáà rẹ̀ ó parí ní oṣù Ọ̀wàrà ọdún-un 2020.

english: Demonstrators are particularly vulnerable as they operate in violation of the law, as Human Rights Watch reminds:
yoruba: Àwọn afẹ̀hónúhàn ni a lè ṣá lọ́gbẹ́ jù lọ nítorí wípé wọ́n tasẹ̀ àgẹ̀rẹ̀ sí òfin náà bí Human Rights Watch ṣe pè fún àkíyèsí:

english: Translation Original Quote
yoruba: Ìtúmọ̀ Ìtúnwí-ọ̀rọ̀ Ọlọ́rọ̀ gan-an

english: The government of Guinea has effectively banned street protests for more than a year, citing threats to public security, Human Rights Watch said today.
yoruba: Human Rights Watch sọ lónìí wípé, ìjọba orílẹ̀-èdèe Guinea ti gbẹ́sẹ̀ lé ìfèhònúhàn l'ójúu pópó fún ọdún kan, ó tọ́ka sí ìdojú-ìjà-kọ ààbò ìlú.

english: Local authorities have prohibited at least 20 political or other demonstrations.
yoruba: Àwọn aláṣẹ ìjọba ìbílẹ̀ ti fọ́n ó tó bíi ogún ìfèhònúhàn ẹgbẹ́ òṣèlú àti àwọn mìíràn ká yángá.

english: Security forces have tear gassed those who defy the ban, and arrested dozens of demonstrators.
yoruba: Àwọn ẹ̀ṣọ́ aláàbò ti sọ tajútajú sí àárín àwọn tí kò gbọ́ràn láti tú wọn ká, wọ́n sì kó àìmọye ènìyàn.

english: Regarding the political situation, the government is delivering conflicting messages: On October 13, President Condé welcomed a dialogue:
yoruba: Ní ti ìṣẹ̀lẹ̀ òṣèlú náà, àjọ ọba náà ń kéde iṣẹ́-ìjẹ́ tí ó ń tako ara wọn: Ní ọjọ́ 13, oṣù Ọ̀wàrà Ààrẹ Condé fẹ́ ìsọ̀rọ̀-ní-tùnbí-ǹ-nùbí:

english: Translation Original Quote
yoruba: Ìtúmọ̀ Ìtúnwí-ọ̀rọ̀ Ọlọ́rọ̀ gan-an

english: Alpha Condé has reiterated his call for a responsible dialogue and for a permanent process of discussions in order to iron out differences and answer all the challenges the country is facing.
yoruba: Alpha Condé ti pè fún ìsọ̀rọ̀ ní tùnbíǹnùbí ó sì fẹ́ kí ìjókòó gẹ́gẹ́ bí tọmọtìyá tí yóò fi pẹ̀lẹ́pùtù yanjú gbọ́nmi-síi-omi-ò-tóo tí ó ń ṣẹlẹ̀ àti ọ̀nà àbáyọ sí àwọn ìpèníjà tí ó ń kojú orílẹ̀-èdè náà.

english: Yet, Ahmed Tidiane Traoré, a presidential counselor, stated the following day on October 12, —two days before the demonstrations started, — to a crowd of RPG youth [ruling Reunion of the People of Guinea party]:
yoruba: Síbẹ̀, Ahmed Tidiane Traoré, olùdámọ̀ràn ipò ààrẹ, sọ lọ́jọ́ tí ó tẹ̀lé e, ìyẹn ní ọjọ́ 12 oṣù Ọ̀wàrà, — ọjọ́ méjì kí ìfẹ̀hònúhàn ó tó bẹ̀rẹ̀, — fún àwọn èrò tó jẹ́ ọ̀dọ́ langba RPG ẹgbẹ́ olóṣèlúu [ruling Reunion of the People of Guinea]:

english: Translation Original Quote
yoruba: Ìtúmọ̀ Ìtúnwí-ọ̀rọ̀ Ọlọ́rọ̀ gan-an

english: We invite the party's youth to remain vigilant in the districts.
yoruba: A rọ àwọn ọ̀dọ́ ẹgbẹ́ òṣèlú náà láti kún fún ìṣọ́ra ní ojúu pópó.

english: They [the opposition activists] have stocked use tires in wholes, we invite young people from the party to get those tires out, prevent them from acting, get those hidden tires, do not attack anyone, do not destroy anything, just defend yourselves.
yoruba: Àwọn [tí àwọn jẹ́ ajìjàngbara alátakò] ti fa ìṣòro, a pe àwọn ìpẹ́ẹ̀rẹ́ láti inú ẹgbẹ́ náà láti wá ọ̀nà àbáyọ sí ìṣòro tó wà nílẹ̀, àmọ́ kí ẹ máà dojú ìjà kọ ẹnikẹ́ni, kí ẹ máà ba dúkìá kankan jẹ́, ju ìdáàbò bo ara yín lọ.

english: All evil-doers will be found and shown to the people.
yoruba: Gbogbo àwọn oníṣẹ́-ibi ni ó di àwárí tí a ó fi ojúu wọn hàn f'áráyé rí.

english: This double talk amongst those in power has further angered the opposition and civil society, according to the site globalguinee.info:
yoruba: Ẹnu méjì àwọn tí ó ń tukọ̀ ìlú ti túbọ̀ mú inú bí ẹgbẹ́ alátakò àti àwọn àjàfẹ́tọ̀ọ́ ọmọnìyàn, ó ní bí ìtakùn globalguinee.info ṣe sọ:

english: Translation Original Quote
yoruba: Ìtúmọ̀ Ìtúnwí-ọ̀rọ̀ Ọlọ́rọ̀ gan-an
