yoruba: Iṣẹ́ ìwádìí fi yé wípé àwọn ìṣípòkiri láti Ilẹ̀-adúláwọ̀ kò déédéé wáyé, ohun tí ó fà á ni "ìlànà ìdàgbàsókè àti ìyípadà àwùjọ" èyí tí ó ń mú ṣíṣíkiri lọ sí àwọn agbègbè àgbáyé wu Ọmọ-adúláwọ̀ — tí kò yàtọ̀ sí aṣípòkiri láti ibòmìíràn lágbàáyé.

english: These stereotypical narratives, however, often inform visa policy:
yoruba: Àwọn ìròyìn abanilórúkọjẹ́ wọ̀nyí, ni ó ń fa sábàbí ìlànà-iṣẹ́ ìwé ìrìnnà:

english: Most countries’ authorities assume that all Africans who travel will not return to their home countries, leaving African visa applicants to bear the burden of proof.
yoruba: Ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ orílẹ̀-èdè ni ó nígbàgbọ́ wípé gbogbo arìnrìnàjò tí ó bá jẹ́ Ọmọ-adúláwọ̀ ni kò ní padà sí orílẹ̀-èdèe rẹ̀, àfi bí arìnrìnàjó bá ní ẹ̀rí tí ó yanrantí tó ni ó lè rí ìwé ìrìnnà ìwọ̀lú gbà.

english: Getting non-African nations to take a more nuanced approach to visa approvals for African nationals is a long battle.
yoruba: Kò rọrùn láti ṣí ojú àwọn tí kì í ṣe ọmọ-adúláwọ̀ lójú nípa orúkọ búburú tí wọn ti sọ orílẹ̀-èdè tí ó wá láti Ilẹ̀-adúláwọ̀.

english: Meanwhile, African nations can take action to improve mobility across the continent.
yoruba: Níbàyìí, àwọn orílẹ̀-èdè Ilẹ̀-adúláwọ̀ níṣẹ́ láti ṣe sí ètò lílọ-àti-bíbọ̀ àwọn ọmọadúláwọ̀. Ìwé-ẹ̀rí-ọmọìlú-fún-ìrìnnà kan ṣoṣo fún gbogbo orílẹ̀-èdè ní Ilẹ̀-adúláwọ̀ jẹ́ ọ̀nà àbáyọ — àmọ́ kò tó.

english: A common African passport is one step  — but it's not enough. The Single African Air Transport market (SAATM), and the Continental Free Trade Agreement, both launched last year, have laid the foundation for some of these shifts, but widespread implementation is still a long way off.
yoruba: Single African Air Transport market náà (SAATM), àti Continental Free Trade Agreement náà, tí a fi lọ́lẹ̀ lọ́dún tí ó kọjá, ti se àlàálẹ̀ ìgbésẹ̀ wọ̀nyí, ṣùgbọ́n ìmúṣẹ ṣì kù díẹ̀ káàtó.

english: Meanwhile, as an African, to dare to travel is to be subjected to cruel humiliations when travelling outside Africa — or to be jolted out of the fantasy of African unity by the harshness of travelling within the continent.
yoruba: Lásìkò yìí, gẹ́gẹ́ bíi Ọmọ-adúláwọ̀, ìyànjú láti rìnrìnàjò ni láti ní ìrírí ìrẹnisílẹ̀ tí àwọn tí ó ń se ìrìnàjò lọ sí òkè-òkun ń rí — tàbí jẹ́ títají nínú àlà ìsọ̀kan Ilẹ̀-adúláwọ̀ tí kò sí.

english: Either way the visa gods demand more sacrifices, while remaining adamantly intransigent.
yoruba: Èyí kéyìí tí ò báà jẹ́, òòsà ìwé ìrìnnà ń béèrè ẹbọ sí i, tí kọ̀ sì yé é gbẹbọ.

english: Social media propelled ethnocentric disinformation and propaganda during the Nigerian elections
yoruba: Ẹ̀rọ Alátagbà ni a fi gbé àwọn ìròyìn irọ́ àti ọ̀rọ̀ ẹlẹ́yàmẹyà jáde lásìkò ìdìbò orílẹ̀-èdèe Nàìjíríà

english: Ethnic driven falsehoods spiked on social media during the elections
yoruba: Irọ́ tí ó ti ara ẹlẹ́yàmẹyà sú yọ lórí ẹ̀rọ alátagbà lásìkò ìbò

english: Voting in progress at presidential election March 28, 2015, in Abuja, Nigeria. Photo by US Embassy / Idika Onyukwu [Image Attribution: Non-Commercial 2.0 Generic (CC BY-NC 2.0)]
yoruba: Ìbò ààrẹ ti ọjọ́ 28, oṣù kẹta ọdún-un 2015 bí ó ṣe ń lọ lọ́wọ́ ní Abuja, Nàìjíríà. Àwòrán láti Iléeṣẹ́ Aṣojúu Ètò Ìrìnàjò sí orílẹ̀-èdèe US ní Nàìjíríà/ Idika Onyukwu [Ìgbóríyín fún òǹlàwòrán: Àìsí-fọ̀rọ̀-ajé 2.0 Àìlámì (CC BY-NC 2.0)]

english: This story is the first in a two-part series on online ethnic hate speech, disinformation and propaganda during the 2019 Nigeria elections.
yoruba: Èyí ni àkọ́kọ́ nínú ìròyìn oníṣísẹ̀ntẹ̀lé ẹlẹ́ka-méjì tí ó dá fìrìgbagbòó lóríi ọ̀rọ̀ ìkórìíra ẹni, ìròyìn ẹlẹ́jẹ̀ àti irọ́ lórí ayélujára ní Nàìjíríà lásìkò ìbò ọdún-un 2019.

english: You can read the second part here.
yoruba: O leè ká apá kejì ìròyìn náà níbí.

english: Nigeria went to the polls to elect a new president and a national parliament on February 23, 2019.
yoruba: Ọjọ́ 23, oṣù kejì ọdún-un 2019 ni àwọn ọmọ orílẹ̀-èdèe Nàìjíríà gba ẹ̀ka ìdìbò lọ láti dìbò yan ààrẹ àti ọmọ ìgbìmọ̀ tuntun sípò.

english: With two main contenders vying for the presidency, incumbent President Muhammadu Buhari obtained 15 million votes and triumphed over his closest rival, Atiku Abubakar, by a "margin of 56 percent to 41 percent".
yoruba: Àwọn méjì gbòógì òǹdíjedupò sí ipò ààrẹ, Ààrẹ tí ó wà lórí àléfà kó ìbò ẹgbẹẹgbẹ̀rún 15 tí ó mú u borí olórogún-un rẹ̀ pẹ́kípẹ́kí, Atiku Abubakar, pẹ̀lú "àlàfo idà 56 sí ìdá 41".

english: Buhari was sworn-in for a second term of four years on May 29, 2019.
yoruba: A ṣe ìbúra fún Buhari fún sáà kejì ọlọ́dún mẹ́rin lọ́jọ́ 29, oṣù karùn-ún, 2019.

english: Read more: #NigeriaDecides2019: Everything you need to know for this year's general elections
yoruba: Kà sí i: #NigeriaDecides2019: Ohun gbogbo tí ó yẹ kí o mọ̀ nípa ìdìbò gbogboògbò ti ọdún nìí

english: However, the election campaign was fought on different fronts, including social media.
yoruba: Síbẹ̀, ohun gbogbo tí ó gbà ni wọ́n fi ṣe ìpolongo ìbò náà, láì yọ bíbẹ ẹ̀rọ alátagbà lọ́wẹ̀ sílẹ̀.

english: There was widespread dissemination of ethnic hate speech at the service of disinformation and propaganda online, particularly on Twitter.
yoruba: Ọ̀rọ̀ ìkórìíra tẹ̀gbintẹ̀gbin tòun ìwà ẹlẹ́yàmẹyà àti ìròyìn irọ́ ràn bíi pápá inú ọyẹ́ ní orí ẹ̀rọ ayélujára, pabambarì lóríi gbàgede Twitter.

english: Ethnic hate in Nigeria
yoruba: Ìkórìíra Ẹ̀yà ní Nàìjíríà

english: Nigeria’s multi-ethnicity – over 250 ethnic groups and 500 languages – has at times been a source of conflict instead of strength.
yoruba: Ẹ̀yà onírúurú – tí ó tó bíi 250 àti èdè 500 – ti fi ìgbà kan jẹ́ orísun àìbalẹ̀ọkàn dípòo ìfọ̀kànbalẹ̀.

english: This becomes particularly obvious during elections when politicians use these divisions to campaign for votes.
yoruba: Èyí fi ojú hàn lásìkò ìbò nígbàtí àwọn olóṣèlú lo ẹlẹ́yàmẹ́lẹ́yá fi polongo ìbò.

english: Naturally, online conversations in Nigeria have not been devoid of ethnic-induced hate.
yoruba: Láti ilẹ̀, ìtàkùrọ̀sọ lórí ayélujára ní Nàìjíríà kò lọ láì sí ìkórìíra.

english: Read more: Nigeria: Curbing the tide of ethnic hate — online and off
yoruba: Kà sí i: Nàìjíríà: Gbígbógun ti àpọ̀jù ìkórìíra ẹ̀yà tẹ̀gbintẹ̀gbin — lójúkorojú àti lórí ayélujára

english: During the 2015 elections, for instance, Twitter Nigeria descended into a bitter and binary sparring match between supporters of the then-two major contestants, Goodluck Jonathan (PDP, an Ijaw Christian) and Muhammadu Buhari (APC, a Hausa, Fulani Muslim).
yoruba: Lásìkò ìbò ọdún-un 2015, fún àpẹẹrẹ, gbàgede Twitter ní orílẹ̀-èdèe Nàìjíríà di ibi ìkorò àti ibi ìdíje ìjuwọ́ láàárín àwọn alátìlẹ́yìn àwọn òǹdíje méjì ìgbà náà, Goodluck Jonathan (PDP, ọmọ lẹ́yìn Krístì tó jẹ́ ọmọ Ijaw) àti Muhammadu Buhari (APC, Ìmàle, Hausa, Fulani).

english: Twitter became a tool for propagating ethnic hate and party politics.
yoruba: Twitter di irinṣẹ́ fún ìgbéròyìn ìkórìíra ẹ̀yà tẹ̀gbintẹ̀gbin jáde àti ohun èlò fún ẹgbẹ́ olóṣèlú.

english: Some thought 2019 would be different because Buhari from the All Progressive Congress (APC) and Abubakar from the People's Democratic Party (PDP) are both Hausa, Fulani Muslims, but that was not the case.
yoruba: Àwọn kan lérò wípé ọdún-un 2019 yóò yàtọ̀ nítorí pé Buhari ti ẹgbẹ́ẹ Àjọ Ìtẹ̀síwájú Gbogboògbò (APC) àti Abubakar láti Ẹgbẹ́ olóṣèlú Ìjọba-tiwantiwa Àwọn Ènìyàn (PDP) tí àwọn méjèèjì sì jẹ́ Hausa, Fulani Ìmàle, àmọ́ bẹ́ẹ̀ kọ́ ló rí.

english: Their vice-presidential candidates – Yemi Osibanjo (APC), a Yoruba, and Peter Obi (PDP), an Igbo, are both Christians— but from different ethnic groups.
yoruba: Àwọn amúgbálẹ́gbẹ̀ẹ́ wọn – Yẹmí Ọṣìńbàjò (APC), ọmọ Yoruba, àti Peter Obi (PDP), ọmọ Igbo, jẹ́ Ọmọ-lẹ́yìn-in-krístì — àmọ́ láti ẹ̀yà ọ̀tọ̀ọ̀tọ̀.

english: It seemed like a repeat of 2015 but now with different protagonists.
yoruba: Ó fẹ́ jọ àtúnwáyé ìṣẹ̀lẹ̀ 2015 ṣùgbọ́n pẹ̀lú atakànàngbọ̀n mìíràn.

english: The political atmosphere became ethnically-charged in 2017, two years before the elections, creating the conditions for an atmosphere of distrust.
yoruba: Ohun gbogbo nípa ìṣèlú Nàìjíríà wọṣọ ẹlẹ́yàmẹ́lẹ́yá ní 2017, ọdún méjì kí ìbò ó tó bẹ̀rẹ̀, tí ó sì fa àìgbàgbọ́ nínú ètò ìṣèlú.

english: The Indigenous People of Biafra (IPOB), a secessionist organization in the southeastern part of the country led by Nnamdi Kanu, also added to the heightened ethnic tensions brewing.
yoruba: Ẹgbẹ́ ajìjàngbara ọmọ ìbílẹ̀ Biafra Indigenous People of Biafra (IPOB), tí ó jẹ́ àgbáríjọpọ̀ àwọn ọmọ ìbílẹ̀ ìlà-oòrùn orílẹ̀-èdèe Nàìjíríà tí Nnamdi Kanu jẹ́ olórí, dá kún rògbòdìyàn tí ó ń rọ́ tìtì.

english: Read more: As ethnic hate speech rises, Nigerian writers push back
yoruba: Kà sí i: Bí ọ̀rọ̀ ìkórìíra tẹ̀gbintẹ̀gbin ṣe ń peléke sí i, àwọn òǹkọ̀wée Nàìjíríà náà múṣẹ́ ṣe

english: Desertification in predominantly-Muslim northern Nigeria led to a southward migration of Nigeria’s cattle herders that ignited violent conflicts with farmers.
yoruba: Ìdi-aṣálẹ̀-ilẹ̀ ní àríwá Nàìjíríà ló mú kí àwọn ọlọ́sìn-ẹran tí ó jẹ́ darandaran tí ó ń bá àwọn àgbẹ̀ jà ó wà sí apá gúúsù.

english: The southern Christian communities’ resentment of the influx of Muslim Fulani herders was portrayed in some narratives as an 'Islamisation' force.
yoruba: Àwọn Ọmọ-lẹ́yìn-in-krístì kan “rí gbígba àwọn Fulani darandaran tí ó jẹ́ Ìmàle tọwọ́tẹsẹ̀ wọlé sí apáa gúúsù gẹ́gẹ́ bíi ìgbésẹ̀ láti 'Sọnidìmàlè' ní tipátipá.

english: The failure of the Nigerian government to investigate these clashes and "bring perpetrators to justice" resulted in the death of about 4,000 people from 2015 to late 2018, according to Amnesty International.
yoruba: Ìkọ̀jálẹ́ ìjọba Nàìjíríà láti ṣe ìwádìí sí àwọn ìkọlù tí ó ń wáyé àti "fífimú àwọn tí ó ṣẹ̀ sófin dánrin", tí ìkọlù náà sì fa ikú àwọn ènìyàn tí ó tó bíi ẹgbẹ̀rún 4 láti ọdún-un 2015 sí 2018, gẹ́gẹ́ bí iléeṣẹ́ Amnesty International ti ṣe ní i lákọsílẹ̀.

english: Hence, ethnocentrism was already at an all-time high before the presidential elections in 2019.
yoruba: Láti ìhín lọ, ẹlẹ́yàmẹyà ti ń peléke sí i kí ó tó di àsìkò ìbò ààrẹ ọdún-un 2019.

english: The prevailing distrust was a fertile ground for false information – online and offline – during the elections.
yoruba: Àìnígbàgbọ́ tí ó wà nílẹ̀ ló fi àyè gba ìgbéjáde ìròyìn irọ́ – lójúkorojú àti lórí ayélujára – lásìkò ìbò.

english: Elections and the credibility of online information in Nigeria
yoruba: Ìbò àti ìgbàgbọ́ ọ̀rọ̀ orí ẹ̀rọ ayélujára ní Nàìjíríà

english: The number of internet users in Nigeria grew from 98.3 million in 2017 to 100.5 million in 2018.
yoruba: Iye àwọn òǹlò ẹ̀rọ ayélujára ní Nàìjíríà fò fẹ̀rẹ̀ sókè láti ẹgbẹẹgbẹ̀rún 98.3 ní ọdún-un 2017 sí ẹgbẹẹgbẹ̀rún 100.5 ní 2018.

english: Facebook maintains the lead as the social media platform of choice with 22 million users, followed by YouTube (7 million+), Twitter (6 million) and Instagram (5.7 million).
yoruba: Facebook ló léwájú gẹ́gẹ́ bí i gbàgede ààyò ọ̀pọ̀ ọmọ orílẹ̀-èdèe Nàìjíríà pẹ̀lú òǹlò ẹgbẹẹgbẹ̀rún 22, tí gbàgede àwòrán-àtohùn YouTube (ẹgbẹẹgbẹ̀rún 7 àti jù bẹ́ẹ̀ lọ) tẹ̀lé e, Twitter (ẹgbẹẹgbẹ̀rún 6) àti Instagram (ẹgbẹẹgbẹ̀rún 5.7).

english: The majority of Nigerian voters are young. Out of the 84 million registered voters for the 2019 General Elections, over half — 51 percent — are young voters aged between 18 and 35, whereas nearly 30 percent are between 36 and 50 years old.
yoruba: Ọ̀dọ́ ni ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ àwọn olùdìbò orílẹ̀-èdèe Nàìjíríà. Lára ẹgbẹẹgbẹ̀rún 84 àwọn olùdìbò tí ó forúkọsílẹ̀ fún Ìbò Àpapọ̀ ọdún-un 2019, tí ìdajì — ìdá 51 — jẹ́ ọ̀dọ́ òǹdìbò tí ọjọ́ oríi wọ́n tó ọdún 18 àti 35, tí ìdá 30 sì jẹ́ ẹni ọdún 36 àti 50.

english: These two groups of voters, which include both digital natives and digital immigrants, form the majority of Nigerian voters who are digitally savvy.
yoruba: Àwọn ọjọ́-orí méjèèjì yìí, tí ó ní onímọ̀ nípa ìlò ẹ̀rọ ayárabíàṣá àti àwọn aṣípò sórí ẹ̀rọ ayárabíàṣá, ni ó pọ̀ jù lọ nínú àwọn olùdìbòo Nàìjíríà.

english: Therefore, it was not surprising that digital media was one of the prominent battlegrounds for election campaigns in 2019.
yoruba: Torí ìdí èyí, kò yanilẹ́nu wípé ẹ̀rọ ayárabíàṣá jẹ́ gbàgede kan gbòógì fún fífi ìpolongo ìbò ọdún-un 2019 sọta ìjà lura ẹni.

english: As a result, the credibility of online information during the 2019 elections suffered great attrition.
yoruba: Látàrí èyí, ó mú u ṣòro láti gbọ́kàn tẹ àwọn ìròyìn orí ayélukára-bí-ajere lásìkò ètò ìdìbò tó wáyé lọ́dún-un 2019.

english: False and misleading information, promoted as gospel truth, was amplified by supporters of the two major parties in Nigeria: the All Progressive Congress (APC) and the People's Democratic Party (PDP).
yoruba: Ìròyìn irọ́ tí kò ní gbọ́ngbọ́n nínú ni wọ́n polongo gẹ́gẹ́ ìhìn rere tòótọ́, tí àwọn alátìlẹ́yìn ẹgbẹ́ olóṣèlú méjèèjì tí ó gbajúmọ̀ jù lọ ní orílẹ̀-èdèe Nàìjíríà sì lukoro rẹ̀: Àjọ Ìtẹ̀síwájú Gbogboògbò All Progressive Congress (APC) àti Ẹgbẹ́ olóṣèlú Ìjọba-tiwantiwa Àwọn Ènìyàn People's Democratic Party (PDP).

english: Based on ethnographic participant observation conducted between October 28, 2018, and May 29, 2019, ethnic hate was employed as a tool for disinformation and propaganda by both sides of the political divide on Twitter Nigeria during the 2019 presidential elections.
yoruba: Gẹ́gẹ́ bí ìkíyèsí ẹ̀yà tí ó wáyé láàárín ọjọ́ 28 oṣù kẹwàá, 2018, àti ọjọ́ 29, oṣù karùn-ún 2019, ọ̀rọ̀ ìkórìíra ẹ̀yà tẹ̀gbintẹ̀gbin jẹ́ irinṣẹ́ fún ìròyìn tí kò ní gbọ́ngbọ́n ń'nú tí ó kún fún irọ́ láti sàkání ẹgbẹ́ olóṣèlú méjèèjì ní oríi Twitter ti Nàìjíríà lásìkò ìbò ààrẹ 2019.

english: These observations were captured as screengrabs of tweets or saved URLs collected over this period.
yoruba: A ká àwọn ìkíyèsí yìí sílẹ̀ láti orí ayélujára ní àsìkò yìí.

english: In terms of ethnically-charged disinformation, some APC supporters accused Obi of being a bigot for purportedly deporting northerners while he was governor of Anambra State, in southeast Nigeria.
yoruba: Tí a bá sọ nípa ìròyìn irọ́ nípa ti ẹlẹ́yàmẹyà, àwọn agbárùkù ti ẹgbẹ́ olóṣèlúu APC yọ ẹnu ìwọ̀sí sí Obi lára nítorí pé ó dá àwọn ará òkè Ọya padà nígbà tí ó wà lórí ipò gẹ́gẹ́ bí aláṣẹ Ìpínlẹ̀ Anambra, ní ìlà-oòrùn gúúsù orílẹ̀-èdèe Nàìjíríà.

english: Tweets went viral that claimed that Yoruba people were burning shops of Igbo traders in Lagos. Both stories were false and will be explored further in Part II of this essay.
yoruba: Túwíìtì tàn kárí ilé kárí oko tí ó sọ pé àwọn ọmọ Yorùbá ń tiná bọ ìsọ̀ àwọn oníṣòwò tí ó jẹ́ ẹ̀yà Igbo ní Èkó. Irọ́ funfun báláwú ni àwọn ìròyìn wọ̀nyí, a ó gbé e yẹ̀ wò síwájú sí i nínú Apá kejì àròkọ yìí.

english: Figure 1: Misinformed propaganda tweet by Festus Keyamo
yoruba: Àwòrán 1: Túwíìtì irọ́ ti Festus Keyamo

english: Figure 2: The true location of the image that Keyamo shared.
yoruba: Àwòrán 2: Àṣírí bi tí àwòrán tí Keyamo tari síta wà ní ti òtítọ́.

english: In another example, a photograph was used to misconstrue facts. On October 28, 2018, Festus Keyamo, then-media director of the Buhari Campaign Organisation, tweeted an image (Figure 1) of a tree growing between an apparently abandoned Nigerian rail track:
yoruba: Fún àpẹẹrẹ òmíràn, a lo àwòrán kan báyìí lọ́nà tí kò yẹ. Lọ́jọ́ 28, oṣù kẹwàá, ọdún-un, 2018, Festus Keyamo, olùdarí ètò ìkéde àná fún Iléeṣẹ́ Ìpolongo fún Buhari, túwíìtì àwòrán kan (Aworan 1) ti igi kan tí ó ń wù láàárín ojú irin kan tí ó ti di àpatì:

english: This is how trees grew in-between rail tracks between 1999 and 2015...
yoruba: Bí igí ṣe ń wù sí àárín ojú irin ní 1999 sí 2015...

english: Now, this is the 'Completion Era' as the tracks are beginning to roar back to life.” The PDP government was in power between 1999 and 2015.
yoruba: Báyìí, ‘Sáà Ìparí iṣẹ́’ rè é, àwọn ojú irin náà ti ń jí padà sáyé.” Ìjọba PDP ló ń tukọ̀ ètò ní 1999 sí 2015.

english: However, a Nigerian Twitter user later traced back the image to an original Arabic-language tweet (Figure 2) posted earlier that same month.
yoruba: Lẹ́yìn-ò-rẹyìn, òǹlò Twitter kan tí ó jẹ́ ọmọ orílẹ̀-èdèe Nàìjíríà tọ ipasẹ̀ẹ àwòrán náà sí túwíìtì kan lédèe Lárúbáwá (Àwòrán 2) tí ẹnìkan tari síta nínú oṣù yẹn.

english: According to the tweet, the photo is from Lebanon.
yoruba: Túwíìtì náà jẹ́rìí wípé Lebanon ni àwòrán ọ̀hún ti ṣẹ̀ wá.

english: Keyamo's intention may have been to show that the Buhari government had surpassed previous administrations on the revamping of the morbid rail lines in the country.
yoruba: Ohun tí Keyamo fẹ́ ṣe ni láti fi hàn wípé ìṣàkóso ìjọba Buhari ti gbé ìgbésẹ̀ àtúnṣe sí àwọn ọ̀nà ọkọ̀ọ ojú irin tí ìjọba àná pa tì.

english: However, the use of an image from a different country made the so-called "gains" questionable.
yoruba: Àmọ́ ṣá, àwòrán orílẹ̀-èdè mìíràn tí ó lò láti fi sọ "ìtẹ̀síwájú" náà, fọ́ gbogbo rẹ̀ lójú.

english: Figure 3: Ethnic hate speech
yoruba: Àwòrán 3: Ọ̀rọ̀ ìkórìíra ẹ̀yà tẹ̀gbintẹ̀gbin

english: Figure 4: El-Rufai later apologized for the “insensitive” tweet shown in Figure 3.
yoruba: Àwòrán 4: El-Rufai tọrọ àforíjì fún túwíìtì “tí ó lè dá wàhálà sílẹ̀” náà tí ó wà ń'nú Àwòrán 3.

english: Online ethnic hate speech was also pronounced before, during and after the elections.
yoruba: Ọ̀rọ̀ ìkórìíra ẹ̀yà tẹ̀gbintẹ̀gbin ṣẹ́ yọ kí ọjọ́ ìbò ó tó kò, lásìkò ìbò àti lẹ́yìn ìbò.

english: In an ethnic slurred tweet (Figure 3) Bashir El-Rufai, son of the Kaduna State Governor, inferred that the Nigerian Civil War was ignited by the Igbo vengeance.
yoruba: Túwíìtì ẹlẹ́yàmẹyà kan (Àwòrán 3) Bashir El-Rufai, ọmọ Aláṣẹ Ìpínlẹ̀ Kaduna, wí pé ẹ̀yà Igbo ló fi ìbínú tan iná ọ̀tẹ̀ tí ó fa Ogun Abẹ́lée Nàìjíríà.

english: Between 1967 and 1970, Nigeria fought a bitter civil war with the secessionist state of Biafra inhabited mostly by the Igbo in the southeastern part of the country.
yoruba: Láàárín 1967 sí 1970, orílẹ̀-èdèe Nàìjíríà ja ogun kíkorò kan pẹ̀lú ìlúu Biafra tí í ṣe àwọn ẹ̀yà Igbo tí ó wà ní apá ìlà-oòrùn gúúsù, tí ó ń gbèrò láti pín yà kúrò lábẹ́ ìṣàkóso ìjọba Nàìjíríà.

english: Hence, according to Bashir El-Rufai, the result of the 2019 elections which was won by his party, the APC, should also be taken as a sweet "revenge" from the Hausa, Fulani.
yoruba: Síbẹ̀, gẹ́gẹ́ bí Bashir El-Rufai ti ṣe sọ, àbájáde ìbò ọdún-un 2019 tí ẹgbẹ́ẹ rẹ̀, APC, gbégbà-orókè. Ó yẹ kí a rí i bíi “ẹ̀san” láti apá ọ̀dọ̀ àwọn ẹ̀yà Hausa, Fulani.

english: He later apologized, after a backlash, for his previous "insensitive" tweet as shown in Figure 4.
yoruba: Ó padà wá á tọrọ àforíjì, lẹ́yìn tí a ti bu ẹnu àtẹ́ lù ú, fún túwíìtì "tí ó lè dá wàhálà sílẹ̀ " bí a ti rí i nínú Àwòrán.

english: He also deleted the earlier tweet (Figure 3).
yoruba: Bákan náà ni ó mú túwíìtì ìsọkúsọ náà wálẹ̀ (Àwòrán 3).

english: Ethnic-motivated false information on social media during the elections falls into two categories: disinformation and propaganda.
yoruba: Ìròyìn irọ́ tí ó ti ara ẹlẹ́yàmẹyà wá lórí ẹ̀rọ-alátagbà lásìkò ìbò ṣe é pín sábẹ́ ẹ̀ka méjì: ìròyìn tí kò ní gbọ́ngbọ́n nínú àti ìròyìn irọ́.

english: Miroslav Tudjman and Nives Mikelic, communication scholars at the University of Zagreb, Croatia, define disinformation as "intentionally deputed mistaken information with the purpose to mislead the user".
yoruba: Miroslav Tudjman àti Nives Mikelic, ọ̀mọ̀wé nípa ìtàkùrọ̀sọ ní Ifáfitì ti Zagreb, Croatia, túmọ̀ ìròyìn tí kò ní gbọ́ngbọ́n nínú sí "ìròyìn àmọ̀ọ́mọ̀ tari síta láti ṣi àwọn ènìyàn lọ́kàn".

english: Hence, the intention to pass across inaccurate, distorted and false evidence as true, distinguishes dis-information from misinformation.
yoruba: Ète títari ìròyìn irọ́ síta bí òtítọ́, ló ya ìròyìn tí ó ń ṣini lọ́kàn àti ìròyìn irọ́ sọ́tọ́.

english: Tudjman and Mikelic assert that propaganda is much more than disinformation or misinformation.
yoruba: Tudjman àti Mikelic sọ wípé ọ̀nà ìtànkálẹ̀ ìròyìn fẹ̀jú ju ìròyìn àmọ̀ọ́mọ̀ tari síta láti ṣini lọ́kàn tàbí ìròyìn irọ́ lọ.

english: This is because propaganda "aims to manipulate the attitudes of the user" through an "accidental or intentional handling with information in [the] communication process".
yoruba: Ìdí ni pé ọ̀nà ìtànkálẹ̀ ìròyìn "máa ń yí ìhùwàsí ẹni padà" nípasẹ̀ "ìṣẹ̀lẹ̀ àìròtẹ́lẹ̀ kan tàbí ìgbésẹ̀ àmọ̀ọ́mọ̀ dá lásìkò ìtari ìtàkùrọ̀sọ [náà] síta".

english: Thus, propaganda weaponizes biased or inaccurate information for political interests and consequently manipulates perception.
yoruba: Bí irú èyí, ọ̀nà ìtànkálẹ̀ ìròyìn máa ń tẹ̀sí apá kan tàbí àìpé ìròyìn fún àǹfààní ọ̀rọ̀ òṣèlú àti yíyí ìrònú padà níparí.

english: Justifiable fears emerged surrounding 2019 elections because online disinformation and propaganda incites electoral violence but also poses "a threat to reconciliation after the elections".
yoruba: Ìbẹ̀rùbojo ọkàn bẹ́ sílẹ̀ látàrí ìbò ọdún-un 2019 nítorí ìròyìn irọ́ àti ọ̀nà ìtànkálẹ̀ ìròyìn ń ṣe àgbédìde àìbalẹ̀ ọkàn tí ó ti ọ̀rọ̀ ìbò bẹ̀rẹ̀ àmọ́ tí ó ń fa "ìdẹ́rùbà fún ìparí-ìjà tí ìbòó bá kásẹ̀ ńlẹ̀ ".

english: Part II of this essay will examine how this played out online, especially on Twitter, with specific examples.
yoruba: Apá kejì àròkọ yìí yóò ṣe àgbéyẹ̀wò bí èyí ṣe wáyé lórí ayélujára, pàápàá lóríi gbàgede Twitter, pẹ̀lú àwọn àpẹẹrẹ mélòó kan.

english: This article is part of a series of posts examining interference with digital rights through methods such as network shutdowns and disinformation during key political events in seven African countries: Algeria, Ethiopia, Mozambique, Nigeria, Tunisia, Uganda, and Zimbabwe.
yoruba: Àpilẹ̀kọ yìí jẹ́ ara àtẹ̀jádé ìròyìn oníṣísẹ̀ntẹ̀lé tí ó ń ṣe àgbéyẹ̀wò ìṣúsí pẹ̀lú ẹ̀tọ́ ìlò ẹ̀rọ-ayárabíàṣá nípa àwọn ìlànà bíi ìṣánpa ìṣàsopọ̀ ẹ̀rọ ayélukára-bí-ajere àti ìròyìn ẹlẹ́jẹ̀ lásìkò ètò ìṣèlú tí ó pọn dandan ní orílẹ̀-èdè méje ní Ilẹ̀-Adúláwọ̀: Algeria, Ethiopia, Mozambique, Nàìjíríà, Tunisia, Uganda, àti Zimbabwe.

english: The project is funded by the Africa Digital Rights Fund of The Collaboration on International ICT Policy for East and Southern Africa (CIPESA).
yoruba: Africa Digital Rights Fund àti The Collaboration on International ICT Policy for East and Southern Africa (CIPESA) ni agbátẹrù iṣẹ́ àkànṣe yìí.

english: From Kenya to Ethiopia, these men received divine dream ‘maps’ to carve caves
yoruba: Ní Kenya àti Ethiopia, àwọn ọkùnrin wọ̀nyí ríran ‘àwòrán-ìtọ́nà’ àt'ọ̀run wá láti gbẹ́ ihò nísàlẹ̀ ilẹ̀

english: Both men say they received explicit instructions from God
yoruba: Àwọn ọkùnrin méjèèjì sọ wípé Ọlọ́run ló yọ sí àwọn

english: Dunbar caves in southern Ethiopia were dug by Mohammed Yiso Banatah with his bare hands.
yoruba: Ihò nísàlẹ̀ ilẹ̀ẹ Dunbar ní gúúsù Ethiopia tí Mohammed Yiso Banatah gbẹ́ jáde pẹ̀lú ọwọ́ọ rẹ̀ láì lo ohunkóhun.

english: He was instructed by Allah to create underground wedding chapels.
yoruba: Allah l'ó pa á láṣẹ láti gbẹ́ ilé Ọlọ́run fún ètò ìgbéyàwó sísàlẹ̀ ilẹ̀.

english: Photo by Amanda Leigh Lichtenstein, used with permission.
yoruba: Àwòrán láti ọwọ́ọ Amanda Leigh Lichtenstein, a fi àṣẹ lò ó.

english: On December 26, 2019, BBC Swahili released a video featuring Francisco Ouma, an elder from Busia, western Kenya, who received a message from God to carve a cave.
yoruba: Lọ́jọ́ 26 oṣù Ọ̀pẹ, BBC Swahili gbé àwòrán-àtohùn kan tí ó ṣe àfihàn-an Francisco Ouma, ẹni àgbà kan láti Busia, ìlà-oòrùnun Kenya, ẹni tí ó gbọ́ ohùn Ọlọ́run láti gbẹ́ ihò nísàlẹ̀ ilẹ̀ jáde.

english: The message came in the form of a map that he received through his dreams.
yoruba: Ìran náà wá nípasẹ̀ àwòrán ìtọ́nà tí ó rí lójú àwọn àláa rẹ̀.

english: Since February 1967, Ouma has followed the divine map delivered in his dream.
yoruba: Láti inú oṣù kejì ọdún-un 1967, ni Ouma ti ń tọ ipasẹ̀ẹ ìtọ́nà látọ̀run wá náà tí ó gbà Iójú àláa rẹ̀.

english: Today, his cave has 24 rooms and counting.
yoruba: Lónìí, ihò nísàlẹ̀ ilẹ̀ẹ rẹ̀ ti ní yàrá 24 tí ó sì ń lé sí i.

english: Screenshot of Francis Ouma, who received a message from God to carve a cave with 24 rooms via BBC Swahili / Instagram.
yoruba: Àgékù àwòrán-an Francis Ouma, tí ó gbọ́ ohùn Ọlọ́run láti gbẹ́ ihò sísàlẹ̀ ilẹ̀ tí ó ní 24 ìyàrá lóríi BBC Swahili / Instagram.

english: Throughout history, many have questioned the veracity of divine intervention through dreams, even casting doubt on one's mental health and stability.
yoruba: Láti ayébáyé, ọ̀pọ̀ ènìyàn ló ti ní kò sí ẹ̀rí tí ó dájú wípé ìran àt'ọ̀run wá ni àwọn irú àlá báwọ̀nyí, tí wọn ń dẹ́jàá ìlera ọpọlọ irú ẹni bẹ́ẹ̀ tí ó pé òún ríran lójú àlá.

english: But prophets from Islam, Judaism and Christianity have all testified to messages from God sent through dreams for millennia.
yoruba: Àmọ́ àwọn òjíṣẹ́ ẹ̀sìn Ìmàle, Júù àti Onígbàgbọ́ gbogboó ti jẹ́rìí sí ìran láti ọ̀dọ̀ Ọlọ́run ent tí ó wá lójú àlá fún ẹgbẹẹgbẹ̀rún ọdún.

english: "God brought me something like a map", Ouma told BBC Swahili.
yoruba: "Ọlọ́run fi nǹkankan bí àwòrán-ìtọ́nà hàn mí", Ouma sọ fún BBC Swahili.

english: Then, when I was digging, this map is what I followed.
yoruba: Nígbà yẹn, nígbà tí mò ń wa ilẹ̀, àwòrán-ìtọ́nà yìí ni mo tẹ̀lé.

english: It wasn't just that when I was digging, better to keep digging, no.
yoruba: Kì í ṣe nígbà tí mò ń walẹ̀ nìkan, ó dára jù kí n máa walẹ̀ lọ, rárá.

english: Using just a plow and his own two hands, Ouma faced trial and error as he hit on stones that prevented him from digging.
yoruba: Ìtúlẹ̀ àti ọwọ́ọ rẹ̀ méjèèjì ni ó lò, Ouma kan àwọn òkúta abẹ́lẹ̀ tí kò mú ìwalẹ̀ náà rọrùn fún un.

english: He finally found the right spot to manifest God's cave map in his mind.
yoruba: Àṣẹ̀yìnwá àṣẹ̀yìnbọ ó rí ibi tí yóò ti mú àwòrán-ìtọ́nà ihò nísàlẹ̀ ilẹ̀ẹ Ọlọ́run tí ó wà ní ọkàn-an rẹ̀ wá sí ìmúṣẹ.

english: In one room, there's a stone with writing on it with the words of Jesus.
yoruba: Nínú ìyẹ̀wù kan, ó ní òkúta kan tí a kọ ọ̀rọ̀ọ Jésù sí lára.

english: Jesus Christ was the one who brought me this news, Ouma said, and then he explained it to me as it was with Moses.
yoruba: Jésù Kristì ni ẹni tí ó mú ìròyìn yìí wá fún mi, Ouma sọ, ó sì ṣàlàyée rẹ̀ fún mi gẹ́gẹ́ bí ó ti ṣe ṣe fún Mósè.

english: Ouma believes he is bringing back another covenant with God to the world.
yoruba: Ouma gbàgbọ́ wípé òun ń mú májẹ̀mú mìíràn pẹ̀lú Ọlọ́run padà wá sílé ayé.

english: The second stage is coming.
yoruba: Ìpele kejì ń bọ̀ lọ́nà.

english: This is the first stage of the covenant.
yoruba: Èyí ni ìpele àkọ́kọ́ ti májẹ̀mú náà.

english: The second is coming.
yoruba: Ìkejì ń bọ̀ lọ́nà.

english: I can't say for sure what it is now because if I announce it, I may be cheating humanity.
yoruba: Mi ò leè sọ ní pàtó ohun tí yóò jẹ́ báyìí nítorí bí mo bá kédee rẹ̀, mo lè máa yan ìṣẹ̀dá ẹ̀dá ọmọ ènìyàn jẹ.

english: Therefore, I will wait for the report to be given at last, Ouma told BBC Swahili.
yoruba: Toríi bẹ́ẹ̀, mo máa dúró fún ìjábọ̀ náà bí ó bá tó àsìkò, Ouma wí fún BBC Swahili.

english: The BBC Swahili video has been viewed nearly 50,000 times with over 100 comments and counting.
yoruba: Àwòrán-àtohùn-un BBC Swahili ti di wíwò fún ìgbà 50,000 pẹ̀lú èsì tí ó tó 100 tí ó sì ń lé sí í.

english: While some have raised questions about the mental stability of those who claim to receive messages from God through dreams, including a professor quoted in the video, many comments supported people of faith who tune into messages shared through dreams.
yoruba: Níwọ̀n-ọn bí àwọn kan ti sọ nípa àìlera ọpọlọ àwọn t'ó ń sọ pé àwọn gbọ́hùn Ọlọ́run lójú àlá, tí ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ èsì àdásí gbè lẹ́yìn àwọn ẹni Ọlọ́run tí ó sọ sí ìran ojú àlá.

english: One Instagram user wrote:
yoruba: Òǹlòo Instagram kan kọ:

english: Translation Original Quote
yoruba: Ìtúmọ̀ Ìtúnwí-ọ̀rọ̀ Ọlọ́rọ̀ gan-an

english: For me, people like these, usually I believe them a lot, much more than those who fill us [up] from continuous contributions of words of hope from houses of worship, 52 years a person just digs — if he didn't have his mind, wouldn't his community or the government not recognize this?
yoruba: Fún èmi, àwọn ènìyàn báyìí, mo máa ń gbà wọ́n gbọ́ gidi gan-an, ju àwọn tí ó máa ń fi ọ̀rọ̀ Ọlọ́run [rọ] wá nílé ìjọsìn, fún ọdún 52 èèyàn-án wa ilẹ̀ — bí kò bá tẹ̀lé ọkàn-an rẹ̀, ṣé kò yẹ kí àdúgbòo rẹ̀ àti ìjọba ó dá a mọ̀?

english: He hasn't even asked for the help of a tractor or money for his labor. We should not judge this person.
yoruba: Kò tilẹ̀ béèrè fún ìrànwọ́ fún katakata tàbí owó fún làálàáa rẹ̀. A kò gbọdọ̀ dájọ́ ẹni yìí.

english: Mohammed Yiso Banatah in 2012 explains the ten dreams through which Allah instructed him to dig underground wedding chapels.
yoruba: Mohammed Yiso Banatah lọ́dún-un 2012 ṣàlàyé àlá mẹ́wàá tí Allah yọ sí òun lójú àlá láti gbẹ́ ilé Ọlọ́run fún ìgbéyàwó sábẹ́ ilẹ̀.

english: Photo courtesy of Amanda Leigh Lichtenstein.
yoruba: Àwòrán láti ọwọ́ọ Amanda Leigh Lichtenstein.

english: Ethiopia's underground wedding chapels
yoruba: Ilé Ọlọ́run fún ètò ìgbéyàwó Ethiopia

english: In southern Ethiopia, a similar testimony exists from an elder named Mohammed Yiso Banatah, who said back in 2012 that he was visited by Allah 33 years ago in a series of ten dreams.
yoruba: Ní gúúsù Ethiopia, ẹ̀rí tí ó jọra á wá láti àgbàlagbà kan tí orúkọ rẹ̀ ń jẹ́ Mohammed Yiso Banatah, tí ó ní lọ́dún-un 2012 wípé Allah yọ sí òun ní ọdún 33 sẹ́yìn lójú àlá lẹ́ẹ̀mẹwàá ọ̀tọ̀ọ̀tọ̀.

english: Through the dreams, he received explicit instructions from Allah to ultimately create underground wedding chapel caves.
yoruba: Lójú àwọn àlá náà, ó gbọ́ ohùn-un Allah láti gbẹ́ ihò ilé Ọlọ́run fún ètò ìgbéyàwó nísàlẹ̀ ilẹ̀.

english: Known as Dunbar Caves, these elaborate chapels exist on Banatah's roadside property halfway between Hawassa and Shashamene.
yoruba: Ihò nísàlẹ̀ ilẹ̀ẹ Dunbar ni a mọ̀ ọ́ sí, ilé Ọlọ́run fẹ̀nfẹ̀ wọ̀nyí wà ní ẹ̀bá ọ̀nàa Banatah tí í ṣe ìlàjì ọ̀nàa Hawassa àti Shashamene.

english: Banatah said it was in his third dream that the blueprint for these chapel caves was burned into his consciousness.
yoruba: Banatah sọ wípé nínú àláa rẹ̀ kẹ́ta ni ó ti rí àwòṣe fún àwọn ilé Ọlọ́run wọ̀nyí.

english: You can read my full narrative account of Banatah's dream sequence and what prompted him to start digging what would become his life's work here:
yoruba: O lè ka ẹ̀kúnrẹ́rẹ́ àkọsílẹ̀ àláa Banatah ní ṣísẹ̀-n-tẹ̀lé àti ohun tí ó gùn ún kí ó tó bẹ̀rẹ̀ iṣẹ́ ìwalẹ̀ ayée rẹ̀ níbí:

english: In his final dream, the tenth one in a series back in 1979, a man appeared in his dream who took Mohammed to a small tree on his property and pointed to its roots.
yoruba: Lójú àláa àsèkágbáa rẹ̀, èyí tí ó jẹ́ ìkẹwàá nínú àkọsílẹ̀ oníṣísẹ̀ntẹ̀lé ọdún-un 1979, ọkùnrin kan fara hàn tí ó mú Mohammed lọ sí ibi igi kékeré kan nínúu ọgbàa rẹ̀, ó sì tọ́ka sí egbòo rẹ̀.

english: The man showed him exactly where to start digging and told him that his life would depend on it.
yoruba: Ọkùnrin náà fi ojú ibi tí yóò ti bẹ̀rẹ̀ ìwalẹ̀, ó sì tún sọ fún un pé lórí iṣẹ́ ìwalẹ̀ náà ni yóò ti là.

english: At midnight, he saw visions of gold.
yoruba: Ní ọ̀gànjọ́, ó ríran rí wúrà.

english: Surroundings up close appeared far away and objects farthest away were pulled up close to him.
yoruba: Agbègbè tí ó sún mọ́ jìnà, àwọn ohun tí ó jìnà di fífà sún mọ́ ọ.

english: He was told where, when, and how to begin digging.
yoruba: A sọ ibi tí yóò ti bẹ̀rẹ̀ ìwalẹ̀, ìgbà tí yó bẹ̀rẹ̀ àti bí yóò ṣe bẹ̀rẹ̀ .

english: The next day, when he woke up, he began to dig into the earth with his bare hands.
yoruba: Lọ́jọ́ kejì, nígbà tí ó lajú sáyé, ó bẹ̀rẹ̀ síí gbẹ́lẹ̀ pẹ̀lú ọwọ́ọ rẹ̀ nìkan láì lo ìtúlẹ̀.

english: These sunlight-flooded caves have been somewhat of a tourist attraction where people stop, pay a modest fee, and tour the quiet stillness at least four meters underground.
yoruba: Ihò nísàlẹ̀ ilẹ̀ tí ìmọ́lẹ̀ oòrùn tán sínúu rẹ̀ wọ̀nyí ti di ibi ìgbafẹ́ olówó kékeré fún àwọn èèyàn láti ṣe ìrinsẹ̀ máìlì mẹ́rin lábẹ́ ilẹ̀ tí ó pa lọ́lọ́.

english: Some couples have even arranged wedding ceremonies there.
yoruba: Àwọn àfẹ́sọ́nà kan ti ṣe ètò ìgbéyàwó níbé.

english: The architectural genius of these spaces reveals the finery and steadiness of Mohammed’s hand – he’s spent careful hours carving, smoothing, cutting, digging, and designing an intricate series of archways, cosy nooks and hidden rooms within rooms, some that have been furnished with soft mattresses and simple earth-slab shelves, while others are stark and cool with tiny, rounded windows flooding through with secret rays of sunlight appearing out of nowhere.
yoruba: Bí a ṣe kọ́ àwọn ìyẹ̀wù wọ̀nyí fi iṣẹ́ ọpọlọ àti itú ọwọ́ọ Mohammed hàn – ó ti fi ìfarabalẹ̀ lọ ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ wákàtí fún gbígbẹ́, dídán, àti ṣíṣe iṣẹ́ ọnà sí gbogbo kọ́lọ́fín inú iyàrá àti ògiri, pẹ̀lú àwọn tìmùtìmù, àti pẹpẹ tí a fi iyẹ̀pẹ̀ mọ nínúu rẹ̀, tí àwọn yàrá mìíràn ní fèrèsé tí ìmọ́lẹ̀ oòrùn ń tàn gbà láti ibi tí ẹnìkan kò mọ̀.

english: Caves have carried deep spiritual and metaphorical significance throughout history.
yoruba: Láti ayébáyé ni ihò nísàlẹ̀ ilẹ̀ ti jẹ́ ibi àpẹẹrẹ tí a kà sí gẹ́gẹ́ bí ibi ti ẹ̀mí.

english: A whole chapter called "Al Kahf" or "The Cave" appears in the Quran.
yoruba: Odindin ìwé kan gbáko tí a pè ní "Al Kahf" tàbí "Ihò nísàlẹ̀ ilẹ̀ " jẹyọ nínúu ìwé mímọ́ọ Kuran.

english: It features a Christian folktale known as the "People of the Cave", in which youth, tortured for their beliefs, fled their city to find refuge in a cave and fell asleep.
yoruba: Nínúu rẹ̀ ni a ti bá ìtàn Ẹ̀sìn ìgbàgbọ́ kan tí a mọ̀ sí "Àwọn ẹni Ihò-òkúta", which nínú èyí tí àwọn ọ̀dọ́, jìyà àìṣẹ̀ nítorí ìgbàgbọ́ọ wọ́n sá kúrò nílùú, wọ́n sì wá ibi ihò-òkúta kan sùn sí.

english: When they awoke and returned, they realized the entire city had become believers.
yoruba: Nígbà tí wọ́n jí, wọ́n padà sílé, wọ́n sì ṣàkíyèsí wípé gbogbo ọmọ ìlú ti di ònígbàgbọ́.

english: Why is Donald Trump so popular in Nigeria?
yoruba: Kíni ìdí irẹ̀ tí Donald Trump ṣe l'ókìkí ní Nàìjíríà?

english: Trump has so many fans in southern Nigeria
yoruba: Trump ní ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ olólùfẹ́ ní gúúsù orílẹ̀-èdèe Nàìjíríà

english: President Donald Trump returns to the White House in Washington on August 19, 2018.
yoruba: Ààrẹ Donald Trump padà sí Ilé Agbára Funfun ní Washington lọ́jọ́ 19 oṣù Ògún, ọdún-un 2018.

english: Image by Samira Bouaou/The Epoch Times, CC BY 2.0.
yoruba: Àwòrán láti ọwọ́ọ Samira Bouaou/The Epoch Times, CC BY 2.0.

english: United States President Donald Trump has received low ratings across the world for his handling of international affairs — but not in some African countries like Nigeria.
yoruba: Ààrẹ orílẹ̀-èdèe Amẹ́ríkà Donald Trump ti ré sí ipò ìsàlẹ̀ lójú àwọn ènìyàn kárí ayé látàrí àwọn òfin rẹ̀ àti bí ó ṣe ń ṣe ìṣàkóso ọ̀ràn tí ó jẹ mọ́ orílẹ̀-èdèe òkèèrè — àmọ́ kò rí bẹ́ẹ̀ ní àwọn orílẹ̀-èdè bíi Nàìjíríà.

english: According to a recent survey by the Pew Research Centre most Nigerians "have confidence" that Trump "will do the right thing in world affairs".
yoruba: Ní kò pẹ́ kò pẹ́ yìí ni ìwádìí àyẹ̀wò tí Pew Research Centre ṣagbátẹrùu rẹ̀ fi hàn wípé ọ̀gọ̀rọ̀ ọmọ Nàìjíríà "fi Ògún-un rẹ̀ gbárí" wípé Trump "yóò gbé ìgbésẹ̀ tí ó lààmìlaka nípa ti ọ̀ràn àgbáyé".

english: The Pew survey results were gathered from telephone and face-to-face interviews conducted under the direction of Gallup — a Washington, DC, based analytics and advisory company.
yoruba: Orí ẹ̀rọ-ìbánisọ̀rọ̀ àti ìfọ̀rọ̀wánilẹ́nuwò ojúkorojú ni Gallup – iléeṣẹ́ aṣàgbéyẹ̀wò fínnífínní àti iléeṣẹ́ olùdámọ̀ràn tí ó wà ní Washington, DC fi gba èsì jọ nínú ìwádìí àyẹ̀wò èrò àwọn ènìyàn-an fún Pew.

english: Tweepsmap analysis of on Trump’s total followers on Twitter shows that Nigerians ranked in the top five across the world:
yoruba: Àgbéyẹ̀wò Tweepsmap kan tí ó dá lóríi iye àwọn tí ó ń tẹ̀lé Trump lóríi ẹ̀rọ alátagbà Twitter ṣe òfófó wípé ipò karùn-ún ni Nàìjíríà dúró sí nínú àwọn orílẹ̀-èdè márùn-ún lágbàáyé:

english: Nigerian writer Adaobi Tricia Nwaubani explained to The World, a public radio show co-produced by the BBC, that Trump's "tough guy image" strikes a chord in Africa's most populous country:
yoruba: Òǹkọ̀wé tí í ṣe ọmọ bíbí orílẹ̀-èdèe Nàìjíríà Adaobi Tricia Nwaubani làdíi rẹ̀ fún àgbáyé lórí ètò ẹ̀rọ agbóhùnsáfẹ́fẹ́ kan tí ó jẹ́ àbáṣepọ̀ pẹ̀lú BBC, wípé ìrísíi Trump gẹ́gẹ́ bí "ọkùnrin alágídí" mú kí àwọn ọmọ orílẹ̀-èdè tí ó kún fún ènìyàn jù lọ ní Ilẹ̀-Adúláwọ̀ ó fẹ́ràn-an rẹ̀ dé góńgó:

english: People admire his tough guy image and his bluntness is entertaining.
yoruba: Àwọn ènìyàn fẹ́ràn-an ìhùwàsí alágídíi rẹ̀ àti pé àìfọ̀rọ̀ sábẹ́ ahọ́n-ọn rẹ̀ dùn ún gbọ́ sétí.

english: He's weird to Americans.
yoruba: Àwọn ọmọ Amẹ́ríkà rí i bí àkàndá ènìyàn.

english: He's strange.
yoruba: Ìhùwàsíi rẹ̀ kò bá tayé mu.

english: He's different from what you've had.
yoruba: Kì í ṣe ẹni tí wọ́n sọ pé ó jẹ́.

english: But we're used to leaders who speak without restraint, who are verbally abusive when they please.
yoruba: Àmọ́ irú olórí tí kì í lọ́ra sọ̀rọ̀ bí ó ti wù ú kò jẹ́ tuntun sí wa.

english: And so, he's not as outlandish to us as he may appear to an American.
yoruba: Torí ìdí èyí, ìhùwàsíi rẹ̀ kò bàjẹ́ tó bẹ́ẹ̀ bí àwọn ọmọ Amẹ́ríkà ṣe ń rí i.

english: The other reason is religion.
yoruba: Ìdí mìíràn ni ẹ̀sìn.

english: Nigerian Christians love Trump.
yoruba: Àwọn Ọmọ lẹ́yìn-in Krístì nífẹ̀ẹ́ẹ Trump

english: Cheta Nwanze, Head of Research at SBM Intelligence told Global Voices:
yoruba: Cheta Nwanze, Olórí Ìwádìí ní SBM Intelligence sọ fún Ohùn Àgbáyé:

english: I'd like to see exactly WHERE in Nigeria this survey was conducted.
yoruba: Ó hùn mí láti mọ IBI tí wọ́n ti ṣe ìwádìí-àyẹ̀wò yìí ní Nàìjíríà.

english: I'm willing to bet that it was largely in southern Nigeria, which explains the love of Trump.
yoruba: Mo mọ̀ dájú wípé kì í ṣe káríi gúúsù orílẹ̀-èdèe Nàìjíríà, tí ó ṣàlàyé ìfẹ́ tí ọmọ Nàìjíríà ní sí Trump.

english: A lot of his base are evangelical Christians, from whom many Nigerians draw their inspiration.
yoruba: Ọ̀pọ̀ nínú àwọn olólùfẹ́ẹ rẹ̀ l'ó jẹ́ Onígbàgbọ́, tí wọ́n ń gbójú sókè wò ó bí àwòkọ́ṣe rere.

english: Nigeria, with an estimated population of 200 million people, has two major religions: Christianity and Islam.
yoruba: Nàìjíríà, pẹ̀lú iye ènìyàn ìlú tí ó tó ẹgbẹẹgbẹ̀rún 200 èèyàn, ní ẹ̀sìn méjì tí àwọn ènìyàn-án ń ṣe jù: ẹ̀sìn Ìgbàgbọ́ àti Ìmàle.

english: Muslims and Christians make up 50 percent and 48 percent of the Nigerian population respectively.
yoruba: Ìmàle àti Ìgbàgbọ́ kó ìdá 50 àti ìdá 48 iye gbogbo ènìyàn t'ó ń gbé Nàìjíríà.

english: The methodology of the recent poll states that the study was conducted in Nigerian "local government areas stratified by geopolitical region".
yoruba: Ìlànà ìwádìí náà fi hàn wípé "iléeṣẹ́ ìjọba Ìpínlẹ̀ tí wọ́n sì pín àwọn ènìyàn sí agbègbè" ni wọ́n ti ṣe ìwádìí àyẹ̀wò yìí.

english: However, Adamawa, Borno, and Yobe states in northwestern Nigeria were excluded from the study due to security concerns.
yoruba: Bí ó ti wù kíó rí, kò sí ohùn àwọn Adamawa, Borno, àti ìpínlẹ̀ Yobe ní àríwá ìlà-oòrùn Nàìjíríà nínú àbájáde ìwádìí náà nítorí ọ̀rọ̀ ààbò.

english: Nigeria has 774 local government areas, the grassroots arm of executive governance structure in the country.
yoruba: Nàìjíríà ní ìjọba ìbílẹ̀ 774, tí í ṣe ẹ̀ka aláṣẹ ìjọba ìbílẹ̀. Bákan náà ni ó ní ẹ̀ka àkóso mẹ́fàá.

english: There are also six geopolitical regions: North Central, Northwest, Northeast, South-south, Southeast, and Southwest.
yoruba: Àárín gbùngbùn Àríwá, Àríwá Ìlà-oòrùn, Àríwá Ìwọ̀-oòrùn, Àjìǹdò-gúúsù, Ìwọ̀-oòrùn gúúsù, àti Ìlà-oòrùnun gúúsù.

english: Nwanze's position that Christians in southern Nigeria must have formed the core of the sample size for the Pew Research results are not unfounded.
yoruba: Ọ̀rọ̀ọ Nwanze pé àwọn Onígbàgbọ́ ní gúúsù Nàìjíríà ló pọ̀ jù lọ nínú ìwádìí àyẹ̀wò Pew Research kò ṣe é má gbàgbọ́.

english: The survey also showed that Nigerian Christians also "have a more favorable opinion of the US (69 percent) than do Muslims (54 percent)".
yoruba: Ìwádìí àyẹ̀wò náà tún fi hàn pé ọ̀pọ̀ ọmọ lẹ́yìn Krístì ní Nàìjíríà "rí orílẹ̀-èdèe US bí ìlú tí ó dára (ìdá 69) ju bí àwọn Ìmàlé ṣe rí i lọ (ìdá 54)".

english: After the killing of top Iranian General Qasem Soleimani, by the United States, Nigeria's police chief issued a national security alert to forestall any disturbances by “domestic interests.”
yoruba: Lẹ́yìn tí orílẹ̀-èdèe Amẹ́ríkà pa Ọ̀gágun ọmọ Iran Qasem Soleimani, ọ̀gá ọlọ́pàá tẹ ìkéde ìṣọ́ra ẹni jákèjádò orílẹ̀-èdèe Nàìjíríà jáde kí ó ba ti ilẹ̀kùn "ogun".

english: The Islamic movement in Nigeria described the US airstrike that killed Soleimani as a "declaration of war on Iran".
yoruba: Ẹgbẹ́ Ẹ̀sìn Ìmàle ní Nàìjíríà ṣàpèjúwe ikú oró òjò ọta ìbọn láti òkè wá tí US fi pa Soleimani gẹ́gẹ́ bí "ìpè ogun sí Ìran".

english: Trump has been described as “one of the most controversial world leaders in modern times."
yoruba: A ti ṣe àpèjúwe Trump gẹ́gẹ́ bí “ọ̀kan lára àwọn olórí àgbáyé sáà tí a wà yìí tí ó ní ọkàn líle.”

english: Yet, he is clearly adored by many in Nigeria.
yoruba: Síbẹ̀, ọ̀pọ̀ ọmọ Nàìjíríà ló fẹ́ràn-an Trump.

english: Twitter was a minefield of false information during the 2019 Nigerian elections
yoruba: Twitter di pápá ìròyìn ayédèrú lásìkò Ìdìbò ọdún-un 2019 ní Nàìjíríà

english: Ethnic hate speech and disinformation were rife on Twitter
yoruba: Ọ̀rọ̀ Ìkórìíra Ẹ̀yà àti Ayédèrú Ìròyìn tàn ká lórí Twitter

english: Image remixed by Nwachukwu Egbunike
yoruba: Àtòpọ̀ àwòrán láti ọwọ́ Nwachukwu Egbunike

english: This story is the second in a two-part series on online ethnic hate speech, disinformation and propaganda during the 2019 Nigeria elections.
yoruba: Èyí ni apá kejì ìròyìn nínú àkọsílẹ̀ ẹlẹ́ka méjì lórí ọ̀rọ̀ ìkórìíra ẹ̀yà lórí ayélujára, ìròyìn ayédèrú àti ìsọkiri lásìkò ìdìbò ọdún-un 2019 lórílẹ̀-èdèe Nàìjíríà.

english: You can read the first part here.
yoruba: O lè ka apá kìíní níbí.

english: In Nigeria, social media has a history of enabling ethnocentric disinformation and propaganda during elections.
yoruba: Ní orílẹ̀-èdèe Nàìjíríà, àwùjọ ìbánisọ̀rọ̀ orí ayélujára jẹ́ ibi tí ìròyìn ìtakora-ẹ̀yà tẹ̀gbintẹ̀gbin àti ìsọkiri ti máa ń gbilẹ̀ bíi ṣẹ́lẹ̀rú lásìkò ìdìbò.

english: During the 2015 elections, Twitter Nigeria descended into a bitter and binary sparring match between supporters of the then-two major contestants, Goodluck Jonathan (PDP, an Ijaw Christian) and Muhammadu Buhari (APC, a Hausa, Fulani Muslim).
yoruba: Ní àsìkò ìdìbò ọdún-un 2015, Twitter Nàìjíríà kó sí ìjà àti ìsọ̀rọ̀-takora láàárín àwọn alátilẹyìn olùdíje-dupò méjèèjì tí ó lérò lẹ́yìn jù lọ lásìkò náà, ìyẹn Goodluck Jonathan (ọmọ ẹgbẹ́ẹ PDP tí ó jẹ́ kìrìsìtẹ́nì àti ọmọ Ijaw) àti Muhammadu Buhari (ọmọ ẹgbẹ́ APC tí ó jẹ́ Mùsùlùmí àti ọmọ Hausa-Fulani).

english: Twitter became a tool for propagating ethnic hate and party politics.
yoruba: Túwítà di ohun èlò fún ìsọkiri ọ̀rọ̀ ìkórìíra ẹ̀yà àti ọ̀rọ̀ ẹgbẹ́ òṣèlú.

english: The 2019 elections were no exception.
yoruba: Àsìkò ìdìbò ọdún 2019 ò yàtọ̀ rárá.

english: On February 15, Reporters Without Borders (RSF) released a statement expressing its concerns over an election campaign "polluted by disinformation".
yoruba: Ní ọjọ́ 15, oṣù Èrèlé ẹgbẹ́ Ajábọ̀ Ìròyìn Láìsí Àlà (RSF) ṣe àkọsílẹ̀ kan tí ó ń ṣe àfihàn èròo wọn lórí ìpolongo ìdìbò tí "ìròyìn ayédèrú ti mú bàjẹ́ ".

english: Nigerians also expressed their concerns.
yoruba: Àwọn ọmọ orílẹ̀-èdèe Nàìjíríà náà fi èròo wọn hàn.

english: Journalist Abdulbaqi Jari tweeted:
yoruba: Akọ̀ròyìn Abdulbaqi Jari túwíìtì pé:

english: Disinformation and politics in African countries
yoruba: Ìròyìn ayédèrú àti ìṣèlú ní àwọn orílẹ̀-èdè ilẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀

english: A 2019 study by Dani Madrid-Morales, University of Huston and Herman Wasserman, University of Cape Town concluded that "mis- and disinformation campaigns have been used to influence political agendas" in Nigeria, Kenya and South Africa.
yoruba: Ìwádìí ọdún-un 2019 kan láti ọwọ́ Dani Madrid-Morales ní Ilé-ẹ̀kọ́ gíga Huston àti Herman Wasserman ní ilé-ẹ̀kọ́ gíga Cape Town fẹnukò pé "ìròyìn irọ́ àti ìròyìn ayédèrú ni wọ́n ti máa ń lò láti fi mú ìfẹ́-inú àwọn olóṣèlú ṣẹ" ní orílẹ̀-èdèe Nàìjíríà, Kenya àti South Africa.

english: The high exposure to disinformation in social media especially during electoral campaigns, leads to a "distrust" among social media users "because that's where they find 'fake news' most often", Madrid-Morales asserted.
yoruba: Ọ̀pọ̀ Ìròyìn ayédèrú lórí àwọn àwùjọ ìbánisọ̀rọ̀ orí ayélujára pàápàá lásìkò ìpolongo ìbò máa ń fa "àìgbara-eni-gbọ́ " láàárín àwọn tí wọ́n ń lo àwùjọ ìbánisọ̀rọ̀ orí ayélujára "nítorí pé ibẹ̀ ni wọ́n ti ń rí 'ìròyìn ayédèrú' lọ́pọ̀ ìgbà", Madrid-Morales sọ̀rọ̀.

english: My ethnographic study between October 28, 2018, and May 29, 2019, that covered the 2019 Nigerian elections held on February 23 (to elect a president and a national assembly), and March 9 (to elect governors and state houses of assembly) revealed two major categories of false information: ethnocentric driven disinformation and political propaganda.
yoruba: Ìwádìí mi lórí onírúurú ẹ̀yà láàárín ọjọ́ 28, oṣù Ọ̀wàrà ọdún-un 2018 àti ọjọ́ 29 oṣù Èbìbí, ọdún-un 2019 lórí ìdìbò ọdún-un 2019 lórílẹ̀-èdèe Nàìjíríà tó wáyé ní ọjọ́ 23, oṣù Èrèlé (láti dìbò yan ààrẹ àti aṣòfin sí ilé ìgbìmọ̀ aṣòfin ti orílẹ̀-èdè) àti ọjọ́ 9, oṣù Erénà (láti yan gómìnà àti aṣòfin sí ilé-ìgbìmọ̀ aṣòfin ti ìjọba ìpínlẹ̀) ṣe àfihàn ìṣẹ̀lẹ̀ ìròyìn ayédèrú méjì pàtàkì kan: ìròyìn ayédèrú tó tako ẹ̀yà kan àti ìsọkiri láti mú èrò inú àwọn olóṣèlú ṣẹ.

english: Ethnically charged disinformation
yoruba: Ìròyìn Ayédèrú tó tako ẹ̀yà

english: Peter Obi, the running mate of the opposition People's Democratic Party (PDP) presidential candidate Atiku Abubakar, was a victim of ethnocentric disinformation during the last elections.
yoruba: Peter Obi, igbá kejì Atiku Abubakar tí ó jẹ́ òǹdíje-dupò ẹgbẹ́ òṣèlú (PDP) jẹ́ ẹni tí ó dojú kọ ìpalára ìròyìn ayédèrú tó tako ẹ̀yà lásìkò ìdìbò tó kọjá.

english: Obi was the former governor of Anambra State, in southeast Nigeria.
yoruba: Obi jẹ́ gómìnà ìgbà kan rí ní ìpínlẹ̀ Anambra ní gúúsù-ìlà oòrùn Nàìjíríà.

english: A Twitter account supporting the Buhari-Osinbajo campaign, Coalition of Buhari-Osibanjo Movement, shared a tweet (Figure 1) which accused Obi of "deporting" northerners from Anambra State as governor.
yoruba: Ìkànni Túwítà kan tí ó ń ṣe àtìlẹyìn ìpolongo fún Buhari-Osinbajo, Coalition of Buhari-Osinbajo Movement pín Túwíìtì kan (Atọ́ka 1) tí ó ń fẹ̀sùn kan Obi pé ó “lé àwọn ará àríwá orílẹ̀-èdèe Nàìjíríà kúrò ní ìpínlẹ̀ Anambra nígbà tí ó jẹ́ gómìnà.

english: Figure 1: Screenshot of a tweet by Coalition of Buhari-Osibanjo Movement accusing Obi of 'deporting' northerners.
yoruba: Àwòrán 1: Àwòrán Túwíìtì kan láti ọwọ́ Coalition of Buhari-Osibanjo Movement tí ó ń fẹ̀sùn kan òbí pé ó ṣe ‘ìdápadà’ àwọn ará àríwá sí ìlúu wọn.

english: Figure 2: Screenshot of a tweet by Nasir El-Rufia
yoruba: Atọ́ka 2: Àwòrán Túwíìtì kan láti ọwọ́ Nasir El-Rufia

english: This charge was amplified by Nasir El-Rufai, Governor of Kaduna State and member of the ruling APC, who tweeted (Figure 2) that Obi was "a tribal bigot".
yoruba: Gómìnà ìpínlẹ̀-ẹ Kaduna àti ọmọ ẹgbẹ́ òṣèlú tí ó ń ṣè ìjọba lọ́wọ́, Nasir El-Rufai, mú ẹ̀sùn yìí rinlẹ̀ sí i, ó túwíìtì (Atọ́ka 2) pé Obi jẹ́ "ẹni tí ó ń ṣe ìyàtọ̀ọ̀tọ̀ ẹ̀yà".

english: This, according to El-Rufai, made Obi unfit to be a vice president of Nigeria.
yoruba: Ohun tí El-Rufai sọ yìí ò mú kí ipò igbákejì ààrẹ tọ́ fún Obi.

english: Read more: Nigerian governor warns foreign governments: Interfere in our elections and 'go back in body bags'
yoruba: Kà sí i: Gómìnà kan ní Nàìjíríà kìlọ̀ fún ìjọba ilẹ̀ òkèèrè: Ẹ dá sí ọ̀rọ̀ ìdìbò wa kí 'ẹ padà sí ìlú yín ní òkú'

english: What really happened?
yoruba: Kí ni ohun tí ó ṣẹlẹ̀ gan-an?

english: In July 2013, 67 Nigerians, mostly from the Igbo ethnic group, "were deported all the way from Lagos and dumped at almost the same spot at the popular Upper Iweka area" in Onitsha, Anambra State, reported the Nigerian Vanguard newspaper.
yoruba: Ilé-iṣẹ́ ìwé ìròyìn Vanguard jábọ̀ wípé ní oṣù Agẹmọ ọdún-un 2013, ọmọ Nàìjíríà 67 tí ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ wọn wá láti ilẹ̀-ẹ Igbo ni "wọ́n dá padà láti Èkó tí wọ́n sì pa wọ́n tì sí ibi kan náà ní agbègbè Upper Iweka" tí ó gbajúmọ̀ ní Onitsha, Ìpínlẹ̀ Anambra.

english: Obi, who was then the governor of Anambra State, described this action by his Lagos State colleague, Tunde Fashola, as "illegal, unconstitutional, and a blatant violation of the human rights of the deportees".
yoruba: Obi, tí ó jẹ́ gómìnà ìpínlẹ̀ Anambra ní ìgbà náà, ṣàpèjúwe ìhùwàsí yìí tí akẹgbẹ́-ẹ ‘ẹ̀ Túndé Fáṣọlá ní ìpínlẹ̀ Èkó hù gẹ́gẹ́ bí "ohun tí kò bá òfin mu àti ìrúfin ẹ̀tọ́ ọmọnìyàn àwọn ẹni tí ó di èrò ìlúu wọn".

english: Following the public fury that this action generated, Premium Times reported that Obi was also guilty of the same action:
yoruba: Lẹ́yìn ìbínúu gbogboògbò tí ọ̀rọ̀ yìí fà, Premium Times jábọ̀ pé Obi náà jẹ̀bi irú ọ̀rọ̀ bẹ́ẹ̀:

english: In 2011, he repatriated child beggars back to Ebonyi and Akwa Ibom states, both in southern Nigeria.
yoruba: Ní 2011, ó lé àwọn atọrọbárà tó jẹ́ ọmọdé padà sí ìpínlẹ̀ Ebonyi àti Akwa Ibom, ní apá gúúsù orílẹ̀-èdèe Nàìjíríà.

english: Figure 3: Screenshot of a tweet by Jubril A. Gawat
yoruba: Atọ́ka 3: Àwòrán Túwíìtì kan láti ọwọ́ Jubril A. Gawat

english: While Obi did indeed deport beggars back to states in Southern Nigeria, he did not deport northerners and the accusation tweeted (Figure 1) by the Coalition of Buhari-Osibanjo Movement Twitter account was inaccurate.
yoruba: Nígbà tí Obi dá àwọn oníbárà padà sí àwọn ìpínlẹ̀ ní Gúúsù Nàìjíríà lóòótọ́, kò lé àwọn ará Àríwá, ẹ̀sùn tí ìṣàmúlò-o Twitter ẹgbẹ́ alátìlẹ́yìn-in Coalition of Buhari-Osinbajo Movement túwíìtì (Atọ́ka 1) kò gún régé.

english: Rather it was APC's Tunde Fashola, who in December 2014, "deported 70 northerners, found publicly begging" back to Kano State, according to the online investigative newspaper Sahara Reporters.
yoruba: Kódà Túndé Fáṣọlá ti ẹgbẹ́ APC ni ó "ṣe ìdápadà àwọn ará Àríwá 70 sí ìpínlẹ̀-ẹ Kano nítorí wọ́n tọrọ bárà" gẹ́gẹ́ bí ìwé ìròyìn aṣèwádìí lórí ayélujára Sahara Reporters ṣẹ jábọ̀.

english: However, this ethnically motivated disinformation was employed by APC supporters on Twitter to discredit their opponent.
yoruba: Bẹ́ẹ̀ àwọn agbèsẹ́yìn egbẹ́ òṣèlú APC ni wọ́n ṣàmúlò ìròyìn ayédèrú tó tako ẹ̀yà kan yìí láti fi bu ẹnu àtẹ́ lu òǹdíje-dupò lábẹ́ àsíá ẹgbẹ́ tó tako ẹ̀gbẹ́ẹ wọn.

english: For instance, Jubril A. Gawat recently appointed as Lagos State's senior special assistant on new media tweeted that (Figure 3) a vote for opposition candidate Atiku Abubakar "is a vote for Igbo".
yoruba: Fún àpẹẹrẹ, Jubril Gawat tí wọ́n ṣẹ̀ṣẹ̀ yàn sípò aṣèrànwọ́ Gómìnà pàtàkì lórí ẹ̀rọ ìgbéròyìnjáde ìgbàlódé tuntun túwíìtì pé (Atọ́ka 3) ìbò kan fún òǹdíje-dupò ẹgbẹ́ atako Atiku Abubakar “jẹ́ ìbò fún ẹ̀yà Igbo.”

english: Nigeria is a country where ethnic identities run deep.
yoruba: Nàìjíríà jẹ́ orílẹ̀-èdè kan tí ọ̀rọ̀ ẹ̀yà ti rinlẹ̀ gan-an.

english: These divisions are usually exploited during elections by politicians because of the obvious need to pitch their opponents into opposing camps of "we" versus "them".
yoruba: Àwọn olóṣèlú sì máa ń sa ẹ̀yàmẹyà yìí bí oògùn ní àsìkò ìdìbò nítorí wọ́n máa ń nílò láti pín àwọn ènìyàn sí ẹgbẹ́ “àwa” pẹ̀lú "wọn".

english: Hence, the allegations that Obi deported northerners was meant to re-ignite the ethnic animosities between the Igbo and Hausa, Fulani that led to the Nigerian Civil War.
yoruba: Nítorí náà, wọ́n ní í lọ́kàn láti fi ẹ̀sùn tí wọ́n fi kan Obi pé ó lé àwọn ará Àríwá padà sí ìlú wọn rú inúnibíni tí ó ti wà tẹ́lẹ̀ láàárín ẹ̀yà Igbo àti Hausa tí ó fa Ogun Abẹ́lée Nàìjíríà.

english: The aim of these disinformation campaigns was to paint Obi as a Biafran ethnic irredentist.
yoruba: Èròǹgbà wọn pẹ̀lú ìpolongo àwọn ìròyìn ayédèrú yìí ni láti ṣe àfihàn Obi gẹ́gẹ́ bí ajìjàǹgbara fún ẹ̀yà Biafra.

english: Located in southeastern Nigeria, the breakaway Republic of Biafra, which lasted for three years through a bitter civil war between 1967 to 1970, is largely populated by the Igbo.
yoruba: Ẹ̀yà tó wà ní Gúúsù-ìwọ̀ oòrùn Nàìjíríà, tí ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ wọn jẹ́ ọmọ Igbo gbìyànjú láti ya kúrò lára orílẹ̀-èdè nípasẹ̀ ogun abẹ́lé tí ó wáyé fún ọdún mẹ́ta láàárín ọdún 1967 sí 1970.

english: Thus, Figure 3 proclamation that "a vote for Atiku is a vote for Igbo..."  was aimed to revive the ghost of the acrimonious ethnic hatred that pitched Hausa against Igbo.
yoruba: Fún ìdí èyí, wọ́n ní í lọ́kàn láti lo àkọsílẹ̀ inú atọ́ka 3 tí ó sọ pé "Ìbò kan fún Atiku jẹ́ ibo fún ẹ̀yà Igbo..." fi jí òkú ìkórìíra ẹ̀yà tẹ̀gbintẹ̀gbin tí ó ti wà láàárín ẹ̀yà Hausa àti Igbo.

english: In 2019 elections, this meant that Atiku is a supporter of the Igbo who had once tried to break away from Nigeria.
yoruba: Ní àsìkò ìdìbò ọdún-un 2019, èyí túmọ̀ sí pé Atiku jẹ́ agbèsẹ́yìn ẹ̀yà Igbo tí wọ́n ti fìgbà kan gbìyànjú láti pínyà kúrò nínú orílẹ̀-èdèe Nàìjíríà.

english: Statements in Figures 1-3 convey strong emotions capable of reopening pent up memories, which in most cases have still not received closure, from both sides of the divide.
yoruba: Àkọsílẹ̀ inú atọ́ka 1 dé 3 ń ṣe àfihàn àwọn èrò tí ó lágbára láti jí ìṣẹ̀lẹ̀ àtijọ́ tí ó ti relẹ̀, tí kòì tí ì tán nínú àwọn ẹ̀yà méjèèjì.

english: The United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization (UNESCO) maintains that disinformation like this targets the "vulnerability or partisan potential of recipients" by turning them into "amplifiers and multipliers".
yoruba: Àjọ UNESCO sọ pé ìròyìn ayédèrú báyìí máa ń lapa lára àwọn “tí ó mọ̀ díẹ̀ káàtó tí ìpalára lè bá tí ó ń gbà á” yóó sì sọ wọ́n di "aláriwo àti alápìínká ìròyìn náà".

english: Ethnically-charged electoral campaigns not only exploit deeply rooted prejudices but also morph recipients into disseminators of false information.
yoruba: Ìpolongo ìbò tí ó bá ti ń tako ẹ̀yà kan máa ń fi ẹ̀tanú tó rinlẹ̀ sínú ọkàn àwọn tí ó ń gbọ́ ọ, ó sì máa ń sọ àwọn olùgbọ́ yìí di alápìínká ìròyìn ayédèrú.

english: Fabricated claims of Yoruba burning Igbo shops in Lagos
yoruba: Irọ́ tí wọ́n pa pé àwọn Yorùbá ń tiná bọ ìsọ̀ àwọn ọmọ Igbo nílùú Èkó

english: Figure 4: Screenshot of a tweet [flagged and pulled down by Twitter] by Chioma spreading disinformation of Yoruba burning Igbo shops in Lagos
yoruba: Atọ́ka 4: Àwòrán Túwíìtì kan [ti Twitter lòdì sí tí wọ́n sì yọ kúrò] láti ọwọ́ Chioma tí ó ń ṣe ìtànká ìròyìn ayédèrú pé àwọn Yorùbá ń dáná sun ìsọ̀ àwọn Igbo nílùú Èkó.

english: Similarly, ethnocentrism was also used by PDP supporters on Twitter to drive votes against the APC in Lagos State.
yoruba: Bákan náà, àwọn agbèsẹ́yìn ẹgbẹ́ẹ PDP náà lo ọ̀rọ̀ ìdójúkọ ẹ̀yà yìí láti kó ìbò ju ẹgbẹ́ẹ APC lọ ní ìpínlẹ̀ Èkó.

english: Figures 4 and 5 show tweets by a PDP sympathizer alleging that Yoruba had set Igbo shops in Lagos on fire.
yoruba: Atọ́ka 4 àti 5 ń ṣàfihàn àwòrán Túwíìtì láti ọwọ́ abánikẹ́dùn PDP kan tí ó ń sọ pé àwọn Yorùbá ti ń ti iná bọ ìsọ̀ àwọn ọmọ Igbo nílùú Èkó.

english: The stories were false and were quickly dispelled by the Lagos State Police.
yoruba: Irọ́ ni àwọn ìròyìn náà, Àjọ Ọlọ́pàá ìpínlẹ̀ Èkó sì tètè fi òtítọ́ hàn láti pa á rẹ́.

english: A Facebook post, using nearly the same words from Figure 4, and a picture depicting roads blocked by burning tires, circulated the same false claims.
yoruba: Àkọsílẹ̀ orí Facebook kan tí ó fẹ́rẹ̀ẹ́ ṣàmúlò gbogbo ọ̀rọ̀ inú àwòrán atọ́ka 4, pẹ̀lú àwòrán ibi tí wọ́n ti fi táyà tó ń jó dí ọ̀nà náà ṣe àpínká ìròyìn irọ́ náà.

english: The photo used was from a February 24, 2017 protest that took place in a province near Pretoria, South Africa, reported African Check.
yoruba: African Check jábọ̀ pé àwòrán tí wọ́n lò yìí jẹ́ àwòrán kan lati ibi ìfẹ̀hónúhàn kan ni ọjọ́ 24 oṣù Èrèlé ọdún 2017 tí ó wáyé ní agbègbè kan nítòsí Pretoria ní orílẹ̀ èdè South Africa.

english: Figure 5: Screenshot of a tweet spreading disinformation of Yoruba burning Igbo shops in Lagos II
yoruba: Atọ́ka 5: Àwòrán Túwíìtì kan tí ó ń ṣe ìtànká ìròyìn ayédèrú kan pé àwọn Yorùbá ń tiná bọ ìsọ̀ àwọn ọmọ Igbo nílùú Èkó II

english: Political propaganda
yoruba: Ìsọkiri láti mú èrò inú àwọn olóṣèlú ṣẹ

english: On February 13, Twitter user Souljah tweeted (Figure 6) that Ballard Partners, a PR firm based in Washington DC, which was allegedly hired as a publicist for the Abubakar presidential campaign, had conducted a poll which predicted a loss for the opposition PDP presidential candidate.
yoruba: Ní ọjọ́ 13 oṣù Èrèlé, olùṣàmúlò Túwítà kan Souljah túwíìtì (Atọ́ka 6) pé Ballard Partners, tí ó jẹ́ iléeṣẹ́ Alukoro kan tí wọ́n gbà síṣẹ́ tí ó kalẹ̀ sí Washington DC, láti ṣe ìpolongo fún Abubakar gẹ́gẹ́ bí Ààrẹ, ṣe ìwádìí àyẹ̀wò lábẹ́lẹ̀ kan tí ó ti ṣàpẹẹrẹ ìfìdírẹmi òǹdíje-dupò lábẹ́ àsiá ẹgbẹ́ alátakò, ìyẹn PDP.

english: The result of the survey was conveyed in a letter signed by Brian Ballard, head of Ballard Partners, on February 5, and addressed to Olusola Saraki, the Director-General of Abubakar's campaign.
yoruba: Ní ọjọ́ 5, oṣù Èrèlé, ìwé àbájáde ìwádìí náà tí Brian Ballard, adaríiléeṣẹ́ Ballard Partners buwọ́lù tẹ Olúṣọlá Saraki, tí ó jẹ́ adarí pátápátá fún ìpolongo ìbò Abubakar lọ́wọ́.

english: Souljah's tweet went viral with over 1 million likes and 1 million retweets for obvious reasons.
yoruba: Túwíìtì Souljah tàn káàkiri tí ènìyàn ẹgbẹẹgbẹ̀rún kan fẹ́ràn-an rẹ̀, tí ẹgbẹẹgbẹ̀rún ènìyàn-án sì ṣe àtúnpín-in rẹ̀ fún ìdí tí ò f'ara sin.

english: The presidential election was previously slated to hold on February 16 (later postponed to February 23) and, with this poll coming three days before the elections, would have been catastrophic for the opposition PDP.
yoruba: Wọ́n gbé ọjọ́ ìdìbò láti yan ààrẹ sí ọjọ́ 16 oṣù Èrèlé (tí wọ́n padà sún un síwájú sí ọjọ́ 23 oṣù Èrèlé), nǹkan ò bá bàjẹ́ fún ẹgbẹ́ asàtakò PDP pẹ̀lú àbájáde ìwádìí tí ó ń fara hàn ní ọjọ́ mẹ́ta kí ìdìbò ó tó wáyé yìí..

english: Read more: Nigeria postpones 2019 general elections hours before polls open, citing 'logistics and operations' concerns
yoruba: Kà sí i: Nàìjíríà sún ìdìbò gbogboògbò ọdún-un 2019 síwájú nígbà tí ìdìbò kú ìwọ̀n-ọn wákàtí nítorí ọ̀rọ̀ 'ètò àti ìlànà ìmúṣẹ́ṣe'

english: Figure 6: Screenshot of a tweet by Souljah
yoruba: Atọ́ka 6: Àwòrán Túwíìtì kan láti ọwọ́ Souljah

english: However, by the evening of February 13, Ballard Partners refuted the said survey (Figure 7) which they described as "fraudulent" and maintained that they had not "conducted any survey research on behalf of the People’s Democratic Party of Nigeria".
yoruba: Sùgbọ́n ní ìrólẹ́ ọjọ́ 13 oṣù Èrèlé, Ballard Partners ní àbájáde ìwádìí náà kò rí bẹ́ẹ̀ (Atọ́ka 7) tí wọ́n ṣe àpèjúwe rẹ̀ gẹ́gẹ́ bí i "jìbìtì", wọ́n sì fi ìdíi rẹ̀ múlẹ̀ pé àwọn kò "ṣe ìwádìí kankan fún ẹgbẹ́ òṣèlú PDP".

english: Ose Anenih, a PDP supporter reported some of the APC Twitter sympathizers who circulated the fake poll to the Twitter handle of the Nigerian police and the Independent Electoral Commission, the electoral umpire, for "criminally and illegally" trying to "interfere with free and fair elections".
yoruba: Ose Anenih, tí ó jẹ́ agbèsẹ́yìn ẹgbẹ́ PDP ṣe ìfisùn lára àwọn ará APC orí Túwítà tí wọ́n ṣe ìtànká àbájáde ìwádìí náà sí ìkànni àwọn ọlọ́pàá orílẹ̀-èdèe Nàìjíríà àti àjọ tí ó ń ṣe àmójútó ọ̀rọ̀ ìdìbò, INEC fún “ìwà ọ̀daràn àti ohun tí ó lòdì sófin” tí ó ń gbìyànjú "láti dí ìdìbò tí ó yẹ kí ó lọ nírọ̀rùn lọ́wọ́ ".

english: But this was not the only case of weaponizing disinformation for political propaganda that was witnessed online during the elections.
yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n èyí kì í ṣe ìgbà àkọ́kọ́ tí wọ́n máa fi ìròyìn ayédèrú mú èrò inú àwọn olóṣèlú ṣẹ lórí ayélujára ní àsìkò ìdìbò.

english: Figure 7: Screenshot of a tweet by Ballard and Partners refuting a fake poll attributed to them.
yoruba: Atọ́ka 7: Àwòrán Túwíìtì kan láti ọwọ́ iléeṣẹ́ Ballard and Partners tí í sẹ́ ayédèrú ìwádìí tí wọ́n purọ́ mọ́ wọn pé wọ́n ṣe.

english: The many lies of a presidential aide
yoruba: Ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ irọ́ olùrànlọ́wọ́ ààrẹ

english: Figure 8: Screenshot of a tweet by Lauretta Onochie, aide to the Nigerian president
yoruba: Atọ́ka 8: Àwòrán Túwíìtì kan by Lauretta Onochie, láti ọwọ́ Lauretta Onochie, tí ó jẹ́ olùrànlọ́wọ́ fún ààrẹ

english: On December 4, 2018, Lauretta Onochie, presidential aide to Buhari [then incumbent presidential candidate]  tweeted (Figure 8) a picture with food and 500 naira notes that was purportedly shared with the crowd that attended Abubakar's presidential rally in Sokoto in northwest Nigeria, the previous day.
yoruba: Ní ọjọ́ 4, oṣù Ọ̀pẹ, ọdún-un 2018 Lauretta Onochie, tí ó jẹ́ olùrànlọ́wọ́ fún Buhari [tí ó jẹ́ òǹdíje-dupò ààrẹ lásìkò náà] túwíìtì (Atọ́ka 8) àwòrán kan pẹ̀lú oúnjẹ àti owóo náírà 500 tí wọ́n ní wọ́n pín fún àwọn èrò lọ́jọ́ kejì ìrìnde ìpolongo ìdìbò fún Abubakar gẹ́gẹ́ bí ààrẹ ní Sokoto, apá àríwá-ìlà oòrùn orílẹ̀-èdèe Nàìjíríà ní àná ọjọ́ náà.

english: Onochie's allegations were completely false. In fact, the picture she shared "was taken in February 2017" at an event unrelated to "electioneering", Chuba Ugwu pointed out in a reply to her tweet.
yoruba: Irọ́ pátápátá ni àwọn ẹ̀sùn Onochie. Kódà, níbi òde kan tí kò tan mọ́ “ọ̀rọ̀ ìdìbò” ni a ti ya àwòrán náà nínú “oṣù Èrèlé ọdún-un 2017″, Chuba Ugwu tan ìmọ́lẹ̀ sí èyí nínú èsì sí túwíìtì rẹ̀ kan.

english: Onochie appears to be a specialist in disseminating falsehoods. The International Centre for Investigative Reporting (ICIR), an online news portal, analysed over 1,000 images shared on Twitter by Onochie between August 1, 2018, and July  31, 2019. The analysis revealed that "in at least 12 cases" Onochie "had used inaccurate pictures".
yoruba: Onochie jẹ́ ògbóǹtarìgì níbi ká máa ṣe àpínká ìròyìn ayédèrú. Iléeṣẹ́ agbéròyìnjáde orí ayélujára kan tí ó ń ṣe ìwádìí ìjábọ̀ ìròyìn (ICIR), ti ṣe àgbéyẹ̀wò àwòrán tó ju 1,000 lọ tí Onochie ti pín sórí Twitter láàárín ọjọ́ 1, oṣù Ògún ọdún-un 2018 àti ọjọ́ 31, oṣù Agẹmọ ọdún-un 2019. Àgbéyẹ̀wò náà fi hàn pé ó kéré tán "ìgbà méjìlá" ni Onochie "ti lo àwòrán tí kò yẹ".

english: Online hate speech: a crime in Nigeria
yoruba: Ọ̀rọ̀ Àtakò lórí Ayélujára: ọ̀ràn ní Nàìjíríà

english: Section 26 of Nigeria's Cybercrime Act prohibits "use of threats of violence and insulting statements to persons based on race, religion, colour, descent or national or ethnic origin".
yoruba: Abala 26 òfin Nàìjíríà nípa ọ̀ràn orí ayélujára kọ "lílérí ìjà àti lílo ọ̀rọ̀ èébú sí àwọn èèyàn nítorí ẹ̀yàa wọn, ẹ̀sìn-in wọn, àwọ̀-ọ wọn, ìràn-an wọn tàbí orílẹ̀-èdèe wọn".

english: Convicted persons risk a five-year jail term or a fine not less than 10 million nairas [about $28,000 United States dollars] or both.
yoruba: Àwọn ẹni tí adé ìwà náà bá ṣí mọ́ lórí á fi ẹ̀wọ̀n ọlọ́dún-márùn-ún gbára tàbí kí wọ́n san owó ìtanràn tí kò dín ní ẹgbẹẹgbẹ̀rún 10 owóo naira [tí ó ń lọ bí i $28,000] tàbí méjèèjì.

english: In March this year, Enough is Enough Nigeria (EIE), a youth-based movement and Paradigm Initiative (PI), a digital rights policy and advocacy group, instituted a court case in an Abuja court against Onochie and Gbenga Olorunpomi, an aide to Kogi State governor.
yoruba: Ní oṣù Ẹrẹ́nà ọdún yìí, Enough is Enough Nigeria (EIE), tí ó jẹ́ àkójọpọ̀ àwọn ọ̀dọ́ kan àti Paradigm Initiative (PI), tí ó jẹ́ ẹgbẹ́ aṣòfin àti ajàfẹ́tọ̀ọ́ ẹni lórí ẹ̀rọ-ayárabíàṣá, ṣe ìfilọ́lẹ̀ ìpèlẹ́jọ́ Onochie àti Gbénga Ọlọ́runpomi tí ó jẹ́ olùrànlọ́wọ́ gómìnà ìpínlẹ̀-ẹ Kogi lẹ́jọ́ ní Ilé-ẹjọ́ kan ní Abuja.

english: The two organisations compiled instances of hate speech "gathered from online comments" made by Onochie and Olorunpomi which they deemed to be in violation of Nigeria’s Cybercrime Act of 2015.
yoruba: Àjọ méjèèjì yìí "ṣe àkópọ̀ àwọn ọ̀rọ̀ àtakò tí ó jẹ́ ọ̀rọ̀ Onochie àti Ọlọ́runpomi lórí ayélujára" tí wọ́n rí i pé ó rú òfin orílẹ̀-èdèe Nàìjíríà nípa ọ̀ràn orí ayélujára ti 2015.

english: Read more: How will propaganda shape Nigeria's 2019 presidential elections?
yoruba: Kà sí i: Báwo ni ìsọkiri yóò ṣe to ìdìbò ààrẹ orílẹ̀-èdèe Nàìjíríà ti 2019?

english: An army of Twitter warriors propagating falsehoods
yoruba: Àkójọpọ̀ àwọn ajagun orí Twitter tí wọ́n ń ṣe àpínká irọ́

english: Most of the instances highlighted above were not mere happenstance. Rather, there was a deliberate and systematic effort to pass off lies as true information.
yoruba: Púpọ̀ nínú àwọn àpẹẹrẹ tí a ṣe lókè yìí kì í ṣe ohun tí wọn kò mọ̀-ọ́n-mọ̀ ṣe. Wọ́n dìídì gbìyànjú láti ṣe àpínká irọ́ bí i pé òótọ́ ni.

english: This is not surprising considering that both APC and PDP engaged an army of online warriors to either "neutralize adverse" social media reports or “fend off” attacks during the campaign periods.
yoruba: Èyí kò yani lẹ́nu rárá nítorí a rí i pé APC àti PDP ni wọ́n di ajagun orí ayélujára láti lè ṣe "ìmúwálẹ̀ ìjábọ̀ búburú" lórí ayélujára nípa wọn tàbí láti “gbèjà” níbi ìdojúkọ lásìkò ìpolongo ìbò.

english: Each side engaged "cyber troops" — "government or political party actors tasked with manipulating public opinion online".
yoruba: Ẹgbẹ́ méjèèjì ni ó ṣe àmúlò "ajagun orí ayélujára" — "àwọn akópa nínú ìjọba tàbí ẹgbẹ́ òṣèlú tí wọ́n fún ní iṣẹ́ láti tọwọ́bọ ọpọlọ àwọn ará ìlú láti yí èròo wọn padà lórí ayélujára".

english: This year's elections were a repeat of 2015, where both APC and PDP engaged in "disinformation, misinformation, propaganda" campaigns on social media that were "carefully designed to hoodwink the unsuspecting electorate", asserts Eshemokha Austin Maho, a Nigerian media scholar.
yoruba: Ìdìbò ọdún yìí jẹ́ àṣẹtúnṣe ti 2015, níbi tí APC àti PDP ti kópa nínú ìtànká ìròyìn ayédèrú àti irọ́ pẹ̀lú ìsọkiri láti mú èrò àwọn olóṣèlú ṣẹ “nínú àwọn ìpolongo wọn lórí àwùjọ ayélujára tí wọ́n “fara balẹ̀ ṣètò láti fi tan àwọn olùdìbò tí kò fura, “báyìí ni Eshemokha Austin Maho, tí ó jẹ́ ọ̀mọ̀wé Nàìjíríà kan nípa ìkéde àti ìgbéròyìnjáde ṣe sọ.

english: They achieved this through the creation of "bogus social media accounts" from which "smear campaigns" and "doubtful information and propaganda" were disseminated.
yoruba: Wọ́n rí èyí ṣe nípasẹ̀ “ìdásílẹ̀ àwọn ìkànnì irọ́ lórí ayélujára "níbi tí wọ́n ti ń pín “ọ̀rọ̀ ibanilórúkọjẹ́ " àti "ìròyìn tí kò ṣe é fọkàn tán pẹ̀lú ìsọkiri láti mú èrò àwọn olóṣèlú ṣẹ".

english: The resultant impact was that Twitter became a battleground of ethnocentric disinformation and political propaganda before, during and in the immediate aftermath of the 2019 elections in Nigeria.
yoruba: Àbájáde tí ipa wọn kó ni pé Twitter di pápá ìròyìn ayédèrú tí ó ń ṣe ẹlẹ́yàmẹyà àti ìsọkiri láti mú èrò àwọn olóṣèlú ṣẹ ṣáájú àsìkò ìdìbò, ní àsìkò ìdìbò àti lẹ́yìn ìdìbò ọdún-un 2019 lórílẹ̀-èdèe Nàìjíríà.

english: This article is part of a series of posts examining interference with digital rights through methods such as network shutdowns and disinformation during key political events in seven African countries: Algeria, Ethiopia, Mozambique, Nigeria, Tunisia, Uganda, and Zimbabwe.
yoruba: Àròkọ yìí jẹ́ apá kan nínú ọ̀wọ̀ọ́ àwọn àkọsílẹ̀ tí ó ń ṣe àgbéyẹ̀wò ìkọlura pẹ̀lú ẹ̀tọ́ ẹni lórí ayélujára nípasẹ̀ àwọn ìlànà bí i pípa òpó ìbánisọ̀rọ̀ àti ìròyìn ayédèrú ní àsìkò tí ọ̀rọ̀ ìṣèlú pàtàkì bá ń wáyé ní orílẹ̀-èdè ilẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀ méje: Algeria, Ethiopia, Mozambique, Nigeria, Tunisia, Uganda, and Zimbabwe.

english: The project is funded by the Africa Digital Rights Fund of The Collaboration on International ICT Policy for East and Southern Africa (CIPESA).
yoruba: Àjọ tí ó ń ṣàmójútó ẹ̀tọ́ ẹni lórí ẹ̀rọ Africa Digital Rights Fund ti The Collaboration on International ICT Policy for East and Southern Africa (CIPESA) ni ó ṣe agbátẹrù iṣẹ́ yìí.

english: Africa's creative industries get a half-billion-dollar boost by big banks to reap the vast fortunes lying in wait'
yoruba: Ilẹ̀-Adúláwọ̀ rí àbọ̀ ẹgbẹẹgbẹ̀rún-lọ́nà-ẹgbẹ̀rún owóo dollar láti ọ̀dọ̀ Ilé-ìfowópamọ́sí ńláńlá fún ìgbéfúkẹ́ Iléeṣẹ́ ọgbọ́n àtinudá

english: Screenshot of Nigerian artist D'banj speaking at CAX Weekend in Cairo, Egypt, 2018.
yoruba: Àwọn ọlọ́gbọ́n àtinudá Ilẹ̀-Adúláwọ̀ gbọdọ̀ 'ká èso ọrọ̀ tí ó pọ̀ tí ó ń dúró fún kíká'

english: Dbanj told investors that "content is the next crude oil" and must be respected as much.
yoruba: Àgékù àwòrán ọ̀kọrin ọmọ orílẹ̀-èdèe Nàìjíríà D'banj ń sọ̀rọ̀ níbi ètò Ọjọ́ Ìsinmi CAX ní Cairo, Egypt, ọdún-un 2018. Dbanj sọ fún olùdókoòwò wípé “iṣẹ́ àtinúdá ni epo rọ̀bì tí ọpọ́n sún kàn” tí ó sì yẹ kí a bu ìyìn fún.

english: In recent years, cultural and creative industries have played a growing role in developing economies, in terms of their economic contribution as well as their power to effect social change and cultural engagement.
yoruba: Ó ti pẹ́ tí àwọn iléeṣẹ́ ìgbélárugẹ àṣà àti ọgbọ́n àtinudá ti ń ṣe ohun mèremère ní ti ìdàgbàsókè ọrọ̀ Ajé, ní ti ipa tí wọ́n ń kó àti agbára tí ó wà níkàáwọ́ wọn láti mú àyípadà dé bá àwùjọ àti ìpàṣípààrọ̀ àṣà.

english: In 2013, cultural and creative industries (CCI) generated $2,250 billion United States dollars worth of revenue and 29.5 million jobs worldwide [but] only 3 percent of these jobs came from Africa and the Middle East, according to a 2013 study by the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization (UNESCO) called “Cultural time.”
yoruba: Lọ́dún-un 2013, iléeṣẹ́ ìgbélárugẹ àṣà àti ọgbọ́n àtinudá (CCI) rí owó ẹgbẹẹgbẹ̀rún-lọ́nà-ẹgbẹ̀rún 2,250 dollar ti Ìṣọ̀kan Orílẹ̀-èdèe Amẹ́ríkà àti iṣẹ́ tí ẹgbẹẹgbẹ̀rún 29.5 kárí ayé [àmọ́] ìdá 3 àwọn iṣẹ́ wọ̀nyí wá láti Ilẹ̀-Adúláwọ̀ àti Àárín gbùngbùn Ìlà-Oòrùn tí ó jẹ́ agbègbè àwọn aráa Lárúbáwá, ìyẹn gẹ́gẹ́ bí ìwádìí àyẹ̀wò fínnífínní Àjọ Ìṣọ̀kan Àgbáyé fún Ẹ̀kọ́, Ìwádìí Ìjìnlẹ̀ àti Àṣà (UNESCO) ọdún-un 2013 tí a pè ní “Àsìkò Àṣà” kan ti ṣe fi hàn.

english: For this reason, African Export-Import Bank (Afreximbank) in collaboration with UNESCO and African Development Bank Group, developed the Creative Africa Exchange (CAX) as a "catalyst that brings together the identified assets and resources within the creative industry" to consolidate, monetize and impact African creative and cultural economies, according to the CAX website.
yoruba: Torí ìdí èyí, Ilé-ìfowópamọ́sí Ọjà títa sókè òkun-àti-kíkó ọjà wọlé (Afreximbank) pẹ̀lú àbáṣepọ̀ọ UNESCO àti Ẹgbẹ́ Ilé-ìfowópamọ́sí Ìdàgbàsókè Ilẹ̀-Adúláwọ̀, ṣe àgbékalẹ̀ Ìpàṣípààrọ̀ Ọgbọ́n Àtinudá Ilẹ̀-Adúláwọ̀ – Creative Africa Exchange (CAX) tí yóò "dúró gẹ́gẹ́ bíi ohun tí yóò ṣe àmúpapọ̀ àwọn nǹkan ọrọ̀ àti àlùmọ́nì tí ó wà nínú iléeṣẹ́ ọgbọ́n àtinudá" tí yóò ṣe àgbéró, mú owó wọlé àti lapa rere lára àwọn ọlọ́gbọ́n àtinudá àti àwọn oníṣẹ́ àṣà, bí ibùdó ìtakùn àgbáyé CAX ṣe ní i lákọsílẹ̀.

english: CAX launched during the Intra Africa Trade Fair in Cairo, Egypt, in December 2018.
yoruba: Ọdún-un 2018 ni ìfilọ́lẹ̀ CAX wáyé ní ibi Ìpàtẹ Ọjà Inú Ilẹ̀-Adúláwọ̀ ní ìlúu Cairo, orílẹ̀-èdèe Egypt, nínú oṣù Ọ̀pẹ̀ ọdún-un 2018.

english: African creative talents from the fields of music, arts, design, fashion, literature, publishing, film and television came together for a Creative Africa Exchange Weekend in Kigali, Rwanda, January 16-18, 2020.
yoruba: Àwọn ọlọ́gbọ́n àtinudá gbogbo láti ẹ̀ka orin kíkọ, iṣẹ́ ọnà, àwòṣe, ẹ̀ṣọ́, ewì, ìwé títẹ̀, àwòrán-olóhùn àti òṣìṣẹ́ ẹ̀rọ amóhùnmáwòràn parojọ fún Ọjọ́ Ìsinmi Ìpàṣípààrọ̀ Ọgbọ́n Àtinudá ní Kigali, ní orílẹ̀-èdèe Rwanda, ní ọjọ́ 16-18 oṣù kìíní, Ọdún-un 2020.

english: It advertises itself as the "first continental event dedicated to promoting exchange within the creative and cultural industry in Africa", with over 2,000 participants from 68 countries.
yoruba: Ó polówó araa rẹ̀ gẹ́gẹ́ bíi "ayẹyẹ àkọ́kọ́ tí yóò kó àwọn ọmọ ilẹ̀ adúláwọ̀ jọ tí ń ṣe ìgbélárugẹ ìpàṣípààrọ̀ láàárín àwọn ọlọ́gbọ́n àtinudá àti aṣàgbélárugẹ àṣà ní Ilẹ̀-Adúláwọ̀ ", tí ó ní àwọn akópa tí ó tó bíi 2,000 láti orílẹ̀-èdè 68.

english: On the second day of the event in Kigali, professor Benedict Oramah, president of the African Export-Import Bank (Afreximbank) announced a $500 million USD fund "to support the production and trade of African cultural and creative products" over the next two years, New Times Rwanda reported.
yoruba: Ní ọjọ́ kejì ayẹyẹ náà ní Kigali, ọ̀jọ̀gbọ́n Benedict Oramah, ààrẹ Ilé-ìfowópamọ́sí Ọjà títa sókè òkun-àti-kíkó wọlé (Afreximbank) kéde owó ìrànwọ́ ẹgbẹẹgbẹ̀rún 500 owó dollar Amẹ́ríkà "tí yóò ṣe àtìlẹ́yìn ìgbéjáde àti káràkátà nǹkan tí ó jẹ mọ́ ti àṣà àti ọgbọ́n àtinudá Ilẹ̀-Adúláwọ̀ " fún ọdún méjì gbáko, New Times Rwanda jíyìn ìròhìn.

english: Omarah told guests at the event that the funds, which would build on what the bank was already doing, would be accessible as lines of credit to banks, direct financing to operators and as guarantees.
yoruba: Omarah gbé e sí àwọn àlejò tí ó wà níkàlẹ̀ níbi ayẹyẹ náà létí wípé owó ìrànwọ́ náà, tí yóò bù kún iṣẹ́ tí Ilé-ìfowópamọ́sí náà ti ń ṣe tẹ́lẹ̀, yóò wà ní àrọ̀wọ́tó ní àwọn Ilé-ìfowópamọ́sí, tí yóò jẹ́ lílò fún àwọn tí ó fẹ́ ẹ.

english: He said that while Africa had a deep pool of talent, it lacked the infrastructure and capacity to commercialize its creative talent and reap the vast fortunes lying in wait, according to Afreximbank.
yoruba: Ó sọ wípé bí Ilẹ̀-Adúláwọ̀ ti ṣe ní ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ ọlọ́gbọ́n àtinudá tó, kò sí ohun èlò tí yóò mú kí wọn ó ká èso ọrọ̀ tí ó pọ̀ tí ó ń dúró fún kíká, ìyẹn bí Afreximbank ti ṣe ṣàlàyé.

english: He continued:
yoruba: Ó sọ̀rọ̀ síwájú sí i :

english: Because of underinvestment in the creative and cultural industries, Africa is largely absent in the global market of ideas, values and aesthetics as conveyed through music, theater, literature, film and television.
yoruba: Nítorí àìtó ìdókoòwò nínú iléeṣẹ́ ọgbọ́n àtinudá àti àṣà, Ilẹ̀-Adúláwọ̀ kò sí nínú ọjà iṣẹ́ ọpọlọ, àti ìdáraáwò púpọ̀ gẹ́gẹ́ bí a ti fi hàn nínú orin, eré ìtàgé, ewì, àwòrán-àtohùn àti ètò orí ẹ̀rọ amóhùnmáwòrán àgbáyé.

english: African countries import overwhelmingly more creative goods than they export or trade amongst themselves.
yoruba: Àwọn orílẹ̀-èdè Ilẹ̀-Adúláwọ̀ máa ń kó ọjà ọgbọ́n àtinudá wọlé ju èyí tí wọ́n tà sókè òkun tàbí láàárin ara wọn.

english: He commended Egypt’s "astronomical growth in creative exports over the last decade".
yoruba: Ó gbóṣùbàa sàńdákátà fún orílẹ̀-èdèe Egypt ní ti “ìdàgbàsókèe ìtàsókè òkun ọgbọ́n àtinudá láàárín ọdún mẹ́wàá tí ó ré kọjá".

english: In December 2019, Afreximbank was honored at the International Fashion Awards (IFA) in Cairo for its role in supporting Africa's creative industry.
yoruba: Nínú oṣù Ọ̀pẹ̀ ọdún-un 2019, a dá Afreximbank lọ́lá níbi Ìfàmìẹ̀yẹdánilọ́lá Ìṣaralọ́ṣọ̀ọ́ Àgbáyé International Fashion Awards (IFA) ní Cairo fún ipa tí ó ń kó níbi ti ìtìlẹ́yìn-in iléeṣẹ́ ọgbọ́n àtinudá Ilẹ̀-Adúláwọ̀.

english: Omarah also commended Nigeria's Nollywood industry.
yoruba: Bákan náà ni Omarah gbóríyìn fún iléeṣẹ́ eré orí ìtàgé Nollywood ti Nàìjíríà.

english: On Twitter, artists who were attendance showed their appreciation for the gathering held at Intare conference center in Kigali:
yoruba: Lóríi gbàgede Twitter, àwọn òṣèré tó wà níbi àpérò náà dúpẹ́ fún àpéjọ náà tí ó wáyé ní gbọ̀ngan Intare tí ó wà ní Kigali:

english: Speaking at the 2018 CAX Weekend in Cairo, Nigerian artist D'Banj told bankers and investors:
yoruba: Nínú ọ̀rọ̀-ọ rẹ̀ níbi ayẹyẹ Ọjọ́ Ìsinmi CAX 2018 ní Cario, ọ̀kọrin ọmọ orílẹ̀-èdèe Nàìjíríà D'Banj sọ fún àwọn òṣìṣẹ́ Ilé-ìfowópamọ́sí àti olùdókoòwò:

english: What we need is for you guys to really understand is that content is the new crude oil and however well you respect the oil industry you have to respect the creative industry.
yoruba: Ohun tí a nílò láti ọ̀dọ̀ọ yín ní fún un yín láti lóye wípé iṣẹ́ àtinudá ni epo rọ̀bì tí ọpọ́n sún kàn tí ó sì yẹ kí a bu ìyìn fún iléeṣẹ́ náà.

english: The concluded CAX Weekend 2020 will be followed by CAX Week on the sidelines of the second Intra-African Trade Fair (IATF2020) from September 1-7, 2020, also in Kigali.
yoruba: Ọ̀sẹ̀-ẹ CAX tí yóò ṣe pẹ̀kí-ǹ-rẹ̀kí pẹ̀lú Ìpàtẹ Ọjà Inú Ilẹ̀-Adúláwọ̀ (IATF2020) láti Ọjọ́ 1-7 kẹsàn-án ní Kigali, yóò tẹ̀lé Ọjọ́ Ìsinmi CAX 2020 tí ó ṣẹ̀ṣẹ̀ tẹnu bọ epo.

english: Broadcasters from Nigeria join global celebration of World Radio Day 2020
yoruba: Sọ̀rọ̀sọ̀rọ̀ ní Nàìjíríà darapọ̀ mọ́ àwọn akẹgbẹ́-ẹ wọn láti sààmì ayẹyẹ Ọjọ́ Ẹ̀rọ-ìgbóhùnsáfẹ́fẹ́ Àgbáyé ọdún-un 2020

english: Radio — the most affordable and portable tool for development
yoruba: Rédíò — ohun èlò fún ìdàgbàsókè tí kò hàn, tí ó sì ṣe é gbé kiri.

english: A man holds a portable short-wave radio in his hand. Photo by Muhammadtaha Ibrahim Ma'aji via CC BY 2.0.
yoruba: Ọkùnrin kan gbé ẹ̀rọ-ìgbóhùnsáfẹ́fẹ́ tí máa ń rin ọ̀nà jínjìn dání. Àwòrán láti ọwọ́ọ Muhammadtaha Ibrahim Ma'aji tí ó jẹ́ àṣẹ ìlò CC BY 2.0.

english: There is no doubt that the radio has had a profound impact on global development.
yoruba: Kò sí irọ́ kan níbẹ̀ wípé Ẹ̀rọ-ìgbóhùnsáfẹ́fẹ́ jẹ́ ohun èlò ìgbéròyìn ká tí ó ti ṣiṣẹ́ ribiribi fún ìdàgbàsókè àgbà-ńlá ayé.

english: To honor the importance and unique value of radio, the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization (UNESCO)  has declared February 13 World Radio Day.
yoruba: Àwọn Yorùbá ní, kí a gbé oyè fún olóyè, kí á gbádé fún ẹni tí ó ni adé", èyí ló mú Àjọ Ìṣọ̀kan Àgbáyé tí ó ń rí sí Ètò Ẹ̀kọ́, Ìmọ̀ Ìjìnlẹ̀ àti Àṣà (UNESCO) ya ọjọ́ 13 oṣù Èrèlé sọ́tọ̀ gẹ́gẹ́ bíi Ọjọ́ Ẹ̀rọ-ìgbóhùnsáfẹ́fẹ́ Àgbáyé.

english: UNESCO set aside this day to draw attention to the power of radio —  which remains the most affordable and portable medium to reach the widest audience.
yoruba: UNESCO yà ọjọ́ yìí sọ́tọ̀ láti ṣí ojú àwọn ènìyàn sí ipa tí ẹ̀rọ-ìgbóhùnsáfẹ́fẹ́ ń kó ní ìgbésí ayé — tí ó jẹ́ ọ̀nà ìgbéròyìnká tí kò hàn, tí ó sì ṣe é gbé kiri.

english: Nigerian broadcasters joined radio practitioners around the world to honor the powerful role that radio plays in global development.
yoruba: Àwọn sọ̀rọ̀sọ̀rọ̀-ọ orílẹ̀-èdèe Nàìjíríà darapọ̀ mọ́ àwọn sọ̀rọ̀sọ̀rọ̀ orí ẹ̀rọ-ìgbóhùnsáfẹ́fẹ́ lágbàáyé láti sààmì ọjọ́ náà àti láti fọn rere iṣẹ́ ìdàgbàsókè àgbà-ńlá ayé tí ẹ̀rọ-ìgbóhùnsáfẹ́fẹ́ ń ṣe.

english: "Even though the new media is taking over the world with the way we do things, radio is still the most viable option for many people to get information, it remains the most powerful tool for journalists to reach people in the farthest and remote areas..." said Bishop George Bako, during his opening remarks at the World Radio Day Symposium. Bako is the former Director-General of the Federal Radio Corporation of Nigeria (FRCN).
yoruba: "Ẹ̀rọ ìgbéròyìnjáde ń yí bí a ti ṣe ń ṣe nǹkan padà, síbẹ̀síbẹ̀ ẹ̀rọ-ìgbóhùnsáfẹ́fẹ́ ṣì ni ó ṣì wúlò jù lọ fún ọ̀gọ̀rọ̀ ènìyàn láti gbọ́ ìròyìn ohun tí ó ń lọ lọ́wọ́, òhun ṣì ni ohun èlò tí ó máa ń lapa tí ó pọ̀ jù nínúu gbogbo ọ̀nà tí àwọn oníròyìn máa ń lò nítorí ó lágbára láti dé ibi jínjìn àti ìgbèríko tí ó jẹ́ ibi kọ́lọ́fín… " Àlùfáà George Bako sọ̀rọ̀, nígbà tí ó ń ṣíde ètò níbi Àpérò Ọjọ́ Ẹ̀rọ-ìgbóhùnsáfẹ́fẹ́ Àgbáyé. Bako ti fi ìgbà kan rí jẹ́ Ọ̀gá-Àgbà pátápátá fún Iléeṣẹ́ Alájọṣepọ̀ Ìgbóhùnsáfẹ́fẹ́ Ìjọba Àpapọ̀ Orílẹ̀-èdèe Nàìjíríà (FRCN).

english: Bishop George Bako speaks at the World Radio Day symposium in Lagos, Nigeria.
yoruba: Àlùfáà George Bako sọ̀rọ̀ níbi àpérò Ọjọ́ Ẹ̀rọ-ìgbóhùnsáfẹ́fẹ́ Àgbáyé ní Èkó, orílẹ̀-èdèe Nàìjíríà.

english: Photo by Ọmọ Yoòbá, used with permission.
yoruba: Àwòrán láti ọwọ́ọ Ọmọ Yoòbá, tí a gba àṣẹ láti lò.

english: FRCN — popularly known as Radio Nigeria — is the foremost broadcast radio station in Nigeria, that serves a teeming population of listeners in the Lagos metropolis on three different stations, namely: Radio One 103.5 FM, Metro 97.7 FM and the multiple award-winning Bond 92.9 FM.
yoruba: FRCN — tí a tún ń pè ní Radio Nigeria — ni ó léwájú nínúu iṣẹ́ẹ ẹ̀rọ-ìgbóhùnsáfẹ́fẹ́ ní orílẹ̀-èdèe Nàìjíríà, pẹ̀lú ẹgbẹlẹmùkù àwọn olólùfẹ́ tí ó ń gbọ́ ọ jákèjádò Ìpínlẹ̀ Èkó th oríi ìkànnì mẹ́ta ọ̀tọ̀ọ̀tọ̀, tí orúkọ wọ́n jẹ́: Radio One 103.5 FM, Metro 97.7 FM àti aláràa gbàyídá inúu wọn Bond 92.9 FM.

english: Each station — with its own unique audience and share of the market — broadcasts in English, Nigerian Pidgin, Hausa, Igbo and Yorùbá languages.
