yoruba: Ọ̀kọ̀ọ̀kan ìkànnì yìí — ní àwọn olólùfẹ́ẹ rẹ̀ àti àwọn tí ó ń gbọ́ ọ — tí ó ń fi èdèe Gẹ̀ẹ́sì, Àdàlùmọ́-Gẹ̀ẹ́sì, Hausa, Igbo àti èdèe Yorùbá.

english: Radio remains the greatest means of news dissemination in Nigeria. FM (frequency modulation) is most common, followed closely by AM (amplitude modulation), according to Media Landscape of the European Journalism Centre — and online radio has also become quite popular.
yoruba: Ẹ̀rọ-ìgbóhùnsáfẹ́fẹ́ ṣì ni ọ̀nà tí ó dára jù lọ fún ìfọ́nká ìròyìn ní Nàìjíríà. FM (Ìgbóhùnsáfẹ́fẹ́ Aláṣeéyípadà) ni ó wọ́pọ̀ jù lọ, AM (Ìgbóhùnsáfẹ́fẹ́ Títóbi) tẹ̀lé e gbọ̀ngbọ̀ngbọn, gẹ́gẹ́ bí iléeṣẹ́ Media Landscape ti European Journalism Centre ní i lákọsílẹ̀ — tí ìgbóhùnsáfẹ́fẹ́ orí ẹ̀rọ ayélujára sì ti di gbajúmọ̀.

english: As of 2019, Bond FM holds the number 1 position in Lagos State as the station with the largest audience, according to the Nigeria Diary Radio Stations Ratings of August 2019.
yoruba: Ní ọdún-un 2019, Nigeria Diary Radio Stations Ratings ti oṣù Ògún fi hàn wípé Bond FM ló di ipò kìíní mú ní Ìpínlẹ̀ Èkó gẹ́gẹ́ bí ìkànnì tí ó ní olùgbọ́ jù lọ.

english: To celebrate, broadcasters from across Nigeria took to Twitter to show some love for radio:
yoruba: Látàrí ayẹyẹ náà, àwọn sọ̀rọ̀sọ̀rọ̀ jákèjádò orílẹ̀-èdèe Nàìjíríà fi gbàgede Twitter kéde ìfẹ́ ẹ wọn fún rédíò:

english: Dan Manjang, the commissioner for information and communication of Plateau state, congratulated broadcasters everywhere for "all the sacrifice, resources and time" put into keeping citizens informed and entertained:
yoruba: Dan Manjang, alákòóso fún oọ̀rọ̀ ìgbóhùnsáfẹ́fẹ́ àti ìkéde ti Ìpínlẹ̀ Plateau, kí àwọn sọ̀rọ̀sọ̀rọ̀ níbi gbogbo fún "gbogbo akitiyan, ìgbìyànjú àti àsìkò" tí wọ́n fi ń kéde ìròyìn àti onírúurú ètò akọ́nilọ́gbọ́n:

english: Radio broadcasting in Nigeria started in 1933 with the British colonial government’s Radio Diffusion Service (RDS), whereby loudspeakers were installed in dedicated public places for people to listen to the British Broadcasting Corporation’s foreign radio service broadcasts.
yoruba: Ìgbóhùnsáfẹ́fẹ́ ní Nàìjíríà bẹ̀rẹ̀ ní ọdún-un 1933 pẹ̀lú Ìtàn káàkiri Rédíò Ìjọba Amúnisìn (RDS), tí ó jẹ́ wípé gbé àwọn ẹ̀rọ-gbohùngbohùn sí ìta gbangba níbi tí àwọn ènìyàn yóò ti tẹ́tí sí ìròyìn òkèèrè ti Iléeṣẹ́ Ìgbóhùnsáfẹ́fẹ́ Ìjọba Gẹ̀ẹ́sì.

english: By 1950, the Radio Diffusion Service took on a new name — the Nigerian Broadcasting Service (NBS) — and later, the Nigerian Broadcasting Corporation (NBC), with broadcast stations in the different regions of the country. NBC later metamorphosed into the Federal Radio Corporation of Nigeria (FRCN) in 1978.
yoruba: Ní ọdún-un 1950, RDS gbé aṣọ tuntun wọ̀ — ó di Iléeṣẹ́ Ìgbóhùnsáfẹ́fẹ́ Orílẹ̀-èdèe Nàìjíríà (NBS) — nígbà tí ó ṣe, ó di Iléeṣẹ́ Alájọṣepọ̀ Ìgbóhùnsáfẹ́fẹ́ Orílẹ̀-èdèe Nàìjíríà (NBC), pẹ̀lú ìkànnì ìgbóhùnsáfẹ́fẹ́ ní àwọn ẹ̀ka tí Nàìjíríà pín sí. NBC pàpà paradà di Iléeṣẹ́ Alájọṣepọ̀ Ìgbóhùnsáfẹ́fẹ́ Ìjọba Àpapọ̀ Orílẹ̀-èdèe Nàìjíríà (FRCN) lọ́dún-un 1978.

english: "The first radio station in Nigeria was established in Ibadan in 1939.
yoruba: "Iléeṣẹ́ Rédíò àkọ́kọ́ ní Nàìjíríà tí a dá sílẹ̀ ní Ìbàdàn ní ọdún-un 1939.

english: The next station was created in Kano in 1944," according to Legit media online.
yoruba: Ìkànnì-i Kano ló tẹ̀lée ní 1944," gẹ́gẹ́ bí iléeṣẹ́ ìròyìn oríaayélujára Legit ti ṣe ṣàlàyé.

english: RayPower FM, the first private radio station in Nigeria, was established in 1994, and by 2007, the masses could get international transmission broadcast worldwide, according to Legit.
yoruba: Legit ṣàlàyé wípé RayPower FM, ni rédíò aládàáni àkọ́kọ́ ní orílẹ̀-èdèe Nàìjíríà, ọdún-un 1994 ni a dá a sílẹ̀, nígbàtí ó mmáa fi di ọdún-un 2007, àwọn olùgbọ́ ti ń gbọ́ ìròyìn kárí ayé.

english: Radio has always served as a tool to check decision-makers, establish and provide access to information and motivate and inspire the people.
yoruba: Rédíò ti ṣiṣẹ́ gẹ́gẹ́ bíi ohun èlò àyẹ̀wò fún àwọn tí ó wà nípò àṣẹ, ìfìdírinlẹ̀ òfin àti ìpèsè ìkéde tí yóò lapa dáadáa lára àwọn ènìyàn.

english: In 2019, African Independent Television and RayPower FM were shut down by the National Broadcasting Commission (NBC) for incisive broadcast and propaganda against the government.
yoruba: Ní ọdún-un 2019, Ìgbìmọ̀ Ètò Ìgbóhùnsáfẹ́fẹ́ Orílẹ̀-èdèe Nàìjíríà (NBC) ṣán African Independent Television àti RayPower FM pa nítorí wípé ó ṣe àgbéjáde ètò tí ó tako ìjọba.

english: Also in 2019, Jay FM in Port Harcourt was shut down for allegedly making broadcasts against the government.
yoruba: Bákan náà ní ọdún- 2019, Jay FM tíó wà ní Port Harcourt di ṣíṣánpa lẹ́yìn tí a fi ẹ̀sùn ìtako ìjọba kàn án.

english: Radio Nigeria truck advertises itself as "the network for the millennium," and joins radio practitioners around the globe in celebrating World Radio Day 2020.
yoruba: Ọkọ̀ọ Radio Nigeria ṣe ìpolówó ara rẹ̀ gẹ́gẹ́ bíi "iléeṣẹ́ ìgbóhùnsáfẹ́fẹ́ ẹgbẹẹgbẹ̀rún ọdún," tí ó sì darapọ̀ mọ́ àwọn òṣìṣẹ́ rédíò kárí ayé fún ìsààmì ayẹyẹ Ọjọ́ Ẹ̀rọ-ìgbóhùnsáfẹ́fẹ́ Àgbáyé ọdún-un 2020.

english: Photo by Muhammadtaha Ibrahim Ma'aji, used with permission via CC BY 2.0.
yoruba: Àwòrán láti ọwọ́ọ Muhammadtaha Ibrahim Ma'aji, tí a gba àṣẹ láti lò ó ní ìbámu pẹ̀lú àṣẹ CC BY 2.0.

english: Radio that unites and uplifts
yoruba: Rédíò tí ó ń mú ìsọdọ̀kan àti ìgbéga wáyé

english: UNESCO implores all nations to celebrate World Radio Day through partnership activities that cut across boundaries by involving all broadcasting associations and organizations, media organizations, government-owned, private and non-governmental organizations.
yoruba: UNESCO rọ ìlú gbogbo láti sààmì ayẹyẹ Ọjọ́ Ẹ̀rọ-ìgbóhùnsáfẹ́fẹ́ Àgbáyé nípasẹ̀ ṣíṣe àwọn ètò àjọṣe pẹ̀lú iléeṣẹ́ ìgbóhùnsáfẹ́fẹ́, iléeṣẹ́ ìjọba, iléeṣẹ́ aládàáni àti iléeṣẹ́ tí kì í ṣe ti ìjọba kárí ayé.

english: The theme of the 14th edition of World Radio Day is "Radio and Diversity."
yoruba: Àkórí Àyájọ́ Ọjọ́ Ẹ̀rọ-ìgbóhùnsáfẹ́fẹ́ Àgbáyé ti ọdún yìí, tí í ṣe ìkẹrìnlá irú ẹ̀ ni "Ẹ̀rọ-ìgbóhùnsáfẹ́fẹ́ àti Onírúurú."

english: Radio Nigeria is living up to its own motto of uplifting the people and uniting the nation" by disseminating informative, educative and motivating content that empowers Nigerians to be patriotic citizens.
yoruba: Rédíò ẹlẹ́rọ-amìtìtì orílẹ̀-èdèe Nàìjíríà ń jí gìrì sí ọ̀rọ̀ àṣàròo rẹ̀ tí ó ní ìgbésókè àwọn ènìyàn àti ṣíṣe ìsọdọ̀kan ètò afúnilóye, akọ́nilẹ́kọ̀ọ́ àti aṣínilétí tó ń ró àwọn ọmọ orílẹ̀-èdèe Nàìjíríà lágbára láti ní ìfẹ́ ìlú ẹni.

english: This comes at a time when Nigeria has faced serious divisions over ethnic, political and cultural tensions throughout the country.
yoruba: Èyí wúlò ní àsìkò tí ìpínyà àti ìyapa ẹ̀yà, àìbalẹ̀-ọkàn látàrí ọ̀rọ̀ òṣèlú tó ń kojúu orílẹ̀-èdèe Nàìjíríà.

english: The 2019 Fragile States Index ranked Nigeria as the 14th most fragile state in the world and the ninth in Africa.
yoruba: Ìpín ipò Ìlú tí ó rọrùn láti fọ́ ọdún-un 2019 fi Nàìjíríà sí ipò kẹrìnlá lágbàáyé, ìkẹsàn-án ní Ilẹ̀-Adúláwọ̀.

english: Since 2011, Boko Haram, the Islamist jihadist militancy in northeast Nigeria, has created a climate of fear and division as their brutal attacks have led to thousands of deaths and millions of displacements.
yoruba: Láti ọdún-un 2011, Boko Haram, ajìjàǹgbara ẹ̀sìn Ìmàle ní Ìlà-oòrùn àréwá orílẹ̀-èdèe Nàìjíríà, ti fi ẹ̀rù sí ọkàn àwọn ènìyàn àti bí àwọn ìkọlù tó rorò wọ́n ti ṣe fa ikú láì rò tẹ́lẹ̀ ìpí àwọn ènìyàn, tí ọ̀pọ̀ọ́ sì ti di àwátì.

english: Read more: Nigeria: A failed state — reality or perception?
yoruba: Kà síwájú sí i: Nàìjíríà: Ìlú tí ó kùnà — òótọ́ tàbí ìwòye?

english: To further continue to uplift Nigeria, the management of FRCN Lagos Operations put together a series of events to commemorate World Radio Day 2020.
yoruba: Ní ìtẹ̀síwájú ìgbésókè orílẹ̀-èdèe Nàìjíríà, àwọn aláṣẹ FRCN Ẹ̀ka ti Èkó ṣe àgbékalẹ̀ ọkànòjọ̀kan ètò láti sààmì Àyájọ́ Ọjọ́ Ẹ̀rọ-ìgbóhùnsáfẹ́fẹ́ Àgbáyé ọdún-un 2020.

english: It kicked off with an essay contest calling for 1,200 words on "why I love listening to the radio" for secondary school students.
yoruba: Eré gbogboó bẹ̀rẹ̀ pẹ̀lú ìdíje àròkọ ọlọ́rọ̀ 1,200 tí ó dá lóríi "ìdí tí mo fi nífẹ̀ẹ́ sí láti máa gbọ́ rédíò" fún àwọn akẹ́kọ̀ọ́ iléèwé gíga.

english: Students of mass communications also submitted a 5-minute documentary on the importance of radio in achieving sustainable development goals. Two winners emerged from both entries.
yoruba: Àwọn akẹ́kọ̀ọ́ ìmọ̀ iṣẹ́ ìròyìn náà ṣe ètò alálàyé oníṣẹ̀ẹ́jú 5 tí ó dá fìrìgbagbòó lóríi pàtàkìi ẹ̀rọ-ìgbóhùnsáfẹ́fẹ́ fún ìmúṣẹ àwọn ìlépa ìmúdúró ìdàgbàsókè. Àwọn àkópa méjì ló jáwé olúborí.

english: Essay winner Ìlọ̀rí Ayọ̀olúwa of Mater Christi Catholic Girls' High School, Igede Èkìtì, Èkìtì State, recalls the first time she encountered radio at the age 5:
yoruba: Olúborí ìdíje àròkọ Ìlọ̀rí Olúwatóbi ti iléèwé Mater Christi Catholic Girls' High School, Ìgede Èkìtì, Ìpínlẹ̀ Èkìtì, mú u wá sí ìrántí ìgbà àkọ́kọ́ tí òùn-ún ṣalábàápàdée rédíò nígbà tí òùn-ún wà ní ọmọ ọdún 5:

english: I think I was 5 years old when I got my first radio.
yoruba: Ó dà bí ẹni pé ọmọ ọdún 5 ni mí nígbà tí mo kọ́kọ́ ní ẹ̀rọ-ìgbóhùnsáfẹ́fẹ́ẹ̀ mi.

english: I fiddled with a few buttons and it came on.
yoruba: Mo tẹ àwọn ohun-àtẹ̀-àṣẹ ara rẹ̀, ó sì tàn.

english: Then I was astonished to hear voices resonating from this "box" and thought there were people trapped in it.
yoruba: Ìyàlẹ́nu ló jẹ́ fún mi bí mo ṣe ń gbọ́ ohùn tí ó ń ti inúu "àpótí" yìí jáde tí mo sì rò wípé àwọn èèyàn ló wà nínúu rẹ̀.

english: I got scared and asked my father what it was and he took his time to explain what a radio was to me.
yoruba: Ẹ̀rú bá mi mo sì béèrè lọ́wọ́ọ bàbáà mi ohun tí ó jẹ́, ó sì ṣàlàyé ohun tí rédíò jẹ́ fún mi.

english: On February 12, secondary school pupils, students of mass communication, ace broadcasters and key personnel from the media industry as well as everyday radio fans converged on the Lekki Coliseum in Lagos for a symposium to talk about the importance of radio for development.
yoruba: Ní ọjọ́ 12 oṣù Èrèlé, àwọn akẹ́kọ̀ọ́ ilé ẹ̀kọ́ gíga, akẹ́kọ̀ọ́ ìmọ̀ iṣẹ́ ìròyìn, ọ̀jẹ̀ sọ̀rọ̀sọ̀rọ̀ àti àwọn alẹ́nulọ́rọ̀ nínú iṣẹ́ ìròyìn àti àwọn olólùfẹ́ẹ̀ rédíò péjúpésẹ̀ sí Lekki Coliseum ní Èkó fún àpérò láti jíròrò nípa pàtàkìi ẹ̀rọ-ìgbóhùnsáfẹ́fẹ́ fún ìdàgbàsókè.

english: On February 12, secondary school pupils, students of mass communication, ace broadcasters and key personnel from the media industry as well as everyday radio fans converged on the Lekki Coliseum in Lagos for a symposium to talk about the importance of radio for development.
yoruba: Ní ọjọ́ 12 oṣù Èrèlé, àwọn akẹ́kọ̀ọ́ ilé ẹ̀kọ́ gíga, akẹ́kọ̀ọ́ ìmọ̀ iṣẹ́ ìròyìn, ọ̀jẹ̀ sọ̀rọ̀sọ̀rọ̀ àti àwọn alẹ́nulọ́rọ̀ nínú iṣẹ́ ìròyìn àti àwọn olólùfẹ́ẹ̀ rédíò péjúpésẹ̀ sí Lekki Coliseum ní Èkó fún àpérò láti jíròrò nípa pàtàkìi ẹ̀rọ-ìgbóhùnsáfẹ́fẹ́ fún ìdàgbàsókè.

english: Photo by Ọmọ Yoòbá, used with permission.
yoruba: Àwòrán láti ọwọ́ọ Ọmọ Yoòbá, a gba àṣẹ láti lò ó.

english: When the sun went down, veteran broadcasters, representatives of the Oba of Lagos, Ọ̀túnba Gani Adams, the Ààrẹ Ọ̀nà Kakanfò of Yorùbá-land and other guests and dignitaries mingled at the Lekki Coliseum for the World Radio Day award ceremony and dinner.
yoruba: Ní ìgbàtí ọjọ́ rọ̀, àwọn ògbóǹtarìgì sọ̀rọ̀sọ̀rọ̀, àwọn aṣojú the Ọba Èkó, Ọ̀túnba Gani Adams, Ààrẹ Ọ̀nà Kakanfò ilẹ̀ẹ Yorùbá àti àwọn àlejò mìíràn péjọ sí Lekki Coliseum fún àpèjẹ alẹ́ àti ìfàmìẹ̀yẹ dánilọ́lá Àyájọ́ Ọjọ́ Ẹ̀rọ-ìgbóhùnsáfẹ́fẹ́ Àgbáyé.

english: Top broadcast professionals like Cordelia Okpei and a host of others graced the event.
yoruba: Àwọn àgbà ọ̀jẹ̀ẹ sọ̀rọ̀sọ̀rọ̀ bíi Cordelia Okpei àti àwọn tó kù wá sí ayẹyẹ náà.

english: Some deserving persons were presented with awards of recognition for their contributions to the development of the broadcast industry and service to humanity.
yoruba: Àmì-ẹ̀yẹ̀ẹ̀ fún akíkanjú lẹ́nu iṣẹ́ àti ìṣiṣẹ́sìnlú lọ sí ọ̀dọ̀ àwọn ẹni tí ó tọ́ sí.

english: The series of events culminated in an on-air phone-in programme, whereby listeners made phone calls to say “happy World Radio Day” in their diverse range of languages and tongues:
yoruba: Ọ̀kan-ò-jọ̀kan ètò náà wá sópin pẹ̀lú ìṣójú òpó sílẹ̀ láti gba ìpè àwọn olùgbọ́ wọlé sórí afẹ́fẹ́, níbi tí wọ́n ti ní kí àwọn ènìyàn ó sọ wípé “ẹ kú Àyájọ́ Ọjọ́ Ẹ̀rọ-ìgbóhùnsáfẹ́fẹ́ Àgbáyé” ní àwọn onírúurú ọ̀kan-ò-jọ̀kan èdè àti ahọ́n:

english: No one was left out of the celebration. Voices of some of the Global Voices Lingua teams were also broadcast on Metro 97.7FM. Some retired broadcasters were invited to read the news or anchor a segment.
yoruba: Kò sẹ́ni tí kò kópa nínú ayẹyẹ náà. Ohùn àwọn ikọ̀ Ohùn Àgbáyé náà bọ́ sórí afẹ́fẹ́ ní orí ìkànnì Metro 97.7FM. Àwọn sọ̀rọ̀sọ̀rọ̀ tí ó ti fẹ̀yìntì ló ka ìròyìn tí wọ́n sì tọ́kùn ètò.

english: Radio Nigeria World Radio Day 2020 is the maiden edition of such events but radio practitioners and advocates expect it to become an annual celebration.
yoruba: Àkọ́kọ́ irú ‘ẹ̀ ni Àyájọ́ Ọjọ́ Ẹ̀rọ-ìgbóhùnsáfẹ́fẹ́ Rédíò Orílẹ̀-èdèe Nàìjíríà ọdún-un 2020 àmọ́ àwọn òṣìṣẹ́ àti olólùfẹ́ẹ̀ rédíò lérò wípé ayẹyẹ náà yóò máa wáyé lọ́dọọdún.

english: This chief hopes Yorùbá speakers adopt his newly invented 'talking alphabet'
yoruba: Olóyè yìí nírètí wí pé àwọn ọmọ Yorùbá yóò tẹ́wọ́ gba 'alífábẹ́ẹ̀tì t'ó ń sọ̀rọ̀ ' tí òun hu ìmọ̀ rẹ̀

english: Will the new Yorùbá orthography become mainstream in the future?
yoruba: Ǹjẹ́ ìlànà ìṣọwọ́kọ Yorùbá tuntun yóò di lílò lọ́jọ́ iwájú bí?

english: Chief Tolúlàṣẹ Ògúntósìn stands next to the paramount king of Yorùbáland, the Ọọ̀ni of Ifẹ̀, seated.
yoruba: Olóyè Tolúlàṣẹ Ògúntósìn dúró lẹ́gbẹ̀ẹ́ ọba ilẹ̀-Yorùbá káàfàtà, Ọọ̀ni ti Ilé-Ifẹ̀, lórí ìjókòó.

english: Photo courtesy of Chief  Ògúntósìn.
yoruba: Olóyè Ògúntósìn ló yànda àwòrán.

english: In the wake of the International Year of Indigenous Languages in 2019 and the International Decade of Indigenous Languages 2022-2032, many Africans have started to take a wide range of actions to advance African languages.
yoruba: Lẹ́yìn ìpolongo kárí ayé nípa Ọdún Èdè Ìbílẹ̀ Àgbáyé ní ọdún 2019 àti ìkéde Ọdún mẹ́wàá Èdè Ìbílẹ̀ Àgbáyé 2022-2032, púpọ̀ nínú àwọn ọmọ Ilẹ̀-Adúláwọ̀ ló ti bẹ̀rẹ̀ ọ̀kan-ò-jọ̀kan àkànṣe iṣẹ́ tó ní ṣe pẹ̀lú ìdàgbàsókè àwọn èdè Ilẹ̀-Adúláwọ̀.

english: Writing the Yorùbá language in the borrowed Latin script may soon become a thing of the past as one Yorùbá man, Chief Tolúlàṣẹ Ògúntósìn, based in Benin, West Africa, has invented a writing system to encode the Yorùbá language.
yoruba: Lílo àyálò ìlànà Látíìnì fún kíkọ èdè Yorùbá yóò di àfìsẹ́yìn tí eégún aláré ń fiṣọ láì pẹ́ ní èyí tí ọmọ Káàárọ̀-o-ò-jí-ire kan, Olóyè Tolúlàṣẹ Ògúntósìn, ẹni tí ó ń gbé ní Ilẹ̀ Olómìnira Bẹ̀nẹ̀, Ìwọ̀-oòrùn Ilẹ̀-Adúláwọ̀, ti hu ìmọ̀ ìlànà tí a ó máa lò fún kíkọ èdè Yorùbá.

english: The newly invented Yorùbá alphabet is making waves in the hopes that it could replace Latin script used for over 100 years.
yoruba: Alífábẹ́ẹ̀tì Yorùbá tuntun náà ti ń gbàlú kan pẹ̀lú ìrètí wí pé yóò pààrọ ti Látíìnì tí ó ti jẹ́ lílò fún ọgọ́rùn-ún ọdún àti jù bẹ́ẹ̀ lọ.

english: The distinct alphabet came to him through divine inspiration in his dreams, according to Chief Ògúntósìn in a Whatsapp interview with Global Voices.
yoruba: Gẹ́gẹ́ bí Olóyè Ògúntósìn ti ṣe rò fún Ohùn Àgbáyé nínú ìfọ̀rọ̀wánilẹ́nuwò lórí WhatsApp, ojú àlá ni alífábẹ́ẹ̀tì àràmàndà wọ̀nyí ti f'ara hàn sí òun.

english: He now travels across Yorùbáland — spanning Benin to Nigeria — to promote his "talking alphabet" as sent to him by his ancestors.
yoruba: Ní báyìí, níṣe ni ó máa ń ṣe ìrìnàjò jákèjádò Ilẹ̀-Yorùbá — láti Bẹ̀nẹ̀ títí dé Nàìjíríà — láti polongo "alífábẹ́ẹ̀tì tí ó ń sọ̀rọ̀ " rẹ̀ bí àwọn alálẹ̀ ti ṣe fi rán an.

english: Chief Ògúntósìn believes that this alphabet was used by Odùduwà, the father of the Yorùbá people, in ancient times — but was lost.
yoruba: Olóyè Ògúntósìn nígbàgbọ́ wí pé Odùduwà, tí ó jẹ́ bàbá-ńlá ìran Yorùbá lo alífábẹ́ẹ̀tì náà ní ayé àtijọ́ — àmọ́ ó ti di ohun ìgbàgbé.

english: There are 25 symbols in all.
yoruba: 25 ni gbogbo àwọn àmì wọ̀nyí lápapọ̀.

english: African linguists assert that if Africa is to grow, it must have its own orthographies or writing systems.
yoruba: Àwọn onímọ̀ nípa èdè ní Ilẹ̀-Adúláwọ̀ sọ wí pé kí ìlọsíwájú ó tó dé bá Ilẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀, ó pọn dandan kí ó ní ìlànà ìṣọwọ́ kọ èdè tàbí ìlànà kíkọ tí ó jẹ́ tirẹ̀.

english: A civilized and ancient Niger-Congo language like Yorùbá should not rely on a borrowed orthography to encode its thoughts and philosophy.
yoruba: Èdè tí ó wà lábẹ́ ìsọ̀rí Niger-Congo tí ó jẹ́ èdè ìran tí ó ti wà lọ́jọ́ tó ti pẹ́ tí ó sì lajú bí èdè Yorùbá ò gbọdọ̀ gbọ́kàn tẹ ìlànà àyálò fún kíkọ èrò àti ìmọ̀ ìrírí ayé rẹ̀.

english: Read more: Yorùbá loan words: How languages evolve
yoruba: Kà sí i: Ọ̀rọ̀ àyálò nínú èdè Yorùbá: Bí èdè ṣe yí padà

english: In 1843, Reverend Samuel Àjàyí Crowther of the Christian Missionary Society developed the Yorùbá orthography by adopting Latin script with diacritics — or accent marks.
yoruba: Ní ọdún 1843, Àlùfáà Sámúẹ́lì Àjàyí Crowther òṣìṣẹ́ Ẹgbẹ́ Iṣẹ́ Ìránṣẹ́ Ẹ̀sìn Ìgbàgbọ́ (CMS) ṣe àgbékalẹ̀ ìlànà ìṣọwọ́kọ èdè Yorùbá nípa yíya ìlànà Látíìnì lò pẹ̀lú àfikún àwọn àmì ohùn — tàbí àmì ìró ọ̀rọ̀.

english: Ever since, thousands of books have been published in Yorùbá using Latin script instead of Ajami, an Arabic script used before 1843 to write in West African Indigenous languages such as Yorùbá and Hausa.
yoruba: Láti ìgbà náà, ẹgbẹẹgbẹ̀rún ìwé ti jẹ́ títẹ̀ jáde ní èdè Yorùbá nípasẹ̀ lílo ìlànà kíkọ Látíìnì dípò Ajami, tí í ṣe ìlànà ìṣọwọ́kọ Lárúbáwá tí ó ti jẹ́ lílò tẹ́lẹ̀tẹ́lẹ́ rí fún kíkọ èdè Ìwọ̀-oòrùn Ilẹ̀-Adúláwọ̀ bí i èdè Yorùbá àti Haúsá kí ó tó di 1843.

english: Some language advocates contend that using Latin, a foreign script, to encode African languages, keeps the continent in an enslaved mindset.
yoruba: Àwọn alágbàwí èdè gbà wí pé lílo ìlànà Látíìnì, tí ó jẹ́ ìṣọwọ́kọ láti ilẹ̀ òkèèrè, fún kíkọ àwọn èdè Ilẹ̀-Adúláwọ̀ sílẹ̀, fi ilẹ̀ náà sínú ipò ẹrú.

english: Instilling this new writing system follows a history of ancient writing systems in Africa, like Egyptian hieroglyphics, the Adrinka collection of the Akan tribe of Ghana, Ethiopian Ge'ez, the Nsibidi ideographic script of West Central Africa which date back to 5000 BC, as well as Vai alphabet scripts are of African origin.
yoruba: Ìpolongo ìlànà ìṣọwọ́kọ tuntun yìí wáyé ní ìbámu pẹ̀lú àwọn ìṣọwọ́kọ ayébáyé Ilẹ̀-Adúláwọ̀, bí i hieroglyphics ti Íjípìtì, Àkójọ Adrinka ti ìran Akan ní Ghana, Ge'ez ti Ethiopia, ìṣọwọ́kọ ìyàwòrán Nsibidi ti Àárín Gbùngbùn Ìwọ̀-oòrùn Ilẹ̀-Adúláwọ̀ tí ó ti wà fún bí 5000 ọdún k'á tó bí Jésù, àti alífábẹ́ẹ̀tì Vai ni Ilẹ̀-Adúláwọ̀ jẹ́ orísun wọn.

english: Divining a 'talking alphabet'
yoruba: Ìṣàyèwò 'alífábẹ́ẹ̀tì tó ń sọ̀rọ̀ '

english: Global Voices Yorùbá Lingua Manager Ọmọ Yoòbá interviewed Chief Ògúntósìn, via WhatsApp voice note messaging, to learn more about how he discovered this new alphabet.
yoruba: Alákòóso Ohùn Àgbáyé lédè Yorùbá, Ọmọ Yoòbá fi ọ̀rọ̀ wá Olóyè Ògúntósìn lẹ́nu wò, nípasẹ̀ iṣẹ́-ìjẹ́ ohùn lórí ẹ̀rọ iìtàkùrọ̀sọ WhatsApp, láti mọ̀ sí i nípa bí ó ti ṣe rí alífábẹ́ẹ̀tì tuntun yìí.

english: Chief Ògúntósìn, now 43, explained that after the demise of his father in 1997, he had to care for his siblings as the oldest son and could not further his education after completing secondary school.
yoruba: Olóyè Ògúntósìn, tó jẹ́ ọmọ ọdún 43 báyìí, ṣàlàyé wí pé òun kò lè ka ju ilé gíga lọ lẹ́yìn ìpapòdà bàbá òun ní ọdún 1997, tí òun sì ní láti ṣe ojúṣe bí bàbá gẹ́gẹ́ bí àkọ́bí láti tọ́jú àwọn àbúrò rẹ̀.

english: However, as a Yorùbá chief, he focused his cultural work on uniting the seven grandchildren of Odùduwa, serving as a mediator.
yoruba: Síbẹ̀, bí olóyè Yorùbá tí ó jẹ́, iṣẹ́ ìgbélárugẹ àṣà rẹ̀ dá lórí ìṣọ̀kan àwọn ọmọ Odùduwà jẹ́ ohun tí ó gbé e lọ́kàn gidi gan-an, tí ó sì ń ṣe bí olùlàjà láàárín wọn.

english: As his cultural integration work progressed, however, he wanted to achieve more.
yoruba: Bí iṣẹ́ ìgbélárugẹ àṣà yìí ṣe ń gbòòrò sí i, kò tẹ́ ẹ lọ́rùn tó bí ó ṣe fẹ́.

english: In 2011, he approached a babaláwo or “diviner” of Ifa, the Yorùbá god of wisdom.
yoruba: Lọ́dún 2011, ó fi eéjì kún eéjì, ó fi ẹẹ́ta kún ẹẹ̀ta, ó gba oko aláwo lọ.

english: The diviner, Olókun Awópẹ̀tu, told him to visit his ancestral shrine within the Farasinmi community in Badagry, Lagos State, Nigeria, and to take whatever he came into contact with at the shrine.
yoruba: Babaláwo náà, Olókun Awópẹ̀tu, wí fún un pé kí ó lọ sí ojúbọ ìdílé rẹ̀ tí ó wà ní agbègbè Farasìnmí ní Àgbádárìgì (Badagry), Ìpínlẹ̀ Èkó, orílẹ̀ èdè Nàìjíríà, wí pé yóò rí atọ́nà tí yóò tọ́ka sí ohun tí Elédùmarè rán an wá ṣe láyé ní ojúbọ náà.

english: There, he found a “strange object” that he took with him back to Porto-Novo, Benin.
yoruba: Ní ojúbọ náà, ó rí “nǹkan àjèjì” kan tí ó mú padà sí ilé rẹ̀ ní Porto-Novo, Bẹ̀nẹ̀.

english: When he arrived, the house was completely dark.
yoruba: Nígbà tí ó délé, òkùnkùn bo iyàrá birimùbirimù.

english: With no light bulbs in the living room, he usually relied on light emitted from the rays of the TV screen.
yoruba: Kò sí iná amọ́roro nínú yàrá ìgbàlejò, ìmọ́lẹ̀ ìtànṣán ẹ̀rọ àmóhùnmáwòrán ni ó máa ń fi ríran.

english: He placed the object on the table and switched on the TV, only to discover, surprisingly, that the object he placed on the table had disappeared.
yoruba: Ó gbé nǹkan àjèjì náà sí orí àga ìgbénǹkanlé, ó sì tan ẹ̀rọ àmóhùnmáwòrán, kàyéfì ló jẹ́ fún un, ohun tí ó gbé sórí àga di àwátì.

english: He turned the entire room upside down and finally found it in a corner of the house.
yoruba: Ó tú gbogbo ilé kí ó tó wá rí i ní kọ̀rọ̀ ilé.

english: That night, he slept with the object under his pillow. He told Global Voices:
yoruba: Lálẹ́ ọjọ́ yẹn, ó fi nǹkan àjèjì náà sábẹ́ ìgbèrí sùn. Ó sọ fún Ohùn Àgbáyé:

english: I had a dream that I visited the sun.
yoruba: Mo lálàá wí pé mo lọ sí inú oòrùn.

english: When I got to the sun, it was dark and I was shown the alphabet in the form of lightning.
yoruba: Nígbà tí mo débẹ̀, ó òkùnkùn ṣú bolẹ̀, a sì fi alífábẹ́ẹ̀tì náà hàn mí ní àpẹẹrẹ ìmọ́lẹ̀.

english: Every time I slept, I had similar dreams, going from planet to planet, teaching people how to use the script...
yoruba: Ìgbàkúùgbà tí mo bá sùn, àlá yìí kan náà ni ní ọ̀nà àrà, mò ń lọ láti agbègbè kan sí agbègbè mìíràn, tí mo sì ń kọ́ àwọn ènìyàn bí a ti ṣe ń lo ìṣọwọ́kọ tuntun náà...

english: For three years, he kept dreaming about the alphabet, seeing visions consecutively, yet he did nothing about it.
yoruba: Fún ọdún mẹ́ta, kò yé lálàá nípa alífábẹ́ẹ̀tì náà, kò yé ríran léraléra, síbẹ̀ kò ṣe nǹkankan sí i.

english: This time around, in 2016, I went to the sun again, I met a man, Lámúrúdu, who taught me the sound of the alphabet, he afterward sanctioned me to go all over the globe teaching people the mastery of the symbols.
yoruba: Lásìkò yìí, ní ọdún 2016, mo tún lọ sí inú oòrùn, mo ṣalábàápàdé ọkùnrin kan, Lámúrúdu, tí ó kọ́ mi ní ìró alífábẹ́ẹ̀tì náà, tí ó sì pa á láṣẹ fún mi pé kí tan ìmọ́lẹ̀ ìmọ̀ kíkọ àti kíkà àmì ìṣọwọ́kọ̀ náà kárí ayé.

english: I usually look old in my dreams — and tired — when I wake up from sleep.
yoruba: Mo máa ń jọ arúgbó lójú àlá — tí yóò sì rẹ̀ mí — bí mo bá jí lójú oorun.

english: Things started to become scary for Chief Ògúntósìn — he began to feel weak, he told Global Voices.
yoruba: Ó wá bẹ̀rẹ̀ sí ní di ẹ̀rù fún Olóyè Ògúntósìn — ó ń rẹ̀ ẹ́ látinú wá, ó wí fún Ohùn Àgbáyé.

english: He decided to narrate his dreams to a close spiritual adviser, Oníkòyí, king of Àjàṣẹ́ in Port-Novo, who counseled him to do what he was instructed in his dreams.
yoruba: Ó pinnu láti rọ́ àwọn àlá náà fún Oníkòyí, Alájàṣẹ́ ti Àjàṣẹ́ ní Port-Novo, ẹni tí ó là á lóye pé kí ó ṣe bí a ti pa á láṣẹ lójú àlá.

english: For this reason, he now travels from place to place in Yorùbáland to pass on his knowledge of the Odùduwà alphabet.
yoruba: Látàrí ìdí èyí, ó ń ṣe ìrìnàjò láti agbègbè kan dé òmíràn ní Ilẹ̀-Yorùbá láti tan ìmọ̀ alífábẹ́ẹ̀tì Odùduwà náà.

english: The following is a short video of teachers instructing students how to write the Odùduwà alphabet in a Benin classroom:
yoruba: Àwòrán-àtohùn àwọn olùkọ́ni tí ó kọ́ àwọn akẹ́kọ̀ọ́ bí a ti ṣe ń kọ alífábẹ́ẹ̀tì Odùduwà ní yàrá-ìgbẹ̀kọ́ kan ní Bẹ̀nẹ̀:

english: Promoting theYorùbá alphabet
yoruba: Ìgbélárugẹ alífábẹ́ẹ̀tì Yorùbá náà

english: In 2017, Chief Ògúntósìn, in the company of prominent traditional rulers in Yorùbáland and the diaspora, paid a visit to Rauf Arẹ́gbẹ́ṣọlá, the one-time governor of Nigeria’s Ọ̀ṣun State, in Òṣogbo, the state capital, to solicit support for his newly found Odùduwà alphabet.
yoruba: Lọ́dún 2017, Olóyè Ògúntósìn, pẹ̀lú àwọn ọba Aláṣẹ igbá-kejì òrìṣà Ilẹ̀-Yorùbá nílé àti lẹ́yìn odi, ṣe àbẹ̀wó to sí Ọ̀gbẹ́ni Rauf Arẹ́gbẹ́ṣọlá, ẹni tí ó fi ìgbà kan rí jẹ́ alákòóso Ìpínlẹ̀ Ọ̀ṣun, ní olú ìpínlẹ̀ náà th Òṣogbo, e one- èdè Nàìjíríà, láti béèrè fún àtìlẹ́yìn fún alífábẹ́ẹ̀tì Odùduwà tuntun náà.

english: Arẹ́gbẹ́ṣọlá now serves as the Minister of the Federal Ministry of Interior of Nigeria.
yoruba: Arẹ́gbẹ́ṣọlá ni Mínísítà fún Ètò Abélé fún orílẹ̀-èdè Nàìjíríà ní sáà ti a wà yìí.

english: A reminder letter was sent to the governor of Osun state after promises made to teach the new alphabet have gone unfulfilled.
yoruba: Ìwé tí a kọ ránṣẹ́ sí gómìnà ìpínlẹ̀ Ọ̀ṣun ní ìrántí àwọn ìpinnu kíkọ́ alífábẹ́ẹ̀tì tuntun náà tí kò tíì wá sí ìmúṣẹ.

english: Three years later, regrettably, verbal promises made by former governor Arẹ́gbẹ́ṣọlá to teach the discovered alphabet in elementary schools across southwest Nigeria have gone unfulfilled.
yoruba: Ọdún mẹ́ta ti lọ, ó bani lọ́kàn jẹ́, ìlérí tí gómìnà àná Arẹ́gbẹ́ṣọlá ṣe láti rí dájú wí pé alífábẹ́ẹ̀tì tuntun náà jẹ́ kíkọ́ ni àwọn iléèwé tí ó ń bẹ ní Ìwọ̀-oòrùn gúúsù ilẹ̀ Nàìjíríà kò tíì di múmú ṣẹ.

english: In a bid to make the Odùduwà alphabet popular, Chief Ògúntósìn has written a book and produced a documentary on the orthography — with snippets uploaded on the internet for public viewing — as well as an abandoned cartoon project which did not see the light of day due to lack of funds.
yoruba: Lójúnà kí alífábẹ́ẹ̀tì Odùduwà náà ó ba di ìlúmọ̀ọ́ká, Olóyè Ògúntósìn ti kọ ìwé kan, ó sì ti ká àwòrán-àtohùn alálàyé kan tí ó tú pẹrẹpẹ́ẹ̀rẹ̀ ìṣọwọ́kọ alífábẹ́ẹ̀tì tuntun náà sílẹ̀ — fún mùtúmùwà láti wò ní abalaabala lórí ayélujára — bákan náà ni ẹ̀patìrì iṣẹ́ akọ́nilọ́gbọ́n kàtúùnù fún àwọn èwe tí kò s'ówó láti parí i rẹ̀ náà ò gbẹ́yìn.

english: Chief Ògúntósìn also uses YouTube, WhatsApp and Facebook Groups: “Ẹ̀kọ́ Aèébàèjìogbè Odùduwà” and "Odùduwà Alphabets" to promote and teach interested language learners.
yoruba: Olóyè Ògúntósìn ń lo gbàgbé YouTube, WhatsApp àti Ẹgbẹ́ orí Facebook: "Ẹ̀kọ́ Aèébáèjìogbè Odùduwà" àti “Alífábẹ́ẹ̀tì Odùduwà” fi ṣe ìgbélárugẹ àti kọ́ àwọn akẹ́kọ̀ọ́ tí ó nífẹ̀ẹ́ sí kíkọ́ ìlànà ìṣọwọ́kọ náà.

english: He calls on all stakeholders to support the promotion of his linguistic discovery that will checkmate Western writing culture and give the Yorùbá people their deserved identity in terms of language development.
yoruba: Ó rọ gbogbo ẹni tí ọ̀ràn kan láti dìde sí ti ìgbélárugẹ àwárí tí yóò gbá ìlànà ìṣọwọ́kọ Àmúnisìn tì sẹ́gbẹ̀ẹ́ tí yóò sì fún ìran Yorùbá ní ìdánimọ̀ tí ó tọ́ tí ó ní ṣe pẹ̀lú ìdàgbàsókè èdè.

english: A kind-hearted Yorùbá man, Sunday Adéníyì, supported the cause by printing 1,000 copies of the "Aèébàèjìogbè Odùduwà Alphabets" exercise book for primary school pupils.
yoruba: Ọkùnrin onínúure kan, Sunday Adéníyì, ṣe agbátẹrù ìtẹ̀jáde 1,000 ẹ̀da ìwé ìgbẹ̀kọ́ "Alífábẹ́ẹ̀tì Aèébáèjìogbè Odùduwà" fún àwọn ọmọ iléèwé alákọ̀ọ̀bẹ̀rẹ̀.

english: Read more: Lost in translation: Why Google Translate often gets Yorùbá — and other languages — wrong
yoruba: Kà sí i: Sísọnù sínú ògbufọ̀: Ìdí tí Atúmọ̀ Google ṣe ń kùnà — nínú títúmọ̀ èdè Yorùbá — àti àwọn èdè mìíràn

english: Copies of the educational pamphlets were printed in Igbo, Hausa, English, and French languages respectively. However, more support is crucial to disseminate the alphabet to a wider audience.
yoruba: Ẹ̀da ìwé ẹ̀kọ́ alífábẹ́ẹ̀tì náà wà ní èdè Igbo, Hausa, English, àti Faransé lẹ́sẹẹsẹ. Síbẹ̀síbẹ̀, àtìlẹ́yìn kì í pọ̀ jù fún ìpínkárí alífábẹ́ẹ̀tì náà.

english: The Odùduwà alphabet is a welcome development.
yoruba: Ìgbésẹ̀ tí ó mú ìwúrí dání ni alífábẹ́ẹ̀tì Odùduwà náà.

english: Nevertheless, the shift from writing in Latin to the new system will be a major challenge.
yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n, sísún láti ìlànà Látíìnì sí ìlànà tuntun ni yóò mú ìpèníjà ńlá lọ́wọ́.

english: That said, the Odùduwà alphabet is a great step in the right direction toward the development and growth of the Yorùbá language — in what Yorùbá people will call their own.
yoruba: Kò jẹ́ bó ṣe jẹ́, ohun tí yóò mú ìlọsíwájú àti ìdàgbàsókè bá èdè Yorùbá ni alífábẹ́ẹ̀tì Odùduwà — ohun tí ìran Yorùbá yóò pè ni tiwa-ń-tiwa.

english: Yorùbá loanwords: How languages evolve
yoruba: Ọ̀rọ̀ àyálò nínú èdè Yorùbá: Bí èdè ṣe yí padà

english: Do you say àkàrà or bean cake?
yoruba: Ṣé àkàrà ni ò ń pè àbí bean cake?

english: Àkàrà or Nigerian bean cake is a staple breakfast in Nigeria, July 11, 2013. Photo by Atimukoh via Wikimedia Commons, CC BY 2.0.
yoruba: Àkàrà tàbí beans cake ní Nàìjíríà jẹ́ oúnjẹ àárọ̀ ní Nàìjíríà, ọjọ́ 11, oṣù kéje, ọdún 2013. Àwòrán láti ọwọ́ Atimukoh láti orí i Wikimedia Commons, àṣẹ CC BY 2.0.

english: Relationships between languages have existed for hundreds of years.
yoruba: Àjọṣepọ̀ láàárín onírúurú èdè ti wà láti ayébáyé.

english: Think of the word "restaurant," borrowed from the French language into English.
yoruba: Fún àkàwé, kí á wo gbólóhùn bí i "restaurant," tí ó jẹ́ ọ̀rọ̀ tí a yá láti inú èdè Faransé wá sínú èdè Gẹ̀ẹ́sì.

english: Today, this loanword — a word adopted from one language into another without translation — circulates in English as if it was never borrowed.
yoruba: Lóde òní, ọ̀rọ̀-àyálò yìí — ìyẹn gbólóhùn tí a gbà lò láti inú èdè kan sí inú èdè mìíràn láì tú ìmọ̀ rẹ̀ — kò l'óǹkà nínú èdè Gẹ̀ẹ́sì àfi bí ẹni pé kì í ṣe ọ̀rọ̀ tí a yá lò.

english: These linguistic borrowings can be attributed to immigration, commerce, and trade as people were exposed to a wide range of ethnolinguistic environments.
yoruba: Àwọn èdè àyálò wọ̀nyí wáyé látàrí àbápàdé onírúurú ènìyàn kárí ayé, bí wọ́n ṣe ń ṣíkiri, ṣe ọrọ̀ Ajé, àti káràkátà.

english: Through these interactions, people were exposed to various linguistic contexts, and words and phrases were borrowed to accommodate these encounters.
yoruba: Látàrí ìtàkùrọ̀sọ tí ó wáyé láàárín àwọn onírúurú ènìyàn wọ̀nyí, èdè wọnú èdè, gbólóhùn àti àpólà ọ̀rọ̀ di àyálò.

english: The Yorùbá case is no exception.
yoruba: Ìṣẹ̀lẹ̀ yìí kò yọ ìran Yorùbá sílẹ̀.

english: Spoken widely by about 40 million speakers in Nigeria, Yorùbá language has been influenced by the English language spoken by the British, who held colonial power in Nigeria from 1914 to 1960.
yoruba: Ó tó ẹgbẹẹgbẹ̀rún ènìyàn 40 tíó ń fọ èdè Yorùbá ní orílẹ̀ èdè Nàìjíríà, irú èdè Yorùbá ti dàpọ̀ mọ́ ṣapala èdè Gẹ̀ẹ́sì, tí í ṣe èdè ìjọba amúnisìn àná láti ọdún 1914 sí 1960.

english: More than half of the vocabulary words used in Yorùbá are borrowed from English. Think of the word "cup", it was domesticated as kó̩ò̩pù.
yoruba: Ó tó ìdajì gbólóhùn èdè Gẹ̀ẹ́sì tí a yà lò nínú èdè Yorùbá. Kí a wo ọ̀rọ̀ bí i "cup" Ó di kó̩ò̩pù.

english: The word "phone" is fóònù, "ball" is bó̩ò̩lù, and "television" is te̩lifís̩ó̩ò̩nù, among others.
yoruba: A pe "phone" ní fóònù, "ball" di bó̩ò̩lù, "television" ni te̩lifís̩ó̩ò̩nù, àti bẹ́ẹ̀ bẹ́ẹ̀ lọ.

english: These English words that were "loaned" to Yorùbá expanded its vocabulary over time.
yoruba: Àwọn gbólóhùn "àyálò" wọ̀nyí mú èdè Yorùbá fẹjú sí i.

english: There are also instances of the Yorùbá language borrowing words from the Hausa language, spoken by 44 million people in the northern part of Nigeria.
yoruba: Bákan náà ni àwọn ọ̀rọ̀ àyálò inú èdè Hausa tí àwọn ẹgbẹẹgbẹ̀rún 44 ènìyàn ní Àríwá ilẹ̀ Nàìjíríà ń sọ lọ sua.

english: This language borrows heavily from Arabic, as well, with words like àlùbáríkà ("blessing"), àlùbó̩sà ("onion") and wàhálà ("trouble").
yoruba: Èdè yìí yá ọ̀kẹ́ àìmọye ọ̀rọ̀ lò láti inú èdè Lárúbáwá, àwọn ọ̀rọ̀ bí i àlùbáríkà ("ìbùkún"), àlbásà ("àlùbọ́sà") àti wàhálà ("ìyọnu").

english: The beauty of Yorùbá loanwords is that speakers now use them in their day-to-day conversations as they get absorbed into the language.
yoruba: Ohun tí ó jẹ́ ìwúrí ní ti àwọn ọ̀rọ̀ àyálò nínú èdè Yorùbá ni bí àwọn ènìyàn ṣe ń lò wọ́n nínú ìtàkùrọ̀sọ lójoojúmọ́ bí wọ́n ṣe ń ṣàn wọ inú èdè náà.

english: It is not uncommon to hear people say, Bá o̩mo̩ ye̩n mú bó̩ò̩lu è̩  or "Help the child take the ball" in English.
yoruba: Wà á gbọ́ gbólóhùn bí i, Bá o̩mo̩ ye̩n mú bó̩ò̩lu è̩ tàbí "Help the child take the ball" lédè Gẹ̀ẹ́sì.

english: Although the underlined word bó̩ò̩lu is not native to the Yorùbá language, speakers manage to make it fit.
yoruba: Adi, ọmọ-ọ̀rọ̀ tí a falà sí lábẹ́ bó̩ò̩lu jẹ́ tiwantiwa nínú èdè Yorùbá, àwọn aṣàfọ̀ mọ bí wọ́n ṣe ń lò ó.

english: One of the challenges with the Yorùbá language with regard to loanwords is that native speakers themselves love translating Yorùbá words into English and using them in sentences instead of the original Yorùbá word.
yoruba: Ìpèníjà kan tí èdè Yorùbá ní nípa ti ọ̀rọ̀ àyálò ò ju ti ògbufọ̀ ọ̀rọ̀ wuuru tí àwọn aṣàfọ̀ èdè Yorùbá máa ń ṣe láti túmọ̀ àwọn gbólóhùn èdè Yorùbá sí ti Gẹ̀ẹ́sì tí wọ́n máa ń lò nínú ìpèdè dípò ojúlówó èdè Yorùbá.

english: An example is the word àkàrà  — most Yorùbá speakers translate it to bean cake in daily interactions —, especially with foreigners.
yoruba: Fún àpẹẹrẹ, àkàrà — tí àwọn ọmọ Yorùbá ti túmọ̀ sí bean cake — pàápàá nínú ìfọ̀rọ̀jomitoro-ọ̀rọ̀ pẹ̀lú àlejò.

english: Using words in their original forms helps ensure that culture — kept alive through language — continues to thrive.
yoruba: Lílo ọ̀rọ̀ ní èdè pọ́nbélé máa ń mú kí àṣà — ó gbòòrò — tí yóò sí máa jẹ́ kí èdè ó di ìtẹ́wọ́gbà.

english: For instance, no one calls Japan’s sushi by any other name — sushi is sushi.
yoruba: Bí a bá wò ó báyìí, kò s'ẹ́ni jẹ́ pe sushi Japan lórúkọ mìíràn — sushi ni sushi ń jẹ́.

english: If this was the case for many Yorùbá words, too, its language and culture could flourish beyond Nigeria and the Yorùbá-speaking world.
yoruba: Bí èyí bá rí bẹ́ẹ̀ fún àwọn ọ̀rọ̀ Yorùbá náà, èdè àti àṣà rẹ̀, yóò gbilẹ̀ kọjá orílẹ̀-èdè Nàìjíríà àti ibi tí wọ́n ti ń fọ èdè Yorùbá kárí ayé.

english: For example, àmàlà is a famous Yorùbá food, even in the diaspora.
yoruba: Fún àpẹẹrẹ, àmàlà jẹ́ oúnjẹ tí ó ilẹ̀ Yorùbá lókìkí, pàápàá ní òkè òkun.

english: This word could easily find its way into the lexicon of other languages if Yorùbá speakers insisted on it.
yoruba: Gbólóhùn yìí ti rá pálá wọnú ìlò ọ̀rọ̀ èdè mìíràn bí àwọn aṣàfọ̀ Yorùbá bá tẹnu mọ́ ọn.

english: Translating it to "yam flour" lessens its status and linguistic root — its "Yorubaness."
yoruba: Títúmọ̀ rẹ̀ sí "yam flour" dín agbára ìpèdè náà kù — yóò sọ "ipò Yorùbá nù."

english: Think of the anglicized Yorùbá word "fanimorious", which is becoming more popular and appears in the Urban Dictionary.
yoruba: Bí a bá wo gbólóhùn èdè Gẹ̀ẹ́sì tí a yí padà sí èdè Yorùbá "fanimorious", tí ó ti ń lókìkí tí ó sì ti wà nínú Ìwé Ìtumọ̀ Ìgbàlódé.

english: It means "appealing", or "beautiful", and comes from the word fanimó̩ra in Yorùbá.
yoruba: Ó túmọ̀ sí “bójúmu,” tàbí “rẹwà,” tí ó súyọ láti fanimó̩ra tí í ṣe gbólóhùn Yorùbá.

english: This could be phono-morphological: Yorùbá language does not allow final word consonants and consonant clusters.
yoruba: Èyí f'ara pẹ́ ìbáṣepọ̀ fonọ́lọ́jì àti mọfọ́lọ́jì: èdè Yorùbá kì í fàyè gba ìhunpọ̀ kọ̀nsónántì àti kí ọ̀rọ̀ parí pẹ̀lú kọ̀nsónántì.

english: As a result, the English suffix -ious was added to the Yorùbá root word.
yoruba: Torí ìdí èyí, a fi àfòmọ́ ìparí -ious èdè Gẹ̀ẹ́sì kún ọ̀rọ̀ ìpìlẹ̀ Yorùbá.

english: However, the fact remains that the word stems from the Yorùbá language. This is a win for the Yorùbá.
yoruba: Síbẹ̀, òtítọ́ farahàn wípé láti ara èdè Yorùbá ni ó ti sú yọ. Ìgbéga ni èyí jẹ́ fún Yor Yorùbá.

english: Recently, several other Nigerian English words were added to the Oxford English Dictionary.
yoruba: Ní kò pẹ́ kò pẹ́ yìí, ọ̀gọ̀rọ̀ èdè Gẹ̀ẹ́sì bí a ti ṣe ń lò ó ní Nàìjíríà di àfikún nínú ìwé ìtúmọ̀ èdè Gẹ̀ẹ́sì ti Oxford.

english: Yorùbá will make giant strides only if its speakers contribute to its growth; Its usage in the media is also important as the world becomes increasingly more digitized.
yoruba: Ọpọ́n èdè Yorùbá yóò sún síwájú bí àwọn tó ń fọ èdè náà bá lọ́wọ́ sí ìdàgbàsókè rẹ̀; ìlò rẹ̀ nínú iṣẹ́ ìkọ̀ròyìn pọn dandan ní ìbámu pẹ̀lú bí ayé ṣe ń lu jára wọn bí ajere lóde òní.

english: Consequently, this will spur further research on the Niger-Congo language.
yoruba: Ní ìparí, èyí yóò túbọ̀ mú kí iṣẹ́ ìwádìí èdè Niger-Congo ó rinlẹ̀.

english: Lost in translation: Why Google Translate often gets Yorùbá — and other languages — wrong
yoruba: Sísọnù sínú ògbufọ̀: Ìdí tí Atúmọ̀ Google ṣe ń kùnà — nínú títúmọ̀ èdè Yorùbá — àti àwọn èdè mìíràn

english: Most translations done by machines render some words wrong
yoruba: Ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ ògbufọ̀ tí ẹ̀rọ ṣe ni kò nítumọ̀.

english: Wikimedia User Group Nigeria, October 2018 via Wikimedia Commons CC.BY.2.0.
yoruba: Aṣàmúlò Ẹgbẹ́ Wikimedia Orílẹ̀-èdè Nàìjíríà, oṣù Ọ̀wàrà ọdún 2018 láti orí Wikimedia Commons CC.BY.2.0.

english: The English language has dominated online discourse as the "universal" language of communication since the inception of the internet.
yoruba: Èdè Gẹ̀ẹ́sì ti jẹ gàba lórí ìbánisọ̀rọ̀ tí ó ń wáyé ní orí ẹ̀rọ ayélukára-bí-ajere gẹ́gẹ́ bí èdè "gbogbo àgbáyé" fún ìtàkùrọ̀sọ láti ìbẹ̀rẹ̀ pẹ̀pẹ̀ ẹ̀rọ ayélujára.

english: As of February 2020, over half of the websites on the internet are in English, according to WebTech3.
yoruba: Nínú oṣù Èrèlé ọdún 2020, gẹ́gẹ́ bí WebTech3 ti ṣe fi hàn, ìdajì ibùdó ìtakùn àgbáyé tó wà lórí ayélujára ni a kọ ní èdè Gẹ̀ẹ́sì.

english: But as more people get online who speak different languages, it has sparked a linguistic digital revolution — immediate access to English translations of multiple languages with the click of a button.
yoruba: Àmọ́ bí ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ ènìyàn tí ó ń sọ oríṣìíríṣìí èdè àgbáyé ṣe ń bọ́ sórí ayélukára-bí-ajere, ó ṣẹ́ ẹtà ìjà fún èdè ẹni — ìráàyè sí ìṣògbufọ̀ sí onírúurú èdè tí yóò ṣẹ̀ ní mọnawáà.

english: Many tech companies have recently put effort into documenting non-English words on the internet, paving the way for the digitization of multiple languages. Google, Yoruba Names, Masakhane MT and  ALC are examples of companies and start-ups that have been trying to marry technology with non-English languages.
yoruba: Ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ iléeṣẹ́ onímọ̀ ẹ̀rọ ti ṣe iṣẹ́ ribiribi ní ti ìṣàkọsílẹ̀ àwọn ọ̀rọ̀ tí kì í ṣe èdè Gẹ̀ẹ́sì sórí ayélujára, tí ó ń ṣe olùlànà onírúurú èdè lórí ẹ̀rọ ayárabíàṣá lọ́nà ìgbàlódé. Google, Yoruba Names, Masakhane MT àti ALC jẹ́ àpẹẹrẹ àwọn iléeṣẹ́ ńlá àti àwọn iléeṣẹ́ kéréje tí ó ṣẹ̀ṣẹ̀ bẹ̀rẹ̀ tí ó ti mú ìmọ̀-ẹ̀rọ ṣiṣẹ́ pọ̀ pẹ̀lú àwọn èdè tí kì í ṣe èdè Gẹ̀ẹ́sì.

english: In late February 2020, Google announced that it would add five new languages to its Google Translate services, including Kinyarwanda, Uighur, Tatar, Turkmen and Odia, after a four-year hiatus on adding new languages.
yoruba: Kí oṣù Èrèlé ọdún 2020 ó tó tẹnu bepo, Google filọ̀ wípé òun yóò fi èdè tuntun márùn-ún kún iṣẹ́ Atúmọ̀ Google rẹ̀, àwọn èdè náà ni Kinyarwanda, Uighur, Tatar, Turkmen àti Odia, lẹ́yìn ìsinmi ọdún mẹ́rin tí wọ́n fi èdè tuntun kún un kẹ́yìn.

english: A man looks perplexed while reading a text online. Photo by Oladimeji Ajegbile, open-source via Pexels.
yoruba: Ọkùnrin kan ń wò bí ẹni tí ó nídààmú nígbà tí ó ń ka gbólóhùn ọ̀rọ̀ lórí ayélujára. Àwòránlláti ọwọ́ Ọládiméjì Ajégbilẹ̀, àṣẹ-àtúnlò láti orí Pexels.

english: But have you ever clicked on the translation option and realized that the English translation is, at best, just OK?
yoruba: Àmọ́ ṣe o ti ṣíra tẹ àṣàyàn ìtumọ̀ rí tí ó ṣàkíyèsí wípé, bákan, ló dára jù lọ?

english: And at worst, not accurate at all?
yoruba: Bákan náà, ló kù díẹ̀ káàtó, kò ṣe déédéé?

english: There are many controversies and difficulties when it comes to doing this kind of language translation and access work.
yoruba: Orísìírísìí àríyànjiyàn àti ìṣòro ló máa ń wáyé bí ó bá kan irú ìtumọ̀ èdè báyìí àti rírí i lò.

english: Twitter offers Yorùbá language translation into English via Google Translate as much as possible, and usually, the outcome isn’t totally bad — perhaps a few words are correct.
yoruba: Twitter máa ń ṣe ìtumọ̀ èdè Yorùbá sí èdè Gẹ̀ẹ́sì nípasẹ̀ lílo Atúmọ̀ Google bí ó ti ṣe fàyè gbà wọ́n, tí àbájáde rẹ̀ sì kù díẹ̀ káàtó nígbàgbogbo — tí àwọn ọ̀rọ̀ kọ̀ọ̀kan sì ṣe déédéé.

english: The reason for these challenges is that tech companies usually collect their linguistic data for English translation sourced from the internet.
yoruba: Ohun tí ó fa àwọn ìpeníjà wọ̀nyí ó ju pé orí ayélujára ni àwọn iléeṣẹ́ onímọ̀ ẹ̀rọ ti máa ń ṣe àkójọ èdè wọn for tí wọ́n ń fi ṣe ògbufọ̀ gbólóhùn ọ̀rọ̀.

english: This data may work for some languages, but languages like Yorùbá and Ìgbò, two main languages from Nigeria, are challenging, due to the inadequate or inaccurate accent marks to indicate tones on these words.
yoruba: Àwọn àkójọ gbólóhùn ọ̀rọ̀ wọ̀nyí lè ṣiṣẹ́ fún àwọn èdè kan, àmọ́ èdè bí i Yorùbá àti Ìgbò, jẹ́ èdè méjì ní orílẹ̀-èdè Nàìjíríà, tí ìpèníjà yìí bá, látàrí àìpọ̀tó gbólóhùn ọ̀rọ̀ àti gbólóhùn tí a ò yán lórílábẹ́ dáadáa tí yóò tọ́ka sí ìró ohùn.

english: In response to why it has taken Google four years to add five new languages, a company spokesperson explained:
yoruba: Láti fèsì sí ohun tí ó fa sábàbí tí ó fi gba Google ní ọdún mẹ́rin kí ó tó ṣe àfikún èdè tuntun márùn-ún kún tilẹ̀, agbẹnusọ iléeṣẹ́ náà ṣe ìṣípayá:

english: Google Translate learns from existing translations found on the web, and when languages don’t have an abundance of web content, it’s been difficult for our system to support them effectively.
yoruba: Orí ìtakùn àgbáyé ni Atúmọ̀ Google ti máa ń ṣa gbólóhùn tí a ti túmọ̀ jọ, àmọ́ bí èdè kò bá ní gbólóhùn ọ̀rọ̀ tí ó pọ̀ tó lórí ayélujára, ó nira fún ẹ̀rọ wa láti ṣe àtìlẹ́yìn tí ó lákaakì fún irú àwọn èdè bẹ́ẹ̀

english: However, due to recent advances in our machine learning technology, and active involvement from our Google Translate Community members, we’ve been able to add support for these languages.
yoruba: Síbẹ̀, látàrí ìlọsíwájú àbùdá kíkọ́ ẹ̀rọ lẹ́kọ̀ọ́ wa, àti àwọn aṣiṣẹ́ Ìtumọ̀ Google lọ́fẹ̀ẹ́, ecent advances in our machine a ti fi àtìlẹ́yìn fún àwọn èdè wọ̀nyí.

english: Also, most people are not so good with the orthographies — or spellings — in these languages.
yoruba: Bákan náà, ọ̀pọ̀ ènìyàn ni kò mọ bí a ṣe ń kọ ọ̀rọ̀ dájúdánu — tàbí pípe ọmọ-ọ̀rọ̀ — inú àwọn èdè wọ̀nyí.

english: As a result, good translations don’t compute because these errors are not flagged as inadequate.
yoruba: Torí náà, ògbufọ̀ tí ó kúnjú òṣùwọ̀n kò jẹ́ àkópọ̀ nítorí kò sí bí a ṣe lè dá àwọn àṣìṣe wọ̀nyí mọ̀.

english: Most translations done by machines render some words wrong, especially words that are culturally nuanced.
yoruba: Púpọ̀ nínú ògbufọ̀ tí ẹ̀rọ ṣe ni kò ní ìtumọ̀, pàápàá jù lọ àwọn gbólóhùn tí ó rọ̀ mọ́ àṣà tí ó ní ju ìtúmọ̀ kan ṣoṣo lọ.

english: For example, Yorùbá words ayaba and obabìnrin have their meanings situated in a cultural context.
yoruba: Fún àpẹẹrẹ, gbólóhùn Yorùbá bí i ayaba àti ọbabìnrin ní ìtumọ̀ tó yàtọ̀.

english: Most machines translate both words as "queen".
yoruba: Ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ ẹ̀rọ ní í máa tú ìmọ̀ gbólóhùn méjèèjì sí "queen".

english: However, from a traditional-cum-cultural vantage point, it is essential to note that the meanings of ayaba and obabìnrin are different: Ọbabìnrin means "queen" in English while ayaba is "wife of the king".
yoruba: Síbẹ̀, tí a bá ti ọ̀nà ìṣe-àti-àsà wò ó, ó ṣe kókó láti sọ wí pé ìtúmọ̀ ayaba and ọbabìnrin yàtọ̀ síra wọn: Ọbabìnrin túmọ̀ sí "queen" lédè Gẹ̀ẹ́sì nígbà tí ayaba jẹ́ "wife of the king".

english: Even with these translation complications, technology has helped with the advancement of  African languages in digital spaces, spurring the coinage of new words.
yoruba: Pẹ̀lú àwọn àìṣedéédéé wọ̀nyí, ìmọ̀-ẹ̀rọ ti ṣe ìrànwọ́ fún ìdàgbàsókè àwọn èdè Ilẹ̀-Adúláwọ̀ lórí àwọn gbàgede orí ayélujára, tí ó ti mú ìṣẹ̀dá ọ̀rọ̀ tuntun wáyé.

english: African languages have grown with the influx of new gadgets like smartphones and tablets, as new words are coined to name these new technological tools and concepts.
yoruba: Èdè Ilẹ̀-Adúláwọ̀ ti gòkè àgbà látàrí àwọn lílo àwọn ẹ̀rọ ìgbàlódé tuntun bí i ẹ̀rọ-ìléwọ́ àti ẹ̀rọ ọpọ́n ayárabíàṣá, tí ó sì ń bí àwọn gbólóhùn tuntun tí a fi ń pe àwọn irinṣẹ́ ìmọ̀-ẹ̀rọ tuntun wọ̀nyí.

english: This process has thus expanded the usage and functionality of these languages.
yoruba: Èyí sì ti fẹ bí a ti ṣe ń lo àwọn èdè wọ̀nyí lójú.

english: With the emergence of new technologies, the vocabularies of many African languages have become more sophisticated.
yoruba: Látàrí àwọn ẹ̀rọ tuntun wọ̀nyí, ìpèdè ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ èdè Ilẹ̀-Adúláwọ̀ ti lé kún sí i.

english: For instance, the Yorùbá language has some tech-influenced words such as erọ amúlétutù ("air conditioner"), erọ Ìbánisọ̀rọ̀ ("phone") and erọ Ìlọta ("grinder").
yoruba: Fún àpẹẹrẹ, èdè Yorùbá ní àwọn gbólóhùn tí ó ní ṣe pẹ̀lú ìmọ̀-ẹ̀rọ bí i ẹ̀rọ-amúlétutù ("air conditioner"), erọ-ìbánisọ̀rọ̀ ("phone") and ẹ̀rọ-ìlọta ("grinder").

english: Similarly, the Igbo language has words such as ekwè nti ("telephone") and ugbọ̀ àlà ("vehicle").
yoruba: Ẹ̀wẹ̀wẹ̀, èdè Igbo náà ní ọ̀rọ̀ bí i ekwè nti ("telephone") àti ugbọ̀ àlà ("vehicle").

english: These societies have given these gadgets names based on the functions they perform.
yoruba: A ṣẹ̀dá àwọn orúkọ yìí ní ìbámu pẹ̀lú iṣẹ́ tí wọ́n ń ṣe.

english: In courses on broadcasting and advertisement in Yorùbá, students learn that most people call TV erọ Amóhùnmáwòrán.
yoruba: Nínú ẹ̀kọ́ ìmọ̀ ìgbóhùnsáfẹ́fẹ́ àti ètò ìpolówó ọjà lédè Yorùbá, àwọn akẹ́kọ̀ọ́ ti kọ́ wí pé ẹ̀rọ-amóhùnmáwòrán ni oọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ ènìyàn ń pe TV.

english: This coinage generates many questions and opinions — some students argue that video cameras and recorders can also be called erọ amóhùnmáwòrán based on their functionalities.
yoruba: Ìṣẹ̀dá ọ̀rọ̀ yìí fa àwọn onírúurú ìbéèrè àti èrò — àwọn akẹ́kọ̀ọ́ kan jiyàn wí pé a lè pe ẹ̀rọ-ayàwòrán náà ní ẹ̀rọ-amóhùnmáwòrán nítorí iṣẹ́ tí wọ́n ń ṣe.

english: These linguistic challenges in the tech space are healthy for languages — it stimulates critical thinking for both linguistic and tech advancement.
yoruba: Àwọn ìpèníjà t'ó tara ìmọ̀-ẹ̀rọ wá yìí ni yóò mú ìdàgbàsókè bá èdè — ó máa ń fa àròjìnlẹ̀ fún ìgbéga èdè àti ìmọ̀-ẹ̀rọ.

english: In 2019, Google opened its first AI research center in Accra, Ghana, focused on improving “Google Translate's ability to capture African languages more precisely,” according to CNN.
yoruba: Lọ́dún 2019, gẹ́gẹ́ bí CNN ti ṣe ròyìn, Google ṣí ibiṣẹ́ ìwádìí AI àkọ́kọ́ irú ẹ̀ sí Accra, Ghana, tí ó ń lépa láti mú kí "Atúmọ̀ Google ó gba àwọn èdè Ilẹ̀-Adúláwọ̀ jọ kí ó lọ geere".

english: Research scientist Moustapha Cisse, who heads Google's AI work in Africa, believes that "a continent with more than 2,000 dialects deserves to be better served," as reported by CNN.
yoruba: Onímọ̀ ìjìnlẹ̀ nípa iṣẹ́ ìwádìí Moustapha Cisse, tó jẹ́ olórí iṣẹ́ Google AI ní Ilẹ̀-Adúláwọ̀, nígbàgbọ́ wí pé ó tọ́ sí "ilẹ̀ tí ó ní ju ẹ̀ka-èdè 2,000 lọ láti jẹ́ àǹfààní iṣẹ́," — CNN jábọ̀.

english: Mozilla and BMZ recently announced their cooperation to open up voice technology for African languages. With initiatives like this, there is more to show in the future with regards to studies in African languages.
yoruba: Mozilla àti BMZ kéde àjùmọ̀ṣe wọn láti ṣe agbátẹrù iṣẹ́ àkànṣe tí ó dá fìrìgbagbòó lórí ìmọ̀-ẹ̀rọ alohùn fún thei èdè Ilẹ̀-Adúláwọ̀. Pẹ̀lú àwọn iṣẹ́ àtinudá bí eléyìí, ọjọ́ iwájú ìwádìí èdè Ilẹ̀-Adúláwọ̀ dára.

english: Churches in Greece and North Macedonia refuse to modify rituals conducive to the spread of COVID-19
yoruba: Àwọn Iléèjọsìn ní Greece àti Àríwá Macedonia kọ̀ láti yí ọwọ́ àwọn ìlànà-ìsìn wọn padà k'ó ba má fàyè gba àjàkálẹ̀ àrùn COVID-19 t'ó ń ràn ká

english: "Institution of the Eucharist", a 1442 painting by Fra Angelico. Public Domain photo via Wikipedia.
yoruba: "Àjọ Oúnjẹ Alẹ́ Olúwa", àwòrán tí a kùn lódà ní 1442 láti ọwọ́ Fra Angelico. Àwòrán tí kò ní olóhun láti orí Wikipedia.

english: While the number of people with COVID-19 steadily increases in the Balkans, a few Christian churches have refused to change liturgical practices that can contribute to the spread of the coronavirus.
yoruba: Bí àwọn tí ó ti kó àrùn COVID-19 ṣe ń pọ̀ọ́ sí i ní Balkans, àwọn ilé ìjọsìn kan kò yí ọwọ́ àwọn ìlànà ìsìn tí ó lè mú kí àrùn Coronavirus ó ràn bí i pápá inú ọyẹ́ padà.

english: The ritual known as the Holy Communion or Eucharist has Orthodox Christian worshipers drinking consecrated wine by a shared spoon, while Catholics eat thin slices of bread directly from the hand of the priest.
yoruba: Ìlànà ìsìn tí a mọ̀ sí Jíjẹara àti mímu ẹ̀jẹ̀ Olúwa tàbí Oúnjẹ Ìkẹyìn ní èyí tí àwọn ọmọ lẹ́yìn Krístì tí ó ń tẹ̀lé ìlànà ìsìn àtijọ́ yóò máa pín wáìnì tí a ti sọ di mímọ́ mu pẹ̀lú ṣíbí kan náà, àwọn Ìjọ Àgùdàá máa ń jẹ ẹ̀bẹ àkàrà fẹ́lẹ́fẹ́lẹ́ tí wọ́n fi ẹnu gbà lọ́wọ́ àlùfáà.

english: The World Health Organization (WHO) recommends avoiding large gatherings and increased levels of personal hygiene and sanitation in order to minimize the spread of the virus by touch, exchange of bodily fluids, and through the air.
yoruba: Àjọ Ìlera Àgbáyé (WHO) rọ̀ wá láti jìnà gbégbérégbé sí ibi tí àwọn èròó bá pitì sí, kí a sì káràmásíkì sí ìlera ara wa kí á ba dín àrànká àrùn ẹ̀jẹ̀ tí ènìyàn lè kó nípasẹ̀ ìfọwọ́kàn, ìfarakan omi tó sun lára ẹlòmíràn, àti láti inú afẹ́fẹ́.

english: In an official statement dated March 9, the Greek Orthodox Church said it will not be modifying the ritual to comply with safety measures.
yoruba: Nínú àtẹ̀jáde ọjọ́ 9, Iléèjọsìn Àtijọ́ Greek sọ wí pé òun kò ní yí ọwọ́ ìlànà-ìsìn padà kí ó bá ìgbésẹ̀ ààbò mu.

english: It also added that the "coronavirus is not transmitted via Holy Communion, and the faithful should pray against the spread of the deadly virus".
yoruba: Bákan náà ni ó sọ wí pé "a kò leè kó ààrùn coronavirus láti ara Jíjẹ ara-àti-mímu-ẹ̀jẹ̀ Olúwa, àti pé kí àwọn ọmọ Ọlọ́run ó gbàdúrà gidi nítorí ààrùn apànìyàn náà".

english: GOC bishop Klimis, the Metropolitan of Peristeri, a suburban municipality near Athens, said that those who believe the virus could spread via religious rituals are blasphemers:
yoruba: Bíṣọ́ọ̀pù ti GOC Klimis, ti Àárín gbùngbùn Peristeri, lábẹ́ agbègbè tó sún mọ́ Athens, sọ wí pé ọ̀rọ̀-òdì sí Olúwa ni bí ẹnikẹ́ni bá sọ pé ìlànà ẹ̀sìn lè mú kí ààrùn ó ràn:

english: The Holy Communion is life.
yoruba: Ìyè ni Ara-jíjẹ àti ẹ̀jẹ̀ mímu.

english: It is a miracle.
yoruba: Iṣẹ́ ìyanu ni.

english: It is a blasphemy to believe that the virus can be transmitted by receiving Holy Communion.
yoruba: Ọ̀rọ̀-òdì sí Olúwa ni láti ní ìgbàgbọ́ wí pé ènìyàn lè tara Jíjẹ ara-àti-mímu-ẹ̀jẹ̀ Olúwa kó ààrùn.

english: There have been 89 confirmed cases of COVID-19 in Greece, with no deaths so far.
yoruba: Ènìyàn 89 ló ti lùgbàdì COVID-19 ní Greece, láìsí ẹni tó kù.

english: Greek authorities, who have recently closed schools and prohibited gatherings in efforts to prevent transmission, urged the Church to reconsider.
yoruba: Àwọn aláṣẹ Greek, tí ó ti ṣán àwọn iléèwé pa, tí ó sì ti f'òfin de àpéjọ lójú ọ̀nà àti dènà àjàkálẹ̀, rọ Iléèjọsìn náà láti ṣe àtúnwò.

english: But state officials themselves seem to be ignoring those concerns. On a major religious holiday last Sunday, the president and some government ministers attended a public mass.
yoruba: Àmọ́ àwọn aṣojú ìjọba tìkarawọn ń tàpá sí òfin ìdènà ààrùn yìí. Lọ́jọ́ ìsinmi ajẹmẹ́sìn kan lọ́jọ́ Ọ̀sẹ̀ tó kọjá, ààrẹ àti àwọn onípò nínú ìṣèjọba rẹ̀ lọ sí ìsìn kan.

english: In neighboring North Macedonia, the Macedonian Orthodox Church – Ohrid  Archbishopric seems to be following a similar path.
yoruba: Ní ìlú tó múlé gbe Greece, ó jọ pé North Macedonia, Iléèjọsìn Àtijọ́ ti Macedonia – Ohrid Archbishopric náà ń tọ ipasẹ̀ kan náà.

english: Although the church has not yet issued any official statement about the outbreak, it has continued to conduct the Holy Communion normally.
yoruba: Bí ó tilẹ̀ jẹ́ pé Iléèjọsìn náà kò tíì ṣe ìfilọ̀ kankan nípa àjàkálẹ̀ náà, ó sì ń fún àwọn ọmọ ìjọ ní Ara jẹ àti ẹ̀jẹ̀ mu bí ó ti máa ń ṣe.

english: Alarms were raised when the official website of the Prespa-Pelagonia Diocese published a translated article by Russian website Pravoslavie.ru (meaning "Orthodox Christianity") claiming it's "impossible for believers to be infected during church rituals".
yoruba: Ìròyìn kàn nígbà tí ojúlé ibùdó ìtakùn Prespa-Pelagonia Diocese ṣe àtẹ̀jáde ògbufọ̀ article àrọko ibùdó ìtakùn tó jẹ́ ti Russia ìyẹn Pravoslavie.ru (ìtumọ̀ "Ẹ̀sìn Ìgbàgbọ́ Àtijọ́ ") tó ń sọ wí pé "kò lè ṣe é ṣe kí àwọn onígbàgbọ́ ó k'árùn láti ara ìlànà-ìsìn ìjọ".

english: The text is signed by Russian priest Sergey Adonin, who claims to have knowledge of microbiology and experience working in hospitals.
yoruba: Àlùfáà Sergey Adonin ti Russia ló buwọ́ lu àpilẹ̀kọ náà, ẹni tó sọ pé òun ní ìmọ̀ nípa ìṣẹ̀dá ẹ̀dá oníyè àìfojúrí pẹ̀lú ìrírí iṣẹ́ ní iléèwòsàn.

english: He stressed in the article that the rule of using the same spoon instituted in the 7th century Bizantium has so far done no harm, because "faith in God protects both the parishioners and the priests".
yoruba: Ó sọ síwájú sí i nínú àpilẹ̀kọ náà wí pé lílo ṣíbí kan náà bí wọn ti ṣe fi lọ́lẹ̀ ní ọgọ́rùn-ún ọdún kéje ayé Bizantium ò fa ìpalára, nítorí "ìgbàgbọ́ nínú Ọlọ́run ń fi ìṣọ́ ààbò bo àlùfáà àti ọmọ ìjọ".

english: Also in North Macedonia, right-wing propagandists expressed support to the church.
yoruba: Ní North Macedonia, àwọn tí ó ń mú ṣe ti ìlànà-ìsìn náà ní kò sí aburú nínú ìlànà iléèjọsìn náà.

english: For instance, one conservative TV host — who in the past promoted anti-vax activists — boasted on Twitter to have participated in risky religious rituals:
yoruba: Fún àpẹẹrẹ, atọ́kùn ètò lórí ẹ̀rọ amóhùnmáwòrán tó jẹ́ adàṣà-àtijọ́-mú-ṣinṣin — ajìjàǹgbara ẹni tó ti fi ìgbà kan rí ṣe ìpolongo ìtako ìbupá — fúnnu lórí Twitter wí pé òun ti kópa nínú àwọn ìlànà-ìsìn ajẹmẹ́sìn tó léwu:

english: Tweet: I received Holy Communion last Sunday in the Church of Holy Annunciation which is part of the Clinical Center in Skopje and will do it again!
yoruba: Túwíìtì: Mo jẹ Ara Olúwa mu ẹ̀jẹ̀ Olúwa lọ́jọ́ Àìkú tó kọjá nínú Iléèjọsìn Holy Annunciation tí ó wà nínú Iléèwòsàn ti Skopje tí n ó sì tún ṣe é!

english: What's your problem?
yoruba: Kí ni ìṣòro rẹ̀?

english: Link title: In spite of the appeal by health authorities: Believers received Holy Communion without fear from the coronavirus.
yoruba: Àkọlé adarí: Pẹ̀lú gbogbo ẹ̀bẹ̀ àjọ tó ń rí sí ètò ìlera: Àwọn onígbàgbọ́ jẹ Ara mu ẹ̀jẹ̀ Olúwa láì fòyà fún ààrùn coronavirus.

english: Sladjana Velkov, an anti-vax celebrity operating in Serbia and North Macedonia, recently declared that the situation is "not serious" and that the new virus is "just a common cold which, like the other common colds, affects only older people or people with compromised immunity".
yoruba: Sladjana Velkov, ẹni tó gbajúmọ̀ gẹ́gẹ́ bí alátakò-ìbupá tó ń ṣiṣẹ́ ní Serbia àti Àríwá Macedonia, sọ láì pẹ́ yìí wí pé nǹkan kò "le tóyẹn" àti pé "ọ̀fìnkìn lásán ni, èyí tí kò yàtọ̀ sí ọ̀fìnkìn tí a ti mọ̀ tẹ́lẹ̀, tó máa ń ṣe àwọn àgbàlagbà tàbí àwọn tí ìlera ara wọn kò pé tó".

english: Meanwhile from Italy, where over 631 people have died from the infection and more than 10,000 are affected, this user tweeted:
yoruba: Ní orílẹ̀-èdè Italy, níbi tí 631 ẹ̀mí èèyàn 631 ti bọ́ tí àwọn tí ó tó 10,000 ti lùgbàdì àrùn náà, aṣàmúlò kan túwíìtì:

english: So far there have been seven confirmed cases of COVID-19 in North Macedonia; 25 in Slovenia; 13 in Croatia; six in Albania; five in Serbia; five in Bosnia; and zero in Montenegro.
yoruba: Bí á bá kà á ní méníméjì, ó ti tó ẹni méje tí ó ti kó àrùn COVID-19 ní North Macedonia; 25 ní Slovenia; 13 ní Croatia; mẹ́fà ní Albania; fi márùn-ún ní Serbia; márùn-ún ní Bosnia; òdo ní Montenegro.

english: There have been 28 cases in Romania and six in Bulgaria.
yoruba: Ó ti tó ẹni 28 tó ti kó o ní Romania, mẹ́fà ní Bulgaria.

english: Christians elsewhere
yoruba: Onígbàgbọ́ níbi gbogbo

english: The world has already witnessed how the novel coronavirus can spread through religious congregations.
yoruba: Ilé ayé ti rí bí coronavirus àkọ́kọ́ irú ẹ̀ ṣe lè ràn níbi ìpéjọ ajẹmẹ́sìn.

english: Last month, a majority of 7,400 confirmed cases of COVID-19 in South Korea — a country that until then seemed to have the outbreak under control — were traced to the group Shincheonji Church of Jesus.
yoruba: Lóṣù tó kọjá, ọ̀pọ̀ ènìyàn tí ó tó 7,400 ni a gbọ́ wí pé ó ti ní àrùn apànìyàn COVID-19 ní South Korea — orílẹ̀-èdè tí ó jọ pé ó ti ń gbá àrùn náà mọ́lẹ̀ — rí àrùn náà lára Iléèjọsìn ẹgbẹ́ Shincheonji ti Jésù.

english: Criminal charges were filed against the sect — often called a cult — and its 88-year-old leader publicly apologized.
yoruba: A fi ẹ̀sùn ọ̀daràn kan ẹgbẹ́ náà — tí wọ́n máa ń pè ní igbẹ́-ìmùlẹ̀ — olórí ẹgbẹ́ náà tí í ṣe ẹni 8-ọdún wá síta láti ṣe ìtọrọ àforíjì.

english: Meanwhile, the Orthodox Diocese of Korea announced changes in its liturgical practices in accordance with the recommendations of the Ministry of Health:
yoruba: Ní tirẹ̀, Àjọ Ìlànà-ìsìn Àtijọ́ ti Korea ṣe ìfilọ̀ nípa àwọn àyípadà tó dé bá ìsìn rẹ̀ ní ìbámu pẹ̀lú àfilélẹ̀ Iléeṣẹ́ Ètò Ìlera:

english: 1. During the Divine Liturgy all believers will wear masks.
yoruba: 1. Gbogbo onígbàgbọ́ yóò wọ ìbomúbẹnu lásìkò tí ìsìn bá ń lọ lọ́wọ́.

english: 2. Before entering the Church, they will disinfect their hands with a disinfectant present at the entrance of the Church.
yoruba: 2. Kí wọ́n ó wọ Iléèjọsìn, wọ́n yóò fi apakòkòrò tó wà lẹ́nu àbáwọlé Iléèjọsìn ra ọwọ́ wọn.

english: 3. They will not shake hands with anyone.
yoruba: 3. Wọn kò ní gba ẹnìkan lọ́wọ́.

english: 4. They will not kiss the hand of the Clergy.
yoruba: 4. Wọn kò ní f'ẹnu ko Àlùfáà ìjọ lọ́wọ́.

english: 5. They will not kiss the Icons, but they will bow before them.
yoruba: 5. Wọn kò ní fẹnu ko àwọn Ère, àmọ́ wọn ó tẹríba níwájú wọn.

english: 6. They will not use the liturgical books at the time of prayer.
yoruba: 6. Wọn kò ní lo àwọn ìwé àdúrà nígbà ìsìn.

english: 7. They will not receive the Antidoron from the Clergy, but on their own as they leave the church.
yoruba: 7. Wọn kò ní gba Àkàrà lọ́wọ́ Àlùfáà ìjọ, àmọ́ fúnra wọn bí wọ́n bá ń jáde kúrò nínú iléèjọsìn.

english: 8. The Agape Meal will not be served following the Sunday Liturgy.
yoruba: 8. Oúnjẹ Àpèjẹ Ifẹ̀ kò ní jẹ́ pínpín lọ́jọ́ Àìkú.

english: 9. The various group meetings of the Faithful as well as the Catechumens will not take place.
yoruba: 9. Àwọn ìpàdé ẹlẹ́gbẹ́jẹgbẹ́ àti ti àwọn tó ń kọ́ ìsìn Ọlọ́run kò ní wáyé.

english: Some churches in Europe have adopted similar measures, such as the Catholic church in Italy.
yoruba: Àwọn ilé ìjọsìn kan ní Ilẹ̀ Gẹ̀ẹ́sì ti ń ṣe àyípadà sí ìlànà ìsìn wọn, bí i ìjọ Àgùdà ti Italy.

english: The diocese in Croatia have also enacted restrictive rules and, in France, a pilgrimage site in the city of Lourdes has been shut down.
yoruba: Àjọ ẹ̀sìn ìgbàgbọ́ Croatia náà en ti ṣ'òfin tó dá lé àrùn náà, ní France, ibi ìrìnàjò mímọ kan ní ìlú Lourdes ti di títì pa.

english: The Orthodox Church of Romania issued a decree announcing "exceptional measures taken only because of the threat of an epidemic":
yoruba: Iléèjọsìn Ìlànà-ìsìn Àtijọ́ ti Romania fi òfin kan síta "tó jẹ́ àwọn ìgbésẹ̀ tí ènìyàn yóò tẹ̀lé bí àjàkálẹ̀ bá dúkokò":

english: Believers who are afraid of virus transmission may temporarily refrain from kissing the holy icons in the churches.
yoruba: Àwọn onígbàgbọ́ tíbẹ̀rùbojo àrùn apànìyàn náà ti sojo s'ọ́kan wọn yóò pa ìfènuko àwọn ère inú ilé ìjọsìn lára.

english: They can exceptionally ask the priest to use their own spoon for the Holy Communion.
yoruba: Bí ó bá wù wọ́n, wọ́n leè sọ fún àlùfáà wí pé ṣíbí ti wọn ni àwọn fẹ́ lò fi gba Ẹ̀jẹ̀ Olúwa mu.

english: After Italy enacted a complete lockdown on national territory, other European states, like the Czech Republic also took more drastic measures on March 10, such as the closure of schools.
yoruba: Lẹ́yìn tí Italy pàṣẹ pé kí gbogbo orígun mẹ́rẹ̀ẹ̀rin ìlú ó di sísé pa, àwọn alámùúlégbè, bí i Ilẹ̀ Olómìnira Czech náà gbé àwọn àgbékalẹ̀ kan lọ́jọ́ 10, oṣù Ẹrẹ́nà tí wọ́n ṣán àwọniiléèwé pa.

english: The Government of North Macedonia declared a state of emergency and also shut down kindergardens, schools, and universities for two weeks.
yoruba: Ìjọba North Macedonia kéde ipò ìlú ò f'ara rọ, ó sì ti àwọn jẹ́léósinmi, iléèwé, títí kan iléèwé gíga jù lọ Ifásitìi pa fún ọ̀sẹ̀ méjì.

english: Check out Global Voices’ special coverage of the global impact of COVID-19.
yoruba: Check Yẹ àwọn iṣẹ́ àkànṣe Ohùn Àgbáyé lórí arapa COVID-19 lágbàáyé.

english: Nigeria enforces travel bans amid sloppy management of COVID-19 cases
yoruba: Orílẹ̀-Èdè Nàìjíríà fi òfin de ìrìn-àjò lójúnà ìṣàmójútó àwọn tó ti kó kòkòrò àìfojúrí COVID 19

english: Travel ban on 13 countries with over 1,000 cases of COVID-19
yoruba: Ìfòfindèrìnàjò àwọn orílẹ̀-èdè 13 tí ènìyàn tó ti kó COVID-19 ju 1,000 lọ

english: Image by Pete Linforth from Pixabay. Used under a Pixabay license, public use.
yoruba: Àwòrán láti ọwọ́ Pete Linforth ní Pixabay. Ìlò àwòrán pẹ̀lú àṣẹ Pixabay, fún ìlò gbogboògbò.

english: Check out Global Voices’ special coverage of the global impact of COVID-19.
yoruba: Yẹ àkọsílẹ̀ àkànṣe Global Voices wò lórí ipa COVID-19 lágbàáyé.

english: Nigeria has confirmed five new COVID-19 cases, bringing the total number of coronavirus patients to eight,  according to the Nigeria Centre for Disease Control.
yoruba: Gẹ́gẹ́ bí àjò tí ó ń kápá ìtànkálẹ̀ àrùn ní Nàìjíríà ṣe sọ, àwọn èèyàn márùn-ún mìíràn ni wọ́n ti fìdí rẹ̀ múlẹ̀ pé wọ́n ti kó kòkòro àrùn COVID-19, àròpọ̀ iye àwọn tí wọ́n ní àrùn náà ní Nàìjíríà wá jẹ́ mẹ́jọ.

english: The increase to eight patients came just 48 hours after Dr. E. Osagie Ehanire confirmed the third case of COVID-19, March 16, as a "Nigerian national in her 30s who returned from a short visit to the United Kingdom on March 13":
yoruba: Iye àwọn ẹni tí ó ní kòkòrò àrùn náà di mẹ́jọ ní ọjọ́ méjì lẹ́yìn tí dókítà E. Osagie Ehanire fìdí i rẹ múlẹ̀ ní ọjọ́ 16, oṣù Ẹrẹ́na pé wọ́n ti rí ẹni kẹ́ta tí ó kó kòkòrò àìfojúrí COVID-19, ìyen "ọmọ orílẹ̀-èdè Nàìjíríà kan tí ó lé ní ẹni ọgbọ̀n tí ó ṣẹ̀ṣẹ̀ dé láti United Kingdom ní ọjọ́ 13, oṣù Ẹrẹ́na".

english: The patient voluntarily began a 14-day self-isolation in Lagos, during which she developed symptoms of fever and cough.
yoruba: Aláìsàn náà ya ara rẹ̀ sọ́tọ̀ fún ọjọ́ 14 ní ìlú Èkó, láàárín àsìkò yìí ni ó bẹ̀rẹ̀ sí i ní àmì àìsàn ibà àti ikọ̀.

english: The patient is currently admitted to the Infectious Disease Hospital, Yaba, Lagos.
yoruba: Aláìsàn náà wà ní ilé ìwòsàn tí wọ́n ti ń ṣètọ́jú Kòkòro àkóràn ní Yaba, ní Ìpínlẹ̀ Èkó.

english: She is clinically stable and responding to treatment.
yoruba: Ara rẹ̀ ti ń balẹ̀, ó sì ń dáhùn sí ìtọ́jú dáadáa.

english: As numbers of COVID-19 cases continue to rise in Nigeria, the government has yielded to public outcry on March 18 by placing travel restrictions on citizens from 13 countries with over 1,000 domestic cases of coronavirus: China, Italy, Iran, South Korea, Spain, Japan, France, Germany, Norway, the United States, the United Kingdom, Netherlands and Switzerland.
yoruba: Bí í iye àwọn ènìyàn tí ó kó kòkòrò àrùn COVID-19 ṣe ń pọ̀ sí i ni Nàìjíríà, ìjọba àpapọ̀ ti gbọ́ ohun tí àwọn aráàlú sọ ní ọjọ́ 18, oṣù Ẹrẹ́na nípa fífi òfin de àwọn tí ó ń rin ìrìn àjò láti orílẹ̀ èdè 13 bí i: China, Italy, Iran, South Korea, Spain, Japan, France, Germany, Norway, United States, United Kingdom, Netherlands àti Switzerland tí ó ní ju ènìyàn 1000 lọ tí ó ti kó kòkòrò àrùn Kòrónà láti má wọ orílẹ̀-èdè Nàìjíríà.

english: Those who have already entered the country from these countries must go through a 14-day quarantine.
yoruba: Àwọn tí wọ́n ti wọ Nàìjíríà tẹ́lẹ̀ láti àwọn orílẹ̀ èdè tí a dárúkọ yìí gbọ́dọ̀ ya ara wọn sọ́tọ̀ fún ọjọ́ 14.

english: On February 27, an Italian national visiting Nigeria was confirmed as the index case for COVID-19 in the country.
yoruba: Ọjọ́ 27 ni oṣù Èrèlé ní a fìdí rẹ̀ múlẹ̀ pé ọmọ orílẹ̀ èdè Italy kan tí ó rìn ìrìnàjò wá sí orílẹ̀ èdè Nàìjíríà jẹ́ ẹni àkọ́kọ́ tí ó ní kòkòrò àrùn COVID-19.

english: Read more: An Italian national is the index case of COVID-19 disease in Nigeria
yoruba: Kà sí i: Ọmọ orílẹ̀ èdè Italy kan tí ó rìn ìrìnàjò wá sí orílẹ̀ èdè Nàìjíríà ni ó kọ́kọ́ ní kòkòrò àrùn COVID-19

english: The second confirmed case, according to the NCDC, is a contact of the index case who has now tested negative twice.
yoruba: Ẹni kejì tí a fìdí rẹ̀ múlẹ̀ pé ó ní kòkòrò àrùn yìí, gẹ́gẹ́ bí NCDC ṣe sọ jẹ́ ẹni tí ó rìnnà pàdé ẹni àkọ́kọ́ tí ó kó àrùn náà, tí ara rẹ̀ sì ti yá báyìí lẹ́yìn tí àyẹ̀wò méjì ti fi hàn pé àyẹ̀wò náà kò sí lára rẹ̀ mọ́.

english: Consequently, the second case was cleared of the virus and was discharged to go home on 13th of March 2020, states the NCDC.
yoruba: Ẹnìkejì yìí ò ní àrùn náà mọ́, wọ́n sì ti fi í sílẹ̀ kí ó máa lọ sílé ní ọjọ́ 13 oṣù Ẹrẹ́na, ọdún 2020, gẹ́gẹ́ bíi àjọ NCDC ṣe sọ.

english: Many Nigerian netizens have not been satisfied with the current response to COVID-19 and have called for tougher measures to prevent the spread of the pandemic in Nigeria.
yoruba: Bí wọ́n ṣe ń bójú tó àrùn COVID-19 kò tẹ́ ọ̀pọ̀ aráàlú lórí ayélujára lọ́rùn, wón sì ti ń béèrè fún àwọn ìgbésẹ̀ tí ó lágbára láti dẹ́kun ìtànkálẹ̀ àrùn náà ní orílẹ̀ èdè Nàìjíríà.

english: Netizen Ayobami decried the slow response of the NCDC. He advised the agency to "stop the media parade and do some work!"
yoruba: Ọmọ ìlú lórí ayélujára, Ayobami kéde pé ìgbésẹ̀ NCDC falẹ̀. Ó gbà wọ́n nímọ̀ràn pé "kí wọ́n dẹ́kun ṣíṣe àṣehàn lórí ayélujára kí wọ́n sì bẹ̀rẹ̀ iṣẹ́!"

english: Gideon says it "should scare all of us" that COVID-19 testing is slow in Nigeria.
yoruba: Gideon sọ pé "ó yẹ kí ó bà wá lẹ́rù" pé ṣíṣe àyẹ̀wò fún kòkòrò àrùn COVID-19 ń falẹ̀ ní Nàìjíríà.

english: "Restrict travelers coming in especially from countries" affected by this virus, insists journalist Bayo Olupohunda:
yoruba: "Ẹ fi òfin de àwọn arìnrìn-àjò tí ó fẹ́ wọlé láti àwọn orílẹ̀ èdè mìíràn" pàápàá jù lọ àwọn tí ó wá láti àwọn orílẹ̀ èdè tí àrùn náà ti gbilẹ̀, akọ̀ròyìn Bayo Olupohunda náà tẹnumọ:

english: Dr. Whitewalker insists that a travel ban is a normal epidemiological intervention in order to stem the tide of transmission during a pandemic like this:
yoruba: Dr. Whitewalker náà tẹnpẹlẹ mọ́ ọn pé kò sí ohun tí ó burú nínú fífi òfin de àwọn arìnrìn-àjò ní àkókò tí wọ́n ṣiṣẹ́ ìṣàdínkù ìtànkálẹ́ àrùn láti lè dẹ́kun àkóràn ní àsìkò ìtànkálẹ́ àrùn bí i irú èyí.

english: Dr. Chikwe Ihekweazu, head of NCDC, pleaded that they are "trying VERY hard to meet all urgent needs":
yoruba: Dr. Chikwe Ihekweazu, olórí àjọ NCDC, bẹ̀bẹ̀ pé àwọn ń "gbìyànjú GIDI láti rí i pé àwọn ṣe gbogbo ohun tí ó yẹ kí àwọn ṣe":

english: On March 17, the Senate, Nigeria's upper legislative house, initially called for a ban on flights from coronavirus high-risk countries like the United Kingdom and China, before extending the restrictions the following day.
yoruba: Ní ọjọ́ 17 oṣù Ẹrẹ́na, ilé ìgbìmọ̀ aṣòfin àgbà ti kọ́kọ́ sọ pé kí wọ́n fi òfin de àwọn ọkọ̀ òfurufú tí ó ń bọ̀ láti àwọn orílẹ̀ èdè tí àrùn náà ti gbilẹ̀ bí i United Kingdom àti China, kí wọ́n tó dúró di ọjọ́ kejì kí wọ́n tó fi òfin náà múlẹ̀.

english: All visitors from affected countries will undergo a "supervised self-isolation and testing for 14 days," reports the Cable Nigeria.
yoruba: Cable Nigeria jábọ̀ gbogbo àwọn tí wọ́n wá láti àwọn orílẹ̀-èdè tí àrùn náà ti gbilẹ̀ ni wọ́n máa yà sọ́tọ̀ pẹ̀lú àbójútó fún ọjọ́ mẹ́rìnlá.

english: The government also temporarily suspended visas-on-arrival in Nigeria.
yoruba: Ìjọba àpapọ̀ sì fi òfin de fífún àwọn ènìyàn ní visa Nàìjíríà.

english: The travel ban comes into effect on Saturday, March 21, 2020, and will last four weeks, which is open to a possible extension upon review.
yoruba: Ìfòfindèrìnàjò náà bẹ̀rẹ̀ ní àbámẹ́ta ọjọ́ 21, oṣù Ẹrẹ́nà, ọdún 2020, yóò sì wà fún ọ̀sẹ̣̀ mẹ́rin tí ó ṣe é ṣe kí wọ́n sún un síwájú lẹ́yìn àpérò.

english: Read more: COVID-19 in Africa: ‘Unprecedented levels of mobilization’ as nations brace for pandemic
yoruba: Kà sí i: COVID-19 ní ilẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀: ‘Ìgbáradì tí a kò rí irú rẹ̀ rí’ bí àwọn orílẹ̀-èdè ṣe ń múra sílẹ̀ fún ìtànkálẹ̀ àrùn

english: Several African countries have been implementing tough protocols to mitigate the spread of the COVID-19 virus.
yoruba: Ọ̀pọ̀ àwọn orílẹ̀-èdè ní ilẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀ ti ń gbé ìgbésẹ̀ láti ṣe àdínkù ìtànkálẹ̀ kòkòrò àrùn COVID-19.

english: These stringent measures include placing travel restrictions on nations with high numbers of COVID-19 cases.
yoruba: Lára àwọn ìgbésẹ̀ yìí ni fífi òfin de ìrìn-àjò láti àwọn orílẹ̀ èdè tí kòkòrò àrùn COVID-19 náà ti gbilẹ̀ láti má ṣe wọ orílẹ̀ èdè wọn.

english: Sloppy management
yoruba: Ìṣàmójútó tí kò péye tó

english: There are reports about the inadequate and slipshod response by health officials to the COVID-19 pandemic in Nigeria.
yoruba: Àwọn ìjábọ̀ kan wà nípa bí ìṣàmójútó àwọn òṣìṣẹ́ elétò ìlera kò ṣe péye tó lórí àwọn tó ní kòkòrò àrùn COVID-19 ni orílẹ̀-èdè Nàìjíríà.

english: A 70-year-old woman who had spent five months in the United Kingdom returned to Nigeria, on March 11.
yoruba: Obìnrin kan tí ó jẹ́ ẹni ọdún 70 tí ó ti lo oṣù márùn-ún ní United Kingdom padà sí Nàìjíríà ní ọjọ́ 11 oṣù Ẹrẹ́na.

english: Soon after, she presented with COVID-19 symptoms like cold and excessive mucous and on March 13, she was rushed to Enugu State Teaching Hospital (ESUTH) Colliery Parklane, in southeast Nigeria.
yoruba: Lẹ́yìn ìgbà díẹ̀ tí ó dé, ó bẹ̀rẹ̀ sí ní àmì àìsàn kòkòrò àrùn COVID-19 bí i òtútù àti ikun tí ó pọ̀ lápọ̀jù ní ọjọ́ 13, oṣù Ẹrẹ́na, wọ́n sì sáré gbé lọ sí Teaching Hospital ti ìpínlẹ̀ Enugu (ESUTH) Colliery Parklane, ní gúúsù ìlà-oòrùn Nàìjíríà.

english: She was isolated in ESUTH Colliery Parklane while her samples were sent to NCDC for diagnosis on March 14.
yoruba: Wọ́n yà á sọ́tọ̀ ní ESUTH Colliery Parklane, wọ́n sì fi àyẹ̀wọ̀ tí wọ́n ṣe fun un ṣọwọ́ sí àjọ NCDC ní ọjọ́ 14, oṣù Ẹrẹ́na fún àyẹ̀wò.

english: On March 15, the woman died after the NCDC had reported that she tested negative to COVID-19.
yoruba: Ní ọjọ́ 15, oṣù Ẹrẹ́na, obìnrin náà kú lẹ́yìn tí àjọ NCDC jábọ̀ pé kò ní kòkòrò àrùn COVID-19.

english: However, in a letter written to Enugu's state governor, the woman's daughter alleged that her mother was "stigmatized" by the hospital staff who placed her in a “dilapidated” isolation centre overgrown with “grass and debris”.
yoruba: Bẹ́ẹ̀, nínú lẹ́tà tí wọ́n kọ sí gómìnà ìpínlẹ̀ Enugu, ọmọ obìnrin náà fẹ̀sùn kan àwọn òṣìṣẹ́ ilé ìwòsàn náà pé "tàbùkù" ìyá òun, wọ́n gbé e sínú "ilé àkọ́kù" tí ó kún fún koríko.

english: Another ill-managed COVID-19 case presented in Lagos, the commercial capital of Nigeria.
yoruba: Ọ̀rọ̀ ẹnìkan tí ó ní kòkòrò àrùn COVID-19 tí wọn kò ṣe àbójútó tó péye fún wáyé ní ìpínlẹ̀ Èkó tí ó jẹ́ olú-ìlú ìdókòòwò ní orílẹ̀-èdè Nàìjíríà.

english: On March 17, David Hundeyin, a journalist with News Wire, reported the poor handling of a suspected COVID-19 case at Dangote Oil Refinery Company in Ibeju-Lekki, Lagos, which has precipitated panic among workers.
yoruba: Ní ọjọ́ 17, oṣù Ẹrẹ́na, David Hundeyin tí ó jẹ́ akọ̀ròyìn pẹ̀lú News Wire, jábọ̀ nípa ìṣàmójútó tí kò gúnrégé tó lórí ọ̀rọ̀ ẹni tí wọ́n furasí pé ó ní kòkòrò àrùn COVID-19 ní ilé iṣẹ́ Dangote ní Ibeju-Lekki, ní Ìpínlẹ̀ Èkó, tí ó sì ti ń fa ìpayà láàárín àwọn òṣìṣẹ́ ibẹ̀.

english: On March 12, an Indian pipefitter from Dangote Refinery flew into Nigeria from Mumbai, after a brief stopover in Cairo, Egypt.
yoruba: Ní ọjọ́ kejìlá oṣù Ẹrẹ́nà, òṣìṣẹ́ iléeṣẹ́ Dangote kan tí ó jẹ́ ọmọ ilẹ̀ India tí ó ń tún ọ̀pá omi ṣe wá sí orílẹ̀-èdè Nàìjíríà láti Mumbai, lẹ́yìn tí ó dúró díẹ̀ ní Cairo, ní orílẹ̀-èdè Egypt.

english: Hudeyin's investigation revealed that the pipefitter developed "a fever, a dry cough, a sore throat and significant breathing difficulty," a day after his return from India.
yoruba: Ìwádìí Hudeyin fi hàn pé ọkùnrin náà tí ó ń tún ọ̀pá omi ṣe bẹ̀rẹ̀ sí i ní "ibà, ikọ́ gbígbẹ, ọ̀fun dídùn àti àìlè mí délẹ̀ ", ní ọjọ́ kejì tí ó dé láti India.

english: Yet, “it is unclear whether anyone at Dangote Refinery attempted to establish contact” with appropriate health officials.
yoruba: Síbẹ̀, "kò tí ì hàn bóyá ẹnikẹ́ni ní iléeṣẹ́ Dangote ti gbìyànjú láti kàn sí" àwọn elétò ìlera tí ọ̀rọ̀ náà kàn.

english: Hudeyin further lamented that the firm took advantage of "the lax regulatory environment" in Nigeria "to put its own interests first", which puts the life of staff as well as the general public at risk.
yoruba: Hudeyin sọ̀rọ̀ síwájú pé ilé iṣẹ́ náà ń lo àǹfààní "àyíká òfin tí kò múnádóko tó" ní Nàìjíríà "láti fi èrè tirẹ̀ síwájú", èyí sì ń fi ẹ̀mí àwọn òṣìṣẹ́ rẹ̀ àti gbogbo àwùjọ sínú ewu.

english: This report forced refinery management to release a report stating that the said patient has been moved to the Infectious Disease Hospital in Yaba, Lagos.
yoruba: Ìròyìn yìí mú kí iléeṣẹ́ náà gbé èrò wọn jáde pé àwọn ti gbé aláìsàn náà lọ sí ilé ìwòsàn tí wọ́n ti ń ṣètọ́jú kòkòrò Àkóràn ní Yaba, ní ìpínlẹ̀ Èkó.

english: How is COVID-19 reshaping the political and global future of China?
yoruba: Ọ̀nà wo ni àrùn COVID-19 ń gbà ṣe àtúnṣe sí ètò ìṣèlú àti ẹ̀yìn-ọ̀la Orílẹ̀-èdè China lágbàáyé?

english: Poster displaying a map of China on the four characters reading 武汉肺炎 meaning "Wuhan pneumonia" (which is still used in Chinese), as the epidemic was initially known, before it was given the name of COVID-19.
yoruba: Àwòrán tó ń fi ààlà-ilẹ̀ orílẹ̀-èdè China hàn lórí ọmọ ọ̀rọ̀ mẹ́rin tí kíkà rẹ̀ jẹ́ 武汉肺炎 tí ó túmọ̀ sí "àrùn ẹ̀dọ̀fóró Wuhan" (tí ó ṣì jẹ́ lílo ní èdè Chinese), gẹ́gẹ́ bí a ti ṣe mọ àjàkálẹ̀ náà ní ìbẹ̀rẹ̀ pẹ̀pẹ̀, kí ó tó yí orúkọ padà sí COVID-19.

english: Image used with permission.
yoruba: A gba àṣẹ láti lo àwòrán.

english: What started at a seafood market as a local health issue has grown into a national health crisis in China.
yoruba: Ohun tí ó bẹ̀rẹ̀ nínú ọjà oúnjẹ inú odò, gẹ́gẹ́ bí i ọ̀ràn àìlera ìbílẹ̀, ti wá di nǹkan tó rànká Orílẹ̀-èdè China.

english: After the Wuhan coronavirus was identified in December 2019, a chain reaction was set in motion that has profoundly shaken Chinese society and challenged Beijing’s political stability.
yoruba: Lẹ́yìn ìfẹsẹ̀múlẹ̀ ìjẹyọ kòkòrò àìfojúrí kòrónà ní Wuhan nínú Oṣù Kejìlá Ọdún 2019, ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ ìṣẹ̀lẹ̀ ló ṣẹ̀ ní ṣísẹ̀-n-tẹ̀lé ló ṣú yọ tó sì fi àwùjọ ilẹ̀ Chinese làkàlàkà tí ó sì tún dojú ìpèníjà kọ ìdúróṣinṣin ètò ìṣèlú Beijing.

english: Gripped by its obsession with information control, the Chinese government, both local and central, delayed the release of life-saving information for weeks.
yoruba: Kíkúndùn ìṣàkóso ìròyìn ti fún ìjọba lọ́rùn, àti ìjọba ìbílẹ̀ àti ìjọba àpapọ̀ ní àárín gbùngbùn, ló máa ń fa ìdádúró fún àgbéjáde ìròyìn tí yóò ṣe ará ìlú láǹfààní fún ọ̀sẹ̀ pípẹ́.

english: When they suddenly announced drastic measures to prevent the spread of the epidemic in late January, for many it was much too late as the Chinese New Year kick-off celebrations had already begun.
yoruba: Nígbà tí wọ́n wá sọ jí láti ṣe ìkéde lórí àwọn ọ̀nà tí yóò dẹ́kun ìtànká àjàkálẹ̀ náà, ó ti bọ́ sórí, nítorí ayẹyẹ ọdún tuntun ìran Chinese ọlọ́dọọdún ti gbérasọ.

english: Doctors and scientists are still researching and debating the possible origin of the previously unknown Wuhan coronavirus, which causes COVID-2019, a respiratory virus that infects the lungs and can lead to pneumonia.
yoruba: Àwọn Dókítà àti àwọn onímọ̀ ìjìnlẹ̀ sì ń ṣe ìwádìí àti ìfọ̀rọ̀jomitoro-ọ̀rọ̀ lórí ohun tí ó lè jẹ́ orísun àrùn tí wọ́n mọ̀ nígbà náà lọ́hùn-ún gẹ́gẹ́ bí kòkòrò àìfojúrí kòrónà ti Wuhan, tí ó padà wá ṣe okùnfà COVID-19, kòkòrò àìfojúrí tó ń mú kí ènìyàn má leè mí sókèsódò tí ó sì ń fa àrùn ẹ̀dọ̀fóró.

english: One possible theory is that it comes from snakes or bats that are consumed as a delicacy in China and were sold at the Huanan wet market in Wuhan where the virus is believed to originate.
yoruba: Ìdámọ̀ràn ohun tí ó lè fa sábàbí àrùn náà kan fi yé wí pé kòkòrò àìfojúrí kòrónà jẹ yọ látàrí ẹran ejò tàbí ẹran àdán tí àwọn ará China máa ń jẹ l'óúnjẹ, tí wọ́n ń tà ní ọjà Huanan wet ní agbègbè Wuhan níbi tí ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ ní èrò wí pé ibẹ̀ ni orísun kòkòrò àìfojúrí yìí.

english: One of the key questions determining the spread of the virus is its transmissibility: whether it can jump from human to human, and how many people can be infected on average by the same virus carrier.
yoruba: Ìbéèrè kan tí ó nílò ìdáhùn ni ti ọ̀nà ìtànkálẹ̀ àrùn yìí: bóyá ó leè rànká láti ara èèyàn kan sí ìkejì, àti ìyè èèyàn mélòó ló leè kó àìsàn yìí látara ẹni tí ó bá ti ní i.

english: The latest medical evidence indicates there is human-to-human transmission, and what is concerning is that it seems to happen before the virus carrier develops symptoms, thus making detection incredibly challenging.
yoruba: Ẹ̀rí láti ìmọ̀ ìlera tó fẹsẹ̀múlẹ̀ ṣe ìṣípayá àrànkán láti ara ènìyàn kan sí ìkejì, tí ó fi jẹ́ wí pé kòkòrò náà yóò ti wà lágọ̀ọ́ ara fún ìgbà díẹ̀ kí ẹni tí ó kó o ó tó máa rí àwọn ààmì rẹ̀ lára, tí èyí ò sì mú mímọ ẹni tí ó bá ti lu gúdẹ àrùn náà rọrùn.

english: As for the rate of transmission, called “basic reproduction number” by epidemiologists, it is believed to be between 2 to 3 in late January, meaning one person infects two to three persons, but the numbers are still being discussed and require further research should proper data be made available.
yoruba: Ní ti bí àrùn náà ti ń ràn, èyí tí àwọn onímọ̀ nípa àjàkálẹ̀ àrùn ń pè ní “òǹkà ìpìlẹ̀ ìbísí“, gbà pé ó wà láàárín 2 sí 3 ní ìparí Oṣù Kìn-ín-ní, ẹni tí ó ní i yóò kó o ran ẹni méjì sí mẹ́ta, ṣùgbọ́n ìfikùnlukùn àti ìwádìí kò dúró, ìyẹn bí àwọn ìwífún-alálàyè tí ó wúlò bá wà ní àrọ́wọ́tó.

english: As the figure of infected people rises daily, a major health crisis has developed in China’s central province of Hubei and its capital Wuhan that have a combined population of nearly 60 million people.
yoruba: Bí òǹkà àwọn tí wọ́n ti ní kòkòrò yìí ṣe ń lọ sókè sí i lójoojúmó, àáríngbùngbùn Orílẹ̀-èdè China tí i ṣe Hubei àti Olú-ìlú rẹ̀ tí í ṣe Wuhan ti ní ìdojúkọ tó gogò lórí ètò ìlera, tí àpapọ̀ àwọn tí wọ́n ń gbé lágbègbè yìí sì jẹ́ ẹgbẹ̀rún-lọ́nà-ẹgbẹ́rùn ní ìlọ́po 60.

english: As cases have been confirmed all over China, all medical staff are on alert, adding pressure on a medical system that is often insufficient for such a large and aging population.
yoruba: Bí iye àwọn tí ó ti kó àrùn yìí ṣe ń pọ̀ káàkiri Orílẹ̀-èdè China, àwọn òṣìṣẹ́ elétò ìlera ti wà digbí, tí wọ́n sì tún kóná mọ́ ètò ìlera tí kò sùwábọ̀ tó fún ìtọ́jú àwọn ọ̀kẹ́ àìmọye arúgbó tó kún ìlú.

english: But the Wuhan coronavirus is not just a health crisis, it is also a major political moment of truth.
yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n àrùn kòkòrò àìfojúrí kòrónà Wuhan náà kì í ṣe ìkọlù ètò ìlera lásán, ó jẹ́ àkókò òtítọ́ ètò ìṣèlú tí ó lákaakì.
